DOC.HEAD: Rocket Carrying Two U.S. Satellites Launched from French Guiana
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to CORRECT to Hurricane Lili, sted Lily
DOC.TEXT: An Ariane rocket carrying two U.S.-made telecommunications satellites blasted off Friday night from this remote launching facility. The unmanned Ariane 44-L rocket, powered by four strap-on liquid fuel boosters, roared off its northeast South American launch-pad on schedule at 7:58 p.m. The rocket carried two satellites built by the Hughes Aircraft Co. of Pasadena, Calif., that were successfully put into geostationary orbit 23,000 miles over the Galapagos Islands west of the Ecuadoran coast. The countdown briefly stopped to top off the third stage with extra hydrogen and oxygen fuel to provide the vehicle with added boost, Ariane officials said. The mission is the 39th since the commercial Arianespace program started a decade ago, and the third since a rocket exploded in February with two Japanese satellites aboard. Weather for the launch was good and did not affect the liftoff despite the presence of residual winds from Hurricane Lili to the north.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Calls No Witnesses in MacDonald Trial
DOC.TEXT: The prosecution rested its case Friday in the bribery and kickback trial of suspended Navajo Chairman Peter MacDonald and his son, and defense attorneys said they would call no witnesses. Closing arguments and jury instructions were scheduled for Monday. Defense attorneys Val Jolley for MacDonald and Steven Boos for Peter ``Rocky'' MacDonald Jr. made their surprise announcements without elaborating. Jolley had said previously he planned to call up to 15 witnesses. ``Their case is in a shambles. We don't have anything we have to defend,'' Jolley said Friday. ``The only time you have to present a defense is when a case is proven beyond a reasonable doubt.'' If convicted in tribal District Court on all 42 counts of bribery, conspiracy and ethics violations, MacDonald could be jailed for up to 23 years and barred from serving in tribal office for four years. When asked whether he was afraid to hear the jury's verdict, MacDonald, a former Marine, said, ``I've faced worse situations than this. I was in the South Pacific in World War II.'' The prosecution rested its case after calling 23 witnesses. The defense earlier asked Judge Robert Yazzie to dismiss all charges. The judge agreed to dismiss three: an ethics and conspiracy charge against MacDonald and an ethics charge against his son. He ruled there was a lack of evidence of wrongdoing over an alleged attempt by the defendants to solicit a consultant contract from Peabody Coal Co. for the younger MacDonald. In addition, the prosecution on Friday dropped one bribery count against MacDonald because a scheduled witness did not appear during the trial. Yazzie ruled that all other counts will be decided by the jury. Still pending against MacDonald are 42 counts of bribery, extortion, conspiracy and ethics violations. His son, an unemployed lawyer who lives in San Jose, Calif., now faces 23 counts, including 11 bribery or theft by extortion, 11 of ethics violations and one of conspiracy. MacDonald is accused of accepting bribes and kickbacks from businesses operating on the Navajo reservation, the nation's biggest. Jolley has argued that MacDonald made no threats or promises when he accepted loans and gifts from businessmen. MacDonald was placed on administrative leave last year by the Tribal Council after allegations of corruption surfaced midway through his fourth, four-year term. He and former Chairman Peterson Zah are on the Nov. 6 ballot for the newly created post of tribal president. The trial, being heard by a jury panel of six Navajos, one Pueblo Indian and five non-Indians, began Oct. 1.

DOC.HEAD: White House Pays Price for Imprecision on Tax Issue
DOC.TEXT: Backpedaling and admitting error, the White House is struggling to pull itself out of three days of embarrassing budget confusion spawned by President Bush. ``Hindsight's always better,'' presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Thursday. He said the White House should have moved quickly to explain Bush's apparent flip-flop on taxes and contradictory statements by administration officials Tuesday and Wednesday. ``I think we just made a mistake in not doing that, frankly,'' Fitzwater said. ``That's exactly what we should have done.'' The misstep has cost Bush dearly, prompting headlines of presidential waffling, zigzagging and retreat. Some Wall Street analysts blame his apparent indecision, along with higher oil prices, for the stock market's plunge this week. There also has been a political price. Republicans worry that the appearance of disarray at the White House and by GOP lawmakers on the budget has given Democrats new ammunition for the November elections. Even the GOP's bedrock opposition to higher taxes is being called into question. ``I'm sick and tired of going home to rural Wisconsin and protecting a Republican image as the party of the rich,'' said Rep. Steve Gunderson. Rep. Fred Grandy, R-Iowa, said, ``I think we made a mistake, this party made a mistake, taking ... this blood oath'' against tax rate increases. At a news conference Tuesday, Bush threw the budget negotiations with Congress into confusion by saying - for the first time in public - that he would be willing to raise income taxes on the rich in exchange for a lower tax rate on capital gains, which are profits on the sales of investments. His statement sent shudders through the ranks of Senate Republicans. They rushed to the White House and told Bush that Democrats would not drop the capital gains tax rate low enough to warrant an increase in income tax rates on the wealthy. The lawmakers said Bush - in a surprising turnabout - agreed that he should drop the idea. Fitzwater agreed with what the lawmakers said. By the next day, the White House was in retreat again. Neither the president nor his spokesman was willing to describe Bush's position. Fitzwater said Bush had not made any commitment to the senators. ``Read my hips,'' Bush said, adding to the confusion during a jogging excursion. The White House was hammered with more unflattering headlines. ``Bush Trips, Capital Reels,'' The New York Times said on the front page Thursday. There was even more chaos Thursday when Bush met with senior congressional Republicans. When the meeting was over, Rep. Bill Archer, R-Texas, said Bush had unequivocally endorsed the idea of a modest increase in income tax rates for the rich in exchange for a sharp cut in capital gains tax rates. That was the position Bush had taken on Tuesday - later disavowed by the White House. Already burned, the White House moved quickly to control the damage. A written statement by Fitzwater said that, yes, Bush did like the idea of trading an income tax increase for the wealthy for a capital gains tax cut. Yet, the White House said Congress would not buy that idea. ``I think it's a waste of time because I just don't think it can get through both houses of Congress,'' Bush said. Thus, the idea was buried. Fitzwater was left with the job of trying to reconcile Bush's statements with the remarks of Republican members of Congress after conferences with the president. ``One of the phenomenons about group meetings is that people hear what they want to hear,'' Fitzwater said. But the spokesman acknowledged that his boss - the president - had been imprecise at Tuesday's news conference when he linked capital gains with a higher tax on the rich. ``I don't think he meant to say it in a way - in the way it was interpreted by some of you,'' Fitzwater told reporters. For his part, the president said he was unfazed by the flap. ``These things come and go,'' he said. ``The best thing - we get a good deal, if we get a good deal, people forget the name-calling and they'll forget the little rancor and the tension at the time.''

DOC.HEAD: Polls Show Big Levin Lead, But Schuette Optimistic
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Bill Schuette is hammering away at Sen. Carl Levin as a free-spending liberal, an entrenched Washington politician who's out of touch with the electorate. Levin depicts himself as a hard-working and effective representative of Michigan's interests. He attacks Schuette as a habitual distorter of the truth. To date, the advantage has been all Levin's in his campaign for re-election. Schuette's approach is ``pretty bizarre,'' says Levin campaign manager Gordon Kerr. ``He's started beating the drum for `Throw the bums out,' but he's one of the bums,'' says Kerr. True, Levin, a Democrat, has been in the Senate 12 years. But Schuette, a Republican member of the House Budget Committee, has been in Congress for six. Schuette points out that Levin has been in public life in various capacities for 23 years, but the impression this has made on the voters appears to be inconsequential. Levin has had essentially the same lead since August, with the latest poll showing his support at 60 percent to 26 percent for Schuette. The campaign has seen its share of attack ads. Schuette accused Levin of voting to raise or protect his pay 22 times and tied Levin into the S&L mess. Levin has gotten $29,000 in contributions over the years from people associated with the savings and loan industry. Kerr referred to the ad as ``fictions, distortions and innuendos.'' Levin is returning a $9,000 pay raise to the Treasury and has voted against pay raises on other occasions. He also returned $10,000 to various donors involved in civil or criminal S&L probes. A Levin TV ad featured newspaper headlines, some of them from editorial pages, saying such things as ``The Schuette Deception'' and ``perjury ... phony.'' Kerr expects Levin's lead to narrow in the final weeks as Schuette steps up his television advertising. ``We've got some Republican votes that Schuette ought to be able to chip away at if he develops a message that connects with people and they can get it out,'' said Kerr. Schuette dismisses the polls as ``bunk.'' ``The graveyards out there are littered with the bodies of candidates who were ahead in September and October and lost in November,'' says the congressman. Schuette's last campaign finance report, released in July, showed he had raised $1.5 million. Kerr says the Levin campaign is approaching its $6 million goal. ``The only problem is we've spent most of it,'' said Kerr. ``We've been on TV virtually nonstop since the Fourth of July.'' Levin is telling voters ``who Bill Schuette is and what he stands for,'' says political pollster and consultant Steve Mitchell. ``Any time your opponent defines who you are, you're in trouble.'' Mitchell concludes it will take a miracle for Schuette to overcome Levin's lead. Schuette tries to use the ongoing budget battle in Washington to build up an anti-incumbent sentiment against Levin. ``It's the gang in charge that's the problem,'' said Schuette. ``There's a wave that's coming across the country'' and people ``want to limit terms and they say we've got to have spending reductions instead of raising taxes,'' he says. ``It doesn't matter how much money Carl Levin puts on TV, it's not going to sweeten the electorate's appetite for more of the same.'' However, Kerr says Levin ``is on the side of average Michigan families and he has an effective record of doing things that affect their lives.''

DOC.HEAD: Latest Breakdown on Foreigners in Iraq, Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Following is the breakdown of the number of foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait as of Oct. 10. Most estimates are based on embassy registrations. An undetermined number of U.S., British, French and West German citizens are being held in Iraq and Kuwait as human shields around strategic targets. Others are believed hiding in Kuwait. Some foreigners, mostly women married to Iraqis or Kuwaitis, have elected to stay. According to U.S. State Department figures, more than 900,000 of the estimated 3 million foreigners in Kuwait and Iraq on Aug. 2, when Iraqi forces overran Kuwait, have left.
AUSTRALIA - Before the Iraqi invasion, there were 127 Australians in the two countries. There are now 44 in Iraq and 50 in Kuwait, including diplomats.
AUSTRIA - Before the invasion, there were 70 Austrians in Iran and the same number in Iraq. One remains in Kuwait and three or four in Iraq, all of Arab background.
BANGLADESH - About 110,000 Bangladeshis were in Kuwait and Iraq when the invasion occurred. About 15,000 remain.
BELGIUM - Before the crisis, there were 38 Belgians in Iraq and 21 in Kuwait. Now 38 remain in Iraq, 2 in Kuwait.
BRAZIL - There were 450 Brazilians in Iraq and Kuwait Aug.2. Eleven are in Iraq now. None are believed to be in Kuwait.
BRITAIN - Before the invasion, there were about 3,000 Britons in Kuwait and 1,000 in Iraq. There are now about 1,000 in Kuwait and 420 in Iraq.
CANADA - Of the approximately 600 Canadians in Kuwait and 200 in Iraq before the invasion, about 50 remain in Kuwait and 50 in Iraq.

CHINA - Virtually all the 5,000 Chinese in Kuwait before the invasion have been evacuated. About 4,800 Chinese remain in Kuwait. About 150 citizens of Hong Kong and Taiwan have been evacuated from Kuwait and Iraq.
CYPRUS - There were 35 Cypriots in Iraq and Kuwait before Aug. 2. Twenty remain.
CZECHOSLOVAKIA - Of the 470 Czechs in Iraq and Kuwait Aug. 2, only six womenmarried to Kuwaitis remain in Kuwait. Eighty remain in Iraq.
DENMARK - Some 35 Danes remain in Kuwait, with 41 in Iraq, out of a pre-invasion total of 100.
EGYPT - Some 335,000 Egyptians have left Iraq and Kuwait, out of more than 1.3 million in Iraq and 300,000 in Kuwait before the invasion.
FINLAND - There are 21 Finns in Iraq and 4 in Kuwait, compared to a total of 46 before the invasion.
FRANCE - There are about 100 French citizens in Kuwait and about 230 in Iraq. Before the invasion, there were 270 in Kuwait and 290 in Iraq.

GERMANY - The German Foreign Ministry refuses to give specific figures on how many of the pre-invasion total of 1,000 remain in Iraq and Kuwait, apparently because of nationals hiding out there. Latest reports mention only 43 being held in Iraq, with 30 still in Kuwait.
GREECE - There were about 127 Greeks in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. Now, 24 remain in Iraq, with 29 in Kuwait.
HUNGARY - There were 178 Hungarians in Kuwait and Iraq before Aug. 2. Now, 32 remain in Iraq, with none in Kuwait.
INDIA - There were about 170,000 Indians in Kuwait and 20,000 in Iraq before the invasion. About 90,000 remain in Kuwait with 6,000 in Iraq.
IRELAND - Of the 380 Irish citizens in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion, there are now 235 in Iraq and about 25 in Kuwait.
ITALY - Before the invasion there were 160 Italians in Kuwait and 380 in Iraq. About 300 remain in Iraq and 10 in Kuwait.
JAPAN - About 790 Japanese were in Kuwait and Iraq at the time of the invasion. Ten are still in Kuwait and 309, including journalists, in Iraq.
LEBANON - Of the estimated 50,000 Lebanese in pre-invasion Kuwait, about 5,000 have left. None of the aproximately 10,000 in Iraq have been reported leaving.
NETHERLANDS - There were 200 Dutch nationals in Iraq and Kuwait before the invasion. About 160 remain in Iraq, with 13 in Kuwait.
NEW ZEALAND - Seven New Zealanders remain in Iraq and 11 in Kuwait out of a combined pre-invasion total of 36.
NORWAY - One Norwegian remains in Kuwait and 26 in Iraq, out of a pre-invasion total of about 46.
PAKISTAN - A total of about 130,000 Pakistanis were in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion, and more than 40,000 have left.
PHILIPPINES - About 90,000 Filipinos were in Kuwait and 3,000 in Iraq before the invasion. About 2,300 remain in Iraq, with estimates of the number in Kuwait ranging from 5,000 to 15,000.
POLAND - There were 3,123 Poles in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. Now there are 1,213 n Iraq, mainly workers fulfilling project contracts.
PORTUGAL - About 15 Portuguese have left Kuwait and Iraq, leaving about 40 in Iraq and 34 in Kuwait.
ROMANIA - There were 3,055 Romanians in Iraq before the invasion. About 640 remain.
SOUTH KOREA - About 1,327 South Koreans were in Kuwait and Iraq, with 184 left in Iraq and nine in Kuwait.

SOVIET UNION - Nearly 10,000 Soviets were in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion. There are now less than 5,000 in Iraq, mostly oil workers and construction specialists and 93 military advisers. About 2,000 are expected to leave by late October. There are none in Kuwait.
SPAIN - Of about 150 Spaniards in Kuwait and Iraq before the invasion, 19 remain in Baghdad and five in Kuwait.
SRI LANKA - About 150,000 Sri Lankans were in Kuwait and Iraq. About 65,000 remain in Kuwait, with 125 in Iraq.
SWEDEN - Out of a pre-invasion total f about 200, only a handful remain in Kuwait, with about 80 in Iraq.
SWITZERLAND - Before the invasion, there were 97 Swiss nationals in Kuwait and 71 in Iraq. None remain in Kuwait and about 70 in Iraq.
THAILAND - There were 7,000 Thais in Kuwait and about 1,150 in Iraq before Aug.2, with 874 still in Iraq now and 20 in Kuwait.

TURKEY - There were 3,000 Turks in Iraq and 1,000 in Kuwait at the beginning of the gulf crisis. Almost all have returned home, leaving about 60 in Iraq and about 40 in Kuwait, mostly women married to Kuwaitis.

UNITED STATES - Of the pre-invasion total of 3,500 Americans in Iraq and Kuwait, about 700 remained in Kuwait and 300-350 in Iraq until the most recent evacuation flight, which carried 321 Westerners from Kuwait to Baghdad and on to London on Oct. 10. Most of them were Americans.
VIETNAM - There were an estimated 17,000 Vietnamese in Iraq before the invasion. Most are still there. There are no figures available for Kuwait.
YUGOSLAVIA - There were about 6,000 Yugoslavs in Iraq and 1,000 in Kuwait Aug. 2. About 300 remain in Kuwait and 1,000 in Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis Unleashes Democratic Forces In Feudal Gulf States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The Persian Gulf crisis has unleashed forces seeking political reforms in the feudal gulf states, including an extraordinary effort to discuss the future of Kuwait if it is freed from Iraqi occupation. Kuwait's exiled rulers have invited 450 prominent citizens to a conference in Saudi Arabia this weekend to consider the future shape of a free Kuwait. The government is eagerly - and uncharacteristically - soliciting the attendance of the Western press at the event. Crown Prince Sheik Saad al Abdullah made it clear that the agenda will range from future defense arrangments to the rights of Kuwaiti citizens and foreign workers. ``The basic topic is liberation,'' Kuwaiti Information Ministry spokesman Feisal Mutawaa said in a telephone interview from the conference site in Jiddah. ``But all issues that members want to discuss will be discussed.'' Sheik Saaid has called for a new social covenant between the rulers and Kuwaiti citizens. It follows widespread criticism by Kuwaiti exiles of the domination of the al-Sabahs, Kuwait's deposed ruling family, over their nation's important financial and political institutions. The debate is raising questions about the mandate of other gulf rulers, benevolent despots who have so far rejected political parties and participatory democracy. ``No government, anywhere in the world, would fail to take heed of changing situations by beginning to adjust, whatever the prevailing situation,'' Sulaiman Mutawaa, minister for planning in the government-in-exile and Feisal's cousin, said in London this week. After his Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein struck a responsive chord among the Middle East's masses by claiming that Kuwait was run by a selfish reactionary regime whose family had hoarded vast wealth for its own benefit. To pre-empt such propaganda attacks, the issue of power-sharing is likely to take center stage in the other gulf states of Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Oman, Bahrain and the United Arab Emirates, Mideast experts say. However, few observers predict any immediate transformation to Western-style democracy in a region without such traditions. The gulf states are a political anachronism, where oil wealth and the accompanying support and banking industries have reinforced a tribal-based feudalism uniqe in modern times. The hereditary Bedouin rulers' power is rooted not only in tradition, but also in their position as the symbolic source of the oil-fueled largesse that has created some of the world's highest per capita living standards. ``The native populations are all beneficiaries of the welfare system, except that isn't all they want,'' said Shahram Chubin, a Middle East specialist who teaches at the Graduate Institute of International Affairs in Geneva. ``The more educated ones want some say in the running of the country,'' he added. ``It's not that they're excluded from the benefits. They're excluded from any power-sharing.'' Both Kuwait and Bahrain have sizeable middle classes and both have experimented with popular assemblies subordinate to the rulers' authority. Sheik Isa bin Sulman al-Khalifa dissolved Bahrain's 19-month parliamentary experiment in 1975 after elements in the National Assembly objected to a docking facilities agreement with the U.S. Navy. Kuwait's 50-member elected Naional Assembly was dissolved by the emir, Sheik Jaber al-Sabah, in 1986 after Iranian attacks on Kuwaiti oil installations which delegates blamed in part on the government's poor security arrangements. Shortly before the Aug. 2 invasion, he reinstated the assembly amid popular pressure for reform, but added 25 appointed members. Saddam's invasion, and the subsequent popular support he garnered throughout the Arab World, have demonstrated the vulnerability of all the gulf states to destabilizaion by revolutionary populist forces. All have pro-Iranian Shiites and Palestinians forming a large part of their laboring underclass. The gulf's ruling families are all Sunnis Moslems, as are most of the citizenry. The dynasties, some in power for centuries, must ``decide whether they can restore a significant part of the status quo or whether the best option is to pre-empt demands for democracy by taking steps along that road,'' said Mideast analyst Don Kerr of the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London. He noted that Jordan, where King Hussein retains a strong measure of personal loyalty from his subjects, is one of the Arab world's most politically liberal nations. Another issue surfacing is what political rights, if any, should be granted to the guest workers on which the gulf states depend heavily. The citizens of Qatar and the United Arab Emirates are minorities in their own countries, and the same situation applied in pre-invasion Kuwait. ``They'd have at some point to ask themselves at what juncture does someone who works there all his life gain the right to citizenship,'' Kerr said. ``These people don't have any share ... and this is what Saddam's playing on in Kuwait.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq's Would-Be Navy Stuck in Italian Riviera
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Every morning, 90 Iraqi sailors hoist the flag on their two Esmeraldas-class corvettes, rev their engines and swivel their 76-millimeter cannons menacingly along the horizon. It is a scene that would worry the U.S. military - if it were not taking place on the sunny Italian Riviera. The two corvettes, and eight other warships floating nearby, were ordered from Italy in 1980. They were to have formed the bulk of Iraq's most powerful naval fleet ever. But as Saddam Hussein's country prepares for war, its would-be navy is stranded at an Italian military base and a nearby shipbuilder's docks, a victim of delays and Italian government embargoes. ``It will be very difficult for these ships to ever arrive in Iraq,'' said Marco Maria Ferranti, spokesman for the Italian shipbuilder, Fincantieri. The shipbuilding deal between Iraq and Italy is an example of the lucrative arms contracts that Baghdad reached with Western countries in the past decade. For Italy, the $2.6 billion contract was a boon for the country's sagging shipbuilding industry. It called for the state-owned Fincantieri to supply Iraq with four Lupo-class frigates, each displacing about 2,500 tons and armed with short-range missiles. The company also agreed to build two Esmereldas-class corvettes and four Wadi-class corvettes, loaded with helicopters, missile and rocket launchers, and anti-submarine torpedos supplied by other Italian firms. The fleet also included a support ship and a floating dock. ``It would have completely transformed the quality and capacity of their (Iraq's) fleet,'' said Jim McCoy, a naval analyst at the London-based International Institute of Strategic Studies. ``They would have become a force in the Persian Gulf.'' The first part of the shipbuilding deal, a support ship, headed for Iraq in 1984. But by then, Iraq was at war with Iran. The ship could not reach its base at Basra since the Shatt-al-Arab waterway was blocked. The vessel docked at Alexandria, Egypt - where it remains. In 1986, two corvettes were formally turned over to Iraq. One hundred Iraqi sailors went to the naval base at La Spezia, 270 miles north of Rome, to train on the ships. But later that year, Italy decided to suspend the sale of military goods to Iran and Iraq. Iraq, which had paid half the price of the ships, cut off further payments. Fincantieri continued to build, hoping the measure was temporary. Their hopes were raised when the Iran-Iraq war ground to a halt in 1988. Finally, in April, the Italian government announced it was prepared in principle to let the ships go to Iraq. But Iraq decided it wanted some compensation for its long wait. According to Ferranti, Iraq demanded more helicopters, radar systems, a high-speed gunboat, shipbuilding plans and a sophisticated electronic warfare command system. The Italian government began to get cold feet. In May, Italian police seized nearly 100 tons of steel parts on suspicions they were destined for an alleged Iraqi ``supergun.'' Italy then refused to let the two Iraqi corvettes go home. ``The position of Saddam Hussein certainly wasn't reassuring,'' said a Foreign Ministry spokesman, Alessandro Di Franco. In the meantime, Iran, worried about its gulf rival, summoned the Italian ambassador to protest any turnover of the ships to Iraq. Negotiations on Iraq's demands were stalled by the time it invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Italy has since observed a U.N. boycott on trade with Iraq, leaving the ships stuck once again. Don Kerr, another analyst at the Institute of Strategic Studies, says the ships could have been useful now to Iraq - ``at the very least like a security blanket.'' However, they would have been no match for the multinational force now in the gulf. What will happen to Iraq's would-be navy? The ships may be sold to someone else, Ferranti said. However, such a sale would mean breaking a legal contract with Iraq and paying it back. ``These aren't packets of nuts. They are warships,'' said Di Franco. ``It's a delicate thing.'' Fincantieri is losing millions of dollars a year maintaining the ships it can't deliver, Ferranti said. Meanwhile, every day, the 90 Iraqis go through their paces on their corvettes, running fire drills, swiveling the anti-aircraft missile ramps and aiming the cannons at imaginary enemies, officials said. The arms have no ammunition, they said. The Italian military keeps an eye on the Iraqis but there are no restrictions on their movements, said Cmdr. Aldo de Franceschi, the chief of staff for the Tirrenia region. ``I think they're very satisfied to be here,'' he said. ``Here they are better off. Above all, they are at peace.''

DOC.HEAD: Milan Looks Foward and Back
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: By DANIELA PETROFF
DOC.TEXT: Audrey Hepurn and Madonna might not know it, but they have a lot in common where fashion is concerned. In fact the looks they helped make famous - the demure 1960s and the sexy 1990s - combine to make up next year's Italian spring-summer fashion. Models with accentuated eye makeup, in pretty printed A-line dresses and high heels, and carrying the inevitable handbag, rubbed elbows down the runway with colleagues wearing bra tops, micro skirts, derriere-hugging hot pants and more unitards than in all the performances of ``Cats'' put together. Prints were another big 1960 revival item during the ready-to-wear ``moda Milanese,'' week that ended Thursday, ranging from the luxurious silk Pucci prints to the Mandrian block prints to the Couregges black-and-white geometric designs. In theory the hot pants and miniskirts were also retro items, but in practice the short shorts and the daring hemlined skirts made the 1960's hot pants and miniskirts look like child's play. The biggest trendsetter for next year's warmer weather is the shift dress, which makes a comeback after seasons of layered fashion. For next season it comes in A-line or trapeze, styles favored in Hepurn's most famous film, ``Breakfast at Tiffany's.'' The hemline is shorter than 30 years ago, usually around the lower thigh, giving it a modern flip look. The dress is also the only real office apparel in the collections, devoted mostly to holiday and after-hours fashion. The prettiest dresses seen on the runway were at the Mariuccia Mandelli Krizia collection. They came in navy blue linen with white lapels and short sleeve cuffs, gaily printed silks, and white jersey with silver trimming. Karl Lagerfeld for Fendi had a series of demure trapeze styles in navy or bright shades with feminine pleats at the back. Giorgio Armani preferred them in stretch brocade to be worn over silk shorts, the pivoting item of his collection. Ferre and Versace spiced them up with plunging or see-through bodices and extra short hemlines. The revival styles paired with red light district fashion seemed to reflect the present mood of Italian fashion. While the designers still want to maintain the tailored look that put them at the top of labeled ready-to-wear in the 1980's, they are in search of tempting new styles that will make women forget their shrinking pocketbook. The result is both good and bad. As one U.S. buyer put it, ``There are always rich people ready to buy expensive extravagant clothes. What is missing are items for the client who wants well-tailored sensible clothes.'' Buyers this season are cutting down their orders, plagued by a recession fears back home, a falling dollar, and a wholesale increase of over 20 percent. The designer who stopped the Milan show for extravagance was Beverly Hills favorite Gianni Versace with his breathtaking printed outfits, from the catsuits with matching color scheme shoes and jewelry, to the multicolored sequined jackets depicting Andy Warhol Vogue covers, of such stars as Marilyn Monroe, James Dean and Madonna. The sexiest show in town was the Dolce and Gabbana collection with its sequined bra tops, bare midriffs, chiffon skirtlets and shimmery hot pants, all accompanied by thigh stockings. The two Sicilian designers, Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana, are considered one of the up-and-coming labels of a fashion scene perceived by some to be lacking new blood. Another new name on the circuit is Moschino who pokes fun at his colleagues by layering each outfit on the runway with every style and trend imaginable. His shows are always very entertaining, and on closer examination contain many good wearable pieces. Favorite items for next season were the red pant suit with the words ``waist of money'' embroidered in gold letters around the waistline of the jacket, and a shift dress with the map of Italy stiched down the front. Far from the crowd, in an elegant showroom, the Spanish designer Sybilla showed her clothes to editors and buyers by appointment. The new collection is minimal fashion at its best. Three ideas proved that Sybilla knows where fashion is going: -a black gown that was pieced together with transparent nylon thread so that it looked like each seperate piece was suspended on the body; -a wrap-around dress made up of a jersey shawl with arm holes that you put on by criss-crossing it over the body, the answer to the elgant traveler's prayer; -and a ``mail order'' catalogue depicting each item in the collection for a quick understanding of what Sybilla is all about. On Wednesday night, Giorgio Armani, still the safest and most consistently beautiful label in Milan, closed the spring-summer 1991 collections. For daytime he offered the softest, most feminine gray business suits, worn with crisp white blouses and a chic unknotted tie. The new blazer has petal slits on the side, lapels, but no collar. The central item of the collection are shorts, which Armani uses under daytime jackets as well as an alternative to underwear in his long evening gowns slit up the front.

DOC.HEAD: Letters from Children Help Relieve Boredom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Friday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Danny sent the scores from the Bronco game. Melissa said her fish was dead. Amy wanted to know if there is going to be a war. The fifth grade class at Mary Blair Elementary School in Loveland, Colo., has adopted Lt. Col Arnold Laidig Jr., 45, as their link to events in the Persian Gulf. Seven letters arrived Thursday, bringing the colonel's haul to 11, and he is thrilled. ``It's a tie for me back to the real world, life goes on,'' said the Army public affairs officer. ``It's a different perspective, it's a refreshing perspective. It's great to get.'' The class adopted the colonel, from Alexandria, Va., because Danny, his 10-uear-old nephew, is one of the pupils. The letters were a mix of personal anecdotes and questions about the situation in the gulf. Melissa was one of the most talkative, saying: ``I have one cat, and I used to have a fish. My brother's fish ate it. I need to get a new one.'' Then she starts asking about his life: ``I wonder what it's like over there. I bet it's kind of scary. I just looked on the map. I found where you are. It is a long way away.'' Doug, even at a distance, managed to hit the nail on the head about the prevailing attitude among soldiers and journalists with his question. ``I only have one question and that is what is it like to be sitting out there doing nothing but waiting there to see if anything happens?'' --- The arrival of October has brought a slight easing in the fierce desert temperatures that kept troops inactive for much of the day. The mercury has started to fall, with the water in storage tanks actually too cold in the morning for some people's taste for showers. Daytime temperatures, while still high by most standards, are down 10 to 20 degrees from the 115-degree norm in August, when the soldiers started to arrive. ``A couple days ago it was 95 and that was magnificent,'' said Col. Burt Tackaberry, 43, of Jacksonville, Fla., the commanding officer of the 24th Infantry division's Aviation Brigade. --- Many troops are also getting their first phone calls home and its always a toss up who is more surprised the caller or the recipient in the United States. One staff sergeant, sitting in the middle of a tractless waste of sand, got through to his wife in Camp Pendleton, Calif., via satellite link. He was obviously having trouble getting a word in edgewise as he kept saying into the phone: ``Uh hon ... honey ... honey.'' Finally he bellowed: ``Honey! Shut up! I love you!''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Bruce Willis doesn't want to forget his humble beginnings, so he still pays rent on a rundown Manhattan apartment. ``To me, it's a reminder of where I came from. That's one memory I don't want to lose,'' Willis said in the Oct. 14 issue of Parade magazine. Before there was ``Moonlighting'' or ``Die Hard'' and ``Die Hard 2,'' Willis supported himself in New York by working as a bartender and security guard. He earned a combined $10 million for the two ``Die Hard'' movies. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Producer Steve Tisch and Roy Orbison's widow, Barbara Orbison, are working on a movie about the rock 'n' roll pioneer. ``I liked that Steve saw the picture the way I saw the picture, a story with heart and inspiration, about a man's journey and not just about rock 'n' roll but the human side of it,'' Mrs. Orbison said. Orbison was known for such rock classics as ``Pretty Woman'' and ``Only the Lonely.'' The movie will cover his life from his childhood in a small Texas town during the Depression to his death from a heart attack in 1988 at age 52. ``Roy had a tremendous life. It had severe ups, like being best male vocalist in 1964, to the severe downs, like tragedies of his losing a wife and kids,'' Mrs. Orbison said. The two were married in 1969. She and Tisch, whose credits include the movie ``Risky Business,'' hope to settle on a writer and director this year and begin filming next spring. Tisch said negotiations were under way with Warner Bros. to finance and distribute the movie. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Bruce Springsteen will join Bonnie Raitt and Jackson Browne for a concert next month to raise money for a non-profit group that is waging a lawsuit accusing the United States of involvement in the drug trade. It will be Springsteen's first official concert appearance since 1988, when he participated in the Amnesty International world tour. Tickets ranging from $25 to $100 go on sale Sunday for the Nov. 16 concert at Shrine Auditorium. The fund-raiser will benefit the Washington-based Christic Institute, which monitors law and public policy. The concert will help finance a lawsuit alleging U.S. officials sanctioned illegal gun and drug sales to finance covert operations during the Iran-Contra affair. --- EASTON, Conn. (AP) - Actor Hume Cronyn got permission to build an apartment for live-in help after arguing that his wife, Oscar-winning actress Jessica Tandy, is ailing and that his eyesight is failing. Miss Tandy, 81, and Cronyn, 79, were turned down in August for a zoning waiver but were approved Tuesday by the Zoning Board of Appeals. ``Old age is a hardship,'' Cronyn told the panel. ``One that you'll be dealing with over the years.'' The apartment on their property would be for a driver or attendant, Cronyn said. He said the need had become more urgent since Miss Tandy was hospitalized for a heart condition following surgery. Cronyn did not disclose the nature of her surgery. Miss Tandy, who won an Oscar for her role as an elderly woman who needed a chauffeur in ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' has suffered from angina for 10 years. Cronyn also said a driver may become necessary because his eyesight is failing. ``I don't know how long we'll go on driving or looking after our place,'' he told the board. --- LONDON (AP) - The Duke and Duchess of York have new digs, Sunninghill Park near Windsor Castle. The duke, Queen Elizabeth II's son Andrew, and his wife, Sarah, along with their two daughters, completed the move Thursday. Andrew took time off from his job as flight commander of the Royal Navy frigate Cambletown to make the move. The two-story, red brick house is set in walled grounds on five acres about 20 miles west of London. Included are tennis courts and a swimming pool. The cost of the home was not disclosed.

DOC.HEAD: House OKs Arts Endowment Extension Without Obscenity Curbs
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain; House floor debate not expected before mid-afternoon EDT
DOC.TEXT: When Rep. Pat Williams won his House floor battle to rescue the National Endowment for the Arts from conservative attack, he happily lost a $1 bet to an old Montana cowboy. Six months ago, Williams says, he was convinced that the federal arts agency wouldn't survive the political controversy over NEA support for arts projects that its critics consider obscene and blasphemous. The Montana Democrat, a staunch NEA supporter, said an elderly cowboy in his home district bet that Williams would prevail when the issue reached the House floor. Williams owes the cowpoke a buck. On Thursday, the House overwhelmingly rejected a move to abolish the NEA, defeated a proposal to impose tough new anti-obscenity restrictions and embraced a bipartisan compromise that would leave the obscenity issue to the courts. The compromise bill, drafted by Williams and Rep. E. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo., after months of intense negotiations, was approved on a 382-42 roll call vote. The margin surprised Williams. ``It was a bigger victory in favor of tolerance and freedom of expression than I had expected,'' he said. ``The House made it much easier for members of the Senate to save the NEA.'' Like a similar measure awaiting Senate floor action, the House bill would shift from the NEA to the courts the burden of deciding whether federally subsidized arts projects are obscene. Under the bill, grant recipients who are subsequently convicted of using their federal funds to create works that violate obscenity laws would be required to return their grant money to the NEA. Once they do, they would be eligible to apply for new endowment grants. The House measure also would order reforms in the NEA's grant-making procedures with the aim of making them more responsive to the taxpaying public. In a provision pushed by Republicans, the bill would increase the share of NEA grant money allocated to the states from 20 percent to 35 percent over the next three years. The bill would extend the NEA's statutory authority for three years, instead of the usual five years, and would declare that works violating the Supreme Court's obscenity standard ``shall not be funded.'' Current restrictions, imposed by Congress a year ago at the urging of Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., forbid NEA financing of works that ``may be considered obscene,'' including depictions of homosexual and sadomasochistic activities and sexual exploitation of children. The House planned to begin debate later today on a separate appropriations bill that would boost the NEA's budget from $171 million to $180 million in the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Rep. Ralph Regula, R-Ohio, obtained permission to introduce a floor amendment to the money bill that would forbid NEA financing of obscene or indecent art. His proposal also would require the endowment chairman to ensure that NEA-supported works are ``appropriate for a general audience.'' Williams and Coleman said that if Regula's amendment is tacked onto the money bill, they will seek to replace it with the terms of their measure so the House will take a uniform position on the NEA in both bills. During an emotional, five-hour debate on the NEA bill Thursday, the House defeated, 361-64, a move by Rep. Philip Crane, R-Ill., to abolish the NEA. Then, it rejected, 249-175, a proposal by Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., to impose stringent new anti-obscenity curbs on NEA grants. This would include a ban on financing works that depict ``sexually explicit conduct'' or child pornography, attack religion, defile the American flag or include ``an actual human embryo or fetus.'' Rohrabacher warned his colleagues that ``the American people are watching this debate'' on television, implying that lawmakers who opposed his amendment would face the wrath of voters in the Nov. 6 elections. He denounced the Williams-Coleman bill as a fraud, and challenged the House to ``set standards so our tax dollars are not channeled into subsidizing child pornography or attacks on Christianity.'' Rohrabacher's opponents charged that his proposal was an unconstitutional attempt to intimidate artists and squelch freedom of expression for political gain.

DOC.HEAD: Father of Quadriplegic Who Sought to End His Life Dies
DOC.TEXT: A man who had been his quadriplegic son's sole caretaker for 12 years died of lung cancer, a week after he apparently helped his son end his life so the young man wouldn't be left alone. Robert Bergstedt, 64, died Thursday at Nathan Adelson Hospice, said his attorney. He checked into the hospital after his 31-year-old son, Kenneth, died last week. Both deaths came before the Nevada Supreme Court ruled on Kenneth Bergstedt's petition that he be allowed to end his life without threat of legal recourse against anyone who helped him die. ``I think the story of Robert's care of his son is really an epic story of eternal love,'' Supreme Court Justice Cliff Young said. ``If anybody's deserving of being considered for canonization or sainthood, I think Robert would be a nominee.'' Kenneth Bergstedt sought to end his life for fear his father, his sole companion, would not be around to take care of him. In court papers he said he found little fulfillment in life, which he spent strapped to a gurney and hooked to a respirator. A lower court had ruled in his favor but asked that he postpone his death until the Supreme Court could rule. ``I've lost two very close friends in the last week,'' said attorney Jack Cherry. Cherry said Bergstedt lost a leg in a 1947 industrial accident, his wife died of cancer in 1978 and he had cared for his son since a swimming accident in 1969 left him crippled. Bergstedt was diagnosed last month as having cancer. ``How tough can one family have it?'' the lawyer said. ``Any time you think you've got it tough, take a look at these folks. Everything's relative.'' Kenneth Bergstedt was found dead Oct. 4 in the mobile home he and his father shared. The coroner's office said it was awaiting toxicology tests before ruling on the cause of death. Robert Bergstedt told the Las Vegas Sun last week that he gave his son sedatives and loosened his respirator after his son told him he could not live any longer. But police said Bergstedt told them his son's respirator had accidentally worked loose and that he had awakened to find Kenneth Bergstedt dead. Young said the Supreme Court plans to rule on the right-to-die case anyway. ``We could say it's moot because Kenneth is dead, but the court has pretty well indicated it wants to face the issue directly,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Chain Selves to Soviet Consulate Gates
DOC.TEXT: Five demonstrators chained themselves to the gates of the Soviet consulate today to publicize the arrests of a Greenpeace crew by the Soviet Union four days earlier. The protesters were demanding that Soviet authorities allow a resumption of radio contact between the 34-member crew of the vessel MV Greenpeace and the enviromental group's London headquarters, said Greenpeace spokeswoman Michelle Grosvenor. She said the protesters will remain chained to the consulate gates until radio contact is resumed and the safety of the crew guaranteed. The crew, including an Austrialian and and at least one American, was seized Monday by the KGB while protesting a planned nuclear weapons test on the Soviet archipelago of Novaya Zemlya. A Soviet Foreign Ministry statement released Thursday said the Greenpeace ship was being towed to the Murmansk where the crew would be handed over to authorities.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Arms Control Pacts Reflect Cold War's Demise
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: It's taking longer than President Bush predicted, but the United States and the Soviet Union are only months away from signing two of the most significant arms reduction treaties in history. One would rid Europe of thousands of tanks, airplanes, antiaircraft artillery pieces and armored troop carriers. Most of the cuts would be in Soviet weapons. The other pact would trim U.S. and Soviet long-range nuclear missiles by about 30 percent overall. Hundreds of warheads would be scrapped under tight supervision. The European treaty is the most comprehensive arms control accord in history. The U.S.-Soviet strategic arms reduction accord, meanwhile, deals with the deadliest weapons and, at 400 to 500 pages, is of unprecedented length. Bush predicted the conventional weapons treaty would be ready by last June at the latest. It looks like it will be ready in mid-November. The heads of the 16 North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries and the six Warsaw Pact nations will sign the treaty in Paris at a glittering summit meeting. Bush hoped to sign the START accord with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow in December. There is a slim chance of that. U.S. officials say early next year is more likely. Deadlines are not the main consideration. Harnessing the race in conventional and nuclear weapons, once a visionary dream, is about to become a reality. Incredibly, the historic development has not captured the public's imagination. One reason is that the end of the Cold War already has soothed nuclear war nerves. Gorbachev is committed to withdrawing many of the tanks to be cut under the treaty, along with the troops that accompany them. Bush has ordered more modest cuts. The Conventional Forces in Europe treaty will make cutbacks legally binding, however. And it will establish a framework for even deeper reductions later on. Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze cleared the last roadblocks in New York last week. These involved limits on land-based airplanes and verification procedures against cheating. The two officials were unable, however, to resolve the remaining differences in the strategic arms reduction treaty. The four key ones are: -The restrictions to be imposed on transfers to allies of weapons barred under the treaty. This mostly involves U.S. nuclear submarine technology for Britain. -The restrictions to be imposed on improving the Soviet SS-18 intercontinental ballistic missiles. -Whether the Soviet Backfire bomber is to be classified as a long-range weapon under the treaty and made subject, therefore, to limitations. -Procedures for verifying the destruction of the bombers, submarines and missiles outlawed under the treaty. Baker indicated last Friday that his talks with Shevardnadze tripped over the transfer issue and that the SS-18 and Backfire problems could be settled once what arms controllers call non-circumvention is cleared up. ``In every nuclear negotiation the Soviets press us on cooperation with Britain and they have acceded ultimately every time,'' a U.S. official said Thursday. ``Personally I am optimistic that we'll settle this one.'' The Backfire bomber also has dogged U.S.-Soviet nuclear arms talks for a long time. The Soviets insist the weapon is of medium-range. The United States insists the Backfire can span oceans and should be restricted both in range and in number. The solution may be an agreement outside the treaty in which the Soviets volunteer to curb Backfire. The SS-18 issue causes the most concern among conservatives in Congress. Some were ready to crucify Baker a few months ago when he tentatively agreed to some tests of the missile, the deadliest in the Soviet arsenal. The Soviets already have agreed to cut their SS-18 stockpile in half - from 308 to 154. The question is at what point improvements in the existing SS-18 amount to creation of an illegal new weapon. The official, who gave The Associated Press a progress report under conditions of anonymity, cautioned: ``I would not downgrade the importance of the specifics of verification.'' Among the tough items are the procedures for inspecting missile plants to guard against the production of illegal weapons. ``They require long hours and a lot of work and focus, but that doesn't mean it's impossible,'' the official said. --- EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid reports on arms control and other U.S.-Soviet issues for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Designate was Chocolate Raider
DOC.TEXT: Bishop George Carey, the next archbishop of Canterbury, says he tried to steal chocolate bars from a freight train when he was 8 years old. The bishop recalls that he was caught by a nightwatchman and what he thought was a box of chocolate Mars bars turned out to be a box of Bibles. He said his captor pulled out a Bible and told him: ``Here's one that will do you more good.'' ``Looking back on 46 years, I am sure it has,'' says Carey in a new book of childhood memories by 70 personalities, ``When They Were Young.'' The book published by Radcliffe Press is to go on sale at the end of the month, with proceeds to help children suffering from cancer and leukemia victims. Carey, 54, is a hospital porter's son and grew up on a municipal housing development in east London. In January, he will succeed Archbishop Robert Runcie as spiritual head of the Church of England and leader of the world's 70 million Anglicans, including 2 million U.S. Episcopalians.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic School Pledge: Liberty and Justice `For the Unborn'
DOC.TEXT: When students at a Roman Catholic school here recite the Pledge of Allegiance, they promise loyalty to a country that offers liberty and justice ``for the born and the unborn.'' The principal at Lorain Catholic High School said she and faculty members added the phrase this week to reflect the church's anti-abortion stance. Some of the school's 400 students in this town 35 miles west of Cleveland said that they were not ordered to recite the phrase to the end of the pledge but that they feel pressured to do so and resent it. ``It's like changing the Constitution,'' junior Angela Martinez said Thursday. Others said the anti-abortion sentiment should be expected in a Catholic schoo. Senior Meghan Chapple said the change gave the same emphasis and values behind Catholic prayers. Of those who disaprove, she said, ``They're at a Catholic school and should be expected to (uphold) the Catholic values.'' Some students had threatened to boycott classes Thursday to protest the change. But students questioned after school said they had not skipped classes and did not know if others had. Principal Joanne Miller said the amended pledge was appropriate and that no students had protested. ``Students come here by choice. They do not come here because this is their district. And when they come they agree to our policies and our philosophy,'' she said. This week has been designated ``respect for life'' week at Catholic schools around the nation. Students are being urged to reflect on the issues of abortion, euthanasia, the homeless and poverty. Robert Kealey, executive director for the National Catholic Education Association in Washington, said he had not heard of any other school altering the Pledge of Allegiance. The association represents most of the nation's Catholic secondary and elementary schools. Jerry Lackamp, spokesman for the Catholic Diocese of Cleveland, said referring to the unborn in the pledge is not policy for Catholic schools in northeastern Ohio. Some students said they recite the pledge, then stop at the new part. ``A lot of students, when they say the pledge, say `justice for all' and then sit down, and you just hear the rest over the P.A. system,'' said Marcie Apont, an eighth-grader.

DOC.HEAD: Bumper Corn Crop in Prospect, USDA Says
DOC.TEXT: Some of their yields have been shaved by dry weather, but farmers nationally are harvesting a bumper corn crop this fall, according to new estimates by the Agriculture Department. Production was estimated Thursday at 8.02 billion bushels, up 7 percent from last year's crop. That's the most since the 1986 harvest of 8.23 billion bushels. However, the new estimate by the department's Agricultural Statistics Board was down 1 percent from last month's forecast of 8.12 billion bushels. ``Early in September, lack of moisture in the western Corn Belt caused deteriorating crop conditions,'' the board's report said. ``Crop conditions lagged furthest behind in Illinois, Indiana and Missouri.'' Farmers harvested 7.53 billion bushels in 1989, and the department in its initial 1990 forecast on Aug. 9 put this fall's harvest at 7.85 billion bushels before raising it last month. John A. Schnittker of Schnittker Associates, a Washington-based consulting firm, said the forecast is ``almost equal to the amount of corn we will need in the next 12 months'' to meet domestic and export demands now projected. But the bad news, he said, is that ``this corn crop coincides with a glut in wheat, especially.'' Big wheat producers, including the United States, are subsidizing exports in an effort to unload surpluses. ``The big wheat crop glutting the world market and the subsidization of wheat, pushing it below corn prices, is the real problem,'' Schnittker said. Based on Oct. 1 surveys, corn yields were estimated at a record 120.3 bushels per acre harvested, compared with 116.2 bushels last year and 121.7 bushels indicated last month. The old record was 119.4 bushels in 1987. As livestock feed, corn is the largest and most important U.S. farm crop and is essential for the production of meat, poultry and dairy products. Consumer food prices, which rose an average of 5.8 percent in 1989, the sharpest year-to-year increase since 1981, are expected to climb an additional 5 percent to 7 percent in 1990. Soybean production, a source of high-protein meal and vegetable oil, was estimated at 1.82 billion bushels, down 5 percent from last year's harvest of 1.93 billion bushels and 1 percent below the September forecast of 1.83 billion bushels. Cotton production was indicated at 14.5 million bales, up 19 percent from last year's output of 12.2 million bales but down 1 percent from the September forecast. The revised estimates showed total wheat production at 2.74 billion bushels, up 35 percent from the 1989 harvest but down slightly from last month. The department's all-crops production index was reported at 111 percent of its 1977 average used for comparison, down one percentage point from September but still the highest reading since the index averaged 116 percent in 1985. In a related report on supply and demand for major commodities, analysts said total corn use in the 1990-91 marketing year that began Sept. 1 is expected to be about 8.095 billion bushels, including domestic and export requirements. With demand slightly exceeding 1990 corn production, that will mean a decrease in U.S. corn stockpiles to about 1.273 billion bushels left over by Sept. 1, 1991. But the downturn would be modest compared with 1989, when the corn stockpile plummeted from 4.26 billion bushels on Sept. 1, 1988 to 1.93 billion bushels on hand last Sept. 1. The report said U.S. corn prices may average in the range of $2.20 to $2.60 per bushel in the 1990-91 marketing year, up 10 cents from the September projection. Corn prices at the farm averaged about $2.36 per bushel last season. No significant changes were reported in the U.S. wheat supply and demand situation, and prices at the farm are expected to average $2.55 to $2.85 per bushel this marketing year from $3.72 in 1989-90. Soybean prices at the farm were forecast at $5.70 to $7 per bushel in 1990-91, compared with $5.70 the past marketing year. That was up 20 cents on the lower end of the range in September. Other 1990 crop estimates based on Oct. 1 indications, compared with 1989 output, included: -Sorghum, 561.9 million bushels and an average yield of 60.7 bushels per acre, compared with 617.9 million and 55.4 in 1989. -Rice, 158 million hundredweight and a yield of 5,629 pounds per acre, compared with 154.5 million and 5,749. -Peanuts, 3.36 billion pounds and a yield of 1,917 pounds per acre, compared with 3.99 billion and 2,426. -Tobacco, 1.58 billion pounds and a yield of 2,166 pounds per acre, compared with 1.37 billion and 2,016. -Sugar beets, 27.1 million tons and a yield of 19.89 tons per acre, compared with 25.1 million and 19.4. -Sugar cane, 25.7 million tons and a yield of 35.7 tons per acre, compared with 29.4 million and 34.5.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Will Press Soviets for Intelligence on Iraqi Military
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney plans to press Soviet government officials for secret information about the Iraqi military while he's in Moscow next week, an aide said. Cheney is scheduled to meet with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Wednesday, as well as with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Defense Minister Dimitri Yazov. Cheney also will meet with Soviet political reform leaders. The Cheney aide, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Thursday that Moscow had not responded to previous U.S. requests for detailed intelligence on Iraqi weapons, most of which were designed and built by Soviets. The Soviets have provided American officials with general assessments of Iraqi intentions regarding the occupation of Kuwait but nothing more specific, the official said. Last month Soviet KGB chairman Vladimir A. Kryuchkov said in an interview with The Associated Press that Moscow was willing to share intelligence on Iraq with Washington but hadn't made the offer directly because it has been rebuffed in the past by the CIA. Nearly all the estimated 3,500 Iraqi tanks deployed in Kuwait and southern Iraq and many of that country's military aircraft are of Soviet design. U.S. officials claim that several hundred Soviet technical specialists are in Iraq advising Iraqi military officials on maintaining warplanes and other Soviet-built equipment. Cheney is scheduled to arrive in Moscow on Tuesday. His will be the second visit to that country by an American secretary of defense. Cheney's predecessor, Frank Carlucci, was there in 1988. Cheney will hold meetings with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her defense secretary, Tom King, in London on Monday before flying to Moscow. He will stop in Paris on his way back from Moscow on Oct. 19 to meet with President Francois Mitterrand and Defense Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement. The London and Paris meetings will focus mainly on the status of arms control negotiations and on prospects for redefining the role of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the Pentagon official said. He said the Persian Gulf crisis was not expected to be a major topic. The Pentagon official said that although Cheney would press the Soviets for specific intelligence on the Iraqi military, discussions on the gulf crisis would be secondary to questions about Soviet economic, social and political reform. He said Cheney would stress to the Soviets that the Bush administration is planning major cuts in defense spending, plus the withdrawal of more than 40,000 troops from Western Europe. This will be highlighted in hopes of encouraging the Soviets to carry through with their declared intentions of reducing military strength, the official said.

DOC.HEAD: Xavier Cugat, 90, In Intensive Care With Heart Trouble
DOC.TEXT: Big-band leader Xavier Cugat has been placed on a respirator three days after his admission to a hospital for heart and lung trouble, his doctors said. The 90-year-old Cugat, who made the rumba popular in America, was in serious condition in intensive care when he was placed on the respirateor Thursday, according to a statement by doctors Jorge Rius and Jaime Pujadas. ``They are waiting to see how he responds to the treatment,'' a hospital spokeswoman said. Cugat checked into the Quiron Clinic Monday with a lung infection and trouble in his left ventricle. Similar problems have forced him into the hospital 27 times since 1980, the doctors said. Cugat is generally credited with introducing tropical rythms into American dance music in the 1930s. He and his band were featured in several popular Hollywood movies. He retired in 1970 and a decade later moved to Barcelona, the capital of the Catalonia region where he was born Jan. 1, 1900.

DOC.HEAD: Budget, Bonds and Big Shots: Will The City Be Saved From Itself?
DOC.TEXT: Vast budget gaps, bond-rating woes and finger-pointing by big shots - New York's crisis has all the marks of the city's near-bankruptcy 15 years ago. But fiscal watchdogs say there won't be a reprise of 1975. That was the year New York pleaded for a federal rescue and the Daily News scored with the headline ``Ford to City: Drop Dead.'' It was the year 25,000 city workers, including 5,000 police officers, were laid off, 8,000 substitute teachers were fired and services were slashed. This year, the headlines trumpet fiscal warnings that seemingly are as perilous, as the economy goes downhill regionally and nationally. Mayor David N. Dinkins, 10 months in office, is plugging a $1.8 billion budget deficit just three months into the fiscal year and grappling with a gap for next year. The first week of October epitomized the city's struggle to limit spending without gutting services. First, the city gave teachers a 5.5 percent raise in a one-year contract settlement. Critics said the amount was too generous and would set a bad example for negotiations with 250,000 other city workers. Responding to a summer crime wave, Dinkins let loose a criminal justice plan with a $1.9 billion price tag. Leaders in the state Legislature promptly said they would block the taxes Dinkins called for to finance the package. Dinkins then imposed a hiring freeze and said he was considering laying off 15,000 workers because of declining revenue. The jobless rate in the city hit 7.9 percent in September, up from 6.2 percent in August. To top it off, Standard and Poor's announced Tuesday it has placed the city's $13 billion in general obligation bonds on ``credit watch,'' meaning the city's bond rating might be lowered. Bond markets have been tumbling since, forcing higher borrowing costs on the city. Then came the name-calling. Former Mayor Edward I. Koch accused Labor Commissioner Eric Schmertz of helping teachers take Dinkins ``to the cleaners.'' Schmertz said Koch was indulging in ``monumental bitchiness'' and had been involved in the most corrupt administration since Jimmy Walker's in the 1920s. Dinkins had to weather bad publicity over a headboard for his bed as he was urging belt-tightening. The headboard reportedly cost $11,500. The administration said that whatever the cost, it would be covered privately. So how bad is the situation, compared with 1975? ``Not the same, not as bad,'' said Edward V. Regan, state comptroller. ``In those days in 1975, the city was unable to borrow, basically unable to pay its bills in a lot of ways.'' Hyman C. Grossman, Standard & Poor's managing director, said, ``We expect (the city) to pull it out, but we have a bigger question mark, which is why we have a credit watch.'' ``The situation is lousy, it's awful, but it's not calamitous,'' said Herbert Bienstock, who was director of the local U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics from 1962 to 1980 and heads a Queens College research unit. The major differences between then and now, the analysts agreed, is that the city was not prepared to handle the crisis of '75. Harrison Goldin said that when he became city comptroller in 1974, the city ``didn't have the foggiest idea'' where its money was. As it turned out, some was in shoeboxes tucked in closets, where Goldin said he found billions of dollars worth of deposits from contractors and negotiable municipal bonds. The city, he said, ``didn't have the basic information to run a corner candy store.'' Very true, agreed Elinor B. Bachrach, now deputy state comptroller for New York City. From 1975 to 1981 she was on the staff of Sen. William Proxmire's Senate banking committee, where the city turned for help. ``In those days the city couldn't even tell how much its deficit was, how many people it had on its payroll,'' Bachrach said. Despite President Ford's opposition to a bailout, the city pulled through 1975, after new fiscal constraints and monitoring were imposed and the feds coughed up $2.3 billion in short-term loans. The restraints included a law that the city's budget must balance, creation of Bachrach's office of deputy comptroller to monitor the city's finances and creation of a special belt-tightening board. They are the same restraints expected to save the city from itself this time. ``In a certain sense, you are seeing the system work, not the system not working,'' said Regan. ``My guess is, other than the economy eroding, the mayor will come to grips with this. It won't get worse.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Delegation Seeks U.S. Goodwill
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Dozens of Chinese government buyers are coming to the United States today to order American goods, but U.S. officials believe the main item on their shopping list is congressional goodwill. The delegation - the largest China has sent here - comes as the House moved toward a vote on the administration's plan to extend trade benefits to China for another year. The benefits, known as Most Favored Nation status, are vital to China because they slash tariffs on Chinese goods sold in the United States - China's biggest export market. China's trade status was in danger last year after its violent suppression of a pro-democracy demonstration at Beijing's Tiananmen Square. Many lawmakers are demanding the administration withhold the favored trade status unless China improves its human rights record. ``They fully realize congressional sensitivities,'' said David Denny of the U.S.-China Business Council, a non-profit group representing U.S. firms doing business in China. The invitation was solicited by China on the advice of U.S. officials and lobbyists who urged them to appease Congress, much as Taiwan and South Korea do with such missions when their trade policies come under fire. Many members of Congress also are upset over China's trade surplus with the United States, its increasing import restrictions against certain U.S. products, and its limits on U.S. investment opportunities. According to U.S. Commerce Department figures, the United States sold China products worth $5.8 billion last year - mostly wheat, Boeing aircraft, cotton and wood. The United States bought from China almost double that amount - $11.99 billion - mostly in apparel and footwear. China, which calculates the trade figures differently, shows a surplus of only $1.3 billion. ``Either way, reducing the surplus, or announcing significant deals, will do them some good with Congress,'' Denny said. Only four lawmakers have agreed to meet with the delegation. The rest have cited scheduling problems or said they don't want to be influenced before the vote on China's trade status, said one source who asked not to be named. Despite an administration ban on high-level contacts with Chinese officials - imposed by President Bush after the Tiananmen Square massacre - the delegation will meet with Lawrence Eagleburger, deputy secretary of state, and Thomas Murrin, deputy secretary of commerce. The administration has made other exceptions to this ban, most recently when Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with his Chinese counterpart at the United Nations, but each time was described as an exception. Other sanctions imposed by the Bush administration, including a suspension of weapons sales and strict limits on loans to China, remain in place. Chinese officials have promised to place orders for U.S. goods worth $200 million or $300 million and negotiate for future purchases. The team plans to visit Washington, New York, Chicago, Houston, Los Angeles and Seattle. The trade mission ``demonstrates China's determination of continuing to open to the outside world,'' according to an announcement by Chinese authorities. But U.S. officials and trade experts are skeptical. ``It's unclear how many new contracts there'll actually be,'' said one official familiar with the mission. ``They may just sign contracts already in the pipeline.'' China's conservative leaders have shown few signs they actually intend to relax their trade policies, since they began rolling back from economic liberalization two years ago. On the contrary. Responding to a decline in economic growth and to fears of inflation, as well as the burden of repaying the country's $40 billion international debt, authorities have restricted imports.

DOC.HEAD: Students Play Mothballed Mozart Work
DOC.TEXT: An unfinished piece of music by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart has been played, possibly for the first time, after a relative decided to auction off the work composed about 200 years ago. Five students at the Royal College of Music on Thursday performed the 35 bars of the ``Quintet in B Flat Major'' for piano and wind instruments, oboe, clarinet, basset horn and bassoon. ``They are an unusual group of instruments and I think the work might not have been completed because Mozart may have found it difficult to find musicians to play them,'' said Stephen Roe, director of manuscripts at Sotheby's. The firm will auction the music Nov. 21. The fragment took 1\ minutes to perform and sounded complete, although it was only the opening of a work. Roe said the single sheet of music was on the same kind of paper Mozart was using in 1783. He said it was brought to one of their offices on the European continent by a member of the family who had preserved it for more than a century and who asked not to be identified.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Says Nicu Ceausescu to Remain in Prison
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court says Nicu Ceausescu must stay in prison, overturning an earlier decision to release the youngest son of Romania's late Communist dictator on health grounds, the Rompres news agency reported. Ceausescu would periodically visit state health facilities for observation, Rompres quoted a Supreme Court statement as saying in its ruling Thursday. A military tribunal on Sept. 18 sentenced Ceausescu to 20 years for ``incitement to murder'' during last December's revolution that toppled his father Nicolae Ceausescu, who was later executed. A lower court later decided to release the younger Ceausescu for three months because he was suffering from severe cirrhosis of the liver and couldn't tolerate jail conditions. Ceausescu was initially charged with ``complicity to genocide.'' During the uprising, 89 people were killed in Sibiu, where he had been Communist party boss since 1987. The state prosecutor announced this week Ceausescu would face further charges of misappropriating food and alcohol from state stocks.

DOC.HEAD: Saudis Reported Speeding Expansion Plans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This SUBS 4th graf, bgng, `Kuwait and' to CORRECT Saudi Arabia to Iraq. Picks up 5th graf pvs, bgng, `Through the'
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia plans to increase crude oil production another 10 percent by the middle of next year and will speed up expansion plans to reach peak output of 10 million barrels a day by 1995, The Washington Post said in Friday's editions. In a dispatch from Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, the newspaper quoted Saudi oil executives as dismissing reports of problems in the expansion plan. Saudi Aramco, the state-owned oil company, now produces 7.7 million barrels a day, a 45 percent increase from the 5.3 million daily barrels it was producing before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Kuwait and Iraq had been producing 4.35 million barrels a day, and that oil was immediately embargoed from world trade. Though the extra Saudi production and increases in output elsewhere have replaced a large fraction of the lost production, worried buyers have pushed the price of oil in international markets from about $21 a barrel in July to around $40 now. In the late 1970s, Saudi Arabia often produced 10 million barrels a day, but production was cut back in the 1980s and facilities were mothballed. Reporting on an interview with Nasr Ajmi, executive vice president of Saudi Aramco, the newspaper said Saudi production would reach 8 million barrels a day by the end of this year. By the middle of 1991, the target is ``8.5 (million) or better,'' Ajmi was quoted as saying. ``We have every reason to believe we can get to that level and sustain it,'' he said. The government had already decided to restore capacity to 10 million barrels a day in the 1990s but now will try to do 10 years of expansion work in five, the newspaper said. Saudi Arabia has by far the largest oil reserves in the world.

DOC.HEAD: Studies Suggest Diet Can Help Prevent Cancer, But Not Treat It
DOC.TEXT: The high fat fare preferred by fast food-loving Americans is a ``killer diet'' that encourages cancer growth, but scientists still don't know exactly why rich food seems to have this effect. At a conference Thursday on the effects of diet on cancer, Creighton University School of Medicine researcher Dr. Henry T. Lynch said there is good evidence that what Americans eat is affecting the way many of them die. ``The man on the street is eating himself to death with a killer diet of high calories and high fat,'' said Lynch. ``They are more vulnerable to cancer. We know that from epidemiological studies.'' But the precise biological link between diet and the development of cancer cells is still unknown. Lynch said that despite claims by some unconventional cancer treatment centers there is no conclusive, clear evidence that any specific food or diet is an absolute protection from cancer. Lynch, a speaker at a meeting of the American Institute for Cancer Research, said all that scientists can say for sure is that a high-fiber, low-fat diet is a ``prudent'' precaution against cancer. This is based on studies of populations in which the occurrence of cancer is lower than the rate in the United States or in other countries that have adopted a Western diet, he said. Laboratory studies using animals fed special diets have shown ``very appealing evidence'' that some nutrients can protect against the formation of cancer cells, Lynch said. But this does not mean that special diets will have the same effect among people. ``In humans, the data is still preliminary and fragmentary,'' said Lynch. ``When bringing dietary manipulation to a clinical application, we're still in a gray zone.'' Once cancer has developed, Lynch said there has been no reputable research showing that special diets or food supplements can effectively defeat the disease. People with cancer may spend thousands of dollars on unconventional treatments based on unusual diets, but they are wasting their money, the researcher said. ``There are no anti-cancer dietary supplements,'' said Lynch, a practicing cancer specialist. ``I know patients who get into that garbage and it's pathetic.'' Carmia Borek, a professor at the Tufts University School of Medicine, said there have been studies showing that low levels of some nutrients are more common among people with cancer. And she said that laboratory studies on isolated cells and in animals have shown that increased levels of some vitamins and other nutrients can interrupt the development of cancer cells. But, she said, there still is no evidence relating these findings to humans, or proving that dietary manipulation can either treat or prevent cancer. ``We still have to do work on that,'' she said. ``I don't think we'll have the final evidence for a long time.'' Lynch said one way to get this evidence would be to study families in which there is a genetic predisposition for cancer. ``There are thousands of families that have been decimated by cancer,'' he said. Some family members, said Lynch, are destined by genetics to have a 50-50 chance of developing the disease. Using controlled diets in carefully designed studies with these families, he said, could give ``final answers'' on cancer and diet in about one generation. ``The evidence is very strong that diet is associated with cancer, but it's not clear if dietary manipulation can prevent the disease,'' said Lynch. ``The hypothesis has to be tested.'' A number of federal and private health organizations have said that the typical American diet includes too much animal fat and too little complex carbohydrates. Some studies have shown that Americans typically consume up to 45 percent of their daily calories from foods rich in fat. The American Heart Association recommends only 30 percent of a diet from fat, and some experts said the fat content should be as low as 20 percent.

DOC.HEAD: DeConcini Predicts He'll Be Exonerated in S&L Ethics Case
DOC.TEXT: Sen.
