Dennis DeConcini says nobody should write his political obituary because of an ethics investigation, and predicts no wrongdoing will be found in his help for a collapsing savings and loan. The Arizona Democrat, after closed testimony Thursday before the Senate Ethics Committee, said he's ``confident the truth will prevail'' and that the six-member panel of his peers ``will exonerate me.'' DeConcini and four other senators are under investigation for the help they gave former savings and loan executive Charles H. Keating Jr. The businessman and his associates contributed $1.3 million to the five lawmakers' campaigns and causes. Congressional sources have said committee special counsel Robert S. Bennett recommended that there was enough evidence to continue the ethics investigation against Sens. DeConcini, Alan Cranston of California and Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan. Bennett recommended dismissal for Sens. John Glenn of Ohio and John McCain of Arizona. McCain is the only Republican in the group. DeConcini met with the committee for five hours, punctuated by several breaks, mostly to answer questions but also to give a half-hour statement defending his cnduct. The committee, which investigates potential violations of Senate conduct, has met individually with DeConcini, McCain and Glenn. Cranston and Riegle are scheduled to appear next week. DeConcini, a three-term senator who is up for election in 1994, said the investigation has been a ``very trying time'' for him, but added, ``I wouldn't write an obituary for Sen. DeConcini if I decide to run again.'' The senator contended there was ``no basis'' to allegations by Common Cause, a group that monitors Congress, that his help for Keating violated Senate rules. Common Cause's complaint that all five senators may have broken the rules triggered the preliminary investigation that began last December. DeConcini played an active role for Keating, inviting other senators to join him in sessions with U.S. banking regulators and urging banking officials to approve the sale, rather than seizure of Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan. His contacts with regulators continued until the time Lincoln was brought under federal control in April 1989, a move that could cost taxpayers more than $2 billion in bailout costs. Lincoln was based in Irvine, Calif., but Keating's main company, American Continental Corp., was in Phoenix. DeConcini has maintained that his assistance for Keating simply was representation for a constituent who was a major Arizona employer. The nation's former top thrift regulator, Edwin J. Gray, accused DeConcini of offering him a deal on Keating's behalf in April 1987, but the senator and three of his colleagues who were present denied the proposal was ever made. DeConcini received $48,100 in contributions from Keating and associates, but announced a year ago he was returning the money because there was a possibility the funds were illegally funneled from Lincoln.

DOC.HEAD: Little Immediate Payoff for U.S. Businesses Seen in Soviet Changes
DOC.TEXT: A key Soviet economic adviser says his country must make ``a very drastic change of the economic and political system,'' but American business leaders say they expect no quick bonanza from the Soviet Union's movement toward a market economy. Stanislav Shatalin, chief adviser for economics on the Presidential Council of the U.S.S.R., told the annual Business Week symposium of chief executive officers Thursday that the Soviet economic system ``is really hard to call economics at all.'' ``It has become clear that the very basis of all our crises is the fact that we have a very inefficient economy,'' Shatalin said. ``This will be very painful because of the fact that we have lagged behind in this area for many decades, unfortunately.'' Some attending the conference were skeptical about the prospects for increased American business from any improvement. ``I don't think there is going to be an immediate payoff at all,'' Warren Bennis, professor of business administration at the University of Southern California and a member of the board of United Research, said in an interview. ``This has been a bureaucratization that has been going on for 70 years,'' Bennis said. ``It's verging on a hopeless situation there. Some American know how and some money may help, but I think it's going to be a much longer time than Eastern Europe.'' ``I don't see any immediate bottom line implications,'' Bennis added. Richard Ruch, chief executive officer and president of Herman Miller Inc., said, ``If you are asking me when Russia is really going to be a market of opportunity, that I'm not so sure of.'' ``I'm sure eventually it is going to happen,'' he said. ``But we hear statements that there is an awful lot of work that has to be done in the Soviet Union.'' ``I think it depends on what business you are in,'' Ruch said. ``If you are in a business that's got a product that they really need, now is the time to set up relationships and get going. ``But if your product is office furniture, like ours, which is always a deferrable, postponable type of purchase, maybe it's still a little bit too early to try to move in.'' ``But we are going to watch them very closely, because it could happen faster than we think,'' Ruch added. Richard Le Fauve, president of Saturn Corp., was guardedly hopeful about prospects for improvement in the Soviet economy. ``I think it depends on us,'' Le Fauve said. ``If we are willing to open up and share with the Russian leadership through letting them visit and learn on the job, so to speak, I think it could happen very soon. If we become conservative and try to teach through a lecturing process, I think it will take forever.'' Shatalin said, ``Without assistance from the West it will be very difficult to accomplish our reforms.'' The Soviet official spoke to an audience of about 200 American executives and their spouses at the National Museum of Women in the Arts.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 22,390.16, down 195.47 points or 0.87 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Kerrey Criticizes Tower's Campaign Tactics
DOC.TEXT: John Tower lied by suggesting that Sen. Jim Exon drinks too much, says a Senate colleague of Exon. ``Mr. Tower's behavior was larval,'' said U.S. Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb. ``His worm-like lies about one of our best citizens should leave little doubt why the Senate - reluctantly and with far more respect than was warranted - did not trust him with America's defenses.'' The Senate last year rejected Tower's nomination as secretary of defense. Tower was campaigning Thursday for Republican Hal Daub when he said that Nebraska Democrat Exon had a reputation for drinking too much. Tower admitted he had never seen Exon intoxicated and refused to name anyone who said they did. Tower's behavior ``also discredits Mr. Daub, who made no immediate attempt to criticize or correct Mr. Tower,'' Kerrey said.
DOC.HEAD: Williams Calls Richards A `Liar'
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial nominee Clayton Williams called Democrat Ann Richards a ``liar'' to her face during a campaign appearance and refused to shake hands. Appearing together before the Greater Dallas Crime Commission for an infrequent joint appearance Thursday, Williams walked over to Richards' side of the stage to greet supporters. When Richards extended her hand, Williams declined to shake it, saying, ``I'm here to call you a liar today.'' Richards responded, ``I'm sorry Clayton.'' Williams then added, ``That's what you are. You've lied about me; you've lied about Mark White and you've lied about Jim Mattox. I'm going to finish this deal today.'' Richards defeated White and Mattox in a bitter Democratic primary. Williams campaign spokesman Bill Kenyon said the Republican was upset that Richards was spreading ``unfounded rumors'' by trying to link Williams with a federal investigation into alleged drug money laundering. Richards had cited a newspaper report which said federal agents were investigating allegations against a Houston loan broker, Lloyd G. Williams Jr., who also has done business with ClayDesta National Bank, the Midland bank owned by the Republican nominee.
DOC.HEAD: GOP Chairman's Mass-Mailing Compares King to Vaudeville Cliche
DOC.TEXT: The state Republican chairman is sending out a mass mailing that compares Democrat Bruce King, an ex-governor on the gubernatorial comeback trail, to a vaudeville cliche. ``Yes, he's back,'' says the letter from John Lattauzio, ``like those tired, old vaudevillian jokes. But time has wrung the humor out of Bruce King as well.'' A King spokesman termed the letter ``beneath any possible comment,'' and Republican nominee Frank Bond disavowed it. The letter calls on the business community to step forth for Bond. At one point it asks businessmen to donate a week's salary to the Bond campaign.
DOC.HEAD: Senate Debate Moved To Washington
DOC.TEXT: The League of Women Voters decided to move Sunday's scheduled television debate between Sen. Rudy Boschwitz and challenger Paul Wellstone from Minnesota to Washington. Boschwitz, R-Minn., says he does not want to miss a Senate vote, and neither candidate's campaign staff could guarantee that Congress would not be in session this weekend, said Marcia Garton, the league's debate coordinator. ``Both of them were leading me to believe that the chance was slim for Sunday but not impossible,'' Garton said. ``Nobody can guarantee us 100 percent that nothing will be going on.'' Wellstone offered Wednesday to travel to Washington for the debate if Boschwitz feared he would miss a vote or Budget Committee meeting. The 1{-hour debate will be televised back to Minnesota by KMSP-TV from studios in the National Press Building.
DOC.HEAD: GOP Fund-Raising Group Agrees To Stop Promotion
DOC.TEXT: A nationwide Republican campaign funding organization has agreed to withdraw its effort to raise money in Idaho by offering people a $25 check, says state Attorney General Jim Jones. The Republican Presidential Task Force has agreed to contact the people and offer them refunds, said Jones. Earlier in the day, Idaho Democratic Chairman Conley Ward asked Jones to investigate whether the fund-raising tactic violates state consumer protection laws or criminal fraud statutes. Letters told the recipients they could cash the $25 checks at ``ABSOLUTELY NO COST TO YOU.'' In fact, however, cashing the check constituted permission for the Task Force to automatically withdraw $12.50 per month from the recipient's bank account until the recipient sent written notice to stop it, Democrats said. Jones said on Sept. 28, he contacted the organization requesting information on what they were doing, and officials agreed to stop it, although there was no admission that there was anything wrong. Jones said the group informed him they sent 7,000 letters to Idaho residents. The same letter went out nationwide, raising protests from Democrats in some states.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Who Fought Phone Company for 17 Years Left Out of Victory
DOC.TEXT: A woman bugged about paying toll charges just to talk to her daughter six miles away has won a 17-year battle to get the phone company to change its rate structure. But she won't fully share in the victory. Estelle Simon, 70, of rural Sudbury, can call her daughter's town of Marlboro for free, but Sudbury residents still will be charged for calling Lincoln, which shares a high school with Sudbury, because of how the system is wired. ``Can you believe this?'' Simon said in an interview this week. ``I blew my top.'' In fact, there will still be a charge to call the local crisis line six miles away in Acton. ``People who are about to commit suicide are not going to make a toll call,'' Simon scoffed. Simon decided to take on AT&T - then the largest corporation in the world - in 1973 when her daughter moved a toll call away to neighboring Marlboro. ``I realized there was a lot wrong with the telephone company,'' she said. Waging battle singlehandedly in rate hearings and regulatory proceedings before the state Department of Public Utilities, Simon argued that small-town residents were subsidizing the phone service of people in big cities. All paid the same $9 for basic service, but big-city dwellers could reach more phones for free. Until 1984, in fact, customers in 93 communities, including Sudbury, were even charged for calls within the same town. Thanks to Simon, New England Telephone Co. on Oct. 19 will eliminate toll charges for calls between neighboring exchanges and reduce rates for other in-state calls. The ruling affects more than 100 exchanges around the state. Public Utilities officials had said during the battle that Simon's case was so well documented that New England Telephone would probably be forced to overhaul its whole rate structure. ``It was very flattering but, at the same time, my heart sank,'' she said. ``Here we were fighting with the phone company to give relief to 4,200 phones, which is all we had in Sudbury. Now we were talking about thousands of phones and millions of dollars, and I knew they were going to fight that much harder.'' Under the new rates, a four-minute morning call from Brimfield to Williamstown in western Massachusetts on a weekday will fall from $1.11 to 23 cents. A four-minute call at the same time of day from Boston to New York costs 87 cents over AT&T. The phone company also eliminated the toll for calling Marlboro. Simon said she recently paid about $100 a month in calls to her daughter. But basic service went up $3, and dialing Lincoln will continue to cost extra in Sudbury, about 15 miles from downtown Boston. The day rate for calls to Lincoln will be 19 cents for the first minute and 9 cents a minute after that. That's because of the wiring configuration between the towns and billing problems, the phone company said, an argument used against Simon for 17 years. ``There are people who are saying, `Gee, I wish you could have included this town or that town.' But you can't get the approval of all of the people all of the time,'' said New England Telephone spokeswoman Roberta Clement. Simon said her battle with the phone company is over. ``I see no reason for me to go downtown and tell the whole story over again,'' she said. ``All they have to do is look at the case. They know I'm right.'' Before she stepped out of the ring, however, Simon forced New England Telephone to stop misleading advertisements that promised toll-free calls between all bordering communities. ``They do these things,'' said Simon. ``But nobody fights back.''

DOC.HEAD: Radical School Choice Measure on Oregon Ballot
DOC.TEXT: America's education establishment is watching an Oregon ballot measure that would let parents send their children to any school in the state. The so-called school choice proposal on the Nov. 6 ballot also would give parents a $2,500 tax credit for sending their children to private or church schools or teaching them at home. Oregon voters face 10 other measures, including two anti-abortion measures, a strict recycling measure, a proposed shutdown of the state's only nuclear plant, a seat belt law and a measure requiring welfare recipients to work. The school choice proposal is widely viewed as a watershed for American education. Vice President Dan Quayle stumped for it last month, sounding the Bush administration's theme that school choice is the path to better schools. ``It is time to shake up the educational system,'' Quayle said in Salem. ``We have competition in just about every other section of our society except for education in the kindergarten through 12th grade.'' Supporters of school choice say competition for students will force schools to do a better job or close. Foes attack the measure's constitutionality, arguing it would amount to providing public funds to aid religion. Teacher unions and others in the nation's public school establishment fear that their necks may be on the block if the measure passes and other states follow. A late September poll indicated the measure was trailing, although polls show strong support for another education initiative. That measure, defeated five times previously, would phase in a permanent limit on property tax rates by 1995. Among the other Oregon ballot contests: -Two anti-abortion proposals, one that would ban abortions except to save the woman's life or in cases of rape or incest, and a less drastic measure requiring a doctor to notify a parent when a minor seeks an abortion. Opponents of both measures have raised more than $550,000, including $89,000 from Planned Parenthood. Supporters reported spending about $80,000 as of Sept. 27. -Strict recycling standards on packaging sold by retailers. The American Paper Institute, Dow Chemical Co., Exxon Corp., Amoco Chemical Co. and Chevron Corp., among other companies and business groups, have raised more than $1.4 million to defeat it. Two committees backing the measure reported raising $293,000, mostly in small donations. -A measure to shut down the Trojan nuclear plant about 40 miles from Portland until certain conditions are met, including creation of a federal disposal site for radioactive waste. Portland General Electric Co., the owner, has spent $1.2 million battling the measure. Backers reported raising $45,000. A similar initiative was defeated in 1986 by 64 percent. Strong support for this year's version in earlier polls has eroded in a recent survey. -An initiative setting up a pilot program of government-financed jobs with businesses in lieu of welfare, unemployment or food stamps. Most workers would be paid 90 percent of the minimum wage. Savings from regular government assistance programs would pay the salaries. The initiative was put on the ballot mainly by the efforts of Jeld-Wen, a Klamath Falls wood products company. Jeld-Wen founder Dick Wendt calls the project the full employment program. Opponents say it actually will penalize laid-off employees who would earn less than unemployment benefits. -A proposal requiring seat belt use. Oregon now requires seat belt use only for people under 16. Voters in 1988 defeated a similar measure extending the law to all ages.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Shield Training Flights Resume After Grounding
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Air Force war planes participating in Operation Desert Shield are flying again after they were ordered grounded for 24 hours following a rash of crashes. Pentagon and Air Force officials said regular training flight schedules resumed Thursday at noon local time (5 a.m. EDT). The flights account for a majority of U.S. air missions in the Persian Gulf region. The Air Force ``has not changed anything'' in flight operations as a result of the suspension of flights, Capt. A.C. Roper, a spokesman for U.S. Central Command, said in Saudi Arabia. He said Air Force officials wanted to ``examine potential hazards and to be sure they were doing everything possible to prevent accidents. ``They have not identified any common cause or common contributing factors'' to the recent accidents, he added. At the Pentagon, spokesman Pete Williams said the number of U.S. aircraft accidents in the gulf - including three separate crashes this week - were not out of the ordinary. However, suspension of training flights indicated otherwise. Williams said the Air Force gave its pilots in the gulf ``safety awareness'' briefings during the flight ban in order ``to review what they need to do to fly more safely.'' Aircraft on operational missions were not grounded, said Col. Miguel Monteverde, another Pentagon spokesman. Those included reconnaissance aircraft, refueling tanker planes and F-15 jets patrolling areas near the Kuwait or Iraqi borders. He said pilots of those planes received special safety briefings but their flight schedules were not changed. ``So there was no degradation of our ability to defend ourselves,'' Monteverde said. Desert Shield, the largest U.S. military buildup since the Vietnam War, involves an estimated 700 Air Force combat and support aircraft. Williams said information about the number of flight hours in Desert Shield is classified and will not be disclosed. As a result, he said, he could not compare the accident rate with that of previous deployments. The toll for accidental deaths since Operation Desert Shield began rose to 31 on Wednesday when an Air Force F-111 fighter-bomber crashed on a training mission in Saudi Arabia, killing both crew members. On Monday, two pilots were killed in the crash of an Air Force F-4 Phantom reconnaissance jet in Saudi Arabia, and just hours earlier two Marine Corps UH-1 Huey helicopters, each carrying four crew members, crashed over the Arabian Sea, killing all eight men. Williams said the Air Force was the only service that has taken special measures to review safety in the gulf since this week's accidents. ``They're concerned about the accidents, they're concerned about the number of accidents that happened so quickly over a short period of time,'' he told reporters. He said, however, that the military's safety record in Desert Shield remained good. ``Given the amount of flying that has to be done, given the extraordinary circumstances and given the higher than ordinary operating tempo in the area, I think our service people are doing very well, but any accident is cause for concern,'' he said. Five U.S. aircraft have been involved in fatal crashes in the gulf area since the start of Desert Shield two months ago: an F-111, an F-4 Phantom reconnaissance jet, an F-15E and two Marine Corps UH-1 Huey helicopters. Also, a C-5 transport plane crashed in West Germany while ferrying equipment to Saudi Arabia. Also, 20 other aircraft have been involved in non-fatal accidents in the gulf area, Williams said. Fifteen of those were helicopters.

DOC.HEAD: Stasi Legacy Casts Shadow Across New Germany
DOC.TEXT: The Stasi secret police is officially defunct, but its shadow of fear still darkens the lives of Germans in their newly unified land. A rash of arrests of former East German spies has embarrassed people who ran West Germany's intelligence network and raised questions about their effectiveness. But the troubles don't stop there. Criminal justice officials fret over the legal complications of prosecuting former Stasi workers who will undoubtedly say they were only following orders, just as Nazi criminals did after World War II. Chancellor Helmut Kohl vows Stasi criminals will be prosecuted, but he warns against letting the Stasi legacy ``poison our nation's atmosphere. ``A suspect must be taken to court if facts warrant it,'' Kohl said in an interview with the Sueddeutsche Zeitung newspaper. He added, however, ``We must in no way open up a witch hunt, but protect our capacity for reconciliation.'' Lawmakers in former West Germany fear that Parliament, called the Bundestag, will be tainted by newcomers from East Germany who may have aided Stasi officers at home. ``It is important to clarify that no Stasi accomplices are among the former Volkskammer (East German Parliament) members now in the Bundestag, nor that they violated basic human rights,'' said Burkhard Hirsch, a lawmaker with the Free Democratic Party. During its existence, East Germany's Ministry for State Security was split into two sections: one for foreign espionage and one that ran a vast, feared network of repression, blackmail, coercion and surveillance at home. It is believed that a number of East Germans with political ambitions had links to the domestic section. Germans are also troubled by Stasi's past links with international terrorism. The Stasi's former leaders are believed to have helped some of the world's most notorious terrorists, including Abu Nidal and ``Carlos the Jackal.'' News reports say international terrorists may still be lurking on German soil. Revelations about the Stasi's malignant grip appear in German news media nearly every day, feeding a public preoccupation with the issue. People were shocked by news reports that Stasi agents may have killed a number of East German dissidents who fled to the West. The deaths were initially ruled accidents, but some of the cases are being reopened. In the old East Germany, people are incensed after hearing news reports that some of the same Stasi officers who spied on them now have jobs in law enforcement. ``There are signs that old Stasi networks have survived and are active in united Germany,'' Dankward Brinksmeier, former chairman of an East German parliamentary committee that investigated the secret police, told the news magazine Der Spiegel. When the occasional individual has admitted to former ties to Stasi, he has been turned into a pariah. One East German politician, Werner Meyer-Bodemann, says he received death threats after confessing last month that he was coerced into working as an informer for the Stasi. His political future is suddenly in doubt. A number of lawmakers from former West Germany want to create a special committee and empower it to look at Stasi files that would shed light on the pasts of Bundestag newcomers. But many former East Germans say not even the federal government should have the right to look at the Stasi files because they contain secrets obtained by spying on East Germans. The files also worry many former West Germans. The Stasi's 90,000 official employees and a force of perhaps more than 180,000 informers did not limit their snooping to East Germans. Visiting West German leaders, lawmakers, businessmen and tourists were the targets of Stasi workers. Germans are uncertain which former Stasi leaders they should prosecute. The long-time head of the Ministry for State Security, Erich Mielke, is under arrest on suspicion of helping members of the outlawed Red Army Faction terrorist gang, among other charges. Spies who gave away Western secrets to the East also face charges. The government plans an amnesty for East German spies who committed lesser offenses, but there's disagreement over who exactly should be covered. There's also uncertainty over who will be jailed from among the domestic secret police, who were responsible for everything from eavesdropping to beating up dissidents. Justice Ministry spokesman Juergen Schmid said former security officers who killed or injured other East Germans will be prosecuted. That includes border guards who killed about 180 East Germans who tried to flee to the West. But he said courts could face some daunting difficulties if suspects contend they were innocent because they were only following orders. The problem, he said, is that ``you have to decide to what extent someone can be blamed for carrying out the will of a politically repressive regime.''

DOC.HEAD: Philanthropy Donates $40 Million to Mark Reform Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: The MacArthur Foundation has pledged $40 million over the next decade to help Chicago schools - once called the worst in the nation - continue on their path to reform. Grants will be awarded to community organizations, individual schools and the school system itself, foundation president Adele Simmons said Thursday. The foundation, one of the nation's largest philanthropies, hopes to encourage communities to develop their own solutions to education problems, Simmons said in a statement. ``We do not believe that any single educational approach will work for every school and neighborhood,'' she said. The grant was announced on the one-year anniversary of the election of local councils to run Chicago's schools in a radical decentralization program. The 545 schools elected councils composed of six parents, two teachers and two community residents without schoolchildren. The councils were given broad powers, including authority to hire and fire principals and balance budgets. A few councils implemented sweeping changes, including year-round classes and school uniforms. In 1987, then-Education Secretary William Bennett called Chicago's schools the worst in the nation.

DOC.HEAD: Child Killed, Nine Injured in Apartment Complex Arson Fire
DOC.TEXT: A man torched an apartment complex with a flare gun after an argument over an $8 debt, killing a 15-month-ol girl, critically burning her parents and injuring seven others, police said. Rescue crews made their way through the rubble today in search of two teen-agers unaccounted for. Forty-eight people escaped unharmed. Bruce Wayne Campbell, a former tenant of the two-story, 24-unit La Villita complex, was jailed on $75,000 bail on charges of arson, police said. The fire apparently was started about 2 a.m. Thursday with a flare gun belonging to Campbell, a friend of a former manager of the gutted complex, police said. Two people, including a pregnant woman, jumped from a second-floor window to escape the fire, said Sally Muir, spokeswoman for the city Emergency Medical Service. The two were hospitalized, one in fair condition, the other in serious. One man said he threw rocks at windows to wake people up. Campbell, 30, was seen arguing with tenants over $8 he was owed, said homicide Detective Michael Huckabay. The fire began in a vacant apartment where Campbell once lived, police said. The body of a 15-month-old girl was found in the rubble. Her parents, Emmett Jackson, 34, and Diathia Reeder, 35, were listed in critical condition, authorities said. Five other people were either treated at hospitals and released or treated at the scene. Fire officials did not know whether the complex had fire and smoke alarms.

DOC.HEAD: Holy Sites at Center of Political Swirl
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to CORRECT spelling of es-Sharif, CORRECTS that Mohammed did not ascend to heaven on a stallion, ADDS background. Pickup 17th graf `The site...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JRL2,3
DOC.TEXT: Marchers at Haram es-Sharif carried a symbolic coffin draped with an outlawed Palestinian flag. Jews, who call the site Temple Mount, swayed in prayer at the Western Wall nearby. Again, the site revered by three religions is at the vortex of a political firestorm. Tens of thousands of Jews heeded the Israeli government call Thursday to come to the Western Wall, also known as the Wailing Wall, to dance at the end of the Sukkot holiday and to support Israel's control of the holy site. The area held holy by Jews, Christians and Moslems played host Thursday to political demonstrations after Monday's riot in which 19 Palestinians died from police gunfire. At the Church of the Holy Sepulchre, built where Christ is believed to have been buried, Palestinians mounted a sit-down strike. Women in traditional Palestinian black dresses decorated with embroidery sat in the courtyard of the church, while other Palestinians sat inside the white stone building. Earlier this year, the church was a focal point of Palestinian demonstrations over efforts by Jewish settlers to occupy a nearby hostel in the Christian Quarter. On Monday, the violence took place when Arabs at Haram es-Sharif began throwing stones down on Jews praying directly below at the Western Wall. Israeli police moved in tear gas, rubber bullets and live ammunition. By the time it was over, about 140 Arabs and 30 Jews were injured, in addition to the 19 Palestinians killed. On Thursday, Arab Christian clergymen walked from the 11th Century church to Haram es-Sharif, which is Arabic for ``noble enclosure.'' The clerics, who included Greek Catholic Patriarch Lutfi Laham and Anglican Bishop Samir Kafity, went for small cups of unsweetened Arabic coffee. They drank with Moslems in a traditional gesture of mourning. ``We came here to share with our brother Moslems their great grief, and we pray to God to grant this land peace and to preserve this Islamic shrine,'' said Bishop Basilus of the Coptic Church. The site generally draws its largest crowds for Moslem Friday prayers, and mosque preachers do not miss the opportunity to comment to the large audience on current events, whether the Persian Gulf crisis or the Israeli occupation. The reverence for the site by both Jews and Moslems was at the heart of the rioting that enveloped the area Monday. As Jews held their daily prayers at the Western Wall for the eight-day harvest festival of Sukkot, a rumor spread on the Temple Mount above that a group of Jewish zealots planned to march there. The group, called the Temple Mount Faithful, wants to build the so-called Third Temple on the site of the Jews' two ancient temples, the last destroyed by the Romans in 70 A.D. However, the site is now occupied by two 7th and 8th Century mosques - Al Aqsa and the Dome of the Rock. Moslems believe it to be the spot where the Prophet Mohammed ascended to heaven. The site is the holiest in Islam outside Saudi Arabia. The Western Wall, the remnant of the last ancient Jewish temple, is the most revered site to Jews. Both are in Jerusalem's Old City, which Israel captured from Jordan along with the West Bank in the 1967 Middle East war. Israel later annexed the area. As the Christian clergymen visited the Mount on Thursday, hundreds of Moslems marched for hours around the Dome of the Rock carrying a coffin covered by a black, white, green and red Palestinian flag. The chanted ``Allahu Akbar!'' - God is great - and ``We will redeem the martyrs!'' At the Wailing Wall, Jews were preparing for the festival of Simchat Torah, or ``Joy of the Torah,'' which ends the eight days of Sukkot. Jews celebrate the end of the Sukkot festival by dancing with biblical scrolls. Many carried guns. Hundred of riot police stood guard.

DOC.HEAD: `Little People' Defended by Manufacturer as Safe
DOC.TEXT: Officials of the company that makes ``Little People'' toys say they're puzzled that New York's attorney general has continued to attack the miniature figures as choking hazards to children. Carol Blackley, a spokeswoman for Fisher-Price, said Thursday she had thought the matter was closed after the company agreed in June to toughen its warning labels and pay $25,000 to New York state. But Attorney General Robert Abrams sent a letter Thursday to Consumer Product Safety Commission chairwoman Jacqueline Jones-Smith asking her to alert parents to the potential choking hazards of Little People. He also asked that CPSC increase the size of its small-parts standard for toys. ``While the commission continues to do no more than `review' the toy, children continue to die,'' Abrams wrote, citing the recent deaths of two 6-month-old boys who choked on Little People. But Blackley said the Little People package clearly states the toys are intended for children ages 2 to 6 and pose a choking hazard to any child who puts the things in his mouth. Fisher-Price, a division of Quaker Oats Co. in Chicago, has been making Little People for more than 30 years. In that time, five children are known to have choked to death on the figures, Blackley said. All but one of those children were below the recommended age range for the toy, she said.
DOC.HEAD: Company Recalling 850,000 Lawn Mower Fuel Tanks
DOC.TEXT: Briggs & Stratton, one of the nation's leading manufacturers of lawn mower engines, is recalling 850,000 fuel tanks sold since July 1, 1989, because they may leak gasoline. The engines, installed on more than 100 brands of walk-behind mowers, have the name ``Quantum Power'' on top, said the Consumer Product Safety Commission. Sears, Snapper and Toro produced some mowers using those engines without the name. CPSC said owners of those machines, purchased after July 1, 1989, should check the engine model number on a plate just above the spark plug. If the first two digits are 12, the fuel tank is subject to recall. If a tank leaks, the CPSC said, the owner should arrange for a replacement at 16,000 Briggs & Stratton dealers at no charge. If it is not leaking, owners are advised to make an appointment for a replacement.
DOC.HEAD: Bush To Visit Mexico, South America
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will visit Mexico next month and five South American countries in December, the White House announced. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Thursday that the president will visit Monterrey, Mexico, on Nov. 26-27 at the invitation of Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari. During the second trip, scheduled for Dec. 2-8, Bush will travel to Brazil, Uruguay, Argentina, Chile and Venezuela. It will be his second trip journey to South America as president. The president has scheduled an Oct. 27 meeting in Honolulu with leaders of 13 Pacific island states of Micronesia, Melanesia and Polynesia. The session with the Pacific island leaders will take place during a five-day political campaign swing that will also take Bush to New Mexico, Arizona, California and Oklahoma. The five-nation South American trip originally had been planned for mid-September, but was postponed because of the Persian Gulf crisis and domestic budget problems. Bush went to Colombia for a one-day drug summit with Latin leaders last Feb. 15.
DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Compromise on Cable Bill
DOC.TEXT: The two lawmakers blocking Senate action on a bill to re-regulate cable television have agreed to a compromise under which cable companies could continue programming deals that freeze out satellite dish owners. Sens. Al Gore, D-Tenn., and Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., reached the accord after the bill's manager, Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, last month declared it ``dead and buried'' for the year because of threats of a filibuster by Wirth and a veto by President Bush. Bush has not backed off his veto threat, but Gore and Wirth agreed Thursday on ``exclusivity'' contracts that would require the Federal Communications Commission to determine their use illegal if abused. Gore, who favored better access by satellite dish owners and other cable competitors like so-called ``wireless cable'' operators to the programming produced by the cable industry, said he hoped the bill could be brought to the Senate floor early next week. ``To those who would continue to block its consideration on behalf of the cable industry or the White House, I would only say that such a move would backfire,'' he said, threatening to introduce a tougher bill on the industry next year. Both the Senate bill and a similar measure passed by the House last month would require cable operators to provide a ``basic tier'' of cable service - local and public TV stations plus government-access channels - at rates regulated by the FCC. The legislation is a response to a growing wave of consumer complaints about excessive rates and poor service in many areas after the industry was deregulated by Congress in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Thrusters Fire on Ulysses as NASA Prepares Shuttle for Trip to Florida
DOC.TEXT: The Ulysses solar explorer fired its thrusters and zoomed farther from Earth, while the shuttle that launched the spacecraft was readied for next week's piggyback jet ride home to Florida. NASA, meanwhile, formed a team to investigate why the shuttle Discovery lifted off Saturday with incorrect instructions for how it should operate some of its computer programs. Ulysses' two-day series of thruster firings were to end this afternoon. The maneuver was designed to turn Ulysses so its main antenna dish pointed toward Earth, allowing faster communication with controllers. The $250 million spacecraft, which will explore the sun's polar regions in 1994-95, is the centerpiece of a $750 million joint mission by NASA and the European Space Agency. Since it was launched from Discovery on Saturday, Ulysses has been communicating with its controllers through one of its smaller antennas. Discovery landed Wednesday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Maintenance crews found Discovery in excellent condition after its 1.7-million-mile, four-day flight, said shuttle processing manager Tip Talone. He said only 10 to 15 of Discovery's heat-shield tiles need to be replaced. Debris that hit the shuttle during its launch and landing caused 13 ``dings'' larger than one inch, and about 50 smaller ones. ``That's a very low number,'' Talone said. ``Every time we come back, we seem to learn more about how to fly and land the thing without taking a lot of hits.'' Talone said Discovery should be ready for a one-day flight back to its Cape Canaveral, Fla., launch site on Monday, riding piggyback on a modified jumbo jet. Shuttle project engineer Chris Fairey said Thursday that the incorrect instructions were loaded into one of Discovery's computers Oct. 4. The investigators will recommend steps to prevent such an error from happening again, he added. The incorrect instructions were noticed and fixed by Discovery's five astronauts about an hour after the shuttle was launched. They never posed a danger to the shuttle or its crew - even if the error hadn't been detected, said Milt Heflin, lead flight director at Johnson Space Center in Houston. Heflin said NASA considered the problem serious because it went undetected before Discovery was launched. Fairey called it ``really minor'' but said it ``did point out a minor deficiency in the way we code our software.'' Ulysses was 3.68 million miles from Earth on Thursday, zipping toward a 1992 flight past Jupiter at 25,372 mph, said Franklin O'Donnell, a spokesman at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Ulysses will use Jupiter's gravity to sling it into orbit around the sun.

DOC.HEAD: Hey Anatoly! The Computer Says You Blew It!
DOC.TEXT: It's bad enough that Anatoly Karpov had to settle for a draw in his first game against world chess champion Garry Kasparov. Now comes the news - from a computer, no less - that he could have won, easily. Chess-playing machine Deep Thought offered an electronic second-guess Thursday, asserting Karpov could have brought Kasparov to his knees with a pawn move. The pair instead battled to a draw in the first game. Kasparov came back to win the second game of the best-of-24-game World Chess Championship. The $1 million match was to continue today. ``Sometimes a machine can see things a human misses,'' said Murray Campbell, one of Deep Thought's developers who works for IBM. ``There would have been a very good chance for Karpov to win, although it's not guaranteed.'' Word of the Deep Thought second-guess filtered in to both players, Campbell said. The word back to Campbell and co-developer Feng-Hsiung Hsu was that Kasparov was already aware of his gaffe, while Karpov was not. USA Today reported that Karpov subsequently acknowledged the supercomputer was right. Karpov's manager was not available for comment Thursday on Deep Thought's thoughts. The computer can consider 1 million moves in a second. Campbell and Hsu were two of five graduate students who developed the chess-playing computer at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh. Deep Thought went on to become the first computer to defeat a chess grandmaster. Kasparov and Karpov have defeated Deep Thought in head-to-head competition. Campbell acknowledged his computer would be overmatched if the champion performed the way he did in game two Wednesday against Karpov. ``Kasparov played very well, better than the machine can play at this point,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Authorities Say Hunters Paid to Kill Captive Bears, Cougars
DOC.TEXT: Hunters paid up to $4,000 to kill bears and cougars raised in captivity during shooting sprees at a game preserve, authorities say. ``This wasn't hunting. It was target practice,'' said Herb Hill, the range manager who reported the hunts. More than two dozen agents raided the 160-acre Texoma Hunting Wilderness on Wednesday. ``Dealing with animals, this is the worst thing I've ever dealt with,'' Sam Cottrell, a state game ranger for 24 years, said Thursday. ``You can't even call it a hunt.'' Agents were to meet today to decide whether to take action against those involved in the alleged hunts. The hunting range bought grizzly bears, black bears, cougars and elk from zoos, preserves and at auctions, Cottrell said. Hunters paid $1,000 to $4,000 to hunt the animals, he said. Grizzly bears are protected under federal law as an endangered species, and the black bear, cougar and elk are protected under state law. Hill said hunters stalked the animals in a fenced area the size of a football field. ``Of course, here are animals - big cats, bears, what have you - that have been raised in captivity, fed every day and watered,'' Hill said. ``It was like shooting fish in a barrel.'' Hill said at least 300 people paid to shoot the animals. He said he notified state agents about the operation two years ago and stayed on in hopes of getting it changed or closed. Authorities said the range operated for nearly five years. Officials said the hunting range is owned by Charles B. Bartholomew of Norman. The investigation was conducted by the state Department of Wildlife and the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. ``We found one receipt for a grizzly bear that was killed,'' Cottrell said. ``They had eight live mountain lions, three (live) black bears, and several elk and deer in deep freezes for taxidermy work.''

DOC.HEAD: Poll Finds 60 Percent Disaprove of Congress' Performance
With PM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: With the November election less than four weeks away, Americans are dissatisfied with Congress in general but more favorably disposed toward their own representatives, according to a New York Times-CBS News poll. Sixty percent of those polled said they disapprove of the way Congress is doing its job, with 27 percent saying they approve, the Times reported today. The approval rating was down sharply from January, when 42 percent said they approved of Congress' job performance. Asked whether most members of Congress ``are more interested in serving the people they represent, or more interested in serving special interest groups,'' 71 percent said special interest groups and 20 percent said the people. The respondents appeared to be less critical of their own representatives than of the rest of Congress. Forty-four percent said their representative deserves re-election, while 40 percent say they would prefer somebody new. Asked about Congress in general, 67 percent said it is time ``to give new people a chance,'' and 20 percent said most members deserve re-election. The results are based on a telephone survey of 960 adults between Monday and Wednesday. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Anatole Broyard, New York Times Book Critic, Dead at 70
DOC.TEXT: Anatole Broyard, a literary critic and former editor of The New York Times Book Review, has died. He was 70. Broyard, who lived in Cambridge, Mass., and died of prostate cancer Thursday at the Dana Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, was a daily book critic for nearly 15 years before serving three years as an editor of the book review. After retiring in 1989, he continued to write a monthly essay, ``About Books,'' in the book review, and compiled for the book review a weekly, unsigned column of excerpts from books, ``Noted With Pleasure.'' Broyard was born in New Orleans. He studied at Brooklyn College and the New School For Social Research. He wrote two books, ``Aroused by Books'' and ``Men, Women and Other Anticlimaxes.'' He taught creative writing at Columbia University, the New School for Social Research and New York University. Survivors include his wife, Alexandra, a son, a daughter and two sisters. Funeral arrangements were not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: `20-20' Producer Resigns Over Bogus Buckwheat Interview
DOC.TEXT: A producer responsible for an interview with a Buckwheat impostor on ABC's ``20-20'' has resigned, the network says. Lynn Murray resigned in a ``mutual decision'' with ABC after last week's segment ``Whatever Happened to `Our Gang?''' said ``20-20'' spokeswoman Maurie Perl. The news magazine aired an interview with a man who claimed he played Buckwheat in the ``Our Gang'' comedies of the 1930s and '40s and was now working as a grocery bagger in Tempe, Ariz. William Thomas, who actually portrayed Buckwheat, died in 1980. Victor Neufeld, the program's executive producer, decided Murray did not properly handle research for the segment, Perl said Thursday. Murray had worked with ``20-20'' in several capacities for 10 years, Perl said. ``20-20'' anchorman Hugh Downs will apologize during tonight's broadcast ``for any pain and discomfort'' the error might have caused Thomas' family, Perl said. Thomas' son, William Thomas Jr., and George McFarland, who played Spanky in the ``Our Gang'' comedies, challenged last week's broadcast. ABC later acknowledged the bogus Buckwheat, Bill English, had pulled a hoax. English had told ``20-20'' during the interview that he had changed his name so he could work at the supermarket without being recognized. Perl said the interview was suggested by a viewer and that English apparently has told people for the past 30 years that he played Buckwheat. The ``Our Gang'' episodes were renamed ``The Little Rascals'' for television.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Stop Performance of Play
DOC.TEXT: A judge has refused the Roman Catholic Church's request to shut down a play it considers blasphemous in a building it owns. ``I'm not a censor and I'm not going to engage in any act of censorship,'' state Supreme Court Justice Irma Vidal Santaella said Thursday in refusing to stop performances of the RAPP theater company's ``The Cardinal Detoxes.'' The play, by Thomas Disch, is a 35-minute monologue delivered by a cardinal who has fatally struck a pregnant woman while driving drunk. Santaella ruled last week that the church had a right to start eviction proceedings against RAPP, which was staging the play in a former parochial school. The judge found that RAPP had violated the part of its lease that allow the landlord - the church - to determine what activities by the theater group are ``detrimental to the reputation'' of the landlord. But the judge said RAPP had a First Amendment right to perform the play in the meantime. The activist lawyer William Kunstler, representing RAPP, said the church was bringing the case ``in the wrong country and in the wrong century.'' In the play, the cardinal calls the church a sham and tries to blackmail other Catholic officials into getting him off the hook by bribing a judge. After he threatens to expose the church's problems if they don't help him, a monk gives him poisoned wine. The church's lawyer, Frank McLaughlin, said, ``The church has been injured, your honor, injured by the blasphemy in the play, injured by the mockery.''

DOC.HEAD: Military Buildup Jolts Saudi Economy
With PM-Gulf-Embassies
DOC.TEXT: The U.S.-led military buildup in Saudi Arabia has local businessmen scrambling for contracts to sell everything from tomatoes to tents. ``The economy here is really, really percolating,'' said Gene Heck, commercial attache at the U.S. Embassy in Riyadh. Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait has thrown most regional economies into disarray, causing big cash flights and paralyzing stock markets. However, in Saudi Arabia, the military deployment countering Iraq has opened a rich field for entrepreneurs. Most are in the kingdom already. Others from the United States and around the world hope to use the military presence to enter the Saudi market for the first time. Heck's job is to help businesses channel their ideas to decision-makers in the military. ``One of the messages we need to get across is that this is just as stable an economy as it was before Aug. 2,'' he said. ``The opportunities are even greater.'' Heck peers over thick glasses at a stack of yellow message slips and rattles off the names of companies who want to do business in Saudi Arabia. He estimates 15-20 firms contact him every day. ``There's a company in Indianopolis that wants to sell mobile field kitchens that prepare 15,000 meals in 24 hours,'' he said. ``They've got retired generals on their board - that usually helps.'' Other business propositions are not quite so well thought out. ``I've got a guy in Jiddah who has 7,000 videotapes that the (Saudi police) won't let him sell, so he wants to sell them to the troops,'' said Heck. Press reports say the foreign military presence in the kingdom is likely to generate about $5 billion in sales from the private sector directly to the military. Everyone seems to want a piece of the action. Omanis want to sell spices to the troops. Thais are hawking fruit juice, and the Dutch and Danish have dairy products. They're all calling Heck, who carries a foot-high stack of catalogues to military procurement people two or three times a week. Col. John Downey, chief of the military contracting office in Riyadh, said he answers 10 to 15 calls a day. He gives callers the numbers of procurement officers in Army, Navy, Air Force, and Marines. All do separate purchasing. ``There are awful lot of people running around looking for opportunities,'' said Keith Poulin, president of Dalil International Development Corp., a business development firm. ``I deal with a large agriculture development company, and the guy there starts talking to me about gas masks. I said `What's this got to do with lettuce and tomatoes?' People jump into new businesses whenever they see an opportunity.'' Poulin said gas masks top the list of items companies are trying to sell to the military. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein has vowed to use chemical weapons if his country is attacked. Poulin also noted that his company received many calls from Saudis willing to sponsor companies who want to do business with the military. Under Saudi commercial law, all foreign companies must have a local sponsor. ``We've had a lot of calls from Saudi firms wanting to identify Canadian sources of goods that are obviously going to be sold to the military,'' said Ron Bollman, Canadian commercial counselor. ``Most of our exporters are looking at protective clothing, electronics and telecommunications.'' Some businessmen, however, feel that there is a dearth of information on the military procurement process. Leo Kelleher, manager of projects for Economic Bureau, a 100 percent Saudi-owned consulting firm, said his company has submitted three proposals to the military three weeks ago ``and we've been going in circles every since.'' Downey conceded that unsolicited proposals to the military may await four to six weeks for a response. ``It's a lengthy process to get it through the loop,'' he said. ``We may not have all the expertise to evaluate it here.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Orders `Gay Flag' Removed From Capitol
DOC.TEXT: Gov. George Deukmejian ordered a ``gay flag'' removed from the state Capitol, saying the banner had been mistakenly hoisted. The rainbow-colored banner with Greek symbols flew next to the Stars and Stripes and California state flag for about three hours Thursday. ``Flags are not to be flown over the Capitol that represent any kind of special-interest group, lifestyle or issue,'' said Susan Trowbridge, the governor's spokeswoman. The Legislature's Joint Rules Committee staff, which governs housekeeping and maintenance in the Capitol, had approved the flag to mark a national ``coming out'' day for homosexuals on Thursday. Assemblyman Terry Friedman, a Democrat, said the Republican governor's decision showed his ``long-standing dislike for gay men and women.'' Flags commemorating Earth Day, prisoners of war, Black History Week and other causes have routinely flown over the Capitol, said Bob Forsyth, a spokesman for David Roberti, Democratic leader of the state Senate.

DOC.HEAD: Most of Nation's 1990 Blood Pressure Goals Met, CDC Says
DOC.TEXT: Americans failed to achieve at least one important goal in a 10-year drive by the government to reduce high blood pressure: losing weight. The national Centers for Disease Control reported Thursday that at least seven of the nine health objectives related to high blood pressure were met, including a nationwide reduction in the prevalence of hypertension. The goal set a decade ago was for at least 60 percent of the population with high blood pressure to have it under control; a recent survey suggests a level of 65 percent, the CDC said. But one important goal was missed: reducing the overweight population to fewer than 10 percent of American men and fewer than 17 percent of women. A 1988 federal survey found 27 percent of men and 26 percent of women were overweight - defined as more than 20 percent above their desired weight. Being overweight increases the risk of high blood pressure, which is a cause of heart disease and stroke. ``Improvements in blood pressure control ... have contributed to a 50 percent decrease in stroke and a 35 percent decrease in coronary heart disease since 1972,'' the CDC said. But there is work to be done, the agency said: ``Despite this progress, 30 million persons in the United States still have inadequately controlled blood pressure.'' In 1979, when the Health and Human Services Department prepared its 1990 health goals, high blood pressure was defined as a reading of 160-95 or higher. The CDC objective was to have at least 60 percent of those with hypertension in control of their blod pressure, and that goal has most likely been met, the agency said. High blood pressure is usually controlled with medication. Comprehensive studies are not yet complete, the CDC said. In 1984, U.S. health officials revised their standard for high blood pressure to a reading of 140-90, and progress toward that measurement is less certain. Other 1990 blood-pressure goals that have been met, according to the CDC, include: -More than half of U.S. adults should know the principal risk factors for heart disease and stroke: high blood pressure, smoking, high cholesterol and diabetes. -More than 90 percent of adults should be able to say whether they have high blood pressure. -At least half of processed food in grocery stores should be labeled with sodium and caloric content. Progress isn't known toward one of the goals: reducing the average daily salt intake to less than 6 grams. No studies have been done to provide such data, the CDC said.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gunfire Kills Parliament Speaker, Two Others, Official Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with official confirming speaker, two others killed. ADDS details, byline. Pickup 6th graf `The shooting...'
DOC.TEXT: Gunfire today killed Egypt's parliament speaker and two other people outside a downtown Cairo hotel, police said. A police lieutenant said Rifaat el-Mahgoub, 64, speaker of the People's Assembly, and two security men were slain. The officer refused to be quoted by name. There was no immediate claim of responsibility and further details on the number of attackers or other casualties were unavailable. The shooting came after the interior minister warned of possible terrorist reprisals for Egypt's stand against Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis. The incident occurred near the Nile River a block from the U.S. Embassy. Its doors were sealed immediately, and an embassy diplomat had to enter through a nearby garage. An hour after the shooting, a black Mercedes sat outside the Semiramis, its rear window and right front window smashed. A dead body lay in the front seat, the head torn apart by gunfire. A blue Peugeot was stopped about 200 yards away, a man's body hanging onto the roadway from the rear seat. It was unclear whether that car was involved in the shooting or was passing when the gunfire occurred. All streets were blocked around the 28-story hotel, one of the newest and poshest in Cairo. Police at the scene said little, but a bystander who said he saw the attack reported that an unknown number of assailants fled on motorbikes. At the Interior Ministry, responsible for Egypt's domestic security, Col. Sayed Rashad said he knew nothing more than that a black Mercedes had been attacked. He said Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa was at the scene. Moussa, whose ministry handles internal security, said Thursday that Arabs angered over President Hosni Mubarak's anti-Iraq position were threatening Egypt with sabotage and assassination. The shooting came as early results showed Egyptians participating in a national referendum Thursday overwhelmingly voted to give Mubarak a mandate to dissolve Parliament. Under the constitution, the affirmative vote will allow Mubarak to disband the assembly, declared illegal by the constitutional court, and call new elections within two months.

Hurricane Lili lashed the North Carolina coast with gale-force winds today, while rain drenched much of the South. Sunny skies and summery weather were expected throughout the West and Midwest. A hurricane watch was posted for the North Carolina coast and flash-flood watches were in effect in Tennessee and West Virginia. Widely scattered showers and thunderstorms were forecast all along the East Coast, as far north as Maine. Coastal flood advisories were in effect in Delaware, Maryland and Virginia. Showers were also forecast for the north-central region and parts of Washington state. Throughout most of the rest of the country, skies were clear and warm weather was predicted. Highs in the 80s were forecast throughout the Midwest, Southwest and West, with highs in the 90s anticipated in the Southwestern desert. Highs in 80s were expected along most of the Eastern Seaboard, with highs in the 50s and 60s in the Great Lakes area and in the 60s in the Pacific Northwest. The high for the nation Thursday was 98 degrees at Borrego Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Mistrial Declared After Juror's Outburst at Victim's Father
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT name to Stewart sted Hawkins.
DOC.TEXT: A mistrial was declared for a defendant in the Bensonhurst racial slaying after a juror screamed at the victim's father, accusing him of staring at her. The courtroom outburst Thursday by Lydia Bermudez came on the second day of deliberations in the case against Charles Stressler. ``What are you looking at?'' Ms. Bermudez yelled at Moses Stewart, the father of slaying victim Yusuf Hawkins. ``You've been doing that to me every day. You know what I'm talking about. You've been doing it every ... day.'' Ms. Bermudez was dismissed. Justice Thaddeus Owens, who had already sent the alternate jurors home, decided deliberations could not continue without 12 jurors, and he declared a mistrial. Stressler, 22, is accused of murder and other crimes in the 1989 slaying of Hawkins, a 16-year-old black shot through the chest when he and three friends crossed paths with a mob of whites in Brooklyn's Bensonhurst section. Stressler will go on trial again Jan. 17. Of those charged in the attack, one has been convicted of murder and two of lesser charges. Four still face murder trials. With the jurors watching Thursday, Stewart stood up and walked toward the door, mumbling angrily: ``If she can't stand the father of the victim looking at her, get her ... out of here. I look at everybody on the jury. I don't care who she is.'' Ms. Bermudez told the judge that she felt intimidated by Stewart. ``I don't need this aggravation from this freaking low-life,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: More Embassies Close in Kuwait, Holdouts Dwindle
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Germany announcing its diplomats have left Kuwait; pickup graf 4 `The Dutch...'
DOC.TEXT: Belgium and Germany today announced they have pulled all their diplomats from Kuwait as Iraqi President Saddam Hussein starves out the last envoys from encircled missions in the conquered emirate. The campaign is a key part of his effort to turn Kuwait into the 19th province of Iraq. In Bonn, Germany, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said the last diplomats in the German embassy drove from Kuwait to Baghdad on Thursday. ZDF television, a German station, said the group included the ambassador and his wife, along with three embassy staff members. The Foreign Ministry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the embassy was vacated because of exhausted food supplies. In their announcement in Brussels, Belgian officials said their remaining two diplomats had also left for Baghdad on Thursday. The Dutch, Italian and Polish embassies, among the compounds besieged exactly seven weeks ago today, have also withdrawn the last of their diplomats from Kuwait City in the past week. That leaves the Americans, British, Canadians and French as the only holdouts among Western missions. Few other nations appear to be staffing their embassies with diplomats. The remaining diplomats were surviving mainly on canned food and occasional loaves of bread carried in by local staff. But they were surrounded by Iraqi troops enforcing a blockade of supplies. In most cases, water and electricity have been cut off. The holdouts are not expected to last long. The ambassadorial standoff reflects the international confrontation of the Persian Gulf in microcosm. Saddam's forces have been locked in a war of nerves and attrition with representatives of many of the countries that have sent troops and equipment to counter the Iraqi president. After Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and annexed the neighboring oil emirate, it ordered all embassies in the emirate to shut down by Aug. 24 and began surrounding holdouts that day. Iraqi authorities said foreign countries would be represented in Baghdad, Iraq's capital. The embassy staffs in Kuwait would lose their diplomatic status and privileges. Initially, dozens of embassies balked, refusing to recognize Iraq's annexation of Kuwait and desperate to help their stranded nationals. However, as the Iraqi siege set in, the remaining diplomats have trickled out. They have said the departures are temporary, and some of them have annnounced that the embassies remain technically open. But it's only a technicality. At the U.S. Embassy, 10 diplomats - and an unknown number of American citizens who took refuge - are eking out a living from canned goods and perishables stored there before Iraqi tanks rolled into Kuwait City. Life at the embassy is ``kind of hot, stuffy and boring,'' a U.S. official in Washington said Wednesday. U.S. diplomats ``are still there because we don't recognize the annexation, we will not recognize an order based on annexation, and we want to help American citizens.'' About 600 Americans are stuck in Kuwait, many in hiding and several reported to be desperately ill. Living conditions at the U.S. embassy are wretched. Power and water have been severed for more than a month, forcing the Americans to forgo baths and boil water from the swimming pool to drink. Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howell, deputy ambassador Barbara Bodine and the other Americans are using outside latrines. They sometimes sleep outdoors at night to keep cool, despite swarms of mosquitoes. Telephone conversations are deliberately brief, under the assumption that the Iraqis have tapped phone lines seeking information on the whereabouts of Americans or Kuwaitis who are harboring them. At the British Embassy, the two remaining diplomats are eating cans of tuna and wieners, as well as vegetables from an embassy garden. They are also brewing their own beer, according to two other embassy staffers sent to Baghdad to stretch out the dwindling supplies in Kuwait for the two remaining. ``Conditions are becoming harsh,'' French Foreign Ministry spokesman Daniel Bernard said Monday. But Charge d'Affaires Jean-Pierre Galtier and his remaining staff ``will stay firmly at their post,'' he said. Life has been no picnic even for those who leave. Iraqi authorities have allowed them to travel to Baghdad but forced them to remain.

DOC.HEAD: 10 Embassies Say They're Still Open in Kuwait
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with Belgium, Germany removing diplomats; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Embassies, Bjt

The following embassies have refused the Iraqi order to close: Bahrain, Britain, Canada, France, Indonesia, Luxembourg, Oman, Senegal, United Arab Emirates, United States. (It is not clear if all of these are staffed by diplomats.) ---

The following nations have either closed their embassies or suspended operations, saying they still do not recognize the annexation of Kuwait: Austria, Bangladesh, Belgium, China, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Egypt, Finland, Germany, Greece, Hungary, India, Italy, Japan, Jordan, Lebanon, Morocco, Netherlands, Niger, Nigeria, Norway, Philippines, Poland, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, South Korea, Soviet Union, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Syria, Taiwan, Thailand, Turkey, Venezuela and Yugoslavia. ---
Pakistan closed its embassy Sept. 4, but the staff remained inside.

DOC.HEAD: Despite Coup Threats, Philippines' Internal Squabbles Grow Worse
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Following this nation's latest revolt last week in the south, a series of political battles has broken out which dramatize the divisions undermining President Corazon Aquino's government. The disputes serve as an example of the political infighting which has hampered the administration's effectiveness in dealing with the nation's problems and reduced public faith in government. The seventh military rebellion against Mrs. Aquino ended last Saturday when renegade Col. Alexander Noble surrendered after seizing two military garrisons and proclaiming independence for the second largest island, Mindanao. Military Chief of Staff Gen. Renato de Villa said after the mutiny that the key to ending the threat of coups was ``better government . . . united to move as one.'' Recent events show little sign of such unity. Noble surrendered to Sen. Aquilino Pimentel, one of the senior military and civilian officials who rushed to Cagayan de Oro on Mindanao to confront the rebellion. No sooner had he returned to Manila than Pimentel accused the senior Cabinet member on the scene, Local Government Secretary Luis Santos, of drinking heavily in Cagayan de Oro instead of helping solve the crisis. Several newspapers also reported hat Santos and his entourage nearly provoked a shootout among government forces by staging a publicity stunt - hauling down an independent Mindanao flag from the camp flagpole and hoisting the Philippine flag. Col. Plaridel Obrique, deputy commander of the 4th Infantry Division, protested that Santos and others from Manila were trying to get the glory for ``recapturing'' the camp when in fact Noble gave up without a fight. The flag-raising idea, reportedly planned for the benefit of photographers, was scrapped after Obrique's troops threatened violence, the papers said. Santos spokesman Antonio Ortiz said Wednesday that Santos ``has no time to answer'' allegations against him. Mrs. Aquino asked for an explanation of the charges but none was offered. Her own spokesman, Tomas Gomez, meanwhile provoked a war of words with Vice President Salvador Laurel by claiming that Laurel supporters signed a $900,000 contract with a U.S. public relations firm to smear the Aquino administration in the United States. ``Where did the money come from?'' Gomez asked. ``Did it come from Imelda (Marcos)? Did it come from ultrarightists who belong to the Republican government (in Washington)? Or did it come from ex-CIA sources?'' Laurel broke with Mrs. Aquino in 1987 and resigned as foreign secretary although he kept his elected post as vice president. Mrs. Aquino has frequently accused Laurel of failing to stand up for democracy in times of crisis. Laurel's office denied the smear campaign allegation and countered by releasing the names of 16 American public relations firms hired by the Aquino administration. ``Now that Gomez has opened this can of worms, he should detail to the public how many precious dollars have been spent while the country grovels under heavy external debt and piecemeal existence,'' Laurel spokesman Ike Gutierrez said. Gomez said the 16 firms were hired to lobby for greater purchases of Philippine coconut and sugar products.

DOC.HEAD: Animal Shelter Pays $425,000 in Fatal Attack by `Pet of the Week'
DOC.TEXT: Sharon Carpenter says a $425,000 settlement from an animal shelter has not erased the memory of seeing her 4-year-old son fatally mauled by a wolf-dog hybrid. ``It put an end to the financial part of it, but it's something we have to live with for the rest of our lives, so it never really ends,'' Mrs. Carpenter said Wednesday. The animal killed Nathan Carpenter on Sept. 23, 1988, two hours after a neighbor adopted it from the Panhandle Animal Welfare Society based here. The wolf-husky mixed breed was advertised as ``pet of the week.'' The adoption violated the shelter's policy against placing wolf breeds, said Donna Olson, the agency's executive director. But a PAWS lawyer said the settlement reached last Friday does not mean the shelter admits liability. Mrs. Carpenter said she did not recognize the dog when she saw it running loose near her home in nearby Wynnhaven. When it entered her yard and lay down 50 feet from her son, she went inside to call the phone number on the dog's tag. ``I looked out the window and saw him ataack Nathan,'' Mrs. Carpenter said. ``I ran outside and pushed the dog off my son.'' An off-duty Okaloosa County sheriff's deputy shot the animal.

DOC.HEAD: State Recalls Imitation `Slap Bracelets' After Girl's Injury
DOC.TEXT: The state has ordered cheap imitations of the Slap Wrap removed from shelves after a 4-year-old cut herself on one of the bracelets. The Department of Consumer Protection ordered the recall Thursday of foreign-made versions of the Connecticut-made Slap Wrap after several imitations failed safety tests. When the 9-inch strip of metal is slapped against the wrist, it wraps itself around the wearer's arm. The department tested three versions of the steel bracelets encased in cloth for exposed sharp edges, which are prohibited on most toys under the state's Child Protection Act. Only the original Slap Wrap made by Simsbury-based Main Street Toy passed, said Lois Bryant, director of the department's product safety division. The bracelets that failed the test were imitations, some of them labeled ``Made in Taiwan'' and some not labeled at all, Bryant said. Illinois-based Walgreen Co. said Thursday it had ordered its drug stores nationwide to remove ``slap bracelets'' from their shelves while the safety of the fad jewelry is being investigated. Nicole Tomaso cut her finger Tuesday by a piece of metal protruding from the bracelet she bought at a Walgreens drugstore, her father, Joseph Tomaso, said. When the 9-inch strip of metal is slapped against the wrist, it wraps itself around the wearer's arm. The bracelet that caused the injury was a copy of Slap Wraps, which sell for $2.49. The imitations cost less, usually 99 cents. Main Street Toy maintains its bracelets, made with stainless steel, are safe, and says imitations are made from cheaper steel that will rust and break. Elementary school officials in Pelham, N.Y., have banned the wraps because of concerns about children cutting themselves.

DOC.HEAD: Brando Plea Bargain Talks Break Off, Murder Trial Set Nov. 5
DOC.TEXT: Attempts to reach a plea bargain for Marlon Brando's son broke down, and a judge set Christian Brando's murder trial for Nov. 5. ``Nobody's talking settlement now,'' Deputy District Attorney William Clark said after a brief hearing Thursday. Clark said that last week Christian Brando's lawyer and prosecutors discussed a possible plea bargain after it became apparent Brando's sister, Cheyenne, was unlikely to testify in the case. Clark said defense lawyer Robert Shapiro's proposals were not accepted. But Shapiro told reporters the defense remains open to negotiations. The 32-year-old Brando is charged in the May 16 murder of his half-sister's Tahitian lover, Dag Drollet, who was fatally shot at Marlon Brando's hilltop mansion. In early statements to police, the young Brando said he didn't mean to kill the 26-year-old Drollet and suggested they were struggling over a gun that accidentally fired. Prosecutors maintain the shooting was intentional and that Brando was spurred into a rage by his sister, who said Drollet had beaten her. Superior Court Judge Robert Thomas said jury selection in the trial would begin Nov. 5. He noted he has received large amounts of mail indicating strong public sentiment in the case. ``If the mail is any indication, there's some very strong feelings about the matter both ways,'' he said, adding he expects a difficult search for jurors unaffected by publicity. Meanwhile, Clark said he was negotiating with French authorities to allow Cheyenne Brando's return to the United States to testify. She is being held in Tahiti on a charge of accessory to the murder. Miss Brando went to Tahiti in June to have the baby Drollet fathered. She was later hospitalized with emotional problems, according to her father, Marlon Brando. Clark said Marlon Brando will testify in his son's trial but he was uncertain whether he would be a prosecution or defense witness.

DOC.HEAD: Rare Asian Elephant Birth at Lincoln Park Zoo
DOC.TEXT: After a long 22-month pregnancy and a short five-hour labor, Bozie, a 15-year-old Asian elephant, has given birth at Lincoln Park Zoo, officials said. ``So far, the mother and baby are doing just fine, and are getting to know one another,'' said zoo Director Lester Fisher. He said the zoo staff believes the calf born Thursday is a female, but they will not know for sure for at least a day. Bozie had no apparent difficulty in the delivery, officials said. She was mated 22 months ago in Springfield, Mo., with Onyx, a 25-year-old bull elephant in the Dickerson Park Zoo. Spokeswoman Carol Leifer of the Lincoln Park Zoo said the baby is only the 16th Asian elephant born in North America since 1985. Five of those babies died soon after birth.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Nationalist Convicted Of Insulting Jews
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with comments from Soviet Jewish leader, defendant acquitted of charge he used violence. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB1,2
DOC.TEXT: A court today convicted a Russian nationalist of promoting racism and insulting Jews and sentenced him to two years in a labor camp, ending a three-month trial highlighting fears of growing anti-Semitism. ``I'm suffering for Russia!'' Konstantin Smirnov-Ostashvili shouted in one of many outbursts during the half-hour session in the heavily guarded Moscow City Court. Andrei Makarov, a prosecutor, said the case shows ``fascism is being born'' in the Soviet Union, likening the situation to that in Germany in the 1930s. Supporters of Smirnov-Ostashvili heckled Judge Andrei Muratov repeatedly as he read a summary of the case, then the verdict. They sometimes drowned him out. It was the first such case brought to trial under a law passed as the Soviet Union grapples with widespread unrest among many of its more than 100 ethnic groups. Smirnov-Ostashvili, 54, was charged with inciting hatred between ethnic groups. He shouted angrily and raised his fist as the judge read a list of witnesses who had testified against him: ``Where's the expertise?'' ``Everything is taken out of context! It's all a lie!'' he shouted from behind a brown wooden partition, guarded by five Interior Ministry soldiers with guns and rubber clubs. Smirnov-Ostashvili was accused of organizing protesters who broke up a meeting at the Central House of Literature in Moscow on Jan. 18 and insulted Jewish writers. The popular weekly publication Ogonyok quoted an unidentified protester as shouting through a megaphone: ``Your time is over. Neither the police, nor the KGB, nor the party will help yuu. Now we will be masters of the country and you newcomers, clear out and go to Israel. How long can we tolerate your Russophobia?'' Muratov determined Friday that Smirnov-Ostashvili had made those remarks. The judge said the defendant's diatribe contained ``insulting, demeaning, threatening phrases virtually intended to humiliate the national honor and dignity of citizens of the Jewish origin.''
