The court dismissed charges that Smirnov-Ostashvili had used violence at the writer's meeting but said he had threatened attacks on Jews. The case received wide publicity in the Soviet media at a time when thousands of Jews are emigrating, many because they fear a wave of anti-Semitic attacks by extreme Russian nationalist groups. The trial followed a five-month investigation during which more than 400 people were questioned. Soviet Jews welcomed the landmark case, which participants said was the first time an accused anti-Semite has been put on trial in Russia. ``It has shown that there is new fascism in Russia, but it has also shown that Soviet law has been made to work and come to the rescue,'' said Alla Geller, a member of the writers group April and a trial spectator. Mikhail Clenov, co-president of Vaad, the Confederation of Jewish Organizations and Communities in the U.S.S.R., said the government should now investigate the entire Pamyat group, a Russian nationalist organization to which the defendant belongs. Some of the 100 spectators in court today wore buttons of Pamyat. They shouted, ``Shame! Shame!'' after the judge read the sentence. Other spectators were Jews, largely silent during the sessions. Early in the session, a spectator threw a bouquet of red carnations at Smirnov-Ostashvili, and he held it up and shouted, ``Zionism won't succeed! Long live Russia! '' The defendant could have received a maximum penalty of five years in prison or labor camps, or a fine of up to 5,000 rubles, about $9,000 at the official exchange rate. The verdict and sentence were decided by the judge and two civilian assistants, without a jury. He was sentenced to two years in a labor camp. Smirnov-Ostashvili has denied being anti-Semitic, but maintains the Soviet Union's 1.4 million Jews hold a disproportionate number of high places in government and society.

DOC.HEAD: Philip Bosco Stars in `The Miser' on Broadway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS four grafs at end with what other critics said. No PMs planned.
DOC.TEXT: Thank goodness for star turns. Philip Bosco and Carole Shelley are the main reasons to see ``The Miser,'' Moliere's comic portrait of greed incarnate, now being revived on Broadway by Circle in the Square. Their performances dominate an otherwise ordinary production marred by Stephen Porter's listless direction and some oddly cast secondary roles. Bosco is almost unrecognizable as Harpagon, the man who worships his money more than life. With a white fright wig and a scruffy, unshaven face, he looks like Ebenezer Scrooge on a bad day. The actor is a master of comic timing as he storms around the stage, blowing out candles - why waste the wax - or ordering his servants to water the wine. Bosco plays Harpagon a little nastier than usual, but it's still funny. His miser's maniacal devotion to gold makes one a bit uneasy. There's a hint of venom underneath the obsessiveness, but it works. Besides, not many actors can get a huge laugh just by coughing. But what a cough. It starts as a low rumble in his throat and bursts forth like an engine of a 747 cleared for takeoff. Shelley, in the much smaller role of the matchmaker Frosine, matches Bosco quip for quip and laugh for laugh. The production, in fact, doesn't really come to life until the actress shows up late in the first act. Tarted up in rouge and masses of red curls, Frosine coos her way into Harpagon's confidence. Shelley and Bosco beautifully play off each other, mining the humor that Moliere finds in the hypocrisy of two people using each other for their own ends. The plot turns on the usual complications of mismatched couples. Harpagon, a widower, wants to marry the young lady adored by his son. His daughter desires a supposedly penniless manservant in the household while Harpagon plans to marry her off to a wealthy older man. The ending is so blatantly contrived that it earns laughs for its artificiality. The translation by John Wood certainly is serviceable, conversational without being too modern. But when the two stars are off stage, the production sags. Harpagon's vexed children, Elise and Cleante, are played by Mia Dillon and Thomas Gibson. Their performances are marked by some mighty strange vocal acrobatics. She simpers. He screeches. What may have been thought of as funny by director Porter becomes annoying. Elise's admirer, Valere, is done in by Christian Baskous' wooden portrayal in which he seems to be reading his lines from a cue card. Only John Christopher Jones as the hapless servant Maitre Jacques can match the comic spirit of Bosco and Shelley. Part of the director's problem may be the awkward elongated playing area with the audience on all four sides. Actors have to race around the stage, and they do it without much style. James Morgan's scenery is sparse but Gail Brassard's costumes are sumptuous, especially for the foppish son Cleante. But ``The Miser'' only really comes alive when Bosco and Shelley are center stage. Without them, the merriment is as minimal as the title character's gift of giving. What other critics said: Frank Rich, The New York Times: ``...the production has been guided with uncharacteristic sloppiness by the Moliere and Shaw expert (and frequent Bosco collaborator) Stephen Porter. ... Mr. Bosco deflates much of the evening by wailing and sobbing in grave self-pity over Harpagon's travails, as if he were somehow imbued with a tragic awareness more appropriate to Shylock than to a role with roots in commedia dell'arte.'' Clive Barnes, New York Post: ``...Bosco ... has never been better. Sometimes as an actor he suffers from a certain orotund self-satisfaction, leading to an easily ingratiating superficiality - best suited to Shaw. But here he attempts something harsher and funnier.'' Howard Kissel, Daily News: ``What better way to celebrate the sentencing of Michael Milken than a revival of Moliere's `The Miser.' ...By the second act, when the paly itself gathers momentum, the production becomes as unpretentiously entertaining as its author intended it to be.''

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu, Hooted by Opposition, Pushes U.N. Peace Corps Plan
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu was greeted by hoots and catcalls today when he opened a special session of parliament by urging support for his plan to deploy Japan's Self Defense Forces overseas for the first time. The prime minister told the deeply divided parliament, or Diet, that Japan's international role is bigger ``than most of us are aware of.'' Such responsibility, he said, justified dispatching his proposed United Nations Peace Cooperation Corps to the Persian Gulf. ``We must not forget the fact that Japan is one of the prime beneficiaries of a world without war,'' Kaifu said. ``Contributing to maintain world peace is both a natural and inevitable cost arising from Japan's position within the international community.'' Kaifu faces powerful opposition over the bill to create the force. Consisting partly of military personnel, the 1,000 to 2,000-member team would perform non-combat services such as transportation and medical aid to assist the multinational effort in the gulf. The prime minister, however, does not appear to have enough legislative support to push the bill through. The three largest opposition parties have said they will not allow its passage. ``Such a bill is nothing but a serious challenge to our peace constitution,'' said Takako Doi, chairwoman of the Socialist Party - the largest opposition group. Japan's Constitution, written after World War II under U.S. occupation, prohibits the use of force to settle international disputes. But the government, feeling pressure from Washington to increase its role in the gulf, has said sending military personnel overseas can be constitutional as long as force is not used and actions are based on U.N. resolutions. Kaifu committed himself to establishing the special corps during a meeting with President Bush in New York last month. Government officials said they will present the bill early next week. The Liberal Democratic Party must win support from one of the three top opposition groups to push the bill through the upper house, where it lost a long-held majority in July 1989 elections. Japan has pledged $2 billion toward U.S.-led multinational efforts in the gulf to force Iraq out of Kuwait. It also promised $2 billion in economic aid to gulf nations hard hit by the international trade embargo against Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Admits to Bank Embezzlement
DOC.TEXT: A former Citibank manager pleaded guilty to embezzling $3 million by writing 165 unauthorized bank checks to buy items ranging from a country home to rare artwork and expensive jewelery. Becky Schafer, 29, who managed the Corporate Trust Services Department at the bank's Wall Street office, entered the plea Thursday before Manhattan Federal Judge John Keenan. Some restitution has been made, said Assistant U.S. Attorney Peter Vigeland. Schafer, who began her job at Citibank three years ago, admitted in court to embezzling the funds between December 1987 and last June. It was estimated that hundreds of unauthorized checks were written, many of them payable to businesses where Schafer went on spending sprees to buy a BMW car, an expensive house in Kansas City, Mo., and other luxuries, according to reports in today's editions of the New York Post and the Daily News. ``I was authorized to write checks and caused checks to be written for my personal use'' Schafer told the judge. The Nebraska native quit her job last June and was arrested Aug. 6. ``All we can say is that she worked for us from 1985 to June of this year,'' Citibank spokeswoman Amy Dates said. Schafer faces a maximum penalty of 20 years in prison and a $250,000 fine or twice the bank's loss, which Citibank placed at $3 million.

DOC.HEAD: Gunfire Kills Parliament Speaker, Three Guards
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs grafs 12-14, `One Soviet...' with 7 grafs to UPDATE with remarks from interior minister, background on past attacks. Pickup 15th, `Moussa warned...'
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen today killed the parliament speaker and three security men outside a downtown hotel. The attack came after the government warned that terrorists might strike to punish Egypt for its opposition to Iraq. There was no claim of responsibility for the attack by gunmen on motorcycles, but the interior minister said he suspected Egyptian Moslem fundamentalists or foreigners. Rifaat el-Mahgoub, 64, speaker of the People's Assembly and the second ranking politician after the president, was shot as he sat in the rear of his chauffeur-driven Mercedes, Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa said. The gunmen then fled as other security men returned their fire, Moussa said. The shooting occurred as el-Mahgoub's car drove by the Hotel Semiramis Inter-Continental, a block from the U.S. Embassy. The speaker was heading for a hotel about 1{ miles away where he was to meet a Syrian delegation. Moussa told reporters that four young assailants attacked el-Mahgoub's vehicle and an accompanying security car from two Suzuki motorbikes. Three escaped on the bikes, he said. They rode through a nearby underpass in front of the hotel, speeding against the traffic on the one-way street. The fourth ran into a densely populated area nearby and disappeared. He wounded two bystanders who tried to stop him, Moussa said. The minister, confirming earlier reports, said two security men were killed in el-Mahgoub's car and another in a security car traveling behind him. An hour after the shooting, el-Mahgoub's black Mercedes sat outside the hotel, its rear window and right front window smashed. One of the two slain bodyguards in the car lay in the front seat, his head torn apart by gunfire. A second car - a Peugeot - was stopped about 200 yards away, a man's body hanging onto the roadway from the rear seat. That man also was identified as a member of a security detail traveling with el-Mahgoub. All streets were blocked around the 28-story hotel, one of the newest and most luxurious in Cairo. Moussa said the assailants awaited el-Mahgoub's car and escort with their rifles hidden in handbags. One Soviet-made hand grenade and four home-made explosives, which were timed to explode but didn't, were found on the roadside near the hotel, Moussa said. Policeman defused them later. Moussa said he suspected the attackers were foreigners or local Moslem fundamentalists. He refused to elaborate. Moussa, who said he was traveling 300 yards behind el-Mahgoub's car during the attack, dismissed questions about whether he was the intended target. Islamic militants tried to kill an interior minister with a bomb and shot at two interior ministers in 1987. One of the ex-ministers was wounded seriously. President Hosni Mubarak's predecessor, Anwar Sadat, was killed Oct. 6, 1981 by Moslem extremists, who then tried and failed to overthrow the government. Today's shooting occurred 90 minutes before Moussa was to have briefed reporters on the outcome of a national referendum Thursday. Results showed 93 percent of the Egyptians voting approved Mubarak's proposal to dissolve the People's Assembly and call new elections. Moussa warned before the vote that Iraqis and other Arabs had infiltrated the country to destabilize the government through terror attacks, including assassinations. Egypt has led Arab opposition to Iraq's annexation of Kuwait. It was unclear what effect el-Mahgoub's assassination might have on the election process. The constitution provides that elections must be held within 60 days of certification of the referendum results. Mubarak scheduled the referendum because the nation's highest constitutional court had declared illegal the election laws under which the parliament was seated. Under Egypt's Constitution, el-Mahgoub as parliamentary speaker was the second-ranking official because Mubarak has not named a vice president. A political moderate, el-Mahgoub had been speaker since 1984. El-Mahgoub mostly took his cue from Mubarak, and despite his ranking in Egypt's heirarchy, had little real authority other than over parliament. His high profile, however, made el-Mahgoub a relatively easy target for attackers. After the shooting, el-Mahgoub's wife was brought to the hotel, crying hysterically. ``Just let me see him!'' she sobbed. In recent weeks, newspaper commentators and cartoonists have mocked the People's Assembly and indirectly skewered el-Mahgoub for his position on the referendum. Although he never said so publicly, he was known to oppose dissolution of the assembly and new elections.

The second-season premiere of Fox's ``The Simpsons'' beat NBC's ``The Cosby Show by half a ratings point, overnight ratings showed today. But NBC officials were not about to have a cow, man. When the national Nielsens come in, Bill Cosby's series ``in all likelihood will win,'' said Preston Beckman, NBC vice president for audience research. ``The Simpsons,'' whose reruns have been clobbered by NBC's hit series since the new season began last month, averaged a 19.9 rating in the 24-city overnight ratings when it began its second season Thursday night. Cosby's show, which began its seventh season last month and has been a perennial ratings winner, received a 19.3 rating. The first half-hour of a new ``Columbo'' episode on ABC was third in the Thursday ratings battle, averaging an 11.5. A CBS movie, ``Dark Avenger,'' was left far behind with a 5.2. The 24-city overnight ratings represent more than 47 percent of the nation's 93.1 million TV househoulds, according to Nielsen Media Research. The high ``Simpsons'' ratings were anticipated by NBC, Beckman said, both because of heavy press coverage of the show's return and heavy promotion of the show this week by Fox Broadcasting Co. ``Fox must have spent an enormous amount on promotion for this show,'' he said. ``Given all that, it's a good number for him.'' Can Matt Groening's bug-eyed, big-toothed cartoon clan continue beating Cosby's Huxtable family? ``It's really difficult to say,'' Beckman said. That will become clearer in about two weeks from now ``when `The Simpsons' aren't on the cover of every magazine around,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Leader Quits Parliament; More Kashmir Violence Reported
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the largest Sikh faction in parliament resigned his seat today and called on the United Nations to arrange a vote for self-determination in the troubled state of Punjab. Simranjit Singh Mann said in a letter to the speaker that he quit to protest the extension of federal rule in Punjab and the refusal to allow elections of a state legislature. Parliament overwhelmingly approved extending federal rule to Punjab last week on the recommendation of Prime Minister V.P. Singh, who said a fair election free of pressure by militant separatists could not be guaranteed. Meanwhile, in Kashmir, northwest of Punjab, ethnic violence erupted today when Moslem militants killed three paramilitary policemen and wounded three others in the city of Sprinagar, witnesses said. They said troops retaliated by setting fire to five houses whose occupants had fled violent gunbattles earlier in the week. About 35 people, mostly non-combatants, have been killed in fighting between militants and government troops that began in Sprinagar on Sunday, and about 175 houses destroyed by fire, residents said. Militants and government troops traded gunfire for eight hours Thursday night in Sopore, 25 miles northwest of Srinagar, according to witnessses. No deaths were reported, but the residents accused the government men of setting fire to 60 shops in the Iqbal market. At least 1,375 people have been killed in the predominantly Muslim Kashmir region since Jan. 20, when the government launched its harshest crackdown ever on the increasingly violent secessionist movement. Meanwhile, in New Delhi, Mann, the Sikh legislator, told foreign reporters two other party members have said they will quit and others will follow. Mann's Akali Dal faction last year won seven of Punjab's 13 seats in the 529-member lower house of parliament. But he declined to take the oath of office when the authorities refused to let him wear his three-foot-long ceremonial sword. Mann was again refused entry into the parliament building today to submit his resignation when he refused to remove the curved sword strapped across his shoulder. He waited 45 minutes for an official to come and take the letter, news agencies reported. An average of about a dozen people are killed every day by Sikh militants in Punjab, a farming state bordering Pakistan. Sikhs have a slight majority in Punjab but make up only 2 percent of India's total population of 880 million. Mann said that in the 41 months since the dismissal of the state legislature, Punjab had become a colony of India. He called for a U.N.-supervised referendum in Punjab to decide its future. ``An international effort is required to get us out of this colonial state,'' he said. ``I think this will have to go to the United Nations.''

DOC.HEAD: Slain Parliament Speaker Served Mubarak Well
With PM-Egypt-Shooting
DOC.TEXT: Parliament Speaker Rifaat el-Mahgoub always lacked the charisma of other political leaders, but he served President Hosni Mubarak's interests well as the nation's second-ranking politician. From the time he took over as head of the People's Assembly in 1984, until he was assassinated today, el-Mahgoub, 64, steered Egypt's unicameral legislature as Mubarak's government and National Democratic Party wanted. As parliament speaker, he was supposed to be neutral, a sort of umpire, between the governing party's majority in the 485-member chamber and the opposition, which held about 100 seats. However, el-Mahgoub's preference for the governing party was evident, sometimes brazen, in his conduct of debates. He used his authority to push through or shelve legislation in accordance with government wishes. This prompted attacks by opposition parties, who characterized him as a dictator. Tall, lean and bespectacled, el-Mahgoub almost always appeared stiff and stern during parliamentary sessions. He often made quick rulings on the outcome of voting by a show of hands, without bothering to count. The People's Assembly elected el-Mahgoub speaker in 1984 and again in 1987. In this post, he was the country's second-highest official in protocol, but he had no real power over national policy. Mubarak suspended the assembly Sept. 26 and called a referendum, held Thursday, that gave him a mandate to dissolve parliament. This was necessary because Egypt's highest court ruled in June that the assembly was elected under an unconstitutional law and was therefore illegal. The outgoing chamber was crisis-ridden from the start. A Cairo court ruled that 78 seats held by National Democrats rightfully belonged to opposition party members. An appeals court agreed. But the assembly ignored the ruling. El-Mahgoub cited a legal provision that on parliamentary membership issues, the assembly is ``master of its own decision.'' El-Mahgoub graduated from Cairo University's law school in 1948 and obtained a doctorate degree in economy from the University of Paris five years later. He assumed several academic posts, including dean of the College of Economy and Political Sciences. He became minister for presidential affairs in 1972 and deputy prime minister three years later. The minister is survived by his wife and four children.

DOC.HEAD: School To Give Phys Ed Credit For Reading Pamphlets About Exercise
DOC.TEXT: Put away the sweats and put on your glasses. The only physical exertion some high school juniors and seniors will have to do next year for credit is to occasionally lift their eyelids, or at least say they did. The Pittsfield School Committee voted this week to let students fulfill physical education requirements by reading about exercise. Starting next September students will have three options. They can take gym classes once or twice a week or enroll in the reading program. The current requirement is gym twice a week. Under the minimum option, students will be able to tell teachers they have read assigned pamphlets about health and physical exercise. No tests, papers or classes will be required. School Committee member George Desnoyers contended that juniors and seniors are old enough to choose whether to exercise. He wanted to eliminate the physical education requirement altogether, but it's required by state law. ``Kids should be encouraged to participate in sports, like intramural sports or joining the Y or the Girls' Club, but the school day is too short, the school year is too short and something has got to give,'' said school committee member George B. Crane. Angel G. Ramirez cast the lone opposition vote. He said too many young people loaf around watching television instead of exercising.

DOC.HEAD: Employers to Prepay Wage Taxes to Help City in Cash Crunch
DOC.TEXT: Several of the largest employers in the city have agreed to prepay $50 million in wage taxes to help the city government, which is expected to go broke in December. The prepayers include the University of Pennsylvania, Bell of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia Electric Co. and Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, according to reports today in The Philadelphia Inquirer and the Philadelphia Daily News. The city failed last month to sell $375 million worth of temporary loan notes meant to keep it going until spring, when property tax payments are due. Lenders apparently were scared off by the city's projected $206 million budget deficit. A spokeswoman for the Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce said the tax prepayments would be announced today. The city spends about $9 million a day, so the $50 million prepayment would only keep the government going for 5{ days beyond Dec. 1, when Mayor W. Wilson Goode has said the city will run out of cash. ``We don't want to overblow this as anything more than a show of confidence,'' Chamber of Commerce Vice President Nicholas DeBenedictis told the Daily News. DeBenedictis said the prepayment, however, was a step in the right direction. ``Our immediate problem is getting cash, and we need some confidence going, some positive action,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Eisenhower's Image to Appear in the Sky at Centennial Celebration
DOC.TEXT: A gigantic image of President Dwight D. Eisenhower will appear in the sky over Abilene and deliver a speech in the finale of events marking the centennial of his birth. The 50-minute ceremony Sunday night at the Eisenhower Center is designed with one thing in mind, said Richard N. Smith, interim director of the research facility and museum. ``This will be unadulterated fun and flag waving and fireworks,'' Smith said. The laser show will be a highlight of a weekend of activities solemn and salutary expected to draw up to 50,000 people. The central Kansas town the country's 34th president called home might feel a little crowded. It's population is 6,300. Eisenhower was born Oct. 14, 1890, in Denison, Texas, but grew up in Abilene. A military career begun in West Point led to service as supreme Allied commander during World War II. In peacetime, the popular Republican served as president from 1953 to 1961. He died in 1969. Sunday would have been Eisenhower's 100th birthday. Evoking the man and his era will be World War II veterans in uniform, vintage military aircraft, even a USO show. War veterans are coming in on the sort of troop trains that took them from their homes 50 years ago. Some will form a battalion-sized encampment at Eisenhower Park. Even a contingent of Soviets, U.S. allies in World War II, is expected to swing down from Lawrence, where they are attending the Meeting for Peace. A new postage stamp will be unveiled marking the centennial of Eisenhower's birth. Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will represent President Bush at a wreath-laying ceremony Sunday at the tomb of Eisenhower and his wife, Mamie. The Rev. Billy Graham will lead an ecumenical service featuring singers from every Abilene church choir. Eisenhower will get in the last word, however. As the late president's image looms overhead, his words will be heard. ``Eisenhower will be resurrected at the last moment on this screen and we'll gradually bring the figure into the heavens, and he'll speak, then the figure will dissipate into the clouds,'' said Gary Caimano of Tamerlane Productions, the Fort Worth, Texas, company coordinating the show. The speech will be one Eisenhower gave in 1945 on returning home from the war. ``We took it from that directly,'' Caimano said. ``We didn't change anything, but the words he says will be appropriate for today.''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Press For New Taxes on Wealthy; House GOP Ignoring Bush
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 8-9, bgng, Bush's spokesman ... to UPDATE with later reaction, details; edits 10th graf for transition
DOC.TEXT: House Democrats rallied around a liberal budget plan today that lays new taxes on the wealthy. Divided Republicans, meanwhile, seemed ready to ignore President Bush's conclusion that a deep cut in the capital gains tax is dead. ``There was a very strong positive attitude on the part of members,'' Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., told reporters after a Democratic caucus. ``There's a sense of unity.'' The Democratic plan would boost taxes on wealthier Americans and offer a small capital-gains tax cut for middle-income families. It is one of many budget proposals sprouting all over Capitol Hill amid frustration over Bush's blurry position on taxing the rich. House Republicans were honing a plan that would hold this year's spending to last year's levels. It would also cut the capital gains tax deeply while gently raising income taxes on the wealthy, a trade Bush likes but has said is unattainable because of Democratic opposition. ``We're doing a House Republican position,'' said Rep. Mickey Edwards, R-Okla. ``We're not developing a White House position. That's different.'' At the Wht summit agreement. As a result, the Democrats would impose a lesser boost ontthe monthly premium that Medicare beneficiaries pay for doctors' coverage. The annual $75 deductible paid by participants for doctors' expenses would increase, but also at a lesser rate.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher: Be Ready for War if Sanctions Fail
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Thatcher's keynote address. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, signaling increasing British impatience with the Persian Gulf standoff, told her Conservative Party today to be prepared for war if sanctions fail. ``We must hope they work. If not, the military option is there. ... We must be ready for any contingency,'' she said in her keynote address, winding up the Tories' four-day annual conference. Amid applause from the 5,000 delegates, Mrs. Thatcher also said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein must face war crimes charges, pay reparation for the devastation of Kuwait and be stripped of power to mount new attacks. ``This tyrant has taken our people hostage,'' she said. ``You get him out, make him pay and see that he is never in a position to do these things again.'' Mrs. Thatcher spoke a day after Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said the international community must assess within weeks whether sanctions are working -and whether only force can end Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Mrs. Thatcher praised President Bush for taking the lead in the gulf crisis, adding: ``In times of great crisis, Britain and the United States stand as always together.'' She focused most of her keynote address on trying to rally the party, which, despite promises of better economic times ahead, is running out of time to reverse its long lag in opinion poll ratings. On Britain's relations with the rest of the 12-nation European Community - the issue that is dividing her Cabinet - she was adament that she will fight plans for economic integration with a single currency. ``Europe cannot be built by ... trying to turn us into regions rather than nations,'' she declared. Mrs. Thatcher's personal ratings have been boosted by the gulf crisis and the fresh life that her swift dispatch of British forces has given to the Anglo-American relationship. Britain had seemed overshadowed by the emergence of a reunified Germany as the dominant West European power. Still, the conference has produced signs of anxiety that after 11 years in power, the Conservatives are running out of new ideas. ``We have to avoid looking like custodians of a finished process, designers whose work is done,'' declared Sir Geoffrey Howe, the deputy prime minister. Security has been extraordinarily tight at the meeting to prevent a possible IRA attack. On Thursday night, police arrested a woman found with two gasoline bombs in a parking lot 200 yards from the conference center and hotel where Mrs. Thatcher is staying. However, police spokesman Brian Jones said: ``This was definitely not a terrorist attack.'' He said the middle-aged woman appeared mentally disturbed. She was spotted with the devices - milk bottles containing gasoline - by a police patrol. One bottle had exploded and the other was still intact. There was no damage. The convention center and Mrs. Thtcher's Hycliff Hotel are ringed by a six-foot spiked fence as part unprecedented security amid new fears of an assassination attempt by the outlawed Irish Republican Army. The IRA, fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland, killed a Conservative Party legislator in July and attempted to kill a government minister last month. At the 1984 Conservative conference, IRA guerrillas blew up Mrs. Thatcher's hotel, killing five party members.

DOC.HEAD: IQ More Influenced By Inheritance Than By Family Setting, Study Says
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUB 2nd graf to CORRECT that three tests were given; pick up 3rd graf pvs, bgng ``Thomas J.'' ^By PAUL RECER
DOC.TEXT: Genetics, not the social class of a family, is the strongest influence on intelligence, according to a study of identical twins who were raised separately. The study, published today in the journal Science, said that twins who were raised separately scored close to the same values in three intelligence tests taken as adults. Thomas J. Bouchard, a University of Minnesota professor who directed the study, said that it shows that inherited characteristics is the most powerful contributor to intelligence. He and his colleagues found that 70 percent of the influence on IQ scores was genetics and only about 30 percent was as a result of environment. ``While 70 percent of the variation in IQ in this group is due to genetic factors, that still leaves considerable room for environmental influences,'' Bouchard said. ``But whatever those influences are, social class isn't one of them.'' In the Science report, Bouchard and his colleagues said that socioeconomic effects have been found to influence IQ scores for young but not among adults. This suggests, the study said, that ``although parents may be able to affect their children's rate of cognitive skill acquisition, they may have relatively little influence on the ultimate level attained.'' The study is based on evaluations of 50 pairs of twins who were separated in childhood, raised apart, and then reunited as adults. Bouchard cautioned that the findings cannot be applied to people in extreme circumstances since none of those studied were retarded or raised by very poor or illiterate parents. ``They do indicate that, in the current environments of the broad middle class, in industrialized societies, two-thirds of the observed variance of IQ can be traced to genetic variation,'' the study said. The study also evaluated the attitudes, interests and personalities of the raised-apart twins and found what was called ``remarkable similarity.'' Childhood environmental influences also seemed to have little effect on physical and emotional traits. Identical twins, the study said, ``are about equally similar on most physiological and psychological traits, regardless of rearing status.'' Bouchard's study is in conflict with some earlier separated twins studies that attributed only about half of the similarity in IQ scores to genetics and said that environmental effects would have a stronger influence on the adult intelligence measures. Co-authors with Bouchard in the study were David T. Lykken, Matthew McGue, Nancy L. Segal and Auke Tellegen, all of the University of Minnesota. Science, which published the Minnesota study, is the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

DOC.HEAD: Retired JAMA Editor Dr. John Talbott Dies
DOC.TEXT: Dr. John Talbott, a physician, researcher and teacher who edited the Journal of the American Medical Association, has died of cancer. He was 88. He died at home Wednesday. Talbott edited the medical journal fored to elaborate. Moussa, who said he was traveling 300 yards behind el-Mahgoub's car during the attack, dismissed questions about whether he was the intended target. Islamic militants tried to kill an interior minister with a bomb and shot at two interior ministers in 1987. One of the ex-ministers was wounded seriously. President Hosni Mubarak's predecessor, Anwar Sadat, was killed Oct. 6, 1981 by Moslem extremists, who then tried and failed to overthrow the government. In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We are shocked by the assassination.'' He said the United States deplored the attack and had no indication who carried it out. Today's shooting occurred 90 minutes before Moussa was to have briefed reporters on the outcome of a national referendum Thursday. Results showed 93 percent of the Egyptians voting approved Mubarak's proposal to dissolve the People's Assembly and call new elections. Moussa warned before the vote that Iraqis and other Arabs had infiltrated the country to destabilize the government through terror attacks, including assassinations. Egypt has led Arab opposition to Iraq's annexation of Kuwait. It was unclear what effect el-Mahgoub's assassination might have on the election process. The constitution provides that elections must be held within 60 days of certification of the referendum results. Mubarak scheduled the referendum because the nation's highest constitutional court had declared illegal the election laws under which the parliament was seated. Under Egypt's Constitution, el-Mahgoub as parliamentary speaker was the second-ranking official because Mubarak has not named a vice president. A political moderate, el-Mahgoub had been speaker since 1984. El-Mahgoub mostly took his cue from Mubarak, and despite his ranking in Egypt's heirarchy, had little real authority other than over parliament. His high profile, however, made el-Mahgoub a relatively easy target for attackers. After the shooting, el-Mahgoub's wife was brought to the hotel, crying hysterically. ``Just let me see him!'' she sobbed. In recent weeks, newspaper commentators and cartoonists have mocked the People's Assembly and indirectly skewered el-Mahgoub for his position on the referendum. Although he never said so publicly, he was known to oppose dissolution of the assembly and new elections.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Sponsors Offer Last-Minute Concessions
DOC.NOTE: EDS: TOP 11 grafs new with renewed veto threat, picks up 7th graf pvs bgng: ``The legislation,'' DELETES last two grafs as redundant
DOC.HEAD: By MIKE ROBINSON
DOC.TEXT: Despite last-minute concessions by civil rights forces, President Bush still plans to veto major legislation designed to combat job discrimination, the White House said today. ``We still believe this is a quota bill,'' Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater told reporters. ``We continue to believe a veto is warranted on that basis.'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh also told Congress that Bush would veto the proposed civil rights bill. He said in a letter to Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole that changes put forth by House-Senate conferees ``do not offer substantial improvement'' and ``in some respects they make the bill worse.'' Civil rights forces had hoped that changes adopted by the conferees in the job discrimination legislation would overcome Bush administration fears that the bill would encourage employers to adopt hiring quotas to avoid lawsuits. But the attorney general's letter made clear that the changes had no effect on the Bush administration's position. ``Accordingly, the president will be compelled to veto S 2104 in its current form,'' Thornburgh said in a letter released by the Justice Department. Bush has said he wants to sign a civil rights bill this year. But Fitzwater said the White House will not accept the current version despite changes that Rep. Augustus F. Hawkins, D-Calif., said backers hoped were ``more in line with the president's views.'' The key change would offer employers greater leeway in defending against discrimination suits. It also would make clear that nothing in the bill was designed to encourage the use of hiring quotas. But Thornburgh said ``the new language makes no material change'' in the bill, which Bush had previously threatened to veto. ``The words are different, but the meaning and effect are the same, and there is no improvement.'' ``The trouble with the bill is not that it explicitly `encourages' or `requires' quotas, but that it will inevitably result in quotas being adopted surreptitiously to avoid the cost and trouble'' of lawsuits, Thornburgh wrote. ``The assertion that the bill ought not have this effect cannot change the fact that it will,'' the attorney general said. The legislation, the top legislative priority of the civil rights movement, would negate six Supreme Court decisions last year. Main features would change complex courtroom procedures in a way that would make it harder for employers to defend against discrimination suits. Other provisions range from a ban on racial harassment on the job to removal of obstacles to reopening court-approved minority hiring agreements. Critics in the administration and the business community say the bill would make it so difficult for employers to win discrimination suits that they would turn to hiring quotas as a way of heading off such charges. A House-Senate conference committee that already had produced a compromise version of the bill went back to work Thursday night and adopted a seven-point package of concessions designed to win Bush's backing. Supporters said that even if the president remains opposed, the changes might attract the two-thirds congressional support for the bill needed to override his threatened veto. The package was adopted 11-8 by the conference committee. Rep. Craig Washington, D-Texas, a strong supporter of civil rights, voted with critics against the package. He said the changes turned the measure into ``the hollow shell of a civil rights bill.'' Washington said long delays in sending the bill to the White House most likely will enable Bush to stop the bill with a ``pocket veto'' if he so desires. Under a pocket veto, the president is able to kill bills by simply refusing to sign them when Congress is not in session. Lawmakers are getting ready to leave Washington for a round of campaigning before November elections. ``I'm not criticizing them, they're senators and stuff,'' Washington said, nodding toward Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. ``But we could have done this three weeks ago.'' Hawkins, also a strong civil rights supporter, said it was time to ``come up with something we hope is more in line with the president's views.''

DOC.HEAD: Defense Bill Heads to House Floor
DOC.NOTE: EDs: TOP 12 grafs new with House rejecting amendment on 5 percent across-the-board cut in defense spending; picks up 2nd graf pvs, bgng, `We're hanging.' EDITS to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: The House today turned aside an across-the-board cut in 1991 defense spending despite lawmakers' warnings of a depression if Congress fails to reduce the military budget. ``Is it going to be guns or is it going to be bankruptcy?'' Rep. James Traficant, D-Ohio, asked his colleagues prior to the vote on an amendment imposing a 5 percent cut on all defense programs. By a resounding 319-97, the House defeated the measure as lawmakers worked with rapid-fire speed on a $268 billion defense spending plan that makes wholesale cuts in President Bush's fiscal 1991 budget request. The legislation halts production of the B-2 stealth bomber at five planes, slashes Bush's proposal for the Strategic Defense Initiative to $2.3 billion and reduces U.S. forces by 77,000. ``We're moving in the right direction, stressing more conventional weapons, less strategic weapons,'' said Rep. John Murtha, D-Pa., chairman of the House Appropriations subcommittee on defense. As members pushed to complete the bill and recess for their first weekend off in three weeks, large chunks of thar Wars that delays early deployment and cuts the number of U.S. troops by 100,000. Facing increasing congressional discontent with the stealth aircraft and its manufacturer, the Northrop Corp., the administration stepped up its effort to save the bomber on Thursday. In a letter to members of the House and Senate Armed Services committees, Bush said the bomber is imperative to U.S.-Soviet negotiations to limit strategic weapons. Meanwhile, Air Force Secretary Donald Rice pleaded with lawmakers not to decide the fate of the B-2 based on an Air Force review that found widespread problems in nearly every aspect of Northrop's business. Earlier this week, Brig. Gen. Robert W. Drewes, who led the eight-man team that conducted the study, told a House panel that Northrop was deficient in six major areas, including cost and schedule estimates. The review did not delve into problems associated with ongoing federal probes of the Los Angeles-based company. Northrop pleaded guilty in February to 34 counts of fraud and was fined $17 million, the largest criminal fine ever imposed on a defense contractor. The plea stems from charges that Northrop falsified reports on the air-launched cruise missile and conducted improper tests on the Harrier AV-8B jet.

DOC.HEAD: Baby Born on Bridge During Tropical Storm Marco
With PM-Tropical Weather, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Riding beside her husband as they drove through the dark in a blinding rain, Brenda Urban gave birth to a boy who couldn't wait for a tropical storm to subside. At 4 a.m. Thursday in the downpour from Tropical Storm Marco, Mrs. Urban and her husband, Rick, were speeding across the three-mile Howard Frankland Bridge. They were trying to get from their home in Lutz to a midwife birthing center 45 miles away in St. Petersburg. ``We were just to the edge of the bridge when I said, `This baby's coming out,'' Mrs. Urban said. ```It was scary, being stuck on the Howard Frankland with no end in sight,'' said her husband, Rick, a computer salesman. ``I was prepared to stop on the middle of the bridge and take care of it right then.'' But a tractor-trailer was bearing down behind them and they couldn't stop. Neither could their first baby. ``It went real fast,'' Mrs. Urban said. ``My husband just reached his arm down and held the baby's head till we got across.'' At the other end of the bridge they pulled over, unwrapped the cord from the newborn's neck and laid him on his mother to keep him warm. ``I kept saying, `I can't believe we had our baby in the car,'' she said. Mrs. Urban eventually made it to Bayfront Medical Center. Emergency workers suggested the baby be named Howard Marco. The Urbans declined. Garrett Michael Urban, 6 pounds, 2 ounces, was declared to be in good health. The family went home Thursday, about time the first rays of sun appeared through the receding storm clouds. ``It was a pretty nerve-wracking experience,'' said the father. He said the episode taught him to ``plan ahead and get a closer delivery site.''

DOC.HEAD: Iranian City Jolted By Quake
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake shook the eastern Iranian city of Zahedan and surrounding regions early Friday, but caused no casualties or major damage, official Tehran radio said. The broadcast, monitored in Nicosia, said the quake, measuring 5 on the open-ended Richter scale, struck at 5:31 a.m. (10:01 p.m. EDT). It was the fourth time the city, capital of Iran's eastern Sistan-Baluchestan province near the Afghanistan-Pakistan border, was jolted in two weeks. The radio said the epicenter was 930 miles southeast of Tehran. The Richter scale measures ground motion as recorded on a seismograph. An earthquake measuring 5 on the scale can cause considerable damage in populated areas.

DOC.HEAD: Police Find Stolen Art At Swiss Railroad Station
DOC.TEXT: Paintings, jewelry and other valuables that belonged to a 17th century Spanish queen and were stolen from an Italian museum have been recovered at a Swiss railroad station, officials reported Friday. Prosecutor Federico Prato said the stolen artworks were found in boxes in the baggage deposit at the station in Mendrisio, just across the border from Italy. Recovered Wednesday were 31 items of the so-called ``Treasure of Loreto'' which had been stolen from the museum in Chiusa, near Bolzano in northeastern Italy, in May 1986. They included four 16th century paintings, valuable china, a silver cup, an ancient Mass book and jewels. They stolen items once belonged to Queen Mria Anna of Spain, the widow of Charles II. Italian art experts consider them priceless. Police said the thieves had recently tried to sell some of the pieces in Switzerland and Germany. No arrests were immediately reported and no details of the operation were given, except that it was carried out in cooperation with Swiss authorities. Some of the stolen artworks are still missing.

DOC.HEAD: Conservationists Say High-Speed Rail Line Threatens Eagles
DOC.TEXT: The government faces legal action unless it alters a planned high-speed rail line through the territory of two rare eagles, a zoo director said Friday. Didier Pons, who runs a zoo in the southern town of Saint-Canat near the eagle habitat, said France would violate a 1989 European Community conservation accord if it constructs the track along the intended route between Lyon and Marseille. The eagles in the area are one of 31 pairs of Bonelli eagles recorded in France, according to conservationists. Experts say the birds cannot live in captivity and are unable to procreate except in their own territory. Pons said Transport Minister Michel Delebarre, when informed of the problem in June, responded with an ``utterly useless'' proposal to shift the proposed track by 100 yards in the affected area. Pons said the environmental wing of the European Community will take the case to the European Court of Justice if French authorities ignore requests to ensure the eagles' protection.

DOC.HEAD: Firecracker Factory Explodes, Kills Five
DOC.TEXT: A clandestine firecracker factory exploded in the central Philippines, killing five people and seriously injuring seven others, police said Friday. Police quoted some of the injured as saying they were making firecrackers from 22 pounds of chloride nitrate when one of them accidentally ignited the chemical, which was kept in a drum. The drum exploded, causing the two-story house, which was made of light materials, to collapse along with three concrete walls nearby. Policewoman Cpl. Filomena Grandea said the accident took place Thursday in Bacolod City on Negros island, about 300 miles southeast of Manila. The manufacture of firecrackers is banned in the Philippines but the practice is tolerated, especially when the Christmas and New Year season is approaching.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Calls Justice Minister's Remarks `Extremely Inappropriate'
DOC.TEXT: In the face of rising U.S. anger, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu again expressed deep regret Friday over the remarks of a Cabinet minister who compared black Americans to prostitutes. ``The statement by the minister of justice is extremely inappropriate and extremely regrettable. Since he is a member of my Cabinet, I have given a stern warning to him,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe quoted Kaifu as telling Japanese reporters. Although Kaifu has previously expressed regret over the remarks made last month by Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama, the issue has failed to die. Japanese commentators have expressed worry that the controversy, the latest involving insulting remarks made by a Japanese official about U.S. minorities, may inflame growing trade tensions. On Thursday, the U.S. Congressional Black Caucus said its members have submitted a resolution to Congress calling on Japan to fire Kajiyama. The city of Trenton, N.J. reportedly canceled a planned visit by members of the Tokyo Metropolitan Assembly. And a group representing all 26 African ambassadors in Japan visited the Foreign Ministry to protest the remarks and demand more awareness of racial issues among Japanese officials. On Sept. 21, Kajiyama told reporters after the arrests of foreign prostitutes in a Tokyo red-light district that such people ``ruin the atmosphere'' of neighborhoods. ``It's like in America when neighborhoods become mixed because blacks move in and whites are forced out,'' he said. Watanabe quoted Kaifu as saying he was ``saddened and very much contrite over this inappropriate statement, which has given feelings of deep unpleasantness to many people, including Afro-American people.'' Kaifu said he was determined to ``implant a correct recognition of minority issues among the Japanese people,'' and noted that Kajiyama had retracted his comments and apologized to U.S. Ambassador Michael Armacost. Watanabe said Kaifu did not indicate whether the Cabinet minister would resign.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.TEXT: A gunman fired on rebel Gen. Michel Aoun today as the Syrian army braced for an attack on his headquarters, but the general survived the assassination attempt, his radio station reported. The broadcast said the attack came as Aoun addressed thousands of supporters forming a human shield around the presidential palace in the encircled Christian enclave. The radio said the attacker fired from a pistol.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Higher Car Sales, Gas Prices Drive Retail Sales Up
With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Rebounding automobile purchases and surging gasoline prices powered retail sales to a strong 1.1 percent gain in September, the government said Friday. That was the biggest advance in four months, but economists said the two special factors were masking an otherwise weak report, which included a large decline in department store sales. Sales figures are not adjusted to factor out price increases. Gasoline costs have shot up since Iraq occupied Kuwait Aug. 2, inflating that sales category. The recovery in auto sales was positive but came after months of deteriorating sales, analysts said. Overall, sales rose $1.6 billion to a seasonally adjusted $151.2 billion, the Commerce Department said. That followed a 0.4 percent decline in August. ``What is underscored by these numbers is that the process of economic decline is a very slow one. Consumers take two steps backward and then one step forward, at least if they're given a bargain as they were with autos,'' said economist David Jones of Aubrey G. Lanston & Co. Retail sales are an important barometer of economic health because they represent about one-third of the nation's economic activity. ``Consumers are gradually becoming increasingly cautious because they see the oil price s Forward 1346 1347 1360 1362 n.q.-not quoted.

DOC.HEAD: British Airways, Aeroflot to Create Airline Called Air Russia
DOC.TEXT: British Airways and the Soviet Ministry of Civil Aviation have joined forces to form a new airline called Air Russia to fly passengers from Moscow to Europe, North America and the Far East, British Airways said Friday. With the Soviet Union moving toward a market economy ``an efficient, competitive, international airline service will be a commercial necessity,'' said British Airways Chairman Lord King. The Soviet Union's state-run Aeroflot has a poor reputation for safety and service. Currently, Aeroflot, British Airways, Pan American World Airways, Virgin Atlantic Airways and most major European airlines fly in and out of Moscow. British Airways said it signed a protocol agreement with the Ministry of Civil Aviation on Friday in Moscow with a view to forming the joint venture airline. Aeroflot would hold a majority stake in the joint venture and British Airways would invest $39 million for the minority stake. Air Russia would begin flying passengers from Moscow's Domodedovo airport in 1992, operating a new fleet of aircraft, British Airways said. The proposals also call for building a new international terminal at the airport and creating an aircraft leasing company that would be jointly owned by Aeroflot, British Airways and a consortium of financial institutions.

DOC.HEAD: Warrant Issued For Arrest Of Nice's Fugitive Mayor
DOC.TEXT: A court issued a warrant Friday for the arrest of the former mayor of Nice, who resigned last month after 24 years in office and took refuge in South America. Jacques Medecin quit on Sept. 16, 10 days before he was scheduled to appear in court to face possible charges of financial misconduct. If Medecin, 62, does not return promptly to France to answer the charges, he could be tried in absentia. If convicted in such a trial, he would face the prospect of immediate imprisonment should he return later. The warrant is not valid internationally, and will not trigger any bid to have Medecin arrested in South America, officials said. However, investigations of Medecin's financial affairs continue, and authorities have left open the possibility that an international arrest warrant could be issued eventually. According to investigators, Medecin was a majority stockholder in a magazine which obtained much of its advertising revenue from the city of Nice and from the regional administrative council. Medecin was the council's president. He also was accused of improperly shifting funds to cover municipal debts. Medecin, who has spent time in Uruguay and Argentina since his resignation, has said he has no immediate plans to return France, but might do so if his lawyers recommend it. The resignation ended a family dynasty in Nice. Medecin was born in 1928, the same year his gather, Jean, became mayor of the Riviera city. Jean Medecin held the post for 38 years, until his son succeeded him in 1966.

DOC.HEAD: OSHA Establishes Regulations in Response to L'Ambiance Collapse
DOC.TEXT: A federal agency established new construction regulations Friday stemming from the 1987 collapse of L'Ambiance Plaza in Bridgeport, Conn., that claimed 28 lives. The Occupational Safety and Health Administration regulations include a requirement that non-essential workers clear out when the lift-slab method of construction is in use. Such a rule would have saved most of those killed at L'Ambiance, officials said at a signing ceremony in which the regulations were formally enacted. ``We often hear we have too much regulation, that we need less government,'' said Rep. Christopher Shays, R-Conn., whose district includes Bridgeport and who lobbied for regulatory changes. ``Well this is a classic example of where you needed more government and where you needed more regulation.'' On April 23, 1987, hydraulic jacks being used to hoist slabs of concrete flooring into place at the L'Ambiance Plaza construction site failed, causing the entire building to collapse. Twenty-eight workers were killed and dozens were injured in the worst workplace accident in the United States in nearly a decade. Only seven of those killed were working on the floor lifting job. Others were performing a variety of construction jobs throughout the building site. OSHA chief Gerard F. Scannell acknowledged ``a lot of criticism on the slowness of promulgating standards.'' The 125 pages of new regulations took three-and-a-half years to put in place. But Scannell said the rgulatory process of study, hearings and comment made the delay inevitable. OSHA officials estimated that the new rules would cost the construction industry only about $400,000 per year. The rules also require that: - Employers provide independent engineering review to ensure structural integrity if workers are allowed to remain in the building site. - Lift-slab operations must be designed and planned by a registered professional engineer. - Jacks must be able to support more than twice their rated weight. - Lifting systems must be designed so that the failure of any one jack does not cause a collapse. Scannell said that in 1987, the most recent year for which statistics are available, less than 1 percent of the 1 million square feet of commercial and industrial space constructed involved the lift-slab technique.

DOC.HEAD: UPI Dismisses Unspecified Number of Employees
DOC.TEXT: United Press International said Friday it would dismiss an unspecified number of employees and concentrate its reporting on 15 populous states. ``There will be some people who will get dismissal notices,'' Milt Capps, the news service's senior vice president for corporate affairs, said. ``There will be some ups in some places and some downs in others to maintain the staffing equilibrium,'' Capps said. ``We will have as many people reporting as we have had, given that we are also relying on stringer correspondents and subcontractors.'' Capps declined to say how many people were being laid off. Capps said UPI would continue to have bureaus in ``virtually every state'' and had no plans to announce any bureau closures any time soon. The 83-year-old wire service announced last month it was closing bureaus in five states. UPI Executive Vice President Pieter Vanbennekom said UPI plans to intensify its reporting of business and finance, economics and trade, government, crime and ``quality of life'' issues. He said wires known as MetroRegional wires would be established serving California, New York, New Jersey, Texas, Pennsylvania, Illinois, Michigan, Florida, Ohio, Massachusetts, Indiana, New Hampshire, Delaware, Maryland and Virginia. UPI derives about 82 percent of its revenue from the 15 states, Vanbennekom said. Similar wires may be established in other states in 1992, depending on the success of the program, he said.

DOC.HEAD: First Nationwide Anti-Drug Campaign For Hispanic Children Launched
DOC.TEXT: A campaign launched Friday is the first nationwide effort aimed at discouraging drug and alcohol use among Hispanic children. The campaign is called ``Piensalo!,'' which is Spanish for ``Think about it!'' It is sponsored by the Department of Health and Human Services and the National Coalition for Hispanic Health and Human Services Organization. ``Like many others, the Hispanic community has developed very serious alcohol and other drug problems,'' said Surgeon General Antonia Novello, the first Hispanic to hold that position. ``Our children are watching us,'' she said. ``The tragedy is that our children witness adult behavior and may mistakenly think that this is the norm.'' The campaign is targeted to Hispanic children between the ages of 8 and 12. It includes information booklets for parents, teachers and children, posters featuring Hispanic celebrities and public service announcements by Dr. Novello and Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan. The government spent $900,000 developing, producing and distributing the materials for the campaign, said HHS spokeswoman Luisa del Carmen Pollard. The campaign was being kicked off in nine cities with large Hispanic populations: Denver, New York, Tucson, Salt Lake City, San Antonio, Los Angeles, Chicago, Miami and San Juan, Puerto Rico. A recent study found that 33 percent of Hispanics under age 21 used alcohol during a one-month period, officials said. Another study indicated that Hispanics ages 12-17 were more likely to use cocaine than white or black Americans of that age.

DOC.HEAD: Three More Spies Arrested as Dragnet Continues
DOC.TEXT: The chief federal prosecutor's office announced Friday the arrest of three more alleged former spies for East Germany, the latest in a series of captures. The prosecutor's office identified the alleged spies only as Dr. Stefan E. and Gunther N. from Berlin, and Gerd K. from Hanover. Stefan E., 36, was responsible for preparing intelligence reports and was the control officer for Klaus Kuron, a top spy, who turned himself in on Sunday, the prosecutor's office said. Kuron started naming names, and his testimony led to the arrest of eight other alleged spies. According to the prosecutor's office, Stefan E. tried to persuade Kuron to work for the Soviet KGB just a week ago. Gunther N., 53, also worked for the Stasi, as the East German security service was called, and was involved with working with Kuron. The prosecutor's officer said that Gerd K., 40, had been trained in the intelligence services. The office did not provide details as to the nataure of Gerd K.'s crimes. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's government has appealed to former East German spies to give themselves up. They are likely to receive lighter sentences if they give up and start talking. The prosecutor's office says there is a pool of 8,0000 former East German spies loose. The arrests could continue for months. Germany was a hotbed of spy activity when the country was still divided and its two parts formed the front of the Cold War.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun Escapes Assassination Attempt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs and REORGANIZES throughout. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A gunman fired at Gen. Michel Aoun today as he addressed thousands of supporters in the Christian enclave, but the bullet missed the general and struck one of his aides, Aoun's radio station said. The assault came shortly after the Syrian army moved thousands of troops toward the enclave for an expected attack on Aoun's headquarters. The radio said Aoun's supporters saw the gunman aiming a pistol at the general and pushed him before it went off. The radio said the assailant was questioned by military officials and confessed that he was ordered to kill Aoun. The radio did not say who gave those orders. The report also did not identify the aide who was hit or describe the extent of his injuries. The broadcast said the attack came as Aoun talked to his supporters who have formed a human shield around the presidential palace in the encircled Christian enclave in an attempt to forestall the expected Syrian attack. ``I am ready to die on the battlefield of honor rather than surrender. Be sure I shall die fighting,'' Aoun told the cheering crowds around the hilltop palace east of Beirut in Baabda, Lebanon's Christian heartland. The Syrians overnight moved thousands of troops and dozens of tank columns to the major entrances of Aoun's territory in what a Lebanese government official said was ``another step in the march to end Aoun's mutiny.'' Syria's troops support the government of President Elias Hrawi, who is trying to end 15 years of civil war. An official in Hrawi's administration said Syrian and Lebanese government troops would attack if a French mediation attempt failed, but he did not set a deadline. Hrawi's army was ordered on maximum alert, and his troops joined the Syrian army in positions facing Aoun's lines along a five-mile front from south Beirut to the central mountains east of the capital. Aoun urged the estimated 150,000 inhabitants of his enclave to form a human shield around his headquarters at the heavily damaged presidential palace. He employed the same tactic last year to prevent a Syrian assault. The move caused an uproar, and France and the Vatican pressured Syrian President Hafez Assad to call off the assault. Hrawi's government ordered the latest blockade of Aoun's enclave as of Sept. 30 in a bid to force the general to step down. Jeeps from Aoun's military toured towns and villages of the enclave today, and soldiers using bullhorns urged the population to ``take up arms and defend yourselves against the aggressors.'' Aoun's radio blared martial music and songs declaring support for the 55-year-old general. ``We shall stay put whatever they do. We shall not walk out on Aoun. We don't accept any other leader,'' one of the songs said. Church bells tolled to signal thousands of Aoun supporters, who clapped, shouted slogans and waved banners around Aoun's headquarters at the shell-wrecked palace. They cheered when Aoun emerged from his underground bunker to address them. ``I salute your steadfastness. You will be mentioned in history books,'' he told the crowd. They are coming to assassinate me, but I am not afraid. I will be more than delighted to fight them off,'' Aoun said in remarks broadcast live by his radio station. Aoun was army commander when former President Amin Gemayel, at the end of a six-year term, appointed him caretaker prime minister in September 1988. Aoun rejected Hrawi's Syrian-backed election on Nov. 24, 1989. The election was held to carry out an Arab League-brokered peace accord distributing power equally between Moslems and Christians as a step toward ending Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Aoun and Hrawi are both Maronite Catholics, the Christian sect that dominated Lebanon for decades after independence from France in 1943. But the general considers the president to be a Syrian puppet. Syria, now the main power broker in Lebanon, has 40,000 troops deployed in predominantly Moslem regions under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate from the 21-nation Arab League.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of second graf
DOC.TEXT: Nashville Mayor Bill Boner has been so diverted by his romance with aspiring country singer Traci Peel that he isn't doing his job, talk show host Phil Donahue says. ``You are very close to giving the finger to the city,'' Donahue said during a taping of ``Donahue'' Thursday. ``You're a distracted mayor. You were an out-of-the-closet adulterer.'' Peel and Boner made national headlines during their reported summer romance while the mayor was still married to his third wife, Betty. Boner married Peel on Oct. 1, three days after his divorce was final. Boner said he has accomplished much during his three-year term. ``I've brought more money into Nashville than anybody else,'' Boner said. ``We lived up to our commitments. We have a totally integrated solid-waste management system.'' Peel sang ``Rocky Top'' during the show, accompanied by Boner on the harmonica. --- NASHVILE, Tenn. (AP) - Singers Webb Pierce and Vern Gosdin, honored this week during Country Music Week, were hospitalized with different ailments. Pierce, 64, a nominee for the Country Music Awards Hall of Fame, was in stable condition in the intensive care unit of Southern Hills Medical Center early Friday, a hospital official said. Pierce, who suffers from pancreatic cancer, underwent abdominal surgery in March. He was hospitalized Thursday when he began hemorrhaging. Pierce recorded ``There Stands the Glass'' and ``Wondering.'' Tennessee Ernie Ford was named this year's hall of fame inductee at the Country Music Association awards show Monday. Gosdin, 55, was in stable condition Friday at Baptist Hospital's coronary care unit with bypass surgery scheduled later in the day, the hospital said. He was adimitted earlier in the day. Gosdin was honored Wednesday at the annual awards banquet of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers. He was recognized for his hit songs ``I'm Still Crazy,'' ``That Just About Does It,'' and ``Who you Gonna Blame it on this Time.'' --- ROCHESTER, N.Y. (AP) - An eighth-grader who is battling cancer got her spirits boosted when rapper M.C. Hammer met with her before a concert. ``He was really, really nice,'' Robyn Best said after talking to Hammer Thursday night at Rochester's Community War Memorial. ``The kids at school are not going to believe this.'' The meeting was arranged by Annette Coley, a secretary at Strong Children's Critical Care Center. Coley wrote about Robyn to local radio station WDKX, which forwarded the letter to Capitol Records and Hammer. Hammer wrote back that he'd be happy to meet Robyn, and the radio station sent her tickets and backstage passes. --- LONDON (AP) - The Duchess of York will make a four-day official visit to Australia next month, Buckingham Palace announced Friday. The duchess was invited to Australia by the Royal Flying Doctor Service, but will also carry out other engagements in New South Wales and Victoria from Nov. 5 to 8. The former Sarah Ferguson, who will turn 31 on Monday, married Prince Andrew, the second son of Queen Elizabeth II, in July 1986. On their wedding day, the queen made Andrew the Duke of York. --- WATERVILLE, Maine (AP) - Syndicated columnist David S. Broder of The Washington Post is this year's recipient of the Elijah Parish Lovejoy award, Colby College officials said. Broder, winner of the 1973 Pulitzer Prize for distinguished commentary, will be honored as the 38th Lovejoy fellow in a Nov. 16 ceremony at Colby's Waterville campus. He will receive an honorary doctor of laws degree and deliver the annual Lovejoy lecture. The award is presented annually in memory of the Colby alumnus who is considered America's first martyr in the struggle to protect press freedoms. Lovejoy was killed in 1837 trying to defend his abolitionist newspaper from a pro-slavery mob. Broder, picked by a panel of journalists and college officials, has written four books on American politics. He also writes a semiweekly column that appears in more than 300 newspapers.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Group Says Iraqi Leadership Considering Withdrawal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 12th pvs, `The purported...' to UPDATE with background on the Kurdistan Democratic Party. Pickup 13th, `If such...'
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi opposition group based in London said today that Iraq is considering withdrawing from Kuwait and that its ruling political party has circulated a questionnaire asking key members for their opinion. The Kurdistan Democratic Party-Iraq said President Saddam Hussein might use the survey as a way of justifying a withdrawal from Kuwait. The Kurdistan party said in a news release received in Nicosia from its London headquarters that the questionnaire was circulated on Oct. 8 to senior Arab Baath Socialist Party members, cadres and activists. ``This latest move shows building tension and anxiety within the Iraqi leadership over the consequences of its invasion and annexation of Kuwait,'' the Kurdistan party said in its statement. ``It may well indicate that Saddam Hussein is contemplating a way out of the crisis by consulting party members,'' it said. ``The regime's propaganda can point back to party approval for a withdrawal ... in order to show a popular backing for any eventual decision taken by Saddam Hussein to seek a compromise in the current crisis.'' The three survey questions reportedly posed were: -Should Iraq remain in Kuwait? -Should Iraq withdraw from Kuwait? -Should Iraq stay in Kuwait even if war broke out? Those surveyed were allowed to answer under condition of anonymity, according to the Kurdish opposition group. The purported survey could not be independently confirmed. However, the Kurdistan Democratic Party-Iraq is known to have good access to information inside Iraq. And the group was the first source to report on the use of chemical weapons against the Kurdish population in Iraq in 1988. If such a questionnaire was distributed, it would represent an unusual attempt by Saddam to rule by consensus rather than decree. The Iraqi leader is known for his obsessive grasp on power in all political and military matters, as well as his tight control over the nationalist Baath Party, which served as his springboard to power. The Kurdistan Democratic Party seeks Saddam's overthrow and establishment of an independent Kurdish state in northeast Iraq. Saddam used chemical weapons in suppressing an April 1988 Kurdish uprising in the city of Halabja in which an estimated 20,000 ethnic Kurds were killed. There are also Kurdish groups in Iran and Turkey who seek independence. Iraq invaded oil-rich Kuwait on Aug. 2, prompting the deployment of a multinational force led by the United States in Saudi Arabia and the Persian Gulf. The force is upholding a trade embargo approved by the United Nations. Saddam annexed Kuwait, claiming it was historically part of Iraq, and has said repeatedly that Iraq would never withdraw.

DOC.HEAD: Gallup Poll: College Students Borrow Too Much
AP Education Writer
DOC.TEXT: Americans say students must borrow too much money to attend college, but agree a college education is worth a lot over an entire lifetime, a Gallup Organization poll showed Friday. The survey found adults nationwide think the cost of higher education is unmanageable without some form of financial assistance. It showed that 91 percent of the 1,014 adults interviewed by telephone in June believe it is not possible today for most people to go to college without receiving some form of financial aid. Sixty percent believe the loan burden most students bear is too high. About half as many, 28 percent, said the loan burden is about right given the value of a college education. Four percent said students borrow too little. ``We must all redouble our efforts to provide the financial resources needed - grants and other aid as well as loans - for every qualified student to attend college,'' said Virginia Carter Smith, interim president of the Council for Advancement and Support of Education (CASE), which commissioned the survey. Students at four-year public colleges are paying an average of $1,809 for tuition and fees this year, up 7 percent, and those at two-year public colleges are paying an average of $884, up 5 percent, the College Board said. At four-year and two-year private colleges, students are paying an average of $9,391 and $5,003, respectively, up 8 percent. Almost half of all college students receive public or private assistance, which reached an all-time high of $28 billion last year, the College Board said. According to the poll, the public supports changing federal government policy to include academic promise as a criterion for financial aid. If the federal government is to give out additional aid, 66 percent said it should be based on both academic ability and financial need. Twenty percent prefer the current system, which is based solely on financial need, with about half as many, 11 percent, voicing a preference for additional aid being based strictly on academic potential. The survey also found that 75 percent believe significant advancements in the areas of medicine and technology could be accomplished if more people obtained a college education, and 58 percent feel that more college educated adults would dramatically improve society's ablity to solve social problems such as crime, drugs and homelessness. CASE, an international association of colleges, universities, and independent elementary and secondary schools, released the survey as part of National Higher Education Week, which begins Sunday. The margin of error was a plus or minus 4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Police Lift Township Curfew
DOC.TEXT: Police, citing a decline in factional fighting, on Friday lifted a 9 p.m.-4 a.m. curfew imposed Sept. 25 in black townships around Johannesburg. Police Col. Steve van Rooyen said there had been a sharp drop in both political violence and ordinary crime since the curfew went into effect. Almost 800 blacks have died in factional fighting in the past two months, but there have been only scattered incidents in recent weeks. The main combatants have been supporters of the African National Congress and Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement. The ANC and other anti-apartheid groups called the curfew a violation of civil liberties. But many township residents said the measure made life safer in black neighborhoods. Also, police and church leaders agreed to stop pauper's burials of some 300 unclaimed corpses from the recent violence. Some 200 victims already have received such burials, in which the deceased is buried in an unmarked grave by the government. Many of those killed were migrant workers whose families live hundreds of miles away and either did not know of the deaths or could not afford to travel to Johannesburg. In another development, police subpoenaed a journalist to testify about a report in which he alleged police bias in the township fighting. Linden Birns of Business Day, the country's leading financial daily, was ordered to appear in court Oct. 22 to answer questions about his report on police actions of Aug. 13.

DOC.HEAD: Two Dead, Two Injured In Dealership Shooting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with details of shooting, police quote and conditions of injured men. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A man who had come to pick up his last paycheck opened fire at a car dealership today, killing one man and injuring two others before turning the gun on himself, police said. Baltimore County Police Sgt. Steve Doarnberger said the unidentified man fired several shots with a 9mm handgun in the service department, then killed himself at Fox Chevrolet around noon. ``He was working here until Tuesday, when he left with the mutual agreement of the (dealership). He came back today and went into the service bay area ... began to open fire,'' said police spokesman E. Jay Miller. The other dead man was a veteran mechanic, police said. The two injured men - the general manager of the dealership and the service manager - were in critical condition at the University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center, said hospital spokeswoman Rochelle Cohen. Employees at the dealership described the gunman as a friendly co-worker who had worked at the dealership for two years.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
