House Approves Defense Spending Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Leads with House approval
DOC.TEXT: The House today approved a 1991 defense spending bill that makes wholesale cuts in President Bush's budget request for strategic weapons programs. By a vote of 322-97, the House adopted the $268 billion package that stops production of the B-2 bomber at 15 planes and slashes spending on the Strategic Defense Initiative to $2.3 billion. The legislation also reduces the number of U.S. troops by 77,000, cuts production funds for the Pentagon's plan to place MX missiles on railroad cars and restores $403 million for the V-22 Osprey tilt-rotor aircraft. Final passage of the bill, which meets the level of defense spending in the budget resolution approved by Congress last weekend, came after the House turned aside across-the-board cuts in the military.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: `Okies' Name Festival after Book They Once Reviled
DOC.TEXT: An eastern Oklahoma town that once reviled writer John Steinbeck for his portrayal of the region in ``The Grapes of Wrath'' has named a festival after the classic. ``We needed some kind of celebration,'' said Don Elwick, manager of the the Chamber of Commerce in this community of 6,400 people. The Grapes of Wrath festival this weekend will feature souvenir bags of dust and a costume contest for the best-dressed Depression victim. There will also be showings of the movie of the book everyone once hated, though some locals were cast in it. ``We weren't the Dust Bowl,'' insists 84-year-old Pauline Plunkett, who was an extra when ``The Grapes of Wrath'' was filmed in 1939. ``They left the impression that all this area of the country was just poor, non-working, ornery people,'' Ms. Plunkett said. ``That wasn't the way it was.'' When the novel ``The Grapes of Wrath'' was published, Oklahomans of the era generally objected. It was banned in some places. But when the book was made into a movie, Hollywood came to Sallisaw for background shots, including one 23-second scene of cars and trucks loaded down with Oklahomans and their belongings in the exodus to California. Ms. Plunkett said she was on her front porch one day when her husband, Olen, drove up in his pickup and yelled, ``Y'all get your clothes ready.'' ``We just hopped in the pickup like we was,'' she said. The next thing they knew, they were in the movies. As the procession of vehicles reached the end of the road for the shot, the film crew paid passengers through the windows in silver dollars. Some recall getting $2, some $5, some $7 for drivers. It was a lot of money then. ``We had people here working for 50 cents a day and supporting a family,'' said Bill Lovern, who played hooky from high school that day.

DOC.HEAD: Hard Luck Bandit Gets Sat Upon
DOC.TEXT: A robber tried to hold up the Perkins Family Restaurant. It was a mistake. First there was the ex-Marine who manages the place. His response to the holdup was to grab the robber's gun. Then there were the five customers who helped chase the man outside. Finally, there was the humiliating moment when all six of them sat on the hapless suspect. ``I just got out of the Marine Corps so I guess some of that kicked in,'' restaurant manager Don Wilson, 25, explained after Wednesday night's incident. ``It was natural, I guess.'' Police arrested Randall Maestas, who was on probation from an earlier robbery. He was being held in the Jefferson County jail Friday on suspicion of attempted robbery. Authorities said he had a scrape over one eye and back pains.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Lawmakers Softening Opposition to Raising Top Tax Rates
With PM-Budget-Taxes, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUB grafs 19 and 20 to CORRECT poll results; pick up 21st graf pvs, bgng ``But coming''
DOC.TEXT: Republican resistance to raising top income tax rates is splintering as Democrats portray the GOP as the party of the rich. ``It is the world of political dynamics in action,'' said Rep. Steve Gunderson, R-Wis. ``I'm sick and tired of going home to rural Wisconsin and protecting a Republican image as the party of the rich.'' A few months ago, Gunderson, a member of the House GOP leadership, was one of a majority of congressional Republicans who pledged in writing not to change tax rates in any circumstance. Now, he and others favor a major revamp including raising the top tax rate on the rich. Some, like Gunderson, would do it in exchange for a cut in the tax rate on capital gains - profits from the sale of investments - and others as an alternative to proposed levies such as a 12 cent increase in gasoline taxes. The driving force behind the GOP conversions is evidence that after years of trying, Democrats are scoring with their us-vs.-them rhetoric with a public made more receptive by the S&L scandal and a faltering economy. ``It's totally inaccurate and unfair. The Democrats have tried to turn the debate into a class warfare,'' complained Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind. ``There really is no need to try to turn what is already a difficult process into a campaign issue.'' But Democrats are doing just that. Democratic members of the House Ways and Means Committee on Thursday proposed raising income tax rates on the wealthiest Americans from 28 to 33 percent. In addition, people earning more than $1 million annually would pay a 10 percent tax surcharge. The extra revenue would be used to ease the hit on Medicare recipients that was proposed by the bipartisan budget summit with President Bush. ``Democrats today embraced a series of changes to restore fairness to our tax system,'' said committee Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill. The Democratic plan clearly was a political statement, veto bait for the president, an attempt to highlight the issue in the final weeks before the midterm elections. Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., and other Republicans worried there may not be enough time to fight back. ``Once it's shaped that way, it's awfully hard to get people focused back,'' she said. Republicans needed to come forward with a clear position but, she said, ``I think maybe the opportunity for reason has now been lost.'' ``This is a policy squabble that has become a public relations catastrophe,'' said Rep. Fred Grandy, R-Iowa. ``We are in damage control.'' ``I wish we were in a big debate over whether we were going to be freezing spending for a while, instead of raising taxes,'' said Sen. Don Nickles, R-Okla., chairman of the Senate Republican campaign committee. ``For the time being, anyway, we've lost the debate on the spending side.'' ``I think so far the Democrats have been pretty successful in demagoguing the (tax) issue. They're taking advantage of it,'' Nickles said. Nickles said Republicans now might support what he called ``making the tax rates more understandable,'' that is, making the marginal tax rates on the wealthy match those of the upper middle class, but without a net increase in revenue. Democratic presidential nominee Michael Dukakis in 1988 tried but failed to woo voters with his ``I'm on your side'' campaign theme. Last year, congressional Democrats revived the concept in their barely successful blockade of Bush's capital gains tax proposals. But a recent national poll by the Times Mirror Center for People & The Press showed 21 percent of the people think Republicans as ``rich, powerful moneyed interests.'' In a previous poll three years ago, 18 percent made such an association. Earlier, Times Mirror incorrectly reported 51 percent think of Republicans as rich and powerful and blamed a computer error. But coming up with a GOP answer the public can understand is a tall order. House GOP leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., said his ranks were divided. ``There are some who are really worried about the rich man vs. poor man argument (who would) without too much prodding go to 33 percent,'' the Democratic position, he said. Others were still wedded to the capital gains tax cut in line with Bush's 1988 campaign position, which Democrats charge would mean a big break for the super-rich, he said. The confusion over where the president is now isn't helping, some say. ``We don't know what game we're playing. We don't know who's on our team,'' said Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn. ``But we're sure the ball is in play.''

DOC.HEAD: Moscow Man Convicted Of Insulting Jews, Sentenced To Labor Camp
DOC.TEXT: A court on Friday convicted a Russian nationalist of fanning ethnic hostility and insulting Jews in a landmark case that had galvanized fears of anti-Jewish pogroms and fueled a Jewish exodus from the country. American and Soviet Jewish leaders hailed the verdict as the first real sign of a government crackdown on Russian anti-Semitism. A lawyer said it was the first time an accused anti-Semite has been put on trial in Russia. The judge sentenced Konstantin Smirnov-Ostashvili, a 54-year-old factory worker, to two years in a labor camp. ``Everything is taken out of context! It's all a lie!'' the defendant shouted angrily in one of many outbursts during the half-hour session in the packed and heavily guarded Moscow City Court. Smirnov-Ostashvili, a member of the nationalist group Pamyat, has denied being anti-Semitic, but maintains that the Soviet Union's 1.4 million Jews hold a disproportionate number of high places in government and society. He was accused of organizing protesters who broke up a Jan. 18 meeting at the Central House of Literature in Moscow and insulted Jewish writers. The court determined he was drunk at the time. The judge also identified Smirnov-Ostashvili as the protester whom the weekly magazine Ogonyok quoted as shouting at the writers: ``Your time is over. Neither the police, nor the KGB, nor the party will help you. Now we will be masters of the country and you newcomers, clear out and go to Israel. How long can we tolerate your Russophobia?'' It was the first trial under a year-old law passed to quell unrest among the Soviet Union's more than 100 ethnic groups. The law punishes inciting hatred and enmity among ethnic groups. Anti-Semitism dates back centuries in Russia, the nation's largest republic, and has frequently been associated with Russian nationalism, although it also has reared its head in most of the other 14 Soviet republics at various times. Smirnov-Ostashvili brought up his national heritage repeatedly Friday. ``I'm suffering for Russia!'' the defendant shouted as he stood behind a brown wooden partition, guarded by five green-uniformed Interior Ministry soldiers bearing guns and rubber truncheons. He wore a jacket over a blue track suit and shouted and jabbed his fist in the air. Supporters of Smirnov-Ostashvili, some wearing Pamyat buttons, heckled the judge as he read a summary of the case and the verdict. ``How are your friends in Tel Aviv?'' they shouted. Protesters outside held a sign that read, ``The Trial of Ostashvili is a Trial of the Russian People.'' Judge Andrei Muratov said the defendant's diatribe at the writers' meeting was not ``a dialogue or polemics'' but contained ``insulting, demeaning, threatening phrases virtually intended to humiliate the national honor and dignity of citizens of the Jewish origin.'' Smirnov-Ostashvili, the judge said, had tried ``to play one nationality against another ... Russians to Jews, by accusing one nationality of illegal actions in respect of another. He was thus irritating and agitating those present in an attempt to cause hostility, discord and enmity.'' The incident and three-month trial have received wide publicity, and many Soviet Jews have cited the case and other threats from Russian nationalist groups as a factor in their decision to emigrate. A record 18,725 Jews arrived in Israel from the Soviet Union in September, and Soviet Jewish groups have said the numbers will continue to soar because of ``an unprecedented panic among the Jewish population.'' In recent months, anti-Jewish graffiti has appeared on synagogues and the doors of homes where Jews live, and hate-mongers have openly distributed leaflets that borrow from Hitler to condemn the ``Zionist menace.'' Jewish leaders said they saw hope in Friday's court action. ``It has shown that there is new fascism in Russia but it has also shown that Soviet law has been made to work and come to the rescue,'' said Alla Geller, a member of the writers group and a trial spectator. An American specialist on Soviet Jewry agreed. ``It sends a clear message that anti-Semitic acts will not be tolerated and those who continue to engage in them can expect to feel the full weight of the law,'' said Myrna Shinbaum. The director of the New York-based Anti-Defamation League's Soviet Jewry project spoke during a visit to Moscow. Mikhail Chlenov, co-president of Vaad, the Confederation of Jewish Organizations and Communities in the U.S.S.R., called the trial a ``first step'' in the crackdown on anti-Semitism. He said the government should also investigate Pamyat. The court dismissed a charge that Smirnov-Ostashvili beat a writer at the meeting but upheld an accusation that he threatened attacks against Jews. Smirnov-Ostashvili could have received a maximum penalty of five years or a fine of up to $8,950. The verdict and sentence were decided by a judge and two civilian assistants, without a jury.

DOC.HEAD: Hurricane Lili Lashes North Carolina
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 20-21 pvs. beginning `The 11-story ...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with 3 drowning deaths in eastern Georgia. Picks up 22nd graf pvs., `In Brantley ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Lili bore down on North Carolina's Outer Banks with gale-force winds early today, while remnants of Tropical Storm Marco moved in from Florida in a squeeze play that unloaded heavy rain on the South. A hurricane warning was posted for parts of the North Carolina and Virginia coasts, where seas swelled in some areas to 8 feet and some residents and tourists began to flee. Further south, officials declared a state of emergency in Augusta, Ga., where flood waters closed roads and engulfed houses. ``All of our roads are flooded,'' said Pam Smith, director of the Richmond County Emergency Management Agency in Augusta. ``People are trapped in their homes. People are hollering out for help through their windows. Some are on the rooftops. There are people in their cars floating down the road.'' At noon a.m. EDT, Lili was about 400 miles southeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C., moving west at near 18 mph with winds near 75 mph. Earlier, the hurricane brought rain, thunderstorms and wind gusts to Bermuda. It was expected to veer northwest and then north. ``If it's going to hit land, it's going to hit tomorrow morning,'' said Daniel Petersen, meteorologist at the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla. ``But it's definitely too early to say, especially if it turns to the north, then you're paralleling the whole East Coast - and at that point it turns into a high-tech guessing game,'' Petersen said early today. A hurricane warning was in effect from northeast of Topsail Beach, N.C., to Virginia Beach, Va. A hurricane watch was extended from north of Virginia Beach to Cape Henlopen, Del., including Chesapeake Bay, and from Topsail Beach southward to Littl River Inlet, S.C. Remnants of Marco, which brought 65 mph wind and 5 inches of rain to Florida's Gulf Coast on Thursday before it broke up, dumped heavy rain early today in Georgia. Overflowed creeks put roads under 6 feet of water, and more than 40 people were forced to evacuate in eastern Georgia's Richmond County. The storm was expected to move through western North Carolina today. The entire East Coast could see severe weather as the storms converge, forecasters said. ``There's not only Marco, but Hurricane Lili, a cold front ... all converging on the East Coast in the next few days,'' said Bob Sheets, director of the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables, Fla. ``All the weather conditions that these are creating can produce heavy rain over the East Coast and that's of some concern.'' On the Outer Banks, hundreds of Ocracoke Island tourists boarded ferries for the mainland today. ``There've been a lot of campers coming off,'' said Laura Peele, receptionist at the Hatteras-Ocracoke ferry office. ``The people who were staying at the Park Service campground and motels, they're trying to get out.'' Some of the island's 700 year-round residents also were leaving the narrow barrier island. ``My wife and two kids I've sent away,'' said Bob Touhey, owner of Ocracoke's Island Inn. ``I'll board up and put things away.'' Rain from remnants of Tropical Storm Klaus was blamed for at least five deaths Wednesday in the Carolinas and a train derailment that spilled 3,000 gallons of diesel fuel but caused no injuries. Three people, including two children, were killed when they were trapped in a stalled car by a surge of water after a dam collapsed in Kershaw County, S.C. Another child was missing and presumed dead. Two men were killed in traffic accidents in North Carolina. Nearly a foot of rain fell within 24 hours by Thursday in parts of South Carolina. Sumter County received more than 15 inches of rain since Wednesday. ``Rainfall like that does not occur more than once in every 100 years. There are certainly some areas where it was a 100-year event,'' said state climatologist John Purvis. In eastern Georgia, police said flooding caused three drowning deaths. In Columbia County, Guy Keller Dean Jr., 49, of Evans, drowned after he was swept away by flood waters as he tried to leave his car and make his way to higher ground, said Coroner Thomas King. In Jefferson County, a man was killed on Georgia Highway 4 eight miles south of Louisville when when his car hit high water and went out of control. Authorities said another body was discovered on a county road road in Wrens. In Brantley County, Ga., the sheriff's department said a tornado apparently touched down late Thursday night in an area along the Satilla River. Deputy Lamar Depratter said some weekend fishing cabins were damaged, but no injuries were reported. In Augusta, Ms. Smith said emergency officials used boats to evacuate some residents and called for citizens with four-wheel-drive vehicles to assist in rescue efforts. The water pressure blew covers off manholes, and several dive teams were brought in to assist people stranded in the flood waters along the highways, Ms. Smith said. A two-mile stretch of Interstate 20 near Augusta was among the roads that were closed. Public schools in Augusta were closed, as were city and county offices and some businesses. ``We got so much rain, so fast in such a short amount of time,'' Ms. Smith said. ``We've never had anything like this.''

DOC.HEAD: Magazine: U.S. has Plans for Four-Day War to Defeat Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 1 graf after 2nd pvs, ``L'Express said...'' to UPDATE with a no comment from the Pentagon. Pickup 3rd pvs, ``The attack...''
DOC.TEXT: A French news magazine reported today that U.S. military officials have drawn up plans to free Kuwait and defeat Iraq in a four-day offensive that would leave Saddam Hussein's armed forces in ruins. L'Express said it obtained an outline of Operation Night Camel from an unidentified adviser to Defense Secretary Richard Cheney. The weekly is a general news magazine and has one of the largest circulations in France. The Pentagon declined to comment on the report. ``We have nothing for you on that,'' Capt. Sam Grizzle, a Pentagon spokesman, said in Washington. The attack would begin on a moonless November night with an air assault by American warplanes dispatched from Turkey, Saudi Arabia and the aircraft carrier Independence, the magazine said. The planes, including B-52s with cruise missiles, would attempt to destroy Iraq's air power, neutralizing radar systems, bombing missile bases and attacking air bases before Iraqi planes could counterattack, L'Express said. ``By dawn, Iraq has lost all capacity to react,'' it said. ``This first phase would have lasted less than six hours.'' In the second phase, L'Express said, warplanes and missiles would be used to ``annihilate'' Iraq's entire military industrial complex. Targets would include nuclear facilities, chemical weapon depots, arms factories, command bunkers and the main highway to Kuwait. Also during this phase, an air attack would be mounted on Iraqi tank units massed near the border with Saudi Arabia, L'Express said. The magazine said the goal of the third phase would be to cut off links between Kuwait and Iraq. It said U.S. Green Berets and Navy commandos would infiltrate behind Iraqi lines to disrupt communications. Then, it said, the multinational force would launch an offensive along the Iraqi-Kuwait border involving tank-killer planes, combat helicopters and 200 U.S. M-1 tanks. This would be aimed at cutting off the 170,000 Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait from supplies and reinforcements in Iraq. The fourth and final phase, according to L'Express, would be an even larger offensive to reconquer Kuwait. It said 11,000 U.S. Marines would land on Kuwait's north coast, while 45,000 Marines, three mechanized U.S. Army infantry battalions, 4,000 French troops, 6,000 British troops and 50,000 soldiers from the pan-Arab force would cross into Kuwait from the south to ``liberate it meter by meter.'' L'Express said U.S. planners estimated the offensive might cost 20,000 American lives. It gave no estimate for dead of other nations. The magazine said planners had two other reservations - that Iraq might retaliate with chemical weapons, and that it might succeed in wrecking Saudi Arabian oil fields.

DOC.HEAD: Report: U.S. Has Drawn Up Invasion Plan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 11th pvs, ``There was...'' to UPDATE with no comment from the Pentagon on the L'Express report. Pickup 12th, ``The Iraqi...''
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Embassies, Bjt
LaserPhotos NY5,6
DOC.TEXT: A French news magazine reported today the U.S. military has drawn up plans to free Kuwait and defeat Iraq in an attack next month, but a group of Iraqi exiles says Saddam Hussein is already considering withdrawing from Kuwait. In another development, a jetliner carrying 272 evacuees from Kuwait and Iraq, almost all Americans, left London today for the United States, the last leg of the first U.S.-chartered flight from Iraq in nearly three weeks. Also today, Germany and Belgium said their last diplomats have left Kuwait, leaving only the U.S. and three other Western missions open there. In other developments: -Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan was greeted by hoots and catcalls today when he opened a special session of parliament by urging support for his plan to deploy Japan's Self Defense Forces overseas for the first time. Lawmakers are deeply divided over whether to create the force. -Saddam told Iraqi children that President Bush and the U.N. embargo on Iraq have deprived them of milk and sweets, but urged them to do without candy to maintain their pride and dignity. The speech, marking Iraqi Children's Day, was read by an announcer on Baghdad radio and television. -Assailants shot and killed Egypt's parliament speaker, Rifaat el-Mahgoub, outside a Cairo hotel, police and witnesses said. The attack came after Egypt's interior minister warned of possible terrorist reprisals for Egypt's stand against Iraq in the gulf crisis. No one claimed responsibility for the killing. The French news magazine, L'Express, said the plan drawn up by the U.S. military officials calls for a four-day offensive in November that would leave Saddam's armed forces in ruins. L'Express said it obtained an outline of the plan from an unidentified adviser to U.S. Defense Secretary Richard Cheney. U.S. planners estimated the offensive might cost 20,000 American lives, the magazine said. It gave no estimate for dead of other nations. The Pentagon declined to comment on the report. ``We have nothing for you on that,'' Capt. Sam Grizzle, a Pentagon spokesman, said in Washington. The Iraqi opposition group, the Kurdistan Democratic Party-Iraq, said that Iraq is considering withdrawing from Kuwait and that its ruling political party has circulated a questionnaire asking key members for their opinion. The group said President Saddam Hussein might use the survey as a way of justifying a withdrawal from Kuwait. The Kurdistan party said in a news rlease received in Nicosia from its London headquarters that the questionnaire was circulated on Oct. 8 to senior Arab Baath Socialist Party members, cadres and activists. The purported survey could not be independently confirmed. However, the Kurdistan Democratic Party-Iraq is known to have good access to information inside Iraq. And the group was the first source to report on the use of chemical weapons against the Kurdish population in Iraq in 1988. In London, a U.S. Embassy spokeswoman said the chartered Pan Am jetliner plane carrying 272 people left at 1:59 p.m. (9:59 a.m. EDT) and would land at Raleigh-Durham International Airport in North Carolina about 7{ hours later. A group of 321 Americans and other Western evacuees from Iraq landed near London on Thursday in the first such flight in nearly three weeks. State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler said in Washington on Thursday that U.S. officials have received reports that Iraqi authorities are now barring American men 55 years and older from leaving Iraq and Kuwait. She said previous indications were that American males of that age and those under 18 were allowed to leave. Recent State Department estimates indicated more than 600 Americans were stranded in Kuwait and more than 300 in Iraq. Some are being held at strategic Iraqi installations to deter possible attack. In Bonn, Germany, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said the last diplomats in the German Embassy drove from Kuwait to Baghdad on Thursday. ZDF television, a German station, said the group included the ambassador and his wife, along with three embassy staff members. The Foreign Ministry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said they finally left the embassy because of exhausted food supplies. Belgian officials in Brussels said their remaining two diplomats also left for Baghdad on Thursday. That leaves the Americans, British, Canadians and French as the only holdouts among Western missions.

DOC.HEAD: Artworks Stolen From Ranch of Colombian Artist Fernando Botero
DOC.TEXT: Fifteen armed men stole artworks from Colombian artist Fernando Botero's ranch outside Bogota after entering his home intending to kidnap him, the artist said. Botero, 52, was in New York on Thursday when the theft occurred. He said in an interview that he believed the robbers ``went in to my ranch to kidnap me. I will not go back to Colombia as long as the situation of danger in my country persists.'' Botero, a painter and sculptor known for his distinctively rotund figures, said the attackers, ``armed with all types of weapons,'' went in to the ranch at around six in the morning and killed two dogs. The intruders also tied up the family taking care of the ranch, including several children, Botero said. ``They went into a vault after cutting through a 5-inch metal door,'' he said. ``They spent all day doing that.'' The robbers took 17 paintings and three sculptures ``of great sentimental value'' to the artist, he said. Botero did not speculate on who was responsible for the crime and said he had no idea why anyone would want to kidnap him. Botero said his housekeepers were unharmed when neighbors found them the evening of the heist. Colombian federal police were investigating the break-in, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Officer Reprimanded After Suspect's Tooth Displayed as Trophy
DOC.TEXT: An officer was reprimanded after a suspect's tooth, knocked out in a scuffle, was placed on a wall at the police station as a trophy, authorities said. Police Chief Sid Klein reprimanded Sgt. William Goatcher, head of a police tactical unit, on Wednesday for allowing another office to display the tooth in public for two months. The chief said the display exhibited ``a clear lack of sensitivity to the feelings of others.'' Klein cleared unit members of charges they used excessive force in arresting the suspect, Henry Charles Bailey, on July 19. But the chief ordered the unit to attend a sensitivity training session. Bailey is still being held in the Pinellas County jail on charges of selling cocaine and committing battery on a police officer.

DOC.HEAD: Proposed Apartment Project Would Use 38-Year-Old Plans By Frank Lloyd Wright
DOC.TEXT: An architect has proposed building a 12-story luxury apartment tower using plans prepared and then abandoned by Frank Lloyd Wright 38 years ago. Architect Louis Astorino told city officials he wanted to build the trangular tower on the edge of Mount Washington, a cliff overlooking downtown and the Monongahela River. The building would have 12 large apartments, one on each floor, that would cost $1 million to $1.2 million each. It would be built on the site of the closed St. Mary of the Mount High School. City officials have welcomed the plan. ``I think it's an exciting, wonderful thing,'' said City Councilwoman Michelle Madoff. ``People would be living in a work of art.'' Astorino said he would not discuss the project until after presenting the plans to St. Mary's parishioners Sunday. The school was closed because of declining enrollment in June 1982. There were no takers when the 1.3-acre site went on the market for $2 million the following year. Wright, who died in 1959, was considered America's greatest architect by many. There are more than 400 Wright-designed homes in the United States. Wright conceived the project in 1952, calling it ``Point View Residences.'' It was commissioned by Pittsburgh department store magnate Edgar J. Kaufmann. It wasn't built because developers at the time thought Mount Washington lacked the shops and services needed by the building's future residents, according to ``Treasures of Taliesin,'' a 1985 book by Wright archivist Bruce Brooks Pfeiffer. Wright's design calls for a triangular tower that would give each unit terraces and balconies facing in all three directions. The building would have eight stories above street level and four descending Mount Washington's face.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Volunteers Bake 24,000 Cookies for U.S. Troops
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Students and other olunteers whipped up a batch of 24,000 cookies to show U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia that they're not forgotton. The Middletown chapter of the American Business Women's Association organized Thursday's baking project, ``Operation We Care.'' About 60 adult volunteers and a dozen students from a commercial food services class participated. The cookies were baked at the Manchester Technical Center, then bagged and packed in boxes, along with donated items like combs, sunscreen lotion, deodorant, gum and games, and poems and letters written by schoolchildren. Helen Dutch, whose husband, son and son-in-law are all servicemen, originated the We Care project. She said she was moved by the children's letters. ``I have been bawling and bawling. This has been overwhelming,'' Mrs. Dutch said. The boxes will be driven to Mechanicsburg, Pa., then loaded on a military transport for the flight to Saudi Arabia.

DOC.HEAD: Biggest Gas Price Hike Sends Wholesale Prices Soaring
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices soared 1.6 percent in September - an annual rate of more than 20 percent - as gasoline prices shot up at their fastest pace on record, the government said Friday. ``The oil shock is hitting with a vengeance. ... It's just one more jolt to an already fragile economy,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. ``This is the start of the wave of double-digit inflation we will have to suffer through for the next quarter or two because of Iraq,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. ``It's going to propel an economy that's already in recession into a deeper recession.'' While the Labor Department blamed much of the steep increase in wholesale costs one step short of the retail level on costlier petroleum, prices excluding the volatile energy and food areas were still up a worrisome 0.6 percent - twice the August gain. The 20.6 percent rise in the cost of gasoline was the highest one-month increase since the government began tracking the commodity in 1947. At the earliest stage of the production process, crude oil prices rose 20.4 percent, fueling analysts' concern that the higher prices will begin affecting the thousands of plastic, chemical and other products made with petroleum. Oil also shows up in utility costs and figures in prices for products that must be transported long distances. In a separate report, the Commerce Department said retail sales jumped 1.1 percent last month, to a seasonally adjusted $151.2 billion, and were bolstered by the soaring cost of gasoline and a partial recovery in auto sales. Excluding gasoline, sales rose 0.8 percent. Analysts say the combination of higher prices and stronger consumer spending deepens the dilemma for the Federal Reserve, which has been under pressure from the Bush administration to ease its inflation-fighting campaign and lower interest rates to spur the economy. ``How in the world can the Fed ease? The consumer at least hasn't rolled over and inflation is rebelling. The two (reports) give a further reason for the Fed to remain frozen in its current posture,'' Dederick said. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``Inflation going up is never good news.'' He declined to criticize the Federal Reserve's apparent tight monetary policy. ``We still are concerned about growth and about preventing a recession. We think the Fed has recognized all these factors and is on the right course,'' Fitzwater said. September's 1.6 percent rise in wholesale prices would translate into an annual increase of 20.9 percent if prices rose at the same pace for 12 straight months, the government said. Before Iraq occupied Kuwait Aug. 2, wholesale prices were rising at an annual rate of just 3 percent. But with the August and September increases figured in, wholesale inflation has increased at an annual rate of 6.3 percent so far in 1990, the government said. Last month's rise in the Producer Price Index for finished goods followed a 1.3 percent increase in August, also caused by higher energy costs brought on by the gulf crisis. It was the biggest two-month jump in wholesale prices since 1980, the government said. Prices at earlier stages of the production process were up sharply, too. Crude-goods costs jumped 4.6 percent while intermediate-goods prices rose 1.8 percent. An example of the three processing stages would be cotton at the crude-goods level, cloth at the intermediate-goods level and clothing at the finished-goods level. At the finished-goods level: -Energy costs overall rose 13.8 percent. Fuel oil prices rose 21.3 percent. Natural gas costs were up 1.3 percent. -Food prices were down 0.9 percent after rising 0.8 percent in August. -Passenger car prices were up a sharp 3.4 percent after rising 0.8 percent. The Consumer Price Index, which measures the prices of goods and services at the retail level, is due out next week. The various changes put the Producer Price Index for all finished goods at 120.3 in September. That means a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 would have cost $120.30 last month, up from $113.60 a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Wilson Has Narrow Lead in Poll
DOC.TEXT: Republican Sen. Pete Wilson holds a narrow lead of 47 percent to 42 percent over Democrat Dianne Feinstein in the race for governor, according to a California Poll published Friday. Although the results were too close to declare Wilson a clear leader, the survey respondents by a 2-1 margin said they expected the Republican nominee to win the Nov. 6 election. Asked who they expected to win, regardless of their personal preference, 55 percent named Wilson and 27 percent said Feinstein, said pollster Mervin Field. ``Wilson voters are supremely confident that he will be elected. While a plurality of Feinstein voters believe she will be California's next governor, their confidence level is not as high,'' Field said. Some 1,021 voters were surveyed by telephone in the Oct. 3-10 poll, which had a margin of error of 3.2 percentage points. Seven percent were undecided, and 4 percent favored minor party candidates. Wilson had leads of 45 percent to 42 percent in an August survey and 45 percent to 40 percent in a June survey. In the latest survey, Wilson was leading by 49 percent to 41 percent among men and by 46 percent to 44 percent among women. The survey found Wilson leading by a 50-39 margin in Southern California while Feinstein led by a 48-43 margin in Northern California.
DOC.HEAD: Court Refuses to Reinstate California Campaign Limits
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Friday refused to reinstate campaign-contribution limits for California's gubernatorial election and other political contests in that state next month. The court, without comment or recorded dissent, let stand a federal judge's ruling that threw out contribution limits imposed by California voters in Proposition 73 two years ago. The judge's ruling lets candidates for governor, other statewide posts and some local offices accept contributions greater than the limits created in 1988. U.S. District Judge Lawrence Karlton ruled on Sept. 25 that the limits gave an unfair advantage to incumbents. Karlton also tossed out a ban on transfers of funds between candidates. Prop 73 barred anyone from contributing more than $1,000 to a particular candidate in a fiscal year. The measure also limited political action committee donations to $2,500 or $5,000 per candidate for each fiscal year, depending on the size of the committee. Wilson, who had only token opposition in the June primary, raised $12.5 million through June and had $3.9 million in the bank as of July 1. Feinstein raised $8.1 million through June but had just $645,344 left over from her victorious primary campaign against state Attorney General John Van de Kamp. The contribution limits were challenged by the Democratic Party and labor unions, which said Proposition 73 unfairly interfered with free-speech rights and the freedom of association.
DOC.HEAD: Close Race in Alaska
DOC.TEXT: Republican Arliss Sturgulewski and Democra Tony Knowles are running virtually even in the governor's race, with third-party candidate Wally Hickel close behind, according to a statewide poll. The poll, commissioned for the Anchorage Daily News and Anchorage radio station KENI, showed 34 percent of the respondents favored Sturgulewski, 29 percent backed Knowles and 25 percent preferred Hickel. The percentage spreads between Sturgulewski and Knowles and between Knowles and Hickel were within the survey's 5 percentage point margin of error. The random telephone survey of 525 Alaskans was conducted Monday through Wednesday by Dittman Research Corp. of Alaska. The survey showed sharp differences in candidate preferences based on sex and region. Sturgulewski was favored by 40 percent of the women surveyed, but only 28 percent of the men. Hickel had more support among men than women and Knowles had equal support among the sexes. Knowles, whose running mate is Native leader Willie Hensley, was preferred by just over half the voters in rural Alaska. Hickel led in Fairbanks and the Interior, where he was the choice of just under half the voters. Sturgulewski, a state senator from Anchorage running with businessman Jim Campbell, has the strongest support in Southeast Alaska and Anchorage, the poll indicates.
