DOC.HEAD: Iranian Nabbed on Palace Lawn With Gift for Princess Diana
DOC.TEXT: An Iranian trying to give Princess Diana a silver clock because he admired her climbed over two fences and through rose bushes before being nabbed on the lawn of her Kensington Palace home, police said Friday. The princess was home at the time of Ali Kashabi's entry into the grounds of the palace shortly before midnight Thursday but was ``not disturbed'' by the incident, said a Buckingham Palace spokeswoman. Kashabi said it was the second time he had been arrested in the Kensington Palace area in as many days. He said he was arrested for drunkenness on Wednesday night but was released. Kashabi told Horseferry Magistrate's Court that he decided to give Princess Diana the silver clock after writing several letters to her but receiving no reply. ``I just wanted to see Lady Diana. I think that she is a very beautiful lady and I admire her,'' he said. ``They told me I was lucky that I wasn't shot. ... It was a frightening experience.'' Police said Kashabi, who gave his address only as California, was caught on the palace lawn after scaling two fences and walking through some rose bushes. He pleaded guilty to breaching the peace and was told to keep out of trouble for a year or he would be fined $200. He was not, however, fined Friday or given a jail sentence. The incident occurred despite the spending of millions of dollars on security at royal palaces after a man broke into Queen Elizabeth II's bedroom at Buckingham Palace in 1982 and sat on her bed chatting with her for more than a half-hour. Since then, other security breaches have occurred, including in February 1987 when a masked man with a hammer and a knife was arrested after a violent struggle close to the private grounds of Kensington Palace. Kensington Palace in west London is home to 14 other members of the royal family, including Queen Elizabeth's sister Princess Margaret.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Indian Demonstrators Would Fast to Mark Columbus' Discovery
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators at the Capitol marked Friday's anniversary of Columbus' discovery of the New World by beginning a fast to protest what they said were violations of Indian rights. A group called Fast for Big Mountain said six people would engage in a water-only fast on the Capitol steps until Nov. 22, Thanksgiving Day. With the 150 demonstrators were four Indians beating a drum. ``Columbus, and the conquistadors who followed him, invaded this hemisphere and exploited, oppressed and killed the original people here,'' their statement began. ``Nearly 500 years later descendants of these indigenous inhabitants are still being exploited, oppressed and killed by descendants of the invaders.'' Columbus first sighted American land on Oct. 12, 1492. In this country the anniversary was celebrated last Monday. The demonstrators cited particularly displacement of Indians on Big Mountain in Arizona, which they said would help a mining operation owned by a British firm. Ron Greenfield, vice-president of Peabody Holding Co., said in an interview that the company has had mines in the Black Mesa area since the 1970s and does not plan an expansion. Ninety percent of its 870 employees at the mines are Indian, he added. Peabody is America's biggest coal mining operation, producing 86.7 million tons last year. It was bought in July by Hanson Industries, the U.S. subsidiary of a British company.

DOC.HEAD: Search for Extraterrestrials Expands to Southern Skies
LaserPhoto LA3
DOC.TEXT: The search for alien civilizations in space expanded to cover the entire sky as a new radio receiver started running in Argentina on Friday, the anniversary of Columbus' discovery of the new world. ``Today represents the opening up of half of the universe to the search by the human species for extraterrestrial intelligence,'' said astronomer Carl Sagan, president of the Planetary Society. ``You have to be made of wood not to be interested in knowing whether we're alone in the universe,'' Sagan said by phone from Ithaca, N.Y., where he is a professor at Cornell University. ``Here we are for the first time in human history when it's technically possible to find out. And it's very cheap. ``Wouldn't we be ashamed of ourselves if the answer was there for the taking and we were too shy to look?'' The Pasadena-based Planetary Society, which advocates space exploration, financed the supercomputer-controlled radio receiver and signal analyzer with $150,000 raised from its 125,000 members in more than 100 nations. The 8.4-million-channel receiver, about the size of two large refrigerators, is called Megachannel Extraterrestrial Assay II, or META II. It is located at Argentina's Institute of Radioastronomy, 30 miles southeast of Buenos Aires. It is identical to META I at Harvard University's Oak Ridge Observatory in Massachusetts. Since 1985, that receiver has listened to Northern Hemisphere skies for signals from aliens. Steven Spielberg, who directed the films ``E.T., the Extra-Terrestrial'' and ``Close Encounters of the Third Kind,'' donated $100,000 for META I. The META project is the world's most powerful operating search for alien radio signals, although nothing has been heard so far. About 100 people watched as the institute's director, Raul Colomb, pointed one of the institute's 98-foot-wide radiotelescope dish antennas toward the Southern Cross, a major Southern Hemisphere constellation, as the receiver was switched on Friday morning. The new receiver is capable of listening to the heart of our Milky Way galaxy. If either receiver ever detects radio signals intentionally sent by aliens, it means ``that it's not inevitable civilizations in their technological adolescence destroy themselves,'' Sagan said. The United States celebrated Columbus Day on Monday, but Friday was the anniversary of Christopher Columbus' arrival in North America from Spain on Oct. 12, 1492. Sagan, who was host of the popular public television series ``Cosmos,'' said discovery of extraterrestrials ``would be still more powerful and significant and historical. It would be a turning point in the history of civilization. Every field of human endeavor will gain something. ``The development of technical civilization is likely to happen on countless other worlds,'' Sagan said. Our galaxy alone contains 400 billion stars, evidence suggests many have planets, and studies show carbon - the basis of life - is abundant in space, he said. More than 50 limited searches for extraterrestrial intelligence have been conducted since the 1960s. Almost all previous efforts listened for radio signals above Earth's Northern Hemisphere, with only brief searches of southern skies. The META receivers, designed by Harvard's Paul Horowitz, listen to radio frequencies around what scientists call the ``water hole.'' They are frequencies emitted naturally by the breakdown products of water: hydrogen, the most abundant element in the universe, and hydroxyl, made of one oxygen and one hydrogen atom. Water has one oxygen and two hydrogen atoms. Astronomers believe that like animals gathering to drink, intelligent aliens would pick the ``water hole'' as a way to contact other civilizations.

DOC.HEAD: Consumer Commission Moves To Ban Baby Bean Bags
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS phone number in 7th graf, Recall instructions
DOC.TEXT: The Consumer Product Safety Commission said Friday it has taken the first step to ban infant ``bean bag'' cushions because of 30 reported cases of babies found dead on them. The commission voted Thursday to publish a notice of proposed rule making in which it will seek public comments to help it develop an accurate definition of the product. The cushions are filled with plastic foam beads or other granular material that can conform to the body of an infant, especially to the face, when the infant is placed stomach-downward. They have been promoted as resting or sleeping places for infants or devices to prop them upright, but in at least 30 cases have led to death through suffocation. The commission announced earlier this year an agreement with all known manufacturers of the cushions to recall them and not produce any more. The recalls, covering about a million cushions, are still in effect. Consumers who have not already returned their infant cushions should stop using them, return to the store or destroy them, the commission said. Recall instructions can be obtained from a toll-free telephone number, 1-800-638-2772. Most manufacturers have offered refunds. Commenting on the commission's vote, Chairman Jacqueline Jones-Smith said, ``Although production of infant cushions has stopped, we need to prevent any future production of this product in order to prevent more deaths.''

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaitis Gather For Talks On Future
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Kuwaitis representing all walks of life began gathering here Friday for a conference on their country's current plight and its future. The exiled emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah, will address the three-day Kuwaiti People's Conference, which begins Saturday. His Kuwaiti critics hope the royal family will loosen its hold on the emirate's financial and political institutions if it regains control. The emir has called for a new social covenant between the al-Sabah family and Kuwait's citizens. The debate has raised questions about the mandate of other gulf rulers, benevolent despots who so far have rejected a multiparty system and participatory democracy as destablilizing influences. The Iraqi invasion and the popular support Saddam has garnered in parts of the Arab world have demonstrated the vulnerability of all the gulf states to destabilizaion by revolutionary populist forces. The Kuwaiti participants at the Jiddah conference include former ministers, parliamentarians, diplomats, businessmen, judges, civil servants, journalists and representatives of public and private organizations. Among them are expected to be members of opposition groups, who had been campaigning for the restoration of Kuwait's Western-style parliament even before the Aug. 2 invasion. The opposition figures insisted even then that they still were loyal to the emir. In statements over the last few weeks, they have maintained that line. Some even say they have dropped their opposition. The conference's first session in Jiddah, the Saudi summer capital, is expected to deal with ways to intensify the opposition to Saddam's invasion and annexation. Conference members also are expected to reject any Iraqi attempt to include a national referendum on Kuwait's future as part of a political solution to the gulf crisis. ``The very presence of this large number of Kuwaitis is in itself a pledge of allegiance for the rule of al-Sabah family and Sheik Jaber,'' said Abdul-Rahman al-Awadi, minister for Cabinet affairs. ``The conference will expose the brutal Iraqi practices against our people inside Kuwait,'' al-Awadi said.

DOC.HEAD: New Name, Symbol Possible for Italy's Communists
DOC.TEXT: Italy's Communist leader, under fire for suggesting the party change its name and symbol, on Friday proposed a referendum on his ideas. Achille Occhetto said if he lost, he would resign as head of the West's largest Communist party and the second biggest political party in Italy after the Christian Democrats. Two days earlier, Occhetto suggested the party drop ``Communist'' and call itself the Democratic Party of the Left. Old-guard Communists, who have the support of about one-third of the party members, accused Occhetto of trying to split the Communists. The name-change proposal follows the collapse of communist regimes throughout Eastern Europe and is aimed at increasing the party's vote totals, which have been sliding in recent years. Occhetto also wants to shrink the party symbol of hammer, sickle and star and put it at the base of a tree symbolizing liberty, strong roots and love of nature.

DOC.HEAD: Mamaloni Forms New Government in Solomon Islands
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Solomon Mamaloni resigned Friday from this Pacific archipelago's ruling People's Alliance Party and said he was forming a new government with members of the opposition. However, the opposition leader said his party would not accept any appointments to the new Cabinet for this island kingdom of about 290,000 residents. Rank-and-file members of the Alliance Party had been scheduled to consider a motion of no-confidence in Mamaloni for his role as parliamentary leader at their annual convention next Saturday. Mamaloni announced the surprise move in a statement. He said he sacked five Cabinet ministers, including his deputy, and replaced them with opposition members. He also reshuffled the rest of the Cabinet. The new ministers will be sworn in Monday, he said. ``The new government, which is a government for national unity, is based on proportionate representation of the nation's scattered provinces - including the capital, Honiara - in terms of population and resources,'' Mamaloni said. He said the new government would ``be guided by the principles of political reconciliation, national reconstruction and policy redirection.'' But opposition leader Andrew Nori said that naming opposition members to a Mamaloni-led government was out of the question. ``The national parliamentary opposition is holding an urgent meeting in Honiara tomorrow to disassociate itself from any moves by the prime minister to form a government,'' Nori said. The Solomon Islands, discovered in 1568, gained independence in 1978 but remains a member of the British Commonwealth.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Defeats Proposal Allowing States To Close Borders To Garbage
DOC.TEXT: New Jersey can breath freely again. It can still ship its garbage to Indiana. A proposal that would have allowed states to close their borders to other states' garbage was killed in House-Senate negotiations Friday. The garbage fight has pitted New Jersey lawmakers against those from Indiana, but the issue had far broader ramifications. By some estimates, as many as two-thirds of the states ship garbage beyond their borders because of landfill shortages. Last month the Senate by a 68-31 vote tacked the interstate garbage shipment prohibition onto an appropriations bill for the District of Columbia. But members of a House-Senate conference committee removed the provision on Friday. The House never enacted a similar measure. ``This is a big win for New Jersey,'' said Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., who had led the fight against the measure sponsored by Sen. Dan Coats, R-Ind. Coats characterized the issue as one giving ``every state the right to determine its own destiny'' in managing and disposing trash. ``We lost the battle but believe ultimately we will win the war,'' Coats said through a spokesman. Coats, who has made the garbage issue a key part of his re-election bid, promised to renew the fight in the next Congress if re-elected. Indiana is among the recipients of a rising tide of out-of-state garbage. Coats' measure would have allowed states to block garbage imports or impose high fees on such shipments. Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., said Coats' proposal was an ``attack'' on New Jersey. He and Lautenberg argued that states must be able to send garbage elsewhere until they can develop environmentally safe and reasonably priced alternatives including more incentives for recycling. New Jersey, which now sends about half its garbage out of state, hopes to ease its garbage problems in the future by reaching a goal of 60 percent recycling. Rep. Dean Gallo, R-N.J., who was a member of the conference committee considering the bill that included the garbage measure, said House members opposed it because the issue had not been thoroughly debated in the House. Senate negotiators agreed to withdraw the provision after only three of the six senators at the conference said they would support it.

DOC.HEAD: Arab League to Hold Session on Temple Mount Clash
DOC.TEXT: The Arab League will meet next week to discuss a response to the clash on Jerusalem's Temple Mount in which at least 19 Palestinians were slain by Israeli police, league sources said Friday. The Palestine Liberation Organization requested the meeting in the hope Arab countries will issue a joint protest against Monday's slayings, said the sources, speaking on condition of anonymity. The sources said a quorum of 11 members of the 21-member league had agreed to attend the meeting Wednesday, but refused to identify them. Arab diplomatic sources named nine members who agreed to the meeting, including the PLO, Iraq, Jordan, Sudan, Yemen, Algeria, Tunisia, Mauritania and Morocco. It was not known whether the members will be represented by their foreign ministers or their permanent delegates to the league headquarters in Tunis. The diplomatic sources noted most of the Arab countries aligned against Iraq in the Persian Gulf crisis - including Egypt, Syria and Saudi Arabia - have not yet responded to the PLO's request for a meeting. The gulf crisis has caused a deep split within the league's ranks. The PLO has sided with Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, whose forces invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat urged Arab countries on Wednesday to ``make a common front against the butchery against Palestinians by the forces of Zionist occupation,'' referring to Israel. The PLO's 90-member central committee ended three days of talks Thursday with a demand that the United Nations take measures to guarantee the protection of Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, PLO spokesman Yasser Abd Rabbo said. The PLO and the United States have been at odds over the contents of a U.N. Security Council resolution condemning Israel for the Temple Mount slayings. The United States has tried to limit the mandate of any U.N. team sent to investigate the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Reiterates Refusal to Release Documents
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh on Friday stuck by his decision to block the release of government secrets that had scuttled the Iran-Contra trial of former CIA agent Joseph Fernandz. The Justice Department's announcement drew a stinging response from the Iran-Contra special prosecutor. Independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh said the dismissal of charges against former CIA agent Joseph Fernandez was forced by an ``overprotective attitude toward classified information.'' ``No matter how the administration rationalizes the nonproduction of this information, it shows a lack of concern for applying the rule of law to officials of the intelligence community,'' Walsh said. He said the administration's stance ``will form the basis for an important part of our final report'' to Congress on the Iran-Contra investigation. Fernandez, former CIA station chief in Costa Rica, was accused of lying to the presidential commission that investigated the Iran-Contra affair and CIA superiors about his role in helping ship arms to the Nicaraguan rebels. Fernandez was accused of lying about the purpose of an airstrip he helped build in Costa Rica that was used by a covert resupply operation set up by White House aide Oliver L. North. A federal judge in Alexandria, Va., last year ruled that Fernandez was entitled to disclose secrets about CIA operations in Central America to show it was deeply involved in the covert resupply effort. U.S. District Judge Claude M. Hilton dismissed the charges against Fernandez after Thornburgh filed an affidavit under the Classified Information Procedures Act that barred the use of the secret evidence. In September, the 4th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Richmond, Va., upheld Hilton's determination that Fernandez was entitled to disclose the secrets at issue during his trial. Thornburgh reviewed his original decision. On Friday, the Justice Department notified Hilton in a letter that Thornburgh would still not allow the secrets to be released at trial. Under CIPA, Hilton's dismissal order does not become final until the attorney general reaffirms his decision to block the release of secrets. The letter by Justice Department attorney James S. Reynolds said Thornburgh's review included a meeting with heads of government agencies responsible for protecting national security. These officials unanimously urged Thornburgh not to withdraw his affidavit, Reynolds said. ``The potentially serious damage to national security which could result from the disclosure of the two categories of information is exacerbated by the prospect for additional disclosures at trial,'' Reynolds wrote. ``One senior official described the potential harm which could result as `devastating.'''

DOC.HEAD: Magazine: U.S. Has Plans For Four-Day War to Defeat Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to ADD background on Dugan, other Pentagon officials saying a U.S. attack would be heavily reliant on air power. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A news magazine reported Friday that U.S. military officials have made plans to defeat Iraq and liberate Kuwait in a four-day offensive that would destroy Saddam Hussein's armed forces. L'Express, a weekly news magazine with one of the largest circulations in France, said it obtained an outline of the plan from an unidentified adviser to Defense Secretary Richard Cheney. It said U.S. planners estimated the offensive, heavily dependent on air power, might cost 20,000 American lives. It gave no estimate for dead of other nations. It said the offensive was to be launched in November by American warplanes from Turkey, Saudi Arabia and the aircraft carrier Independence. The magazine made no mention of the thousands of Western hostages held in Iraq and Kuwait at strategic sites. A Pentagon spokesman declined comment. ``We have nothing for you on that,'' said Capt. Sam Grizzle, a Pentagon spokesman. Pentagon officials previously have said they would rely on air power in any attack on Iraq. Air Force Gen. Mike Dugan was fired in September for public comments about U.S. plans for heavy bombing in Baghdad that would specifically target Saddam and his family. The head of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Colin L. Powell, and Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia, have said that air power is the only way to defeat Iraqi forces without overwhelming casualties. L'Express said that aside from the high casualties, planners had two other reservations - that Iraq might retaliate with chemical weapons, and that Baghdad might succeed in wrecking Saudi Arabian oil fields. The so-called Operation Night Camel would begin on a November night with an air assault by the American warplanes, including B-52s with cruise missiles, the magazine said. The planes would aim to destroy Iraq's air power before Iraqi planes could counterattack. Radar systems would be neutralized, missile bases bombed and air bases attacked, L'Express said. The magazine said this first phase would last less than six hours. ``By dawn, Iraq has lost all capacity to react,'' it said. In the second phase, warplanes and missiles would be used to ``annihilate'' Iraq's entire military industrial complex, L'Express said. Targets would include nuclear facilities, chemical weapon depots, arms factories, command bunkers and the main highway to Kuwait. An air attack would also be mounted on Iraqi tank units massed near the border with Saudi Arabia in the second phase, L'Express said. In the third phase, the goal would be to cut off links between Kuwait and Iraq, the magazine said. U.S. Green Berets and Navy commandos would infiltrate behind Iraqi lines to disrupt communications. The multinational force would then launch an offensive along the Iraqi-Kuwait border involving tank-killer planes, combat helicopters and 200 U.S. M-1 tanks to cut off the 170,000 Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait from supplies and reinforcements, the magazine said. In the fourth and final phase, there would be an even larger offensive to reconquer Kuwait, L'Express said. The magazine said 11,000 U.S. Marines would land on Kuwait's north coast. At the same time, 45,000 Marines, three mechanized U.S. infantry battalions, 4,000 French troops, 6,000 British troops and 50,000 soldiers from the pan-Arab force would cross into Kuwait from the south to ``liberate it meter by meter.''

DOC.HEAD: Enema Kits Recalled
DOC.TEXT: The major maker of barium enema kits is recalling some products because they may be linked to severe reactions, including nine deaths, from the common medical procedure, federal officials said Friday. E-Z-EM Inc. of Westbury, N.Y., sent recall notices to customers a week ago, saying evidence suggests water-soluble proteins in inflatable latex cuffs on the enema tips may be triggering the reactions. The FDA has received 150 reports of allergic reactions related to barium enema procedures in 1989 and 1990, said FDA spokeswoman Susan Cruzan. In nine cases, the patient died, she said. The company makes 85 percent to 90 percent of the kits, which are used to diagnose disorders of the intestines. About 8 million to 10 million barium enemas are performed annually, Cruzan said. The reports have been related to the company's enema kits with inflatable latex cuffs. Company officials did not return a telephone call for comment. In light of the reports, the FDA asked radiologists and other health professionals to report any adverse reactions related to barium enema procedures that have occurred in the past 12 months. ``FDA is particularly concerned because some of these allergic reactions have been fatal and occurred within minutes of beginning the procedures,'' the agency said in its October issue of FDA Drug Bulletin, a publication sent to physicians. The procedure involves injecting a barium-containing fluid into the rectum and colon, which enables these organs to show up on an X-ray. In some cases, the reactions occurred after the enema tip had been inserted, but before the barium had been introduced, the FDA said. The FDA said the cause of the problem is still unclear.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Erupts at Chevron Chemical Plant East of Houston
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with fire extinguished; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Fire erupted Friday afternoon at a Chevron Chemical Co. plant, sending flames shooting 100 feet in the air. No one was hurt and the fire was extinguished within two hours, authorities said. The blaze began shortly before 1:30 p.m. in one section at Chevron's Cedar Bayou Chemical Plant, said spokesman Clay Hooper. A Chevron fire brigade at the plant extinguished it by 3:30 p.m. Cedar Bayou is a small community near Baytown. The towns are about 30 miles east of Houston. The fire broke out in a unit of the plant that uses ethylene to make an additive for detergents, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Students in Lyon Call Germany `Enemy,' Occupy Language School
DOC.TEXT: About 12 right-wing extremist students occupied a German cultural center on Friday in a protest against what they called France's ``hereditary enemy.'' The students, members of the neo-royalist Action Francaise, staged a sit-in for about one hour at the local chapter of the Goethe Institute language school and cultural center. ``We intend to open up French eyes about the unification of Germany, which was too rapid,'' the students said in a statement. ``Germany is the hereditary enemy of France.'' No violence was reported by the students, most of whom are studying medicine. Officials of the Goethe Institute were unavailable for comment. East and West Germany unified Oct. 3, less than a year after the fall of the Berlin Wall, to become the richest and most heavily populated nation in Western Europe with about 78 million people. Repeated polls have shown overwhelming numbers of French citizens welcome the unification, despite having gone to war with Germany twice this century.

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Talks of War if Sanctions on Iraq Fail
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, winding up her Conservative Party's annual conference Friday, told Britain to prepare for war if sanctions fail in the Persian Gulf crisis. ``We must hope they (sanctions) work. If not, the military option is there. . . . We must be ready for any contingency,'' she said, signalling increasing British impatience at the standoff. Delegates cheered as Mrs. Thatcher spelled out a tough line on Iraq in her 45-minute keynote address at the end of the four-day conference in this south England resort. She painted Britain as America's No. 1 ally in the gulf, rejected plans for economic integration of the European Community, and attacked the revamped Labor Party as hard-line socialists masquerading as ``a party of moderation.'' The hall resounded with applause as the prime minister, who turns 65 Saturday, threaded her way through 5,000 delegates who waved Union Jacks and sang the favorite Tory anthem, ``Land of Hope and Glory.'' But the party remains in trouble, heavily dependent on her promises that inflation, which edged up to 10.9 percent Friday, will fall sharply next year. Labor is posing its biggest threat since Mrs. Thatcher won power 11 years ago. The Conservatives have narrowed a yearlong lag in opinion polls, but Labor remains 8 to 14 points ahead. The conference appeared short on new ideas for a party that may fight an election before its next meeting. The weekly Economist, which generally supports the Tories, commented Friday, ``For a party used to wallowing in victory and self-congratulation, it was a strangely glum affair.'' On Iraq, Mrs. Thatcher said President Saddam Hussein must face war crime charges, pay reparation for the devastation of Kuwait and be stripped of power to invade again. ``This tyrant has taken our people hostage,'' she said. ``You get him out, make him pay and see that he is never in a position to do these things again.'' On Thursday, her foreign secretary, Douglas Hurd, urged an assessment within weeks to determine if sanctions are working or if only force can end Saddam's Aug. 2 invasion on Iraq. Mrs. Thatcher praised President Bush, adding, ``When the call came to send forces to the gulf, it was independent nations - above all the United States and Britain - which took rapid and decisive action.'' On Britain's relations with the rest of the 12-nation European Community - the issue that divides her party and Cabinet - she said she will fight plans for a single currency despite linking the pound this week to Europe's other major currencies. Sterling joined the community's exchange rate mechanism. She is gambling that inflation will fall as a spinoff of stabilizing the pound against the strong German mark, combined with the past two years of high British interest rates. Low inflation would enable her to cut interest rates and put the government in better shape to call an election next year. Mrs. Thatcher's third five-year term expires in June 1992.

DOC.HEAD: Renegade Insurgents Step Up Attacks On Kabul
DOC.TEXT: Moslem fundamentalists have stepped up attacks on the Afghan capital and are poised for a major assault to bring down the Communist government, sources said Friday. More moderate guerrilla leaders predicted the attack would accomplish nothing except massive bloodshed and have begun to map out plans to stop them. ``It will be a massacre,'' said one rebel leader, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said he feared his outspokenness would be punished with reduced arms shipments to his fighters. There had been a period of relative calm in Kabul, the Afghan capital, until the fundamentalist guerrillas stepped up attacks. The government's well-equipped army and air force have responded with air and artillery strikes, diplomatic and guerrilla sources said. At least 60 people have been killed and scores more injured in two weeks of heavy fighting. There were reports that government troops had decimated two guerrilla columns marching toward the capital. Those reports could not be independently confirmed. ``We're attacking all the time but the time has not been set yet for the big offensive,'' said Hamid, a guerrilla spokesman who, like many Afghans, uses only one name. According to the sources, Gulbuddin Hekmatyar, the most radical and anti-Western of U.S.-backed guerrilla leaders, has been chosen to lead the major assault on the capital of 1.5 million. For more than 12 years, Pakistan's powerful intelligence agency has been a conduit for U.S. military aid to the guerrillas, who are fighting to unseat successive Communist governments in their neighboring homeland. Rumors have been circulating in this dusty border city for weeks that Hekmatyar and Shah Nawaz Tanai, the former defense minister of Afghanistan who defected to the guerrillas in March, were planning another coup attempt. Tanai orchestrated a failed coup last March that left hundreds dead, destroyed sections of the capital and severely handicapped Afghanistan's air force before forces loyal to President Najibullah crushed the mutineers. Afghan and Pakistani sources say arms shipments to Hekmatyar have risen dramatically since Benazir Bhutto's government was ousted on Aug. 6 and replaced by her right-wing opponents. Ms. Bhutto reportedly sought a reduced role for the firebrand Moslem rebel leader. ``For months he was getting very little. Now he is getting everything,'' said another guerrilla spokesman Abdul Wakeel. Soviet troops sent to Afghanistan backed up Najibullah's government until they withdrew from Afghanistan in February 1989. The guerrillas had presented a unified front until then, but the alliance has gradually disintegrated. Several key commanders, including Haq and Ahmed Shah Masood - considered the most effective rebel leader - met Friday to map out a strategy to stop Hekmatyar and find an acceptable political alternative to Najibullah. Moscow and Washignton are reportedly close to an agreement that calls for elections, overseen by a transitional government that includes neither Najibullah nor the guerrilla leadership.

DOC.HEAD: Persian Gulf Crisis at a Glance
DOC.TEXT:
Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:
Gunmen in Cairo killed the parliament speaker and three security men outside a hotel. There was no claim of responsibility. The attack came after the government warned that terrorists might strike to punish Egypt for its opposition to Iraq. --- A Shiite Moslem gunman fired at Christian Gen. Michel Aoun as he addressed thousands of supporters, but the bullet missed the general and wounded one of his aides, Aoun's radio station said. The assassination attempt came shortly after the Syrian army moved thousands of troops toward the enclave for an expected attack on the headquarters of Aoun, who has resisted orders by Lebanon's government to step down. --- U.S. forces in the Persian Gulf area now total more than 200,000, including elements of two armored cavalry units that arrived this week, Pentagon sources said Friday. The sources also said a Marine amphibious force is planning a practice assault on the Arabian coast soon as a trial run for a possible U.S. invasion of Kuwait. --- The French magazine L'Express reported that U.S. military officials have drawn up plans to free Kuwait and defeat Iraq in a four-day war in November that would destroy Saddam's armed forces. L'Express said U.S. planners estimated the offensive might cost 20,000 American lives. It gave no estimate for dead of other nations. L'Express said it obtained an outline of the plan from an unidentified adviser to Defense Secretary Cheney. U.S. officials refused to comment, in line with Pentagon security rules. --- Western diplomatic defiance of Iraq's seizure of Kuwait weakened Friday when Germany and Belgium announced that their last envoys had left the occupied nation. In Bonn, a spokesman said the last diplomats, including the ambassador and his wife, in the German Embassy drove from Kuwait to Baghdad on Thursday. Belgian officials in Brussels said their remaining two diplomats also left for Baghdad Thursday. --- Members of Japan's deeply divided parliament hooted at Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu when he opened a special session by asking for support for his plan to deploy armed forces overseas. Japan has not sent forces overseas since World War II. --- Iraq said it may stop Soviet detainees from returning home if they have knowledge of Iraqi weapons systems. The evacuation began Sunday and Iraq has promised to let at least 2,000 Soviets leave. --- An Iraqi opposition party-in-exile said the Iraqi ruling Arab Baath Socialist Party has circulated a questionnaire asking prominent members whether they believe Iraq should pull out. The claim by the Kurdistan Democratic Party-Iraq could not be independently confirmed. If true, it would represent an unprecedented quest for consensus by Saddam Hussein.

DOC.HEAD: Curfews, Roadblocks and Water Cannons Keep Arabs from Prayer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with additional quotes from Israeli officials, Army comment on deaths. Picks up 14th graf pvs, `Monday's rioting..
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JRL5,6,9,10
DOC.TEXT: Israel used curfews, roadblocks and water cannons Friday to stop thousands of Arabs from attending Moslem Sabbath services at the Temple Mount, where police killed 19 Palestinians earlier this week. In the occupied territories, troops shot and killed two Palestinians and wounded at least 10 in clashes with stone-throwing youths, Arab reports said. Also Friday, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Israel would reject any effort by the U.N. Security Council to send a team to investigate the Temple Mount deaths, which occurred Monday. Shamir said a U.N. investigation would be an infringement on Israel's sovereignty over Jerusalem. Israel captured the Arab sector, which contains the Temple Mount, from Jordan in the 1967 Middle East war and later annexed it. ``In the recent past in the Middle East, there have been a number of incidents where people were killed,'' he said. ``We did not see the Security Council being pressured to such grave discussions and with such broad outcomes.'' A Security Council resolution condemning the incident has been hung up over differences on the form of a U.N. investigation and whether to emphasize protecting Palestinians. The issues have divided the United States and its allies. The Arab League will hold an urgent meeting on the confrontation next Wednesday, sources in Tunisia said. Defense Minister Moshe Arens said the U.S. was ``trying to walk a fine line'' in order not to jeopardize its international coalition against Iraq. ``But I think if they conclude that the way to keep this coalition is to blame Israel for an event whose roots lie in Moslem fanatacism, they will make a mistake,'' Arens said on Israel television. Deputy Foreign Minister Bibi Natanyahu said the U.N. response to the events ``lends rioters an international license to continue their rioting.'' A Palestinian human rights group, Al Haq, issued a preliminary report on the killings, calling them a massacre and urging ``international protection'' for Palestinians. The group said massive stone-throwing, which police say prompted their gunfire, did not begin until after tear gas was fired onto the Temple Mount. It also accused paramilitary border police units of opening fire without warning. Since the revolt against Israeli occupation of the territories began in December 1987, 760 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians. An additional 278 Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaboration with Israeli authorities. Forty-eight Israelis have died in the violence. The latest victims were Amar Derouchme, 20, from the West Bank village of Toubas, and Rami Jarar, 18, from nearby Jenin. The army said Derouchme was a former prisoner shot by soldiers in a stone-throwing clash and that it was checking the circumstances of Jarar's death. Arab reports said Jarar was shot as soldiers chased curfew violators. Monday's rioting on the Temple Mount - sacred to both Moslems and Jews - started when Arabs threw stones down at Jews worshiping below at the Western Wall, also known as the Wailing Wall. The Moslems had been inflamed by rumors that a zealous Jewish group, the Temple Mount Faithful, was planning a march to the Mount to reclaim the site for Judaism. Police and Arab hospitals said 19 Palestinians were killed and 140 were injured in police gunfire on the Mount. At least 28 Jewish civilians and six police were injured in the stoning, police said. Israeli politicians on the left and right charged that Israeli security forces were unprepared for trouble despite advance warnings. Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek accused the Arabs of planning the riot. Police Chief Yaacov Terner said, however, the rioting was spontaneous and that there was no concrete intelligence that a major Arab demonstration was planned. On Friday, hundreds of police and paramilitary units were on duty around the Mount, and a helicopter circled above. Palestinians from the West Bank were stopped by army roadblocks from approaching Jerusalem. In the city, police blocked hundreds of young men from walking to prayers, halting them at the gates to the Old City or to the Mount. Police turned water cannons on a group of 200 Palestinian youths who tried to march to the Mount. The youths retreated to a nearby street and pelted passing cars with stones. About 2,000 managed to attend the prayers, about one-fifth the usual Friday crowd. At the service, prayer leader Sheik Mohammed Hussein praised those killed Monday as ``martyrs'' and pledged: ``We will defend our mosque until the last drop of our blood.'' His sermon was interrupted by worshipers' shouts of ``God, destroy the Jews.'' Many Palestinians also were blocked from prayers by army curfews. More than one million Palestinians in Arab east Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza were confined to their homes for a fifth day because of Monday's riot. Residents of the Gaza Strip used a two-hour lifting of the curfew Friday to burn tires and shout anti-Israeli slogans in street demonstrations, residents said.

DOC.HEAD: Company Defends Record
With AM-Military Spending, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The head of Northrop Corp. defended his company Friday against charges that the manufacturer of the B-2 bomber can't manage its business. ``Northrop's long record as an asset to this country deserves to be weighed in the haste to discuss its liabilities,'' said Kent Kresa, who is chairman of the board, president and chief executive officer. Kresa's testimony came at the end of a difficult week for Northrop. A top Air Force official testified on Tuesday about deficiences in six major areas at the company, including cost and schedule estimates. The Air Force's assistant secretary for acquisition, Jack Welch, said in an interview with the Los Angeles Times that testing of the second B-2 bomber had been delayed nine months. Meanwhile, the House approved a 1991 defense appropriations bill that halts production of the B-2 bomber at 15 planes. Lawmakers have expressed dismay over the aircraft's cost of nearly $865 million a copy. In a lengthy statement, Kresa said he accepts responsibility for the ``failures of individuals and management oversight that took place in the past.'' ``Our failings should never have occurred. The systems that allowed them to occur have been changed and are being changed. Some changes in our business and management systems we should have made long ago, and didn't,'' Kresa said. The Northrop president detailed steps the company has taken, including changes in top management and an examination of values and ethics among employees. Kresa said lawmakers were ``rightfully outraged'' by the events that led to criminal penalties against Northrop. Northrop pleaded guilty in February to 34 counts of fraud and was fined $17 million, the largest criminal fine ever imposed on a defense contractor. The plea stems from charges that Northrop falsified reports on the air-launched cruise missile and conducted improper tests on the Harrier AV-8B jet. In his appearance before the House Goverment Operations subcommittee on legislation and national security, Kresa sought to assure lawmakers about Northrop's major program, the B-2 bomber. The stealth aircraft and employees on the project have faced allegations of overcharging, mismanagement and destruction of material, Kresa said. Since those charges in February 1988, the Justice Department, Air Force and Pentagon have been unable to find any evidence to support the allegations, he said. ``Not a single charge has been placed against anyone for anything,'' Kresa said.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Asks Retrial, Arguing Marshals May Have Influenced Jurors
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's attorney asked on Friday for a retrial, saying deputy U.S. marshals may have influenced jurors by telling them alternate jurors would have voted to convict the mayor of all charges. Attorney R. Kenneth Mundy also argued that a retrial was justified because some jurors witnessed an undercover drug sting operation at the hotel where they were sequestered. Barry was convicted on Aug. 10 of a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge and acquitted of another. The jury could not reach a verdict on 12 other charges, including three felony perjury counts, and prosecutors have said they won't pursue a new trial on those. Mundy asked in court papers for a postponement of next Friday's scheduled pre-sentencing hearing. Barry's parole officer had earlier asked a delay in that proceeding in order to prepare a pre-sentencing report for U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. Mundy's request for a retrial comes following interviews with jurors in the case who said deputy U.S. marshals told them the alternate panelists would have voted ``guilty, guilty, guilty.'' According to Mundy's filing, at least two of the jurors wondered whether the drug sting at their hotel had been staged for their benefit. Barry had been arrested in an undercover sting operation on Jan. 18. That incident produced one of the misdemeanor possession charges the jury could not decide. The mayor is scheduled for sentencing on Oct. 26. He could face a maximum penalty of one year in pison and a $100,000 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Father of One-A-Day Vitamins Dies
DOC.TEXT: Dr. Walter Ames Compton, a former chairman of Miles Inc. whose research into nutrition led to the introduction of One-A-Day vitamin supplements and chewable children's vitamins, has died at age 79. Compton died at his home Thursday. Hartzler-Gutermuth Funeral Home said the cause of death was Alzheimer's disease. His career at Elkhart-based Miles Inc., formerly known as Miles Laboratories, spanned more than 45 years, and culminated in his appointment as president in 1964 and chairman in 1973. He retired in 1981, when he was elected honorary chairman. He began working at Miles while still in medical school, serving as a summer assistant to J. Maurice Treneer, the father of Alka-Seltzer. In 1938, he was named the company's first medical and research director. Two years later, his research paid off with Miles' introduction of One-A-Day vitamin supplements. The company introduced Chocks, the first chewable children's vitamin, in 1960. Flintstones chewable vitamins and the Bugs Bunny vitamin line followed. ``Dr. Compton was the first at Miles to see the connection between nutrition and health,'' reported a Miles publication issued to celebrate the corporation's 100th birthday in 1984. Survivors include his wife, Phoebe; three daughters; and two sons.

DOC.HEAD: White House: Veto Still Planned for Civil Rights Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs of comment from Republican congressman after 11th graf bgng, `The business...' Picks up 12th graf prvs, `Bush has...'
DOC.TEXT: The White House said Friday that President Bush still plans to veto a major job-discrimination bill despite last-minute changes designed by proponents to overcome administration objections. Presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said changes adopted by House-Senate conferees did not eliminate features in the civil rights bill that administration contends would encourage employers to adopt hiring and promotion quotas to avoid lawsuits. ``We still believe this is a quota bill,'' Fitzwater told reporters. ``We continue to believe a veto is warranted on that basis.'' The legislation would undo six Supreme Court decisions that civil rights lawyers claim make it harder for plaintiffs to prove employment discrimination. The White House statement and a letter by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh to Congress that summarized the president's objections to the bill prompted accusations from a leading civil rights group that the administration was negotiating in bad faith. The Leadership Conference on Civil Rights charged in a statement that White House chief of staff John Sununu and presidential counsel C. Boyden Gray ``insisted on provisions that would gut the bill and actually weaken civil rights laws.'' The group released a copy of a Sept. 21 proposal made by Sununu and Gray that it said would allow businesses to hire on the basis of ``legitimate community or customer relationship efforts.'' ```Customer relations' was the code word used by airlines to restrict flight attendant jobs to young, single women,'' the civil rights coalition said. ``The administration's proposal could allow law firms, banks and other employers to bar blacks or Jews or Catholics from certain jobs because customers prefer not to deal with them.'' Arthur Fletcher, a leading black Republican whom Bush appointed to chair the Civil Rights Commission, expressed dismay that the White House was listening so closely to business interests. ``The business community, which seems to have the upper hand on this one this time, really doesn't want to be held accountable for their efforts with respect to hiring, training, development and promotion'' of minorities, Fletcher said. A leading Republican member of the House, Hamilton Fish of New York, also expressed regret over the White House statement. Fish said he and other Republican lawmakers who have worked on the bill have tried without success to meet personally with Bush to urge his support. ``There is still the outside chance'' that Bush will sign the measure, Fish said. ``I don't think the president is focused on this. How could he be with the budget, diplomacy and half a dozen other major issues?'' Bush has continually said he wants to sign a civil rights bill but not one that would prompt hiring and promotion quotas. Thornburgh said the changes adopted Thursday by House-Senate conferees ``recognize that the bill contains serious deficiencies.'' But the amendments ``do not offer substantial improvement'' and ``in some respects they make the bill worse,'' he said. Language stating that the bill does not require or encourage quotas won't eliminate the problem, Thornburgh said in a letter to Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole. ``The trouble with the bill is not that it explicitly `encourages' or `requires' quotas, but that it will inevitably result in quotas being adopted surreptitiously to avoid the cost and trouble'' of lawsuits, Thornburgh wrote. ``The assertion that the bill ought not have this effect cannot change the fact that it will,'' the attorney general said. Thornburgh's letter also said that despite changes, the bill still narrowly restricts the ability of employers to defend charges that business policies unfairly discriminate against women and minorities. Ralph Neas, executive director of the civil rights coalition, called Thornburgh's description of the bill ``highly misleading and inaccurate. It does a disservice to the president and the nation.'' ``They are ignoring all the changes made by the House and Senate,'' Neas said. Neas said language now cited by Thornburgh as objectionable was included in the bill last summer at Sununu's behest to define practices that employers could cite in defending discrimination suits. To show that a practice was necessary to good business, employers would have to show that it bore ``a significant relationship to successful performance on the job,'' according to the language.

DOC.HEAD: Reclusive Billionaire's Estate Finally Settled
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen years after his death, the estate of billionaire recluse Howard R. Hughes Jr. has been settled. Records show that $1.13 billion, the bulk of Hughes' estate, was administered through Chancery Court by his cousin, William R. Lummas. The court approved the final accounting of the Delaware administration of the estate Tuesday. The heart of Hughes' empire was invested in Summa Corp., a personal holding company incorporated in Delaware. Hughes died in 1976 at the age of 72. Richard L. Sutton, an attorney for Lummas, said that about $150 million in cash awaits distribution to Hughes' heirs across the country. Real estate in Nevada and California also will be liquidated. ``For all practical purposes, it is the end of the administration of the Hughes estate and the heirs have received their distributions,'' Sutton said.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Supreme Court Overturns Decision on Former KGB General
DOC.TEXT: A former KGB general won a partial legal victory Friday in his battle to get the Kremlin to restore benefits and honors that it withdrew when he was fired for criticizing the spy agency. The Russian Supreme Court overruled a decision last week by the Moscow City Court and ordered the city court to reconsider Oleg D. Kalugin's challenge of his demotion by Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzkhov, Tass reported. Kalugin, who had accused the KGB of tapping telephones and spying on free trade unionists, clergymen and others challenging Communist authorities, was stripped last summer of his rank, honors and pension. If Kalugin is successful in his attempt to have them restored, it could be a landmark case for citizens challenging official secrecy about government decisions. Kalugin in August complained to the City Court that he was unfairly demoted on June 29 by Ryzkhov, denied his awards by President Mikhail Gorbachev and wrongly stripped of his pension by KGB chief Vladimir Kryuchkov. The Moscow court last week threw out the complaint against Ryzkhov on the grounds that the decision had been taken by the 13-member Council of Ministers - Ryzkhov's Cabinet - and no person could be singled out. But Kalugin's lawyers submitted statements by several ministers that the decision to demote Kalugin was made without their knowledge. The Supreme Court ordered the Moscow court to review Kalugin's complaint against Ryzkhov. ``Appeals can be lodged against a particular official's personal actions, as well as his actions on behalf of the body he represents,'' Tass quoted the high court as saying. Kalugin called the ruling a ``step towards justice.'' The city court also is considering the complaint against KGB chief Kryuchkov, but has taken no action on the allegation against Gorbachev. The three-judge panel is scheduled to meet again Oct. 23. Under the reforms introduced by Gorbachev, the Soviet Parliament has asserted greater control over the government. But Kalugin and other reformers argue that many officials continue to follow secret orders. Officials in the KGB, which in earlier years arrested, incarcerated and executed millions of citizens with impunity, have told the Soviet people that the days of terror are over. But the KGB and the Soviet leadership reacted harshly last summer after Kalugin went public with his criticism of the agency, which gathers intelligence abroad and is responsible for state security at home. Publicity surrounding the case helped Kalugin win a seat representing the southern Russian city of Krasnodar in the Soviet parliament last month. Viktor Alexeyev, chief of the KGB legal department, told the court that the agency revoked Kalugin's military pension after he was demoted, in accordance with a Soviet law. Alexeyev said Kalugin, 55, could receive a normal old-age pension when he becomes eligible, in five years.

DOC.HEAD: Former President Carter Revisits Haiti
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) - Former President Jimmy Carter spent five hours in Haiti on a visit Friday in support of December general elections here. ``The elections this year will be successful. They will be honest and free and open, and also safe,'' Carter said in an interview with the independent Radio Haiti-Inter. Elections are scheduled for Dec. 16. Carter was on his way to Guyana, the South American country where preparations for elections are also being made. He arrived by private plane at International Airport and was welcomed by Foreign Affairs Minister Paul Christian Latortue. Carter paid courtesy calls on President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot and army chief of staff Lt. Gen. Herard Abraham. In the company of Electoral Council President Jean-Robert Sabalat, Carter inspected voter-registration bureaus in the capital. Carter said registration in rural areas was very good, but in some parts of the capital ``not many people have registered yet.'' This poor Caribbean island nation has 3 million potential voters. In 1987, during the last attempt at free general elections, 75 percent of eligible voters registered. The election collapsed when thugs supported by the army shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters. Hundreds were killed and wounded in pre-election violence. The three-week voter-registration period began Oct. 5. Carter arrived at 9:30 a.m. and left for Guyana at 2:30 p.m. It was his third visit to Haiti since Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot's provisional government took power in March. He had visited Haiti in October 1987. ``The army is giving full support to the election this time,'' Carter said. The president-elect will be sworn in on Feb. 7, 1991, on the fifth anniversary of the overthrow of dictator Jean-Claude Duvalier. Elections will be monitored by the United Nations, the Organization for American States, the Caribbean Community and Carter Center observers. Carter said he would return himself in December. He was accompanied on Friday by his wife Rosalynn and by Robert Pastor, Latin American specialist at the Carter Center.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Approves $57 Billion More for Bailout
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Banking Committee on Friday approved $57 billion in new taxpayer bailout funds for savings and loan depositors - more than the $50 billion committed in the original rescue package enacted just 14 months ago. On a voice vote with no audible dissent, the 21-member committee gave its assent to a plan carrying the bailout through the 1991 fiscal year that began just 13 days ago after Bush administration officials said the rescue effort would falter for a lack of funds. While administration officials had been saying since June that the bailout would need another $40 billion to $80 billion in new government money, they had made no specific request to Congress until this past Wednesday. Bush had contended the $50 billion he requested and received from Congress last year to close or merge insolvent thrifts and cover their losses of federally insured deposits would put the S&L crisis behind the nation. But with declining real estate values in many areas of the country, the losses have continued to swell as regulators moved into the insolvent or nearly insolvent thrifts. On Wednesday, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady wrote the chairmen of the Senate and House banking committees that the bailout ``will virtually cease within the next two months unless additional funds are provided.'' Brady requested $40 billion in new money to carry the rescue through the next 12 months. But he also wanted lawmakers to abandon their requirement that the Resolution Trust Corp. maintain a 15 percent reserve to cover more unexpected losses in the event the value of assets on S&L books fall further. To maintain those reserves, he said, would require another $17 billion. Rather than see the present $8 billion reserve exhausted, the Senate committee opted to provide the full $57 billion, even though the administration expects to spend only about $50 billion this fiscal year. House Banking Committee Chairman Henry Gonzalez, D-Texas, said Friday that his panel will take up Brady's request next week. Money to carry out the plan must be provided through a separate appropriations bill.

DOC.HEAD: Times Mirror Corrects Poll Figures On Republicans and Rich
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs with GOP comment.
DOC.TEXT: The Times Mirror Center for The People & The Press said Friday a national poll it took last month showed that 21 percent o the people, not 51 percent as reported, associated Republicans with ``rich, powerful moneyed interests.'' In a previous poll three years ago, 18 percent made such an association. The big jump to 51 percent was widely published and frequently cited by political commentators. Times Mirror said the incorrect figure was due to a computing error. It said it also overstated the percentage of people who spontaneously said they associated Republicanism with conservatism, being business oriented and not being for the people. Scott Sowry, a spokesman for the Republican National Committee, said the party was certain that the apparent jump was an error. ``That's what we've been saying all along,'' Sowry said.

DOC.HEAD: 2 Live Crew Faces Contempt for Late Court Appearance
DOC.TEXT: Bawdy rappers 2 Live Crew face contempt of court charges for showing up late to their own obscenity trial on Friday. Band members Luther Campbell and Chris Wongwon showed up 30 minutes late for Friday's proceedings and Mark Ross trailed in more than an hour late, infuriating Broward County Judge June Johnson. Johnson said she would sentence the three on contempt charges when the trial ends. Each faces up to six months in jail. The three are on trial on misdemeanor obscenity charges stemming from a June 10 adults-only performance at a nightclub in nearby Hollywood. The performance came four days after a federal judge declared obscene their sexually explicit album, ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' If convicted, each rapper faces up to a year in jail and fines of up to $1,000 each. On the fifth day of jury selection, the judge upheld the prosecution's removal of a potential black juror. Defense attorney Bruce Rogow failed to persuade the judge that the man had been removed because of his race. Rogow has unsuccessfully tried to show that Broward's selection of jurors from voter registration lists is unconstitutional because blacks and youths are underrepresented. No jurors had been chosen by Friday afternoon. 2 Live Crew members maintain young and black jurors are needed for a fair trial because obscenity is defined by local community standards. Broward Assistant State Attorney Pedro Dijols, who is black, said the juror candidate, Vernard Kinnel, had identified himself as a 2 Live Crew fan. ``I want the record to clearly reflect, very clearly, your honor, this prosecutor is a black Puerto Rican and this prosecutor has heard an answer from Mr. Kinnel that he is a fan of this particular group that we have on trial,'' Dijols told the judge Thursday. Johnson ruled Friday that Kinnel's removal was not racially motivated. Of the 70-member jury pool, only seven potential jurors remained from the first string of 25 potential jurors. One was a middle-aged black man. The second group of 25 potential jurors was brought in Friday afternoon, and 11 had been eliminated by day's end. Those remaining included three middle-aged black women. Defense attorneys said they believed jury selection would be completed by Monday afternoon. Last week, an all-white jury convicted Fort Lauderdale record store owner Charles Freeman of a similar obscenity charge for selling a tape of ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' to an undercover deputy.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
German Interior Minister Shot and Wounded by Assailant
DOC.TEXT: Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble was shot and seriously wounded late Friday by at least one assailant, police said. Police said Schaeuble was struck by one or more bullets, and that a suspect had been taken into custody. The attack occurred in Oppenau in the Offenburg district of Baden-Wuerttenberg state outside Freiburg, police said. Schaeuble's injures were believed to be serious, Baden-Wuerttenberg state police said. No other details were immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Rwandan Ambassador Suspects Ugandan Plot In Invasion
DOC.TEXT: The ambassador from Rwanda says that refugees who have invaded the central African country appear to be backed by the Ugandan government and have been receiving arms from fellow exiles based in the United States. Ambassador Aloys Uwimana said he asked U.S. officials to assess the possibility of an invasion two years ago and they told him ``no movement was afoot.'' Several thousand armed refugees from the Tutsi tribe invaded the country from Uganda Sept. 30, and fighting continues. Uwimana was interviewed after the embassy released a statement Thursday denying accusations that government soldiers have massacred hundreds of civilians belonging to the minority Tutsi tribe, which is also the tribe of Uganda's president, Yoweri Museveni. Uwimana said there is growing suspicion that Ugandan leaders are behind the invasion by Rwandan Tutsis who have been living in Uganda for two decades. ``We don't want to directly charge the government of Uganda, but we recognize the facts,'' the ambassador said. The invaders are from a group of 250,000 people who fled Rwanda two decades ago after the majority Hutu tribe took over rule of the country from the Tutsi. Uwimana said about 15 Rwandan Tutsis representing the refugees in Uganda are now based in the United States and have been involved in purchasing black market arms for the invading group. State Department spokesman Mark Dillen said Friday that U.S. officials in Rwanda had spoken with travelers from troubled areas of the country but could not confirm whether a massacre took place. Dillen said he could not comment on Uwimana's statements about U.S.-based rebels or the possibility of Ugandan involvement. U.S. officials earlier said they were considering a Rwanda request for medical and other supplies. Dillen said the conflict was continuing in the northeast part of the country, with fighting centered around the towns of Gatsibo and Gabiro. The capital, Kigali, remained calm although a nighttime curfew was in effect, the spokesman said. U.S. civilians have been evacuated and the State Department has warned U.S. citizens to avoid travel to the country. Rwandan President Juvenal Habyarimana said 14 civilians had been killed in fighting between government and rebel forces and about 3,000 people had been arrested, many of them belonging to the Tutsi tribe. He also denied the reports from Rwandan exiles that soldiers fired on civilians and killed more than 1,000 people in 10 villages on the border with Uganda. On Thursday, the United States ``underlined to the government of Rwanda the importance of respect for human rights,'' Dillen said. ``In particular, we have urged the government of Rwanda to enforce President Habyarimana's declaration that Rwandans should avoid any acts of retribution based on ethnic differences.'' Habyarimana and most of the people in his government belong to the Hutu tribe, which makes up 85 percent of Rwanda's population.

DOC.HEAD: Aid Committee Meets Without Much Result
DOC.TEXT: A U.S.-led international committee met a second time Friday to discuss providing billions of dollars in economic aid to countries hurt by the Persian Gulf crisis but did not resolve several disputes dividing its members. The three-hour closed-door meeting at the U.S. Treasury of representatives of 20 countries and international bodies was the second session of the Gulf Crisis Financial Coordination Group. President Bush announced formation of the group on Sept. 25, calling for a generous response from the world community to help countries hurt by the U.N.-sponsored embargo of Iraq. The administration believes its effort o isolate Iraq might begin to crumble unless aid is funneled to countries who lost trade with Iraq or who are coping with the flood of refugees produced by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The coordinating group has been divided by such basic issues as how much money should be contributed and which countries should receive it. An administration official who spoke on condition of anonymity said the group resolved several administrative issues in Friday's meeting. It agreed to rotate the location of the meetings and awarded the chairmanship of the group to Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady. A State Department official will serve as deputy chairman. The next meeting was planned for Rome during the first two weeks of November. The official said the substantive issues, athough discussed, were not resolved but nevertheless described the meeting as ``quite successful.'' However, a senior Treasury official shortly after the Sept. 26 session had said most of the unresolved matters would be cleared up before Friday's meeting. Officials said previously that the United States would like to channel most of the aid to three ``front line'' states - Egypt, Jordan and Turkey. However, Saudi Arabia and Kuwait have complained that Jordan is showing reluctance to support the trade embargo and therefore should not get help. And, some nations think the list of aid recipients should be expanded to include Third World nations particularly hard hit by oil prices rising over $40 a barrel. A World Bank study had identified Bangladesh, India, Pakistan, the Philippines, Sri Lanka and Sudan as among the nations hardest hit. There had also been disagreement over the amount of aid. According to a German official, the United States had been pushing for $14.5 billion, while some European countries believed $9 billion was a more realistic figure. The nations participating with the United States in the coordinating group are Japan, Germany, Great Britain, France, Canada, Italy, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Qatar, South Korea, Belgium, the Netherlands, Sweden and Switzerland. Also participating are representatives of the 12-nation European Community, the Gulf Cooperation Council of Persian Gulf countries and the 154-nation International Monetary Fund and its sister lending organization, the World Bank.

DOC.HEAD: Court Bars Former Guatemalan Dictator as Presidential Candidate
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ruled Friday that former dictator Efrain Rios Montt and his running mates were not qualified to run for president in next month's national elections. Chief Justice Edmundo Vasquez Martinez announced the court's decision, which upheld an Aug. 22 ruling by the National Election Board that the constitution barred former dictators from running for office. Rios Montt, then a brigadier general, took power after a military coup in March 1982 and ruled Guatemala until August 1983 when he was removed by another coup. Pending the court's ruling, Rios Montt has campaigned hard, and has been leading in polls for the Nov. 11 presidential race. The court, acting on an appeal by Rios Montt's three-party coalition, had issued an injunction Sept. 12 ordering the election board to register the retired general as a candidate temporarily until it could hear arguments in the case. In reversing the injunction, Vasquez Martinez told a news conference the appeal ``lacked legal merit.'' He said Rios Montt's backers can still appeal to Guatemala's Constitutional Court within 48 hours. Vasquez Martinez said the nine-member court also barred Rios Montt's running mate, Harris Whitbeck Pinol, and the rest of his coalition ticket, including candidates for legislator and a Central American congress. Rios Montt's spokesman, Juan Callejas, said the coalition will take the case to the Constitutional Court. ``We will appeal according to our plan,'' Callejas said in a telephone interview. He said the publicity the case generated has been helping Rios Montt's campaign. ``We will win on the first round November 11,'' he said. Guatemalans seeking a strong hand in government have been turning to Rios Montt and his coalition of the United National Front, the Institutional Democratic Party and the Republican Front, polls show. Guatemala is troubled by an upsurge of violence and reports of official corruption and drug smuggling. A born-again Christian, Rios Montt was one of three officers asked by the armed forces to take over the country after the 1982 coup. That June he bounced the other two and named himself president. While president, he drew international condemnation by ordering the execution by firing squad of more than a dozen leftist guerrilla leaders. Military troops also were accused of conducting brutal campaign that left thousands of peasants dead in the northwest highlands. The board's decision confirmed a Supreme Court opinion based on Article 186 of Guatemala's 1985 constitution. According to that provision, neither ``the head and leaders of a coup, armed revolution or similar movement that has altered constitutional order, nor those who have assumed the head of government as a result can run for president or vice-president.'' Guatemala's 19 political parties are fielding a total of 13 candidates for the presidential race. If no candidate gets 50 percent of the vote in November a runoff will be held Jan. 6 among the two top vote-getters. The winner will replace Vinicio Cerezo, a centrist Christian Democrat voted in for a five-year term in January 1986, and only the second civilian president in more than three decades. Before Cerezo, Guatemala was ruled by rightist military officers - some elected and some placed in power through coups - who have been battling a leftist insurrection since the early 1960s. The only other civilian president was Julio Cesar Mendez Montenegro, who served from 1966 to 1970. The November balloting will also elect a vice president, a national legislature, about 300 municipal governments nationwide, and deputies to a Central American Parliament to be created soon by Guatemala, Nicaragua, Honduras, El Salvador and Costa Rica.

DOC.HEAD: Top Business Leaders Say Economic Growth To Stagnate In Second Half
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS Mobile to Mobil Corp. in 18th graf: ``Another council,''
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Economy, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Top business leaders predicted Friday that the U.S. economy will stagnate during the second half of this year. A minority said a recession is here or on the way. The Business Council's fall forecast projected a nearly imperceptible 0.3 percent economic growth rate in the second half of 1990, and said oil-driven inflation will climb to 6.1 percent before falling back below current levels. One-fourth of the corporate economists preparing the report foresee a recession, a minority supported by several of the Business Council members. ``As far as I'm concerned, we're in a phase of a recession,'' said Edmund T. Pratt Jr., chairman of Pfizer Inc. Asked whether he thought the nation ws in a recession, Lewis T. Preston, chairman of J.P. Morgan & Co., replied: ``I do.'' The outlook for a short boost in inflation is based on the assumption there will be no war in the Persian Gulf. The forecast was presented to the 100 leaders of the nation's top corporations at their semiannual, two-day meeting at this mountain resort. Preston, a council vice chairman, noted major differences between the council's forecast last spring and the current one. The projections prepared by the 19 corporate economists for the May meeting predicted 2 percent economic growth in the second half of the year and 2.5 percent in 1991. The current expectation foresees just 0.3 percent growth in the second half, 1.2 percent in the first half of 1991 and 2.6 percent in the second. ``There's an even bigger change in mood'' on the part of the economists, Preston told reporters. After suggesting moderate growth last May, ``now, by contrast, they're much more worried - not worried enough, in my judgment - but much more worried.'' Indeed, while only five of the 19 believe an economic downturn will occur in 1990's final quarter, the panel has increased its recession risk assessment from 22 percent in its April survey to 39 percent in its latest survey completed in September. Economists generally define a recession as two straight quarters of negative economic growth. ``The probability of recession by mid-year 1991 has increased from 29 percent to 47 percent,'' their report said. Preston said the economists are virtually unanimous in thinking that the recent oil price hikes will not last. ``That's because of the critical assumption of a decided majority that there either will be no Persian Gulf hostilities or that if hostilities do occur, they will be relatively brief and not result in significant damage to oil field facilities,'' he said. ``Because the consultants believe oil prices will come down significantly, they do not at this point believe that what has happened to crude will have permanently distorting effect on the Consumer Price Inex,'' he added. In their report, the economists said they expect CPI inflation to reach 6.1 percent by year's end and then slow to 4.5 percent in the first half of 1991 and to 4.2 percent in the second. Another council member, Allen E. Murray, chairman of Mobil Corp., told reporters he sees no petroleum shortages this winter and that crude oil prices which have doubled since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait will ``come down and come down hard.'' ``This assumes no war,'' he added. Other highlights of the council forecast included: -The economists expect economic weakness to be concentrated in housing, consumer spending on durable goods and business investment. -Industrial production will advance less than 1 percent between the middle of 1990 and the middle of 1991 before accelerating to a 3.6 percent annual rate in the second half. However, orders, sales and profits in the industrial sector will show little or no growth over the next six to nine months. -Most of the council economists foresee continuing, gradual improvement in the nation's merchandise trade balance, with the gap declining from $109 billion in 1989 to $98 billion in 1990 and $91 billion in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: West Africans Plan Summit to Discuss Liberia
DOC.TEXT: An emergency summit of West African leaders will focus on Liberia's civil war and the continued role of a regional military force in the nation, a presidential spokesman said Friday. President Felix Houphouet-Boigny called the meeting for Monday in his hometown of Yamoussoukro. At least five heads of state are expected to attend, said spokesman Yves Binni, who would not identify the leaders. Members of the 16-nation Economic Community of West African States have become split over its deployment of a five-nation army to Liberia. The 6,000-member troop force - including soldiers from Nigeria, Ghana, Guinea, Gambia and Sierra Leone - was sent Aug. 5 to help end Liberia's fighting. At least 5,000 civilians have been killed by three warring sides and about 250,000 Liberians have fled to neighboring states. Another 250,000 of the nation's 3.2 million people have been displaced within their country since rebel leader Charles Taylor invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24. This week, the West African force drove Taylor's rebels from the Liberian capital of Monrovia to the eastern suburb of Paynesville. The West Africans plan to install an interim government named by exiled and refugee Liberian politicians, business leaders and clergy. Taylor has named himself president of his own government and says the other administration, with a mandate to organize elections, is a puppet of West African states. Ivory Coast's support for Taylor was the subject of a meeting last week between Houphouet-Boigny and U.S. Ambassador Donald Petterson, the top State Department official for Liberia.
