Diplomatic sources in Abidjan said Petterson tried to persuade Houphouet-Boigny not to back calls for a withdrawal of the West African army. The diplomats said the Ivory Coast leader surprised Petterson by immediately telephoning six heads of states and inviting them to a summit. Ivory Coast denies backing Taylor, though defense sources confirm Ivorian police have escorted truckloads of weapons across Ivory Coast's western border into rebel-held Liberian territory. Taylor's fighters have overrun most of the country, while a breakaway rebel faction led by Prince Johnson remains in Monrovia along with remnants of slain President Samuel Doe's army. President Blaise Compaore of Burkina Faso, where some Taylor rebels say they trained, has denounced the West African deployment and warned the conflict could spread to neighboring states.

DOC.HEAD: Karpov Calls Time Out Before Third Game
DOC.TEXT: Challenger Anatoly Karpov, trailing by a game in the $3 million World Chess Championship, used one of his three time-outs to postpone Friday night's match against Garry Kasparov. Karpov sent word of his decision at 11:53 a.m., seven minutes before the deadline for a time-out. Chief Arbiter Geurt Gijssen was phoned by Lajos Portisch, Karpov's second, with the news of the postponement. They do things a little differently in the chess world than in other competitions. Portisch was required to sing a song familiar to Gijssen in order to prove the call was legitimate. ``This was accomplished to his satisfaction,'' the championship media center said in a statement. Karpov and Kasparov battled to a draw in Monday night's opening match, with the champion drawing first blood with a victory on Wednesday. The championship will resume on Monday at 5:30 p.m., with Karpov playing the white pieces. Karpov provided no explanation for his decision in a letter delivered to Gijssen and signed by Dr. Nikolai Krogius, head of the challenger's delegation. Each player has the right to take three time-outs during the 24-match competition. Generally, the time-outs are taken on a Monday or Friday to give a player a long weekend. They can also be used for illness.

DOC.HEAD: Proportion Of Unwanted Births Increases
DOC.TEXT: The proportion of unwanted births among women who have been married is increasing, according to the National Center for Health Statistics released Friday. The center's National Survey of Family Growth said that in a random sampling weighted to represent the entire population, 10.3 percent of the 1.6 million births to these women that occurred between 1983 and 1988 were unwanted at the time of conception. The proportion was 14.3 percent in a 1973 survey and had dropped to 7.7 percent in 1982. The increase was most pronounced among women living below the poverty line. From 1982-88, the proportion of births unwanted at the time of conception among this group rose 74 percent - from 11.9 percent to 20.7 percent. Among women who had never been married, a quarter of the 2.5 million births from 1983-88 were unwanted at the time of pregnancy.

DOC.HEAD: Government in Nigeria Legalizes Controversial Voting Method
DOC.TEXT: Ignoring mounting opposition, the military on Friday enacted a decree that legalizes a balloting system in which the voters must stand in line behind the candidate of their choice. The system that officials call ``open balloting'' will be used in local council elections in Dec. 8 to test the popularity of two political parties the government created to end military rule. Under the decree, voters must arrive at polling booths by 11 a.m. and expect to spend the day there. Nigeria is Africa's most populous country with about 119 million residents. The government's manipulation has made many voters apathetic, critics say, and waiting in line will only irritate them more, creating a headache for police. Problems are expected particularly in the predominantly Moslem northern states, where religious leaders have said it would be unthinkable for male and female voters to line up together. Professor Humphrey Nwosu, chairman of the National Electoral Commission, said last month the system was chosen because it was ``something indigenous, simple, uncomplicated, cost-effective and credible.'' Voters will choose between candidates of the right-leaning National Republican Convention and left-of-center Social Democratic Party. President Gen. Ibrahim Babangida created the two parties and wrote their manifestos last year after he banned all 13 independent groups seeking to contest promised 1992 general elections. Babangida said he wanted to do away with political groupings divided along tribal and religious lines and start from scratch. But critics say civilian politicians have managed to evade Babangida's intentions, colonizing the created parties with their own personal agendas. Politicians representing the Moslem north have essentaillly taken over the Republican party, these critics say, while those representing the mostly Christian and animist south occupied the Social Democratic Party. Babangida seized power on Aug. 27, 1985, the sixth military man to take power since Nigeria's independence from Britain in 1960. Nigeria has not had a successful civilian government in that time.

DOC.HEAD: Major Test Rocks Desert After Technical Delay
DOC.TEXT: Scientists detonated a nuclear weapon Friday after a 2{-hour technical delay, delivering a blast that was felt in Las Vegas high rises, 105 miles from ground zero. The weapon was up to 10 times more powerful than the atomic bomb that destroyed Hiroshima. Friday's test was the seventh of the year and the third in three weeks at the sprawling Nevada Test Site. A 5.7 reading on the Richter scale was recorded at the National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., according to spokesman Waverly Person. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage if it occurs in a populated area. Department of Energy spokesman Jim Boyer, who monitored the test 34 miles from ground zero, said scientists seemed pleased with the results. ``All I see is happy faces,'' Boyer said. ``The situation appears normal. Everything looks real good.'' The test, code-named Tenabo, was scheduled for 8 a.m., but was delayed until 10:30 a.m. because of technical problems. ``The test was put on hold until they checked out the mechanisms,'' Boyer said. ``I don't have any details and I doubt if they'd tell me. Obviously, it wasn't anything very serious.'' The nuclear weapon was buried 2,000 feet beneath Pahute Mesa, about 105 miles northwest of Las Vegas. DOE monitors atop high rise buildings in Las Vegas said the blast was ``felt distinctly'' at the Sahara, Rio and Palace Station hotels. Gilbert Yarchever, who has an apartment on the 25th floor of the Regency Towers, a high rise building east of the Las Vegas Strip, said ``anything hanging moved.'' The blast was listed as having an explosive force of 20,000 to 150,000 tons of TNT, the upper limit allowed by nuclear treaties with the Soviet Union. The atomic bomb that destroyed Hiroshima had an explosive force of 15,000 tons. Managers of high rise buildings were warned by the DOE that the explosion could cause some motion, a standard warning given when a blast is expected near the upper limits. The test was originally scheduled for Thursday morning, but was postponed because of winds blowing toward Las Vegas. Tests are called off if winds are blowing toward a populated area in case radioactive gases escape from the underground test area.

DOC.HEAD: Rwanda To Allow Monitoring of Suspected Rebels
DOC.TEXT: Rwanda insisted on Friday its soldiers had killed hundreds of rebels wearing civilian clothes, not innocent villagers. It agreed to let a Vatican-led committee monitor conditions for captured rebel suspects. The government also announced it freed about 1,200 of nearly 3,000 suspected rebel supporters arrested in Kigali, capital of the small central African nation. Foreign governments expressed concern about counterinsurgency measures in Rwanda after people who fled into Uganda said soldiers indiscriminantly fired on civilians in up to 10 villages Monday and killed more than 1,000 people. Most of those held are members of the minority Tutsi tribe and include businessmen, intellectuals, senior civil servants and clergymen, according to sources in Kigali. A predominately Tutsi refugee force invaded Rwanda from neighoring Uganda Sept. 30. To ease international concern, Rwanda said Friday it will allow a diplomatic committee to see how detainees are being treated. The group will be led by the Vatican's representative in Rwanda and will include envoys of Germany, Burundi and the International Committee of the Red Cross. President Juvenal Habyarimana on Wednesday denied that any civilians died. Foreign Minister Casimir Bizimungu later said troops attacked rebels who had changed into civilian clothes. Bizimungu estimated that from 200 to 300 insurgents were killed, according to an African envoy who attended a Thursday briefing. ``He told us no civilians were killed,'' the envoy said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The information was made available to The Associated Press in Nairobi. In Washington, the State Department said it stressed ``the importance of respect for human rights. In particular, we have urged the government of Rwanda to enforce their president's declaration that Rwandans should avoid any acts of retribution based on ethnic differences.'' The Department said it had been unable to confirm details of the purported massacre. In the early 1960s, the majority Hutu group crushed a Tutsi uprising, killing more than 10,000 and forcing hundreds of thousands to flee, including the Tutsi king Kigeri V. Rwanda refuses to repatriate any of the refugees, estimated at more than 1 million, citing overcrowding. The Maryland-sized country of 8 million averages about 566 people per square mile, about nine times the U.S. average. The rebel force, which includes many deserters from Uganda's army, seeks to overthrow Habyarimana. The rebels accuse his government of corruption, human rights issues and failing to resolve the refugee problem. They are led by a former Ugandan army commander, Maj. Gen. Fred. Rwigyema, a Tutsi of Rwandan origin, and are based in northeastern Rwanda. They call themselves the Rwandese Patriotic Front and deny they seek to restore the monarchy. Bizimungu accused Uganda of supporting the rebels, despite its condemnation of the invasion. He claimed Rwigyema was in Kampala, the Ugandan capital, last weekend stocking up on food and weapons. A statement from the Rwandese Embassy in Washington Friday claimed a group of Ugandans has worked since 1984 to secretly arm refugees planning an attack. The group, which calls itself The Rwandan Diaspora, claimed it was organizing education aid for Tutsi children and sought donations from major U.S. corporations and groups, the statement said. The group has been shipping weapons to Uganda for the rebels since 1987, it said. There was no immediate comment from several people identified by the embassy as leaders of the group.

DOC.HEAD: Hunters Who Paid ill Captive Animals Left Behind Pictures, Receipts
DOC.TEXT: Hunters who paid thousands of dollars to gun down endangered animals left their names, addresses and pictures of themselves with their kills as evidence, game officials said Friday. ``It will be an officer's dream'' to seek charges against the hunters, state game ranger Sam Cottrell said. ``We even have their pictures.'' Cottrell was one of more than two dozen federal and state agents who raided Texoma Hunting Wilderness in southeastern Oklahoma Wednesday, closing down the hunting range and confiscating piles of records and animal skins. Several live animals were seized. ``It was pretty awful. It was not much sport at all,'' Tom McKay, senior resident agent for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, said Friday. McKay said each hunter paid from $1,000 to $4,000 to select an animal from a cage, have it released onto a ``killing area'' about the size of a football field and shoot it. Among the native animals killed were grizzly bears, black bears, deer, elk and cougars, all of which are protected under federal or state laws. McKay said the game refuge had a permit for the hunting of certain exotic animals, such as foreign deer, but that the permit excluded the native, protected species. Records indicated most of the native animals had been brought in from other states, McKay said. Transporting such an animal across state lines without a permit violates the federal Lacy Act. Conviction on such a charge could bring a penalty of five years in prison and a $250,000 fine, he said. Cottrell said that a brief examination of the records indicated that between 200 and 300 native animals had been killed at the preserve. The 160-acre preserve had been open for three or four years and apparently purchased animals from zoos, preserves and at auctions, officials said. Authorities also raided the home and office of the preserve's owner, Charles B. Bartholomew of Norman, McKay said. Norman is about 20 miles south of Oklahoma City in central Oklahoma. The hunting range was near Bennington, about 200 miles away. Authorities said it would take about a week to sift through the seized records and determine what federal and state charges to file, and against whom. Besides Bartholomew, authorities are focusing on hunters and taxidermists named in the receipts.

DOC.HEAD: American Pilot Killed in Gulf Crash Died Without Seeing Son
DOC.TEXT: An American pilot killed when his F-111 fighter-bomber crashed in Saudi Arabia died without seeing his 4-week-old son. Capt. Fredrick Reid, 33, of Harrisburg, Pa., and his weapons systems officer Capt. Thomas Caldwell, 32, of Columbus, Ohio, were killed outright when their F-111 went down over the Saudi Arabian peninsula Wednesday on a training mission. Reid's second son, Cody, was born after Reid was sent to the gulf as part of Operation Desert Shield, the U.S. military response to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Reid had been based at the British air force's Lakenheath base in the eastern English county of Suffolk. Reid's tearful wife Vicki, said Friday at their home in Mundford in neighboring Norfolk county that her husband had lived for flying and his family. She said he had not been afraid of going to join the U.S.-led international force massing in the gulf. ``It was part of his job. He loved flying - that's why he was in the air force,'' she said. ``We were both aware of the danger, but you always think it won't happen to you.'' Mrs. Reid said her husband was a calm, strong man. ``He was outgoing and friendly and we have made a lot of friends here in the village where we live,'' she said. ``He loved adventure and outdoor camping, things like that.'' Lt. Cmdr. J D van Sickle, a military spokesman, said the incident was under investigation. The F-111 was attached to the 48th Tactical Fighter Wing at Lakenheath. The aircraft was the latest version of a 23-year-old swing-wing jet that first saw action in Vietnam, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Wall Street Journal Publisher Freezes Spending, Salaries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to CLARIFY spending freeze on total, not individual salaries; SUBS 15th graf, `Dow Jones ... to CLARIFY possible dismissals. Picks up 16th graf pvs, `The memo ...' A version moved on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: Dow Jones & Co., publisher of The Wall Street Journal, is freezing budgets for capital spending and salaries and imposing other news and business cutbacks to cope with weak financial results and the sluggish economy. The cuts, announced in an internal memo to managers Thursday, followed weeks of rumors about a possible retrenchment and triggered concern over possible future layoffs at the media and financial industry giant. Dow Jones earlier this week announced a 17.5 percent drop in third-quarter profit, reflecting a steady downturn attributed principally to the company's acquisition of the financial information service Telerate Inc. Dow Jones also has been hurt by the recession plaguing Wall Street since the 1987 stock market crash. Operating income at Dow Jones' business publications, which include the Journal and Barron's weekly, dropped 80 percent in the second quarter. Advertising linage at the Journal dropped 16 percent in the period. The internal memo from Dow Jones chairman Warren H. Phillips and publisher and president Peter R. Kann freezes all capital expenditures immediately and holds all 1991 department budgets - including total salary costs - at 1990 levels. Accounting for inflation, the budget cut would amount to more than 5 percent for 1991. The memo, a copy of which was obtained Friday, also said Dow Jones will reduce management bonuses next year, eliminate all temporary help, try to eliminate all editorial staff relocations and reduce space devoted to news in the Journal. ``We have no reasons to believe that the deteriorating economic climate and business results we've been experiencing the past three months are aberrational,'' the three-page memo said. ``It's likely we, like many other companies in our industry, will be facing adverse market conditions for most of our publications and services, particularly in the U.S. in 1991,'' it said. ``Thus it's prudent for us to take steps now to reduce our costs further.'' Phillips and Kann said the cuts were ``the preferred method of trimming our costs structure'' but said they could not guarantee that they would meet company goals. ``Thus we shouldn't be making any such promises to employees throughout the company,'' the memo said. The memo did not rule out layoffs, fueling rumors at the Journal and other Dow Jones units of forced reductions or closings of advertising locations or news bureaus. ``I think what it means is fewer bodies,'' said Ronald Chen, a Journal copy editor who heads the union representing about 2,000 Dow Jones employees. ``Executives say `I don't think attrition is working,' '' Chen said Friday. ``The only other thing we can think of is forced departures. That's the kind of thing we see that worries us.'' Union members earlier this year ratified a three-year contract providing for pay increases of 5.5 percent this year and 5 percent a year in 1991 and 1992. Chen said the increases would not be affected by the announced cuts. Dow Jones spokesman Roger May said staff reductions were part of the company's eventual goal, but that they could be achieved through reduced hiring, unfilled vacancies and dismissals based on performance, among other steps. Dow Jones has more than 9,000 full-time employees. The memo said the company will continue to accept ``reasonable'' losses on some operations, including overseas editions of the Journal and Telerate's strugging trading service. The memo said Dow Jones will sell its corporate jet and reduce its aviation staff, and sell excess land purchased for Journal printing plant expansion and printing presses in storage. Among other editorial reductions, the memo said Dow Jones would reduce Journal special report inserts and table plans for a Journal magazine among other moves to contain or reduce costs.

DOC.HEAD: More Western Missions in Kuwait Close; Americans Return Home
LaserPhotos DHA1,101,102
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with refugees landing in U.S., report 200,000 troops in gulf, Kuwait invasion practice. Picks up 7th graf pvs, `The largest...'
DOC.TEXT: Western diplomatic defiance of Iraq's seizure of Kuwait weakened Friday when Germany and Belgium announced that their last envoys had left the occupied nation. A jetliner carrying 257 evacuees from Kuwait and Iraq landed in North Carolina. The Pan Am jet, the first U.S.-chartered flight in nearly three weeks, landed Friday afternoon at Raleigh-Durham airport with 123 American citizens, six Canadians and others of unknown nationality. About 100 of those on the flight from London were under 13, including a few infants, officials said. Also Friday, a French news magazine reported that the U.S. military has drawn up plans to free Kuwait and defeat Iraq in an attack next month. A group of Iraqi exiles said Saddam Hussein is already considering withdrawing from the emirate Iraq overran Aug. 2. Iraq, meanwhile, said it may stop Soviet detainees from returning home if they have knowledge of Iraqi weapons systems. The evacuation began Sunday and Iraq has promised to let at least 2,000 Soviets leave. U.S. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney plans to ask Soviet officials next week for intelligence data on the Iraqi military, which was armed largely by the Soviet Union. There were signs that Western impatience with the standoff was growing and that the U.S.-led forces arrayed in Saudi Arabia and elsewhere in the region could be sent to war to force Iraq from Kuwait. Pentagon sources said a Marine amphibious force was planning a practice assault on the Arabian coast soon as a trial run for a possible U.S. invasion of Kuwait. A French magazine reported Friday that U.S. military officials have drawn up an offensive plan against Iraq. The U.S. forces in the gulf area now total more than 200,000, including elements of two armored cavalry units that arrived this week, the Pentagon sources said. Officials indicated the buildup may be winding down. The largest weapon used so far against Iraq has been the trade embargo imposed by the United Nations. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told her Conservative Party to be prepared for war if those sanctions fail. ``We must hope they work,'' she said in an address at the close of the party's annual conference in Bournemouth, England. ``If not, the military option is there.'' The 5,000 delegates applauded when Mrs. Thatcher said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein must face war crimes charges, pay reparation for the devastation of Kuwait and be denied the power to mount new attacks. The French magazine L'Express reported that U.S. military officials have drawn up plans to free Kuwait and defeat Iraq in a four-day war in November that would destroy Saddam's armed forces. L'Express said it obtained an outline of the plan from an unidentified adviser to Defense Secretary Cheney. The weekly publication is a general news magazine, similar to Time or Newsweek, and has one of the largest circulations in France. L'Express said U.S. planners estimated the offensive might cost 20,000 American lives. It gave no estimate for dead of other nations. U.S. officials refused to comment, in line with Pentagon security rules. Saddam has claimed that Kuwait is historically part of Iraq and has said repeatedly that Iraq will never withdraw. However, an Iraqi opposition party-in-exile said the Iraqi ruling Arab Baath Socialist Party has circulated a questionnaire asking prominent members whether they believe Iraq should pull out. The claim by the Kurdistan Democratic Party-Iraq could not be independently confirmed. If true, it would represent an unprecedented quest for consensus by Saddam. Saddam has declared Kuwait to be Iraq's 19th province, and Iraqi forces have encircled and cut off supplies to diplomatic missions since ordering them closed on Aug. 24. Diplomats from nations that oppose the Aug. 2 invasion have tried to hold out but are slowly abandoning the embassies for lack of food and intolerable living conditions. Electricty and water have been shut off to most of them. In Bonn, a German Foreign Ministry spokesman said the last diplomats in the German Embassy drove from Kuwait to Baghdad on Thursday. ZDF television, a German station, said the group included the ambassador and his wife, along with three staff members. The Foreign Ministry official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said they had run out of food. Belgian officials in Brussels said their remaining two diplomats also left for Baghdad Thursday. That leaves the Americans, British, Canadians and French as the only holdouts among Western missions. In other developments: -Saddam Hussein told Iraqi children that President Bush and the U.N. embargo on Iraq have deprived them of milk and sweets, but urged them to do without candy to maintain their pride and dignity. The speech, marking Iraqi Children's Day, was read by an announcer on Baghdad radio and television. -In Cairo, Egypt, gunmen killed the parliament speaker and three security men outside a downtown hotel. The attack came after the government warned that terrorists might strike to punish Egypt for its opposition to Iraq. There was no claim of responsibility. -Members of Japan's deeply divided parliament hooted at Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu when he opened a special session by asking for support for his plan to deploy armed forces overseas. Japan has not sent forces overseas since World War II.

DOC.HEAD: Hey, Dude, Cosby Beats Simpsons - But Just Barely
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf,`The first ...' to CORRECT to`Colombo' movie sted episode. Picks up 8th graf, `The ratings ...'
DOC.TEXT: In their first real head-on battle, NBC's ``The Cosby Show'' just barely beat the second-season premiere of Fox's ``The Simpsons,'' ratings for the season's big sitcom duel showed Friday. Cosby's show, which has been trouncing reruns of ``The Simpsons'' since the season began, had an 18.5 national rating Thursday, just one-tenth of a ratings point higher than the Nielsens for Fox's bug-eyed, big-toothed cartoon clan. In results made public earlier Friday, Fox's show even eat the Cosby comedy in the 24-city overnight ratings race. But both Fox and NBC officials said that a Cosby victory was likely when the national ratings came in. ``We'e very pleased,'' Peter Chernin, Fox Entertainment Group president, said of the ``Simpsons'' ratings. ``We think it's a good number, a good start for us. It was better than we thought we'd do.'' NBC officials also were pleased that The Cos withstood the challenge from the off-the-wall animated sitcom that had been a hit for Fox on Sundays, then was shifted to Thursday nights to take on NBC's long-time ratings champion. Fox heavily promoted the start of its new ``Simpsons'' episodes ``and gave it its best shot this week,'' said Preston Beckman, NBC vice president for audience research. ``But `Cosby' withstood the onslaught pretty well.'' The first half-hour of competing network shows Thursday - a 2-hour repeat of the ``Columbo'' movie on ABC and a movie, ``Dark Avenger,'' on CBS - averaged ratings of 10.6 and 5.4, respectively. Each ratings point represents 931,000 homes. The ratings for Thursday's ``The Simpsons'' were nearly double those of the previous week, when a rerun was shown. Cosby's show dropped by a ratings point on Thursday, a comparison with its Oct. 4 ratings showed. Chernin avoided speculating on whether he thought ``The Simpsons'' might eventually beat Cosby's show in the ratings. ``We've always said we'd be thrilled to be a strong second, and we still feel that,'' he said, later adding: ``Honestly, I don't know where it's going to go. We're just trying to savor today's happiness and not make predictions.'' NBC's Beckman also declined to say what he thought were the chances of ``The Simpsons'' beating ``The Cosby Show'' this season. Whether the two shows will continue to be neck-and-neck in the Nielsens ``I really can't say,'' he insisted. ``This is one of the most exciting races in television in several years. Time will tell.'' ``Give `The Simpsons' its due,'' he added. ``It took on Cosby and performed well. But basically, Fox has an isolated hit there.''

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Rain In South and East
DOC.TEXT: The storms Klaus and Marco brought heavy rain Friday to the South and along the Atlantic Coast. Showers were scattered through New England and the Midwest. There was flooding along the Linville River in western North Carolina, with low-lying portions of Avery and Watuaga counties under water. Georgia was saturated with 4 to 11 inches of rain. A flood watch was posted through early Saturday for the southwest portion of New York state. There was flooding in South Carolina and northern Indiana, the National Weather Service said. High winds were reported in northwest Montana and southeast Washington. A high wind watch was posted through Saturday across northwest and southeast Wyoming. Extreme high and low temperatures were reported around the nation Friday. Low temperature records for the date tied or broken Friday included 53 degrees at Brownsville, Texas; 45 degrees in Lake Charles, La.; and 28 degrees in Muskegon, Mich. On the other extreme, Cape Hatteras, N.C., reached 85 degrees Friday, breaking its high record for the date. Miami warmed to 91 degrees, tying its high for the date. At 3 p.m. EDT, the center of Hurricane Lili was about 345 miles southeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C., moving northwest at about 14 mph. A tropical storm warning was posted over Cape Lookout, N.C., north to Virginia Beach, Va. A tropical storm watch extended from Virginia Beach to Cape Henlopen, Del. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 45 degrees at Williston, N.D., to 94 degrees at Palm Springs, Calif. The low temperature for the Lower 48 was 15 degrees at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Russian President Resumes Work After Accident, May Get Safer Car
DOC.TEXT: Russian President Boris N. Yeltsin, who made his political comeback by railing against official privileges, found himself facing the issue Friday on his first day back at work after a car crash. Yeltsin, limping slightly, officially resumed work at the Russian republic parliament by opening a committee meeting. He had been hurt in a road accident Sept. 12 near his office and had been recovering at home, Tass reported. The accident stirred debate in the Russian parliament over giving the republic leader a special car for safer transportation. He had been riding in a Soviet-built Volga sedan. After the accident, Russian officials ordered four armor-plated luxury cars for Yeltsin and his prime minister, Ivan Silayev, from Gorky Auto Works plant. But the plant refused, saying it only made such cars for national leaders. British newspapers last week reported Yeltsin would swap his car for an armor-plated Mercedes Benz. Russian republic officials quickly denied the report, saying they had received no such offer. The latest wrinkle came Friday, when the labor newspaper Trud reported the Konaly motor works east of Moscow, which makes armored vans for banks, has offered to build safe, ``comfortable'' cars for Yeltsin and his prime minister, Ivan Silayev. ``As the recent accident shows, an armor-plated car today is not only a luxury, but also a means a safe transportation,'' Trud said. The newspaper did not say whether Yeltsin accepted the offer, and Tass did not way whether Yeltsin made any comment about it at the parliament. Yeltsin has stressed his connection with ordinary people by riding in buses and ordinary cars. Riding a populist appeal, he made his political comeback this year came after denunciation in 1987 by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for demanding faster reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Peasant Party Leader Announces Presidential Bid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf to UPDATE with other Peasants Party candidate
DOC.TEXT: The leader of the Peasants Party, a group claiming 2 million members, on Friday announced his candidacy for president. Roman Bartoszcze joins Solidarity chairman Lech Walesa, Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and at least 11 other candidates who are known to be collecting signatures for a place on the Nov. 25 ballot. The candidates must gather 100,000 signatures by Oct. 25 to run in Poland's first popular presidential election to replace Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former Communist Party leader who has asked Parliament to shorten his term. The political camps supporting Walesa and Mazowiecki say they are close to collecting sufficient signatures. The Solidarity chairman and his former adviser, now split over the pace of reforms, are the leading candidates and polls show them running nearly even. Bartoscze, whose candidacy was approved Friday by his party's ruling council, is expected to draw a following among farmers disgruntled about the low prices for agricultural products as the economic system is overhauled. The Peasants Party includes former Rural Solidarity activists as well as members of the United Peasant Party, which was part of the coalition led by Solidarity that took power in September 1989. Another representative of the peasant movement, Sen. Gabriel Janowski, was put forward Friday as a candidate. Janowski, a member of the upper house of Parliament, is Rural Solidarity chairman.

DOC.HEAD: Child Testifies Relative With AIDS Forced Him Have Sex
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf,`Under the ...' with lawyers refusing to say if the boy has been tested for the virus. Picks up 8th graf, `If convicted ...'
DOC.TEXT: A man with AIDS forced an 8-year-old relative to have oral sex, the child and a prosecutor told jurors Friday in a test case of a new state law. Randall Lee Dempsey, 34, of rural Marion is charged with criminal transmission of the HIV virus and aggravated criminal sexual assault. He has pleaded innocent to the charges. The case is believed the first test of the state's new criminal HIV transmission law, which took effect Sept. 11, 1989. ``This is a classic case of child sex abuse in the family setting. But there is one unique and quite dangerous element to this case,'' Williamson County State's Attorney Charles Garnati said in his opening statement. ``He (Dempsey) did so after testing positive for the HIV virus and he did so after being told by his own doctor that he was infected with the HIV virus.'' The defense made no opening statement Friday. Under the law, the attacker must know he is carrying the AIDS virus when he performs an act, such as sexual intercourse, which would expose someone to the virus. Conviction does not require that the victim develop AIDS. It is not known if the boy has been tested for the virus. Lawyers say they are bound by state law not to discuss the case outside the courtroom. If convicted, Dempsey faces up to seven years in prison on the transmission charge and up to 30 years on the assault charge. He was being held in the Williamson County Jail on $50,000 bond. Garnati said Dempsey returned to Marion from California to live with his parents after becoming ill. Blood tests Dempsey underwent for the HIV virus in December turned up positive. ``The defendant's mother will tell you that the defendant never really did accept the fact that he was infected with the HIV virus,'' Garnati told the jury. Garnati told jurors that on May 27, the child slept in the same bed with Dempsey, and that Dempsey forced the youth to have oral sex against the boy's objections. The boy told a relative the next morning, despite Dempsey's promise to give him a pet turtle to keep quiet, Garnati said. ``How did a little 8-year-old boy know how to describe something like that?'' Garnati asked. ``The only conclusion is that he is telling the truth and that man did it,'' he said, pointing at Dempsey. The boy, now 9, answered attorneys with short sentences and appeared cheerful throughout Friday's testimony. In his cross-examination, Public Defender Larry Broeking asked the boy about statements he made to his father denying that abuse occurred. But under Garnati's questioning, the child insisted Dempsey assaulted him. After testifying, the boy waved happily to Dempsey and climbed down from the witness stand. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome cripples the body's defenses against disease, leaving a person prey to life-threatening infections and certain cancers. The fatal, incurable disease is spread by a virus transmitted mainly through sexual intercourse, shared hypodermic needles and from infected mothers to their infants before or during birth. In infected people, the AIDS virus is found in blood and semen.

DOC.HEAD: Sharp Cost Increases Feared In Household Products
DOC.TEXT: The nation's first laws restricting air pollutants in household goods could force some products off store shelves and raise the costs of others, manufacturers said Friday. But the state's largest consumer group said Thursday's sweeping decision by the state Air Resources Board is ``very fair and will be absorbed into the economy, providing a better quality of life.'' The board, which enforces air quality standards and sets emission levels, ordered a 45 percent cut in household hydrocarbons, the smog-forming pollutants in 16 types of products. The products include hair sprays, floor wax, window cleaners, furniture polish, engine degreasers, tile cleaners, hair mousses and gels, laundry prewash, insect repellents, aerosol shaving creams, nail polish removers, oven cleaners, windshield washer fluids and room air-fresheners. The regulations would remove about 45 tons of hydrocarbons daily from the atmosphere, an amount equivalent to the pollutants spewed by 1.4 million automobiles, the board said. The new rules will be phased in over five years, beginning in 1993, and mark the first time air pollution from household products has been ordered reduced. The decision also reflects the board's desire to target consumer-product pollution, a departure from the panel's traditional role of regulating automobile and industrial pollution. ``We hope we can make the changes in the time required, but in some cases, we don't know,'' said Ralph Engel, head of the Chemical Specialties Manufacturers Association. ``It will cause some pain and it will close some products.'' Among those that could be forced off the shelves are engine degreasers and aerosol-propelled air fresheners because technology is not yet available to enable those products to meet the board's standards, Engel said. His organization represents 426 companies, including manufacturers of household cleaners, disinfectants, beauty aids and automotive cleaners - virtually every product covered by the order. California accounts for about 12 percent of the companies' sales. The state estimated the regulations could increase costs from a penny to 23 cents per product. However, Engel said the increases could reach seven times the board's estimate and other industry reresentatives said the cost of reformulating the compounds would likely drive retail prices up. Harry Snyder, executive director of Consumers Union of California, the state's largest consumers' group, disagreed. ``The industry estimates are always 10 times to 100 times higher than what the additional costs actually are,'' Snyder said. ``Whatever cost increase there is will be absorbed by the economy. This is the kind of thing consumers have been asking for and are willing to pay for.'' The chemical industry ``can't figure a way to make money off these regulations. None of them have been willing to sell safety,'' he said. The regulations, the most comprehensive in the nation, stem from a 1988 California law requiring a crackdown on hydrocarbons in consumer goods. For example, hair spray - the largest producer of household hydrocarbons - has an average hydrocarbon content of about 94 percent for aerosol sprays and 70 percent for pump sprays. By 1998, the maximum level of hydrocarbons allowed in hair sprays would be 55 percent. Windshield washer fluids have the second-highest rate and room air-fresheners the third. Products in the 16 categories emit about 100 tons of hydrocarbons a day. The board's ruling would reduce those emissions to about 45 tons by 1998.

DOC.HEAD: Animal Activists to Protest Noise Ban
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf, `Silver said ...' to restore dropped word `not.'Picks up 9th graf, `The protesters ...'
DOC.TEXT: Animal activists protesting a state-sponsored deer hunt this weekend will challenge a new hunter-harassment law by making noise to try to frighten off the deer, their attorney said. ``We think it should be proper to make noises in order to alert the deer of possible harm,'' Boca Raton lawyer Barry Silver said Thursday. The activists, who have a state permit to gather on a roadside, also will protest the permit's noise restrictions, which Silver said violate free-speech rights. The activists were to gather Saturday outside the Camp Blanding Wildlife Management Area while the hunters are inside. The annual Youth Deer Hunt, in which parents and guardians teach children aged 8 to 15 to hunt safely, is sponsored by the state's Game and Fresh Water Fish Commission. Lt. Jim Huffstodt of the game commission said protesters will be in a designated area about one-quarter to one-half mile from the nearest hunting site. Huffstodt said game officers will enforce a state law that took effect on Oct. 1 that prohibits interfering with hunting, trapping and fishing and disturbing fish and game animals. Silver said the protesters consider the law vague, unconstitutional and unfair. ``It seems to us unfair not to be able to protect an animal but perfectly legal to destroy it,'' he said. The protesters are seeking to challenge restrictions placed on a permit they received from the Florida Department of Transportation. Don Quilio, the department's assistant district maintenance engineer in Lake City, said he was surprised to learn that the permit prohibited shouting and would remove that restriction if the protesters ask him to do so. But he said he stands by the restrictions against noisemakers and ``any type of noise pollution'' because airhorns and other unusual noises could confuse drivers of passing vehicles.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Tells Children to Forego Milk, Maintain Pride
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein told his country's children Friday that President Bush is depriving them of milk and sweets, but urged them to maintain their pride and dignity. In a speech read by an announcer on Baghdad radio and television, Saddam said Bush was behind a supposed milk and sugar shortage in Iraq, placed under a U.N.-sanctioned trade embargo following its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``We can cope, but what's most important is our pride and dignity,'' Saddam was quoted by the unidentified announcer. The statement, monitored in Nicosia, said Bush was trying to turn Iraqi children into slaves and control their future ``to satisfy world Zionism.'' Iraqi authorities have claimed there is a milk shortage, but Western journalists who visited Baghdad recently say stores are well stocked with milk. Saddam was speaking on the eve of Iraqi Children's Day, which commemorates the deaths of 39 Iraqi schoolchildren on Oct. 13, 1987, when an Iranian surface-to-surface missile hit their school in Baghdad's Dora district.

DOC.HEAD: Hunter Describes `Anguished Cry' in Shooting of Woman Mistaken for Deer
DOC.TEXT: A supermarket manager unleashed a ``terrible, anguished cry'' after he shot a woman he apparently mistook for a deer, his hunting companion testified Friday. Donald Rogerson, the manager of a supermarket produce department, was hunting in the woods behind Karen Wood's suburban home on Nov. 15, 1988. Thinking he saw a deer, he fired his rifle. Mrs. Wood was hit in the chest and died. A grand jury cleared Rogerson, but a second grand jury indicted him on a manslaughter charge. He went on trial Tuesday in Penobscot County Superior Court in Bangor, and has pleaded innocent. The prosecution contends Rogerson acted negligently or recklessly when he shot Mrs. Wood, 37, who was standing behind her home in the Bangor suburb of Hermon. She had just moved from Iowa to Maine with her husband and year-old twin girls. Authorities said Rogerson was about 180 feet from her when he fired. Defense attorneys contend the shooting was an accident. The case triggered a fierce public debate over hunting in a state where 216,476 people bought hunting licenses last year and 30,260 deer were killed. Peter Anderson said he was hunting a short distance from Rogerson when he heard a shot and, moments later, heard ``a terrible, terrible anguished cry.'' ``I heard cries of, ``Oh No! No!'' Anderson said. Anderson said he ran over and saw Rogerson kneeling beside Mrs. Wood. He quoted Rogerson as saying: ``I've shot a human being. Oh God. Why does God allow this to happen??'' Anderson said he was afraid Rogerson was so distraught he might try to kill himself with his rifle. He also quoted Rogerson as saying, ``Why did she have to have white mittens? I saw white mittens. I thought it was a (deer) flag.'' On Thursday, prosecutors introduced into evidence the mittens found near Mrs. Wood's body. Inspector Gary Sargent of the Maine Warden Service identified the mittens, which are white with brown leather palms, and said they were about the same size as an upraised deer tail. But he added that they were only ``about half'' the size of the white area that is visible on the backside of a running deer, which comprises both the underside of the tail and the animal's rump.

DOC.HEAD: Rural Backyard Dishes Favored in Cable TV Deal
DOC.TEXT: A new proposed compromise for re-regulating cable TV would require the industry to sell network programs to some 3 million mostly rural owners of backyard satellite dishes, its Senate sponsors said Friday. Providing details of an accord negotiated over the past two weeks, Sens. Al Gore, D-Tenn., and Timothy Wirth, D-Colo., said cable networks could still restrict their programs to subscribers of local cable distributors. But Gore said the compromise also now includes ``critical language protecting the backyard home satellite dish market'' - a provision that cable operators have vigorously fought the past eight years. ``The war for satellite television dish owners has been won,'' Gore said. However, he acknowledged that the bill could still be stymied in the waning days of the 101st Congress by objections from ``no more than a handful of colleagues'' and the Bush administration. ``To those who would continue to block its consideration on behalf of the cable industry or the White House, I would only say that such a move would backfire,'' he said, threatening to sponsor a tougher bill next year. Wirth said ``some of the provisions ... very damaging to the cable industry, which is headquartered in Denver'' were changed in the compromise after the bill was pulled from the Senate floor last month in response to his threat of a filibuster then. ``I'm not happy with every aspect of it, but important concessions were made on both sides and I believe the result is both workable and fair,'' he said. Wirth described the new provision on backyard satellite dishes as a recognition that their primarily rural market is in ``areas that cable and broadcasters cannot now serve and are unlikely to be able to serve in the future.'' Both the Senate bill and a similar measure passed by the House last month would require cable operators to provide a ``basic tier'' of service - local and public TV stations plus government-access channels - at rates to be regulated by the Federal Communications Commission. Rates for cable network programs such as Cable News Network, MTV or ESPN would not be regulated unless anticompetitive abuses could be demonstrated. Rates for premium programming such as Home Box Office and Cinemax would remain deregulated. The legislation is a response to many consumer complaints about excessive rates and poor service in many areas after the industry was deregulated by Congress in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Morocco Supports Saddam's Linking Kuwait to Palestinian Issue
DOC.TEXT: King Hassan II on Friday showed support for Saddam Hussein's efforts to link the Palestinian uprising to any Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait. He told Parliament the Iraqi president had succeeded in linking the two issues in international opinion and that this gives Saddam an ``honorable way'' to pull his troops out of Kuwait without losing face. ``This step is sufficient and has woken up the international conscience about a solution to the Palestinian problem,'' Hassan said. Iraq invaded the small, oil-rich emirate on Aug. 2. The monarch urged Saddam not to push the link too far. He advised him to rapidly pull out of Kuwait while settling for a ``moral engagement'' by the world regarding the Palestinians. ``Thus, the Iraqi president will spare the Arab nation a war that will destroy not only its military potential but its economic, industrial and agriculture infrastructure,'' the king said. Hassan said Israel would profit from such a war. Morocco is one of the few Arab countries to have contributed troops - a token deployment of 1,200 men - to the U.S.-led multinational force defending Saudi Arabia and tightening the United Nations embargo against Iraq and occupied Kuwait. Saddam and the Palestine Liberation Organization have said any withdrawal from Kuwait must be accompanied by an Israeli pullout from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, captured by Israel from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East war. The demands gained heightened world interest this week after Israeli police killed 19 Palestinian rioters and wounded 140 at the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, sacred to both Jews and Moslems. Arab League sources reported Friday that Morocco agreed to a PLO call for an urgent meeting next week to discuss a common Arab response to the killings.

DOC.HEAD: Hospital Will Investigate Birth to Woman Refused Help
DOC.TEXT: A hospital said Friday it was reviewing an incident in which a mentally ill woman gave birth in a tree planter after being kicked out of an emergency room because she was causing a disturbance. ``We're reviewing the case, and it's probably going to take a little while because it involved more than one agency,'' D.C. General Hospital spokeswoman Ann Chisholm said. Hospital officials declined further comment. Two police officers who heard Priscilla Jones screaming in the tree planter early Sept. 9 helped her give birth to a 3-pound, 5-ounce boy, police said. The homeless woman had falsely claimed to be pregnant on many occasions over the last three or four years, according to Victoria Roberts, administrator of Luther Place shelter where Jones sometimes lived. Jones is heavy-set, known for violent outbursts and frequent claims of pregnancy, and it may not have been apparent she was pregnant. ``No one believed her, even most of our workers, until a month before she actually delivered when we had a sonogram done,'' Roberts said. The night before the birth, Jones walked to the shelter in obvious distress, Roberts said. ``It was very obvious she was in labor,'' she said. ``The two women who called an ambulance told them that her contractions were about five minutes apart. What we don't know is whether the ambulance crew conveyed that information to the hospital.'' Jones has lived on the streets for about 10 years. Her violent rages and pregnancy claims probably are known to employees of a number of groups who operate services for the homeless, several police officers, and possibly the paramedics to arrived to help, Roberts said. ``The ambulance drivers probably recognized her. We've had to call police because she has been violent in the past,'' she said. Emergency room officials escorted her out after she began screaming. Jones walked about a block and gave birth, Roberts said. Sgt. Joseph Goodwin and Officer Patricia Newkirk were driving by in their patrol car when they heard the woman's shrieks, police said. After the baby was born, they took the woman and child back to the hospital, where they were admitted. The baby remained at D.C. General on Friday, and Luther Place workers were trying to convince Jones to move into the shelter, Robert said. ``She is severely ill and very resistant to help and this has been very traumatic for her,'' she said. ``Clearly mistakes have been made. We have a health care system that is simply overloaded and not able to deal with the reality of the situation.'' Several weeks before the birth, shelter officials had arranged to have Jones committed to St. Elizabeths Hospital because they were concerned she would harm the fetus. Hospital workers arrived too late, however, Roberts said. ``They arrived the Monday after the Saturday night she delivered,'' Robert said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Government Decrees Anti-Crime Campaign
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet government Friday announced it was taking urgent steps to fight organized crime and black marketeering, which have spread rapidly as private businesses have opened across the country. The decree by the Council of Ministers, or cabinet, said law enforcement agencies will receive better ``material and technical supplies'' and new staff, the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. In addition, special units of the KGB will be set up to combat organized crime, and a law enforcement center will be established to coordinate the activities of the KGB, Interior Ministry police and other agencies. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had promised on Wednesday that he would propose ``tough measures that will represent a powerful weapon in the hands of law enforcers and authorities.'' As Gorbachev has edged the country from a centrally planned to a market-based economy, protection rackets have preyed on fledgling small businesses. Black marketeers have also dealt in an ever-widening circle of goods, ranging from cigarettes at $5 a pack to personal computers at $42,500. The decree appeared aimed at such activity, which is widely resented by ordinary citizens who scrape by on salaries averaging $425 a month. But it also seemed to be part of a conservative backlash against economic reforms and an attempt to inject discipline into the crumbling central planning system. Many Soviet entrepreneurs operate in legal gray areas, buying materials at subsidized state prices and selling finished products for as much money as people will pay. Such activity would be legal in Westen countries, but is branded as speculation or profiteering by some Soviet officials. The decree could bring a crackdown on numerous cooperative businesses, from restaurants to dressmakers and small construction firms, which buy and sell goods without government approval. On Sept. 27, Gorbachev issued a related decree threatening to fine businesses that fail to fulfill goverment contracts. The move was widely viewed by Soviets as an attempt to bolster the central planning system at a time when many factories and farms are trying to bypass Moscow and trade directly with each other. Gorbachev's initiatives have sometimes appeared contradictory. He has both advocated transition to a market system and tried to keep the old economic system running. He has declared allegiance to ``the socialist ideal'' while also calling himself a ``radical'' and a ``pragmatist.'' Tass provided few details on the law and order decree. It did not say how many personnel would be added to law enforcement agencies, whether the agencies' budgets would rise, or what tactics they would use.

DOC.HEAD: St. Louis Man Sentenced in Battle Over John Lennon Car
DOC.TEXT: A former restaurant owner involved in litigation over a $350,000 Mercedes-Benz Pullman car once owned by John Lennon was sentenced Friday to 15 months in prison for money laundering. Edward Murphy, 44, pleaded guilty in August to violating federal currency reporting requirements. He admitted his girlfriend bought cashier's checks at six St. Louis area banks to avoid reporting transactions exceeding $10,000. Murphy, who once owned the American Cafe in St. Louis, was sentenced by U.S. District Judge John Nangle. Murphy used the cashier's checks to wire $45,000 in April 1988 from Mercantile Trust in St. Louis to London as payment of legal fees connected with the litigation, U.S. Attorney Stephen Higgins said. Ownership of the car was being challenged by former Supremes singer Mary Wilson. The car was sold by a repair shop in Basingstoke near London for $3,750 in 1982, two years after Ms. Wilson and her ex-husband, Pedro Ferrar, left it there for repairs. The car passed through several owners before Nick Miranda, a former St. Louis used car dealer, bought it in December 1984. Ms. Wilso won repossession of the car in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Security Council Agrees on Resolution Condemning Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Yemeni comment, PLO appears isolated. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council reached broad agreement Friday night on a resolution condemning Israel for the police killing of 19 Palestinians and asking a U.N. investigation into the deaths, diplomats said. Colombian Ambassador Enrique Penalosa, a member of the Security Council, said ``there is general agreement on a resolution,'' and that members hoped for a meeting and vote soon. ``We expect a unanimous vote,'' said Yemeni Ambassador Mohammed Abdulaziz Sallam. ``We are pleased with the condemnation and the call for action.'' Informal, closed consultations were delayed while delegates sought approval from their governments on the latest draft. The agreement would avert a U.S. veto of a harsher PLO resolution condemning Israel and would preserve the fragile U.S-led coaltion against Iraq that would have been jeopardized by a U.S. veto. The accord, reached after five days of marathon negotiations and U.S. lobbying, indicated the non-aligned movement had split on the issue and was not wholehertedly in the camp of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The PLO said it still objected to the latest draft, one of at least four documents the past four days, but the PLO appeared to be isolated. The PLO resisted a moderate draft resolution backed by the United States, Britain and others, which condemned Israel's use of force on the Temple Mount in Jerusalem last Monday but also parceled out blame to Palestinian stone-throwers. Palestinians on the mount were hurling rocks down on Jews praying at the Western Wall, or Wailing Wall, when police intervened and later began shooting. The draft resolution also asked the U.N. secretary-general to send a mission to investigate the violence and report its conclusions about ensuring the safety of Palestinians in the occupied territories. ``It's time to fish or cut bait,'' U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering told reporters Friday on entering the council chamber. The United States was bent on avoiding using its veto power, fearing a veto could endanger U.S. credibility in the Arab world and undermine the U.S.-led coalition against Iraq. Its drafting of a tough resolution condemning Israeli security forces was a rare gesture against its Israeli ally and marked a significant shift. America commonly shields Israel in the Security Council by vetoing condemnations. The PLO rejected the U.S. resolution as too weak and insisted there be no criticism of Palestinian stone-throwers. It initially sought a three-man Security Council mission that would make recommendations on how to protect Palestinians in the occupied territories. Israel had rejected such a mission in advance as infringing on its sovereignty. The Security Council includes five permanent members with veto power: the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union. The 10 other members are Canada, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, Finland, Ivory Coast, Malaysia, Romania, Yemen, Zaire.

DOC.HEAD: Right-Wing French Leader Asks Troops to Ponder Why They're in Gulf
DOC.TEXT: Jean Marie Le Pen, leader of the extreme right-wing National Front Party, sent an open letter Friday to French troops in the Persian Gulf region asking them to consider why they are there. ``For what reasons have our troops intervened far from our borders when our vital interests are not threatened?'' wrote Le Pen, a paratrooper in the Algerian war for independence in the 1950s. President Francois Mitterrand has dispatched about 13,000 French soldiers, airmen and sailors to the gulf to enforce the U.N. embargo against Iraq and occupied Kuwait. ``The contrast between the insufficience, not to say mediocrity, of your salaries compared to the opulence of the Arab potentates and international companies for whom you've been sent to fight shocks many French people,'' Le Pen told the soldiers. Le Pen, who favors expelling Moslem immigrants from France, has been one of the few major French political figures to criticize Mitterrand's policy in the gulf. Political observers believe Le Pen hopes to pick up support if the gulf crisis becomes a greater burden for France. The National Front has scored about 15 percent in national opinion polls.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Would Transform Cambodia Aid to Open Funds
DOC.TEXT: The Senate late Friday approved $20 million in new U.S. humanitarian aid to Cambodia, an apparent replacement for the past policy of covert aid to rebels fighting the Phnom Penh government. Senate Intelligence Committee Chairman David Boren, D-Okla., argued that aid to non-communist resistance forces should be given openly and through humanitarian channels. ``It is ... healthy for us to provide this aid in this form,'' Boren said. ``This is a policy question that should not be discussed behind closed doors. ... It givss us an opportunity to involve the American people in an open public discussion of this matter.'' Boren's committee voted earlier this year to end the $13 million program of covert aid to the non-communist resistance, which is allied with the dreaded Khmer Rouge in seeking to oust the Vietnam-backed communist government. The Khmer Rouge ran Cambdodia from 1975 until its government was ousted by a Vietnamese invasion in 1979. It killed more than a million of its own citizens. ``There is a strong likelihood that in the past some of the funds from the United States may have been used, directly or indirectly, to benefit the Khmer Rouge, and it's time we had restrictions that are enforceable,'' Boren said. Opponents of current U.S. policy say the covert aid has helped improve the fortunes of the Khmer Rouge. ``This is the killing fields,'' said Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo. ``The Khmer Rouge are still an active organization with Pol Pot (their ruthless leader) still in control. And their methods, if anything, have become more sophisticated in their evil.'' The $20 million aid figure apparently was arrived at by combining the $13 million covert program with a $7 million overt humanitarian program. Senators added the Cambodia aid directive to a $15.3 billion foreign aid bill for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1 as they began sorting through a series of proposed amendments. Work on the bill was not expected to be completed until Monday, and then it must go to a House-Senate conference committee to work out differences between competing versions. At the same time, the Senate also voted to strip from the bill a provision that would have given $15 million to the United Nations population fund, an agency which conducts family planning programs in 138 countries worldwide. On a vote of 51-38, the Senate failed to come up with the 60 votes needed to cut off a filibuster threatened by abortion opponents. They contended that the U.N. agency should get no money because it operates in China, whose one-child-per-family policy leads to forced abortions and sterilizations. ``The United States should not be involved either directly or indirectly with such grievous violations of human rights,'' argued Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H. President Bush vetoed last year's version of the foreign aid bill over a similar provision, forcing Congress to back down.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth Planeload of Middle East Refugees Arrives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting to add writethru designator. LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with details about evacuees, quotes; CORRECTS that seven Canadian on board, sted six. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 260 Americans and other refugees from Kuwait ended a long and tiring odyssey Friday, some rejoicing as the plane landed on native soil while others began searching for a new homeland. As Hurricane Lili churned off the North Carolina coast, the chartered Pan Am Boeing 747 dubbed the Clipper Wild Wave touched down about 4:40 p.m. Of the 257 refugees aboard, state officials said there were 123 American citizens, seven Canadians, and the rest were of unknown nationality. They included two young girls who had not seen their mother for more than 10 weeks. ``When the plane touched down in North Carolina, I hollered so loud `Thank God I'm in freedom city,''' said Mohammad Issa, a U.S. citizen of Jordanian descent who was accompanied by his wife and parents. The first group off the plane were woman in Middle Eastern garb, such as flowing robes and veils, carrying sleeping children and some personal belongings as they came down the ramp. North Carolina National Guardsmen escorted other children of varying ages off the plane. A number of young men in casual clothes and men in business suits also were on board. Issa said his family's journey by bus from Kuwait to the Iraqi capital, Baghdad, was the ``most miserable trip we've ever taken. There was no food. A trip that was supposed to take 1{ hours, maybe two, took 14 hours.'' ``They were trying to break us down mentally, to make us suffer some,'' said Issa, a former U.S. Marine once stationed at Camp Lejeune, N.C. Two girls on the plane, ages 4 and 6, were reunited with their mother, who left Kuwait on Aug. 1 to visit her father in Chicago. Iraq invaded Kuwait the next day. ``When they came through the door, that was one relieved mother,'' said Joe Dean, secretary of the North Carolina Department of Crime Control and Public Safety. ``They were clinging to their mother about as tight as you could cling to your mama. And she was clinging to them about as tight.'' The woman's husband, an oil engineer and Kuwaiti citizen, was not permitted to travel with their children. The flight arrived in London on Thursday night, where passengers spent the night before completing the final leg of thir journey away from the crisis in the Middle East. All qualified for the evacuation flight because they were either citizens or family members of citizens of the United States or Canada. About 100 of those on the flight are under age 13, including a few infants who are newborn or nearly newborn, officials said. Officials with the state Division of Emergency Management said three on board would be in wheelchairs. It was the fourth refugee flight from Iraq and Kuwait to land at Raleigh-Durham, where one terminal has been vacant for more than a year because of airline industry consolidations. The terminal ``has lots of room,'' said Renee Hoffman, spokeswoman for the North Carolina Department of Crime Control and Public Safety. ``Some of the other terminals used at other locations were regular terminals so it was very crowded. Since we've got this terminal dedicated to the repatriation, it goes very smoothly.'' Ms. Hoffman said it normally takes four to six hours to process the refugees and send them on their way to other flights or hotels. The terminal includes a customs area, a cafeteria, a medical area, a bank, loan officers from the federal government, airline reservation personnel, and a media room for those who want to speak to reporters. The news media aren't allowed to go into the terminal while refugees are there.

DOC.HEAD: Former Spy Says KGB Was Behind Eastern Europe Tumult
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 12th graf pvs `Gordievsky eluded' to ADD excerpts from book. Picks up 13th graf pvs. `The book's...' Edits thereafter to trim
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet KGB helped spark last year's revolutions in Eastern European to put pro-Gorbachev, reform Communists in power, former KGB double agent Oleg Gordievsky said Friday. But the secret agents and their Communist Party bosses never expected the outpouring of anti-Communist fervor that followed, and they were helpless to stop it, he said. ``Here they just lost because they wanted it to stop and it was impossible to stop the momentum, it was too late,'' said Gordievsky, who worked as a double agent for 13 years until he defected to Britain in 1985. Gordievsky did not say where he learned about the alleged KGB involvement in Eastern Europe's tumult. He said he regularly meets U.S. government officials and analysts and is a consultant of the journal ``Intelligence and National Security.'' Dressed immaculately in a double-breasted suit, the bespectacled Gordievsky, who turned 52 on Wednesday, was without his red-haired wig and beard disguise, a security precaution to foil would-be KGB assassins. In an interview at a London hotel, he talked animatedly about his defection, which sparked a tit-for-tat expulsion of 31 Soviet and 31 British diplomats, trade representatives and journalists. Despite the goodwill of Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev's perestroika and glasnost, Gordievsky would still face a death sentence in the Soviet Union. ``The feelings of irritation, evil and unpleasant feelings of jealousy and revenge in the KGB and among other traditional Soviet Communist apparatchiks is still the same,'' he said. Gordievsky, who said his father and brother were both KGB agents, became a double agent for the British while posted in Copenhagen in the early 1970s, he said, as a result of his disillusionment over the 1968 Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia. ``I knew that all the purges, all the brutal, brutal repressions were true. What Khrushchev said in his secret speech to the 20th Party Congress was just the tip of the iceberg. Incredible crimes had been committed,'' Gordievsky said. The former spy was transferred to London, becoming one of the top KGB agents in Britain until he was recalled to Moscow and questioned about his activities. Gordievsky eluded his KGB tail and escaped to the West, where he has co-authored ``KGB: The Inside Story'' to be published in Britain and the United States on Oct. 19. ``The KGB looked to Gorbachev to provide the dynamism and discipline necessary to break out of the Soviet Union's economic stagnation and establish a stable correlation of forces with the West,'' said excerpts of the book that appeared in Saturday's issue of The Times. ``In the months before (Communist Party General Secretary Konstantin) Chernenko's long-expected death in March 1985, the KGB put great care into briefing Gorbachev in a way that would allow him to impress the rest of the Politburo with his grasp of Soviet and world affairs. ``His election as general secretary in March 1985 was not, of course, due wholly or even mainly to support from the KGB. But the center (the KGB's Moscow headquarters) saw the election, nonetheless, as a major victory.'' The book's co-author, Cambridge University historian Christopher Andrew, said despite Soviet attempts to discredit Gordievsky, he was in a unique position to know what went on inside Lubyanka, the KGB's headquarters. ``Oleg Kalugin, the youngest general in the KGB first chief directorate, said Gordievsky carried away from the first chief directorate virtually everything that could be carried away ... it's a metaphor for simply saying he knew a helluva lot,'' Andrew said in an interview. ``KGB: The Inside Story,'' reportedly reveals KGB involvement in the shooting down of the Korean Airlines Flight 007 in 1983, which killed 269 people. Andrew said Gordievsky was in London at the time and received a series of KGB instructions about the incident. The book reportedly identifies some key U.S. officials who worked, sometimes unwittingly, for the KGB and the identity of the infamous fifth man. It is widely believed that a fifth spy worked with Guy Burgess, Donald Maclean, Anthony Blunt and Kim Philby, prominent Britons who were recruited by the KGB from Cambridge University. Gordievsky said the fifth man was a member of the British intelligence community.

DOC.HEAD: German Interior Minister Shot, Seriously Wounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with suspect identified as Dieter K., revolver used, teen-aged daughter saw attack. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Interior Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble, who guided negotiations of the treaty that linked the two German states, was shot and seriously wounded late Friday at a campaign gathering, police said. Schaeuble, 48, was struck by two bullets in the head and chest and seriously wounded, but his life was not immediately in danger, Interior Ministry spokesman Roland Bachmeier said. Other reports said one bullet hit Schaeuble in the neck. Police arrested a 37-year-old suspect who ``comes from the criminal drug scene,'' the ZDF television network reported. The Interior Ministry in Bonn said the gunman had been undergoing treatment for schizophrenia. ARD television identified him only as Dieter K., and said he used a revolver in the shooting. Ralf Krueger, head of the Baden-Wuerttemberg state criminal office, said there was no evidence the suspect had a terrorist background, and that he probably acted alone. Police denied an early report that two others involved in the 10 p.m. shooting had fled. Schaeuble is a member of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's inner circle and was considered a possible successor to the chancellor. As interior minister he was responsible for many police functions, including drug probes, but not investigating terrorism. The attack, at a restaurant in Oppenau, in the Offenburg district outside Freiburg in southwest Germany, was the most serious incident since East and West Germany reunited on Oct. 3. Schaeuble was rushed to the hospital in Offenburg for treatment, about 9 miles west of where the attack took place, police said. A security guard who threw himself in front of Schaeuble was wounded in the stomach, according to the Interior Ministry. Schaeuble was named interior minister by Kohl in April 1989, replacing former minister Eduard Zimmermann. Previously Schaeuble was Kohl's chief of staff. A popular, boyish-looking figure, he has been a member of Kohl's Christian Democratic Union Party since 1966, and a strong backer of Kohl's successful efforts to unite the two Germanys. Following his smooth handling of negotiations that led up to unification, Schaeuble had been tipped as a future Christian Democrat candidate for chancellor. Many Germans recall Schaeuble's emotional announcement to Parliament last Nov. 30 that Deutsche Bank chief Alfred Herrhausen, the nation's top banker, had been killed in a bomb blast. Violent attacks on top politicians have been rare in postwar German history, although top businessmen have been terrorist targets. Schaeuble is said to be one of Germany's most heavily protected politicians. After the shooting, the suspect was wrestled to the ground by members of the minister's entourage until he could be handcuffed by police, according to ARD. It quoted a Munich-based journalist at the scene as saying Schaeuble was able to speak before being taken to the hospital. One of Schaeuble's teen-aged daughters witnessed the attack, said Olga Piess, who was at the restaurant. The shooting was the most serious attack on a public figure in Germany since April 25, when an apparently deranged woman stabbed Social Democratic leader Oskar Lafontaine in the neck during a campaign stop in Cologne. Lafontaine, Kohl's leading challenger in the December election, returned to the campaign trail after leaving the hospital weeks later.

DOC.HEAD: Fired Mechanic Kills Two, Wounds One Before Killing Himself at Dealership
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with injured man dying of injuries, CORRECTS first name of injured man to John David, sted John. Picks up 6th graf, ``He seemed ...' No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A disgruntled former employee opened fire at a car dealership Friday, killing a fellow auto mechanic and the general manager and wounding another man before turning the gun on himself, police said. Employees said Wilton Reed, 25, of Baltimore, was fired Wednesday when he refused to work on a car that had been returned to the dealership's service shop. Baltimore County police spokesman Jay Miller said Reed walked into the service shop just before noon, and fired on his former co-workers with a 9mm pistol. A veteran mechanic, Robert Daughton, 35, was killed outright, and the general manager of the dealership, William Bishop, 46, died of his injuries several hours later at University of Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore. The service manager, John David Laird, 35, who fired Reed, remained in critical condition at the hospital Friday night, Miller said. ``He seemed like a friendly enough guy ... I guess something just snaps in a person,'' said employee Kim Miller, 25. ``From what I heard, he had problems with his girlfriend. I guess they were engaged to be married and she broke off the engagement two weeks ago.'' Reed refused to work on a car that had been returned to the dealership, telling Laird he had not worked on it the first time, several mechanics said. Reed was told he had to work on the car on his own time, and when he refused, he was fired, Miller said. Reed methodically shot the three before killing himself, employees said. Reed had a casual conversation with one of the employees when he first walked in, Miller said. The employee noticed Reed was wearing a suit and tie and asked him if he had come to pick up his last paycheck, he said. Reed told the employee he wasn't there to pick up his last check and walked into the bay area, where there were 18 mechanics working. He walked to Bishop's office and shot him, turned and shot Laird and walked to the fourth service bay where he shot Daughton in the head. Reed pointed the gun at a customer who was standing next to Daughton, but the customer ducked behind a car, Miller said. Employees at the dealership described Reed as a friendly co-worker who had worked at the dealership for two years.

DOC.HEAD: Atlantis Prepares for First Launch in Eight Months
DOC.TEXT: The space shuttle Atlantis, grounded for over seven months, emerged from its hangar Friday evening in preparation for a launch next month. The shuttle, strapped atop a giant crawler-transporter, began its methodical six-hour journey to its launch pad 3.4 miles away. Once in place Saturday morning, NASA crews will make final preparations for Atlantis' launch on Nov. 7 or Nov. 8, carrying a Defense Department satellite into space. The launch had originally been scheduled for July 9 but was canceled when technicians discovered a liquid hydrogen leak in the craft. Unable to stop the leak, Atlantis was rolled back into the Vehicle Assembly Building. Technicians eventually traced the source of the leak to a 17-inch diameter plumbing line, which had contaminated seals. After repairing the leak, shuttle crews began to reassemble the craft, but were interrupted by another setback. A 70-pound scaffolding beam, left by workers in the engine compartment, damaged fuel lines as the orbiter was hoisted upright. NASA spokesman Bruce Buckinghm said NASA will test the fuel systems of the shuttle within the next couple of weeks to ensure their safety. Atlantis' last flight, also on a secret Defense Department mission, was Feb. 28 to March 4. Atlantis' sister ship Columbia is scheduled to roll to its launch pad Saturday night for a flight in December.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Toddler Trades Hospital Food for Airline Food
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2 grafs for 7th graf, `The Gonzales ...' to UPDATE with Tracey arriving in Texas, greeting her brothers. Picks up 8th graf, `Before undergoing ...
DOC.TEXT: A 3-year-old Texas girl unable to digest food was discharged from the hospital Friday, nearly three months after undergoing a liver and small intestine transplant. On her return home, her first meal, of all things, was airplane food. Tracey Kay Gonzales, of Corpus Christi, received a new liver and small intestine in a 14-hour operation in July.
