Her doctors say her success will clear the way for transplants on others with life-threatening intestinal defects. The toddler's quick recovery won her a trip home. She left the hospital early Friday and, after weeks of hospital food and an occasional meal away from the medical center, she graduated to airline food. ``She'll eat anything,'' said Tracey's mother, Pam. ``Most of the time, she's talking about food: `Take me here or take me there to eat.''' Bessie Peters, in the billing department of the airline's caterer, said passengers aboard Tracey's plane were served omelets with cheddar cheese or turkey, muffins or croissants and orange juice and milk. When she arrived at the Corpus Christi airport, Tracey rushed to see her two brothers, Gary, 10 and Tommy, 8, whom she last saw in April. She told them the first thing she wanted to do was to play football. However, doctors have said Tracey will not be able to play contact sports. Before undergoing surgery, the girl suffered from short gut syndrome, in which the small intestine was too short to process food sufficiently. She sustained liver damage on a high-protein diet fed intravenously. ``Before the transplant, she was eating. She has taste buds. Her body just couldn't do anything with it,'' Children's Hospital spokeswoman Sue Cardillo said Friday. Tracey will return to Pittsburgh on Oct. 21 to begin outpatient treatment. While she's home, doctors will watch for signs of infection or rejection. Tracey is taking the experimental drug FK-506, which doctors say is safer and more potent than the common anti-rejection drug cyclosporin. The drug made Tracey's operation possible, and the survival of two other transplant patients on FK-506 will make surgery possible for others, said transplant pioneer Dr. Thomas Starzl. ``The bottom line is that intestinal transplants are going to be practical and are going to be widely used,'' Starzl said. Small-intestine transplants have a poor success rate. Since 1983, one adult and three children have died within a year of their surgeries at Pittsburgh hospitals. One adult and a teen-ager are still alive. The small intestine transplanted into Tracey works just like her own would have if it had been healthy, with muscles moving the food down the digestive tract. ``It's a little bit surprising. There were studies that suggested that that might not be possible,'' Starzl said. While she had her dysfunctional old liver, Tracey retained water and looked chubby Thursday night at the hospital. Dr. Jorge Reyes said doctors would gauge Tracey's recovery by the amount of water loss and muscle gain. ``Part of the assessment is to see how her swelling is coming down and how her lean muscle mass is building up,'' said Reyes, another of the girl's surgeons. Since the surgery is new, it's difficult to measure progress, he said. ``Her postoperative time was relatively uneventful and she recovered in good time, but there's really nothing for a base to compare it to,'' Reyes said.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Kill Egypt's Parliament Speaker, Four Guards
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with added details of shooting, funeral plans, Abu Nidal group fingered earlier, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos CA1,2,4,5
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen killed the parliament speaker and four security men outside a luxury hotel Friday, days after the government warned that terrorists might strike to punish Egypt for its opposition to Iraq. There was no claim of responsibility. Officials said they suspected either Moslem fundamentalists or terrorists from Iraq. Police stepped up security in Cairo and put airports on alert after the shootings. Rifaat el-Mahgoub, 64, speaker of the People's Assembly and the second ranking politician after the president, was shot in his chauffeur-driven Mercedes-Benz as the car passed the Hotel Semiramis Inter-Continental, said Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa. Moussa told reporters four gunmen, aged 20 to 25, attacked el-Mahgoub's car and a security car as el-Mahgoub was driving to an official function at another hotel about 1{ miles away. He said two men were standing on the road, their rifles hidden in bags. They opened fire, joined by two others on motorbikes. Three men escaped on the bikes. The fourth ran into a densely populated area nearby and disappeared. Police said a police brigadier and lieutenant who chanced by on another security mission tried to chase the running gunman, but he killed the brigadier and badly wounded the lieutenant. The shooting occurred a block from the U.S. Embassy. The minister said two security men were killed in el-Mahgoub's car and another in a security car traveling behind him. A Soviet-made hand grenade and four homemade explosives were found on the roadside near the hotel and defused. A military funeral for the five victims was planned for Saturday. President Hosni Mubarak and other high-ranking officials are scheduled to attend. The assassination came one day after a national referendum to decide whether Mubarak should dissolve Parliament and call new elections. Moussa warned before the vote that Iraqis and other Arabs had infiltrated Egypt to undermine the government through terror attacks, including assassinations. Egypt has led Arab opposition to Iraq's Aug. 2 occupation of Kuwait. The interior minister said Friday he suspected the attackers were foreigners or local Moslem fundamentalists, but refused to elaborate. The state-owned Al-Ahram newspaper, quoting police sources, said last Monday that local Moslem extremists were collaborating with Palestinian terrorists sent to Egypt by Iraq on sabotage missions. It said the extremists provided weapons and explosives to five Palestinians of the Abu Nidal group. Abu Nidal - real name Sabry el-Banna - leads a radical Palestinian faction and is known worldwide as a terrorist mastermind. The state-owned Middle East News Agency quoted a security officer at Cairo airport on Friday as saying all airports were on a high state of alert to prevent the assailants from leaving Egypt. Security checkpoints were set up along Cairo bridges and near the attack site. An hour after the shooting, el-Mahgoub's black Mercedes sat outside the hotel, its rear window and right front window smashed. One of the two slain bodyguards in the car lay in the front seat, his head torn apart by gunfire. A second car - a green Peugeot - was stopped about 200 yards away, a man's body hanging onto the roadway from the rear seat. The man was identified as a security agent traveling with el-Mahgoub. Moussa said he was traveling 300 yards behind el-Mahgoub's car. He dismissed questions about whether he was the intended target. Islamic militants tried to kill an interior minister with a bomb and shot at two interior ministers in 1987. One was wounded seriously. Mubarak's predecessor, Anwar Sadat, was killed on Oct. 6, 1981 by Moslem extremists, who then tried unsuccessfully to overthrow the government. In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We are shocked by the assassination.'' The shooting occurred shortly before Moussa was to have briefed reporters on the outcome of the referendum. Results showed 93 percent of Egyptians voting approved Mubarak's proposal and the president later issued a decree dissolving the assembly and calling for elections on Nov. 29. Mubarak scheduled the referendum after a constitutional court declared illegal the election laws under which Parliament was seated. Because Mubarak has not named a vice president, the speaker of the People's Assembly ranks right behind the president. El-Mahgoub had been speaker since 1984. A member of the governing National Democratic Party, el-Mahgoub used his authority to pass legislation in accordance with the government's wishes.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Charges Martinez Fund-Raiser
DOC.TEXT: A leading fund-raiser for Gov. Bob Martinez was indicted Friday on charges of felony theft and official misconduct charges, a newspaper reported. The Orange County grand jury indictment against B.J. West was sealed, but her attorney, Bob Leventhal, said it contained felony charges of grand theft and official misconduct, The Orlando Sentinel reported in Saturday's editions. The charges stem from allegations that West violated state travel laws and misused her position as a $46,340-a-year employee for the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services. Upon conviction, each charge carries a maximum penalty of five years in prison and a $5,000 fine. Martinez named West chairwoman of the Orlando-Orange County expressway authority in 1987, the same year the health agency hired her to solicit corporate contributions for its programs. She also raises money for Martinez' campaign. A Martinez spokesman said the governor had no comment. West denied the charges, saying ``I will not rest until my name and my reputation are totally cleared of these unfounded charges.'' The grand jury based its probe on a state comptroller's investigation that found West was overpaid about $4,000 for salary, travel and telephone expenditures, the newspaper reported. The investigation, completed in May, found that West improperly claimed to be working for the health agency on 25 days that she was traveling for the expressway authority. One trip involved a transportation convention in Spain for which she claimed both sick leave and regular work time with HRS. The comptroller's investigators did not find that West campaigned for Martinez on state time. West has repaid the money, the newspaper said. West blamed opponents of a controversial toll road the expressway authority wants to build for spreading lies about her work. She has said she did not understand how to fill out the time sheets. Mac Stipanovich, Martinez' campaign manager, criticized Orange-Osceola State Attorney Lawson Lamar, a Democrat, for seeking the indictment. The Republican governor seeks re-election Nov. 6. ``I think he's showboating,'' Stipanovich said. ``I can't think of another instance in which a state employee was indicted for incorrectly filling out travel forms.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Producers Call for Fund to Protect Latin American Economies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with accord on oil fund, drug communique; picks up 5th graf pvs, `Earlier in ...; INSERTS 1 graf after 14th graf pvs, `Peru is..' to UPDATE with 4 new members admitted; picks up 15th graf pvs, `Mexico, Venezuela...
DOC.TEXT: The presidents of eight Latin American countries agreed Friday to create a fund from windfall oil earnings that would be used to help Latin countries suffering from low prices for other raw materials. The fund was proposed by the leaders of Mexico, Venezuela and Colombia, all oil producers. Later, the summit of eight presidents who met here Thursday and Friday ordered consultations on how to create the fund. Host President Carlos Andres Perez said the fund aims at stabilizing prices for traditional Latin American exports - such as oil, copper, coffee and sugar. ``All of Latin American nations are recurrently affected by dramatic ups and downs in prices of its exports. One day it is oil, next it is sugar and copper,'' Perez said at a news conference. The idea of the fund would be to soften the fall of countries whose commodities suffer price swings. But it wasn't immediately clear how the plan would be carried out. The eight presidents later released a communique promising to intensify their fight against drug trafficking, but warning their efforts would be useless if rich countries did not curb demand. ``A global strategy is needed in the fight against drugs,'' the presidents said. Earlier in the week, Chilean President Patricio Aylwin proposed that oil-producing countries donate some of their export earnings when oil prices were especially high. On Friday, Perez and presidents Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico and Cesar Gaviria of Colombia proposed the initiative be extended to include donations from earnings for other raw products, such as coffee and sugar. In practice, however, oil is one of the few raw materials to produce windfall income in recent decades. Venezuela is likely to get at least $2.4 billion in extra revenue thanks to soaring oil prices since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Perez did not explain how the fund would operate or how much money would be invested. He said all nations would contribute in order to receive benefits. While oil exporters like Mexico, Ecuador and Venezuela are theoretically favored by skyrocketing oil prices, experience has shown that oil boom periods result in severe inflation and economic destabilization. Several weeks ago, Perez announced Venezuela would create a stabilization fund with its extra oil revenue to avoid inflationary pressures. Venezuela has been forced to submit its economy to an austerity plan since the last oil boom bubble bust. ``The current oil prices don't do anyone any good, neither producers nor consumers,'' Ecuadoran President Rodrigo Borja said Thursday. In addition to Borja, Perez, Mexico's Salinas del Gortari, Gaviria of Colombia and Chile's Aylwin, the presidents attending the summit were Carlos Menem of Argentina, Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil and Luis Alberto Lacalle of Uruguay. Peru is also a member of the Rio Group, but President Alberto Fujimori failed to win congressional authorization to leave his country and instead sent a delegation headed by his wife. The presidents decided Friday to expand the group to include Bolivia and Paraguay, and to invite one representative each from Central America and another from the Caribbean. Venezuela, Mexico, Colombia, Ecuador and Trinidad and Tobago together produce over 5.8 million barrels of oil daily. The other Latin countries are net oil importers whose economies have been badly hit by high oil prices. Along with the energy crisis, the main subject of the Latin summit was a proposal by President Bush to create a hemispheric free-trade zone from Alaska to Patagonia. Bush is scheduled to visit Argentina, Paraguay, Brazil and Venezuela in early December. ``He will notice our receptivity to his proposal,'' Perez said.

Saddam Hussein is starving the last foreign diplomats from their encircled compounds in Kuwait, a triumph in his campaign to turn the invaded emirate into the 19th province of Iraq. The Dutch, Italian and Polish embassies, among the compounds besieged exactly seven weeks ago today, have withdrawn the last of their diplomats from Kuwait City in the past week. The Belgian and German governments say they will follow suit shortly. The announcements leave the Americans, British, Canadians and French as the only holdouts among Western missions. Only a few other nations appear to be staffing their embassies with diplomats. The remaining diplomats are surviving mainly on canned food and occasional loaves of bread carried in by local staff. But they are surrounded by Iraqi troops enforcing a blockade of supplies. In most cases, water and electricity have been cut off. ---= SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) - California has adopted the nation's toughest air-quality standards for household products, ordering a 45 percent cut in smog-forming pollutants from such items as hair spray, window cleaner and floor wax. The order Thursday by the Air Resources Board will be phased in from 1993 to 1998 and could add up to 23 cents to the price of the 16 types of products covered, said Jim Boyd, ARB executive officer. Products covered include engine degreaser, windshield washer fluid, furniture polish, room air freshener, laundry prewash, nail polish remover, insect repellent, oven cleaner, hair styling gel and mousse, tile cleaner, and shaving cream. When fully in force, the rules would eliminate about 45 tons per day of hydrocarbon emissions, an amount equal to the emissions of about 1.4 million vehicles. Currently the household products emit about 100 tons of hydrocarbons a day. ---=

Hurricane Lili lashed North Carolina's Outer Banks with gale-force winds early today and combined with remnants of Tropical Storm Marco in a squeeze play that unloaded heavy rain on the South. A hurricane watch was posted for the North Carolina coast, where residents watched seas swell to 8 feet and awaited word on whether to leave their homes. By 10:30 p.m. EDT, Lili was about 620 miles southeast of Cape Hatteras, N.C., moving west at 23 mph with winds of 75 mph. Earlier, the hurricane brought rain, thunderstorms and wind gusts to Bermuda. ``The current feeling is that it will just skirt the coast,'' said Joe Pelissier, a National Weather Service forecaster in Raleigh, N.C. ---= BONN, Germany (AP) - The Stasi secret police is officially defunct, but its shadow of fear still darkens the lives of Germans in their newly unified land. A rash of arrests of former East German spies has embarrassed people who ran West Germany's intelligence network and raised questions about their effectiveness. But the troubles don't stop there. Criminal justice officials fret over the legal complications of prosecuting former Stasi workers who will undoubtedly say they were only following orders, just as Nazi criminals did after World War II. Chancellor Helmut Kohl vows Stasi criminals will be prosecuted, but he warns against letting the Stasi legacy ``poison our nation's atmosphere. ---= BOSTON (AP) - A woman bugged about paying toll charges just to talk to her daughter six miles away has won a 17-year battle to get the phone company to change its rate structure. But she won't fully share in the victory. Estelle Simon, 70, of rural Sudbury, can call her daughter's town of Marlboro for free, but Sudbury residents still will be charged for calling Lincoln, which shares a high school with Sudbury, because of how the system is wired. ``Can you believe this?'' Simon said in an interview this week. ``I blew my top.'' There also will still be a charge to call the local crisis line six miles away in Acton.

Gunmen killed the parliament speaker and four security men outside a luxury hotel Friday, days after the government warned that terrorists might strike to punish Egypt for its opposition to Iraq. There was no claim of responsibility in the slayings. Officials said they suspected either Moslem fundamentalists or terrorists from Iraq. Police stepped up security in Cairo and placed airports on alert following the shootings. Rifaat el-Mahgoub, 64, speaker of the People's Assembly and the second ranking politician after the president, was shot in his chauffeur-driven Mercedes as the car passed the Hotel Semiramis Inter-Continental, said Interior Minister Abdel-Halim Moussa. ---= BEIRUT (AP) - A Shiite Moslem gunman fired at Christian Gen. Michel Aoun on Friday as he addressed thousands of supporters, but the bullet missed the general and struck one of his aides, Aoun's radio station said. The assassination attempt came shortly after the Syrian army moved thousands of troops toward the enclave for an expected attack on the headquarters of Aoun, who has resisted orders by Lebanon's government to step down. The developments contributed to the growing instability in the Middle East, where the United States is struggling to hold together its alliance of Arab states opposed to the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Syria, the main power-broker in Lebanon and Iraq's arch-rival, is an important part of that effort. But the U.S.-Arab alliance has been shaken b Israel's slaying of 19 Palestinians in Jerusalem on Monday. ---= MOSCOW (AP) - A court on Friday convicted a Russian nationalist of fanning ethnic hostility and insulting Jews in a landmark case that had galvanized fears of anti-Jewish pogroms and fueled a Jewish exodus from the country. American and Soviet Jewish leaders hailed the verdict as the first real sign of a government crackdown on Russian anti-Semitism. A lawyer said it was the first time an accused anti-Semite has been put on trial in Russia. The judge sentenced Konstantin Smirnov-Ostashvili, a 54-year-old factory worker, to two years in a labor camp. ``Everything is taken out of context! It's all a lie!'' the defendant shouted angrily in one of many outbursts during the half-hour session in the packed and heavily guarded Moscow City Court. ---= BERLIN (AP) - Like an old ghost in a new house, Erich Honecker is haunting the reunited Germans. Toppled from power a year ago, the 78-year-old former Communist chief is confined to a Soviet military hospital near Berlin, guarded by stone-faced soldiers. His health is the topic of nearly daily news reports, some saying the ousted East German leader, who is suffering from kidney cancer, is well enough to be imprisoned and others saying he is not. As Germans forge their new country, many are demanding punishment for despised members of the East Berlin regime that ran the country into the ground. Honecker tops the list. ---= LOS ANGELES (AP) - The search for alien civilizations in space expanded to cover the entire sky as a new radio receiver started running in Argentina on Friday, the anniversary of Columbus' discovery of the new world. ``Today represents the opening up of half of the universe to the search by the human species for extraterrestrial intelligence,'' said astronomer Carl Sagan, president of the Planetary Society. ``You have to be made of wood not to be interested in knowing whether we're alone in the universe,'' Sagan said by phone from Ithaca, N.Y., where he is a professor at Cornell University. ``Here we are for the first time in human history when it's technically possible to find out. And it's very cheap. ``Wouldn't we be ashamed of ourselves if the answer was there for the taking and we were too shy to look?''

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Insurgency Devastates Kashmir's Economy
DOC.TEXT: The 16th-century Mogul rulers of north India thought of Kashmir as a paradise and left the dusty, scorching plains for summer holidays in the lush valley surrounded by steep Himalayan foothills. They started a tradition, and eventually 750,000 people visited Kashmir each April-October season. This year, not even 20,000 have come. A Moslem insurgency and a harsh government crackdown have made the valley more a battlefield than a tourist destination. Soldiers are billeted in Srinagar's luxury hotels and patrol the boulevard along Dal Lake. Gunfire echoes in the still nights. ``We have been devastated,'' said Mohammed Yusuf Chapri, whose family has been in the tourism business since 1870. ``Tourism has dropped 99.5 percent.'' Chapri, a burly man in his 50s, owns two houseboats, the floating hotels that made Dal Lake famous. At least 1,150 are anchored on the lake, ranging from economy one-roomers to luxurious six-bedroom units richly paneled in walnut. ``Even in World War II, tourists flocked to Kashmir,'' Chapri said. ``From what I've heard, this is the worst year for tourism in Kashmir in the past 120 years.'' The government agrees, but says it can do little. ``We have to live with the fall in tourism until conditions return to normal,'' said Ved Marwah, an adviser to Gov. Girish Saxena appointed by the federal government. ``People dependent on tourism have suffered,'' he said. ``What we have done is to ensure that their loans are not called and no penalty interest is levied for inability to pay back.'' Others suffering include tour operators, hoteliers and owners of shikaras, the gondola-like boats that carried vacationers on sightseeing trips and floating picnics. Chapri estimated the total number of people dependent on the industry at about 500,000. Kashmir's economic disaster extends far beyond tourism. The valley's largest industry is agriculture, which accounts for 80 percent of its income. Rice grown in Kashmir is consumed in the region, but apples are sold to other parts of India. This year, the deep red and golden apples of Kashmir have been picked and stored, but few buyers have come. ``There are just no traders,'' said an orchard owner who could not find buyers for his $16,000 harvest. ``This fighting has scared them away.'' Truck owners, whose vehicles carried Kashmir apples to the main wholesale market in New Delhi, also fear entering the valley. Marwah, the governor's adviser, said state authorities had started an apple-marketing program but would buy only 100,000 tons of a crop that totaled 1.7 million tons. One economic benefit of the insurgency was greater output of handicrafts and hand-woven carpets and handicrafts, he said. As Marwah explained: ``There's so much trouble, people stay more at home, and if they're home, they tend to work more.'' A government fund of $9 milion has been set up to buy handicrafts and sell them elsewhere in the country. Tourist shops in neighboring Nepal are filled with Kashmiri shawls, jewelry and papier-mache boxes, which they sell to Indian, Japanese and Western tourists who used to visit Srinagar. ``The economy is under stress, but the government has done a lot,'' Marwah said. ``Tourism is a vital input, but its failure doesn't bring the economy to a grinding halt.'' In Srinigar, it is easy to see the effects of the insurgency and the limited government efforts to take up the economic slack. Hundreds of people sit aimlessly along Dal Lake and in the old city during daylight hours, when the curfew is relaxed. Many housewives use apples in curry because they are cheaper and more plentiful than meat and vegetables. ``We have been used to the best of times,'' said Chapri, the houseboat owner, ``and now we're seeing the worst.''

DOC.HEAD: Jackie Robinson Court-Martial Movie Guilty of Poor Script
DOC.TEXT: During World War II, at what now is Fort Hood, Texas, a black lieutenant in the then-segregated Army refused the contemptuous order of a white civilian driver to sit in the rear of a post bus. Military police were called. The young officer - who in 1947 would become famed as the first black to play major league baseball - was further insulted by the MPs. He sharply protested and was brought up on charges. ``The Court-Martial of Jackie Robinson,'' premiering tonight on Ted Turner's TNT cable network, dramatizes that shameful, relatively little-known period in the history of the Army and the United States. TNT deserves credit for the effort. Unfortunately, the road to disappointment is paved with good intentions, and ``Court-Martial'' is a two-hour example of that. On the bright side, Andre Braugher is first-rate as the proud, fiery Robinson. So is Dale Dye in a small supporting role as a tough, white lieutenant colonel who respects Robinson both as a man and a soldier. The bad news is the script, which took four people to write. It has no real focus, as so often is the case with four-handed scrivening. The movie could have been taut and engrossing had it just zeroed in on events leading up to the court-martial and the trial itself. Instead, it often flounders about as it tries to re-create the times in which Robinson lived, telling, among other things, of his love for the coed (Kasi Lemmons) he married and of his warm, strong-willed mother (Ruby Dee). No real insights emerge, just that the women helped keep him going when he wanted to quit UCLA, where he was a sports star, and after Pearl Harbor, when he was drafted into the Army and faced bigotry the second he got off the bus for basic training. The script also has two baseball scouts (Bruce Dern and Paul Dooley) who periodically pop in and out of the story. One is a racist, and both work for Brooklyn Dodgers' President Branch Rickey, who later hired Robinson. No doubt their presence is intended to get the baseball angle in. Bad move. It only clutters things up. The movie does occasionally show signs of life, particularly in its depictions of the nastiness of racial segregation in the Army and the hurt of being called ``coon'' and ``boy'' while facing the same war overseas as whites. As the film shows, Robinson refuses to give in. Seeking more seating for blacks in the cafeteria at Fort Hood's segregated post exchange, he crisply tells one racist major: ``The Negro troops are prepared to fight and die, just like white troops. If they're going to die like whites, they might as well eat like them.'' There are good scenes, too, showing the friendship between the impatient, rightly frustrated Robinson and the wise, knowing boxing great he meets in the Army - Sgt. Joe Louis (quietly and effectively played by Stan Shaw). The younger man, asking Louis how he endures the racist slurs he's gotten in the boxing ring, comes to adopt the boxer's reply as his personal motto: ``I hit 'em first, faster and harder.'' Another plus: The film's realistic depictions of military matters. That's largely due to Dye, a retired Marine captain who, as he did in ``Platoon,'' doubles here as an actor and a technical adviser. It's too bad that Braugher's performance, Dye's work and generally good efforts by the other players go for naught. But there's little any actor can do with a script that is so uneven that its key moment, the court-martial, has no high drama at all. It comes off flatter than a first sergeant's feet. At least TNT is trying to do something other than the major networks' usual disease-of-the-week or trash-of-the-week movies. But if TNT executives keep getting scripts as wobbly as ``The Court-Martial of Jackie Robinson,'' they should be made to stay after telecast and write 100 times, ``The play's the thing.'' --- Elsewhere in television ... IT'S BEEN SWELL, MOLLY DODD: ``The Days and Nights of Molly Dodd'' are coming to a close, but not until next spring. The Lifetime cable network, which picked up the series from NBC last year, has ended production of the saga of a New York City divorcee played by Blair Brown. The final 13 episodes of the series - Lifetime made 26 others - will start airing in January. The first, Lifetime says, will reveal the father of Molly's unborn baby.

DOC.HEAD: Bad Reaction for Chemical Stocks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on financial wires.
DOC.TEXT: For a classic demonstration of how a bear market works, the stocks of companies in the chemical industry seem to possess all the necessary elements. Their prices have been battered across the board in recent months as the stock market as a whole has fallen to its lowest levels in a year and a half. The selling has been relentless, even for stocks of companies that appeared to be well-positioned in specialized markets presumed to be resistant to recessions and the effects of soaring oil prices. ``We realize that a bear market is tough on everyone,'' says Paul Leming, chemical industry analyst at Wall Street's Morgan Stanley & Co. ``The level of pain and suffering in the chemical industry has gone beyond the bounds of good taste, however.'' Through August and September, Leming said, the chemical stocks he follows tumbled an average of 25 percent, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock composite index dropped 14 percent. ``The market seems to be making no distinction between the fundamentals of different companies,'' he said. ``The stocks are just being taken out and shot.'' There are a couple of broad reasons why the chemical stocks' reaction to recent events has been so pronounced, observers say. First of all, the business has a firmly entrenched image as a smokestack industry whose fortunes have long been sensitive to the ups and downs of the economic cycle. Whisper ``recession'' and the chemical stocks feel a breeze. Secondly, the industry is a heavy user of petroleum-based raw materials, putting it squarely in the path of the oil-price increases that have followed Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. ``The sharp escalation in oil prices is having a major impact on the fundamentals of the basic chemical industry,'' says George Krug, who follows the stocks for Oppenheimer & Co. A good many analysts argue, however, that the same conclusion isn't warranted, or at least not to the same degree, for companies in specialty chemicals - for example, coatings, adhesives, dyes and cleaning materials, which oftentimes are made with the commodity chemicals produced by the basic manufacturers. ``In many respects, specialty chemical companies are a world apart from their basic chemical counterparts,'' Stephen Grant, an analyst at Value Line Investment Survey, says in the advisory firm's latest quarterly report on the industry. Basic chemical manufacturers most likely will have to absorb the brunt of the increase in petrochemical costs, passing only part of the increase through to the specialty companies, Grant argues. Therefore, he says, ``raw materials costs for specialty chemical producers probably will continue to advance only modestly. ``And for these technology-based companies with proprietary products, the higher costs should be easy to pass on to customers.'' Nevertheless, Grant acknowledges, specialty chemical makers do suffer from exposure to weakness in the markets they supply. ``Primary end markets include autos, construction and electronics, each of which is in a slump.'' As for the chemical industry as a whole, most analysts believe a full-fledged revival may have to await signs pointing to the next upward turn in the economic cycle. Said Leming at Morgan Stanley: ``Today's problems - the predominant one being overcapacity - are likely to sow the seeds for tomorrow's boom. As profitability deteriorates, there should be a slowdown in capacity additions. ``We don't believe it's appropriate to give up on the chemicals forever, because we think this group will once again have its day in the sun. Unfortunately, that day could be as far away as 1995.''

DOC.HEAD: Bonn Tries To Keep Government From Moving to Berlin
DOC.TEXT: The government and Parliament flew to glamorous Berlin en masse to celebrate German unity in the traditional capital, but this dull little city on the Rhine is determined they won't escape for good. During its 41 years as West Germany's capital, Bonn has become ``a symbol of the first successful German democracy,'' Mayor Hans Daniels said proudly. Wolfgang Schnitzler, a 60-year-old taxi driver who may lose his job if Bonn loses the politicians, said: ``To my way of thinking, moving the government to Berlin would be a criminal act.'' Berlin became the symbolic capital on unity day, Oct. 3, but Bonn still is the seat of government. Whether the government moves is up to Parliament. The Bonn-Berlin competition has taken some nasty turns. Bonn boosters say Berlin should not be the seat of united Germany because it was the center of Nazi power in 1933-1945. In a newspaper interview published on unity eve, Daniels said Bonn, ``which has no triumphal arches, has never displayed itself with arrogance.'' His not-so-oblique reference was to Berlin's Brandenburg Gate and the Nazi parades that once passed through it. Backers of Berlin say Bonn is too small and unexciting to be the new Germany's political heart. ``Berlin is supremely suited in view of its location, its history and its role as a cultural crossroads,'' said Walter Momper, mayor of Berlin. In the eyes of the world, Berlin is in the same class as London, Rome, Paris, and Madrid, he said. That kind of talk irritates Daniels. Keeping the government and Parliament in Bonn would make it impossible for Berlin to gain the power it once held over Germany, he said, and ``the Germans would be declaring a national modesty.'' Modest is an apt word for Bonn. The government is housed in buildings whose architectural styles range from drab to dismal. Parliament meets in the former waterworks, a vast, ugly structure on the riverbank. Visitors spend little time in Bonn. Its best-known sights, such as Beethoven's birthplace, the charming market square and the 18th century city hall, can be covered easily in less than a day. Lawmakers from now-defunct East Germany showed some curiosity when they attended the all-German Parliament's first working session, but left town quickly when it was over. Some complained of trouble in finding a place to eat late at night. Farm tractors pulling loads of manure frequently cause traffic jams. By contrast, Berlin is home to a seemingly infinite array of cultural and historical offerings, including the Reichstag, the remains of the Wall, numerous museums and some of the best music and theater in Europe. Government does not depend on such things, Daniels said. He described Bonn, on the rim of Western Europe, as a perfect bridge between the new Germany and the West. Daniels pointed out that moving the government would be enormously expensive. Some experts say the transfer could cost up to $65 billion at a time when hundreds of billions are needed to absorb and rebuild East Germany. The mayor acknowledges his city would become a virtual ghost town if the government left, since most of Bonn's 300,000 people are somehow linked to it. Bonn also is in the middle of a costly construction program that includes a new Parliament, and the mayor said much money would be lost if it were stopped. Chancellor Helmut Kohl has indicted he is in no hurry to move the government. ``This is certainly not a question which is of any urgency to me, as far as the agenda is concerned,'' he said Sept. 30. Whether the new Parliament will agree is another question.

DOC.HEAD: Panama Digging Out After Dictatorship and Invasion
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhotos
DOC.TEXT: The economy is growing and unemployment is shrinking. Exiles have returned and so have millions of badly needed dollars sent abroad for safekeeping. Problems still abound 10 months after the U.S. invasion that deposed and captured Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, but Panama is gradually crawling out from under years of corrupt military leadership and U.S. economic sanctions. It is a slow process. Squabbling within the coalition government may be scaring off foreign investors and suspicion lingers that Panama is a country without a plan. Unemployment and underemployment are estimated at about 25 percent. That is down from 35 percent at the beginning of 1990, but 30,000 more Panamanians join the labor force each year. Noriega collaborators are in the new civilian police force, but are being systematically retired and more than half Noriega's officers are out, including the highest ranks. Graduates of military academies are not welcome in the new police, who replace Noriega's Panama Defense Force. Although 2,000 people remain homeless because much of the El Chorillo slum was destroyed in the invasion, thousands more are in new or renovated housing and the rest are to be housed by year's end. Officially, the invasion cost the lives of 314 Panamanians, 202 of them civilians. Many critics put the toll at several times that and accuse the Panamanian and American governments of covering up, but little evidence has been produced. The economy, which shrank about 16 percent in 1987-89, is expected to grow by 7 percent this year. Panama is resuming payment to foreign creditors on a debt that is among the world's highest per capita. No physical signs of the invasion remain, but it is far from forgotten. ``I think most Panamanians feel the invasion was a liberation, but it definitely left an open wound in the national psyche,'' said Roberto Eisenmann, publisher of the independent newspaper La Prensa. ``This is becoming even more evident as time goes on. The only medicine is to come out of it a demilitarized country. If Panama remilitarizes, history will not forgive us.'' Noriega closed Eisenmann's paper and the publisher spent years in exile. ``They are amateurs,'' he said patiently of the new administrtion. ``They were condemned to the opposition for 21 years. They are learning the process.'' Some new Cabinet ministers literally had to look in the telephone book to find their new offices, he said. President Guillermo Endara has been criticized as weak after two decades of military rule. ``I think if you scratch the surface, you will find out many people want a weak president right now,'' Eisenmann said. ``Endara is probably the right man for the job at this time in our history.'' ``The dictatorship was a parenthesis in our history, a long one but a parenthesis,'' he said. ``Panama now needs to fall back on its traditions'' of democracy ``and make it work.'' Panama has no organized political opposition at the moment. The military's Revolutionary Democratic Party, in power since 1968, seems to have dropped from sight, but still has six members in the 57-seat National Assembly. Endara's opposition comes from within the governing alliance. Analysts generally agree elements of the coalition, especially the Christian Democrats, will break off and bid for power as the 1994 elections approach. The president has said he will preserve the alliance as long as possible, and his government appears to be in no immediate danger. ``More binds the parties together than separates them,'' U.S. Ambassador Deane Hinton said in an interview. ``They are condemned to work together.'' Outside the government, the parties are involved in a political feud that sometimes resembles a brawl: - Mayor Guillermo Cochez, whose Christian Democrats hold the most National Assembly seats, suggested in a newspaper column that the Endara government ``has few differences from one'' in the Noriega period. Endara, who represents the smaller Authentic Liberal Party, suggested Cochez resign. - The three smallest coalition parties teamed up with Noriega's old party to bump the Christian Democrats from the assembly presidency. First Vice President Ricardo Arias Calderon called the three parties Noriega sympathizers. - Endara vetoed more than half the first 20 major bills to reach his desk. - Second Vice President Guillermo Ford claimed the new police force, controlled by Arias Calderon, was ineffective against crime. The two are expected to be opponents for the presidency. Dissent within the government is strange to Panamanians after 21 years of military rule that began with a coup in 1968 by Gen. Omar Torrijos. Endara and his vice presidents ``are not the paternal leaders Panamanians have gotten used to,'' said Mayin Correa, a former opposition legislator who has been host of a political talk show since returning from exile in Miami. Radio stations broadcast a National Assembly debate on revoking the immunity of three members from the military party accused of committing crimes while Noriega was in power. One called her accuser a child molester. He said she was a drunk. Ms. Correa says she welcomed the system's openness, but wouldn't want to be in the assembly now. Sovereignty issues have affected otherwise good relations with the United States. At the behest of Foreign Minister Julio Linares, Endara has suggested the United States owes reparations for damage wrought by the invasion. No amount has been mentioned. ``It's a nice issue to beat (Washington) over the head with, but it isn't going anywhere,'' Ambassador Hinton said, and suggested the demand was primarily for internal political consumption. Losses from looting and other causes not stemming from the fighting have been estimated at up to $1.5 billion, which is generally considered high. Little was paid by insurance companies, which cited act-of-war clauses. The nited States has allocated $430 million for Panamanian recovery, with about $130 million dependent on an agreement to exchange banking information in criminal cases. Linares, the foreign minister, has said he will not approve an accord that weakens Panama's confidential banking system, although it was used in drug deals under Noriega. Hinton said: ``Only if you believe it is in Panama's interests to shield illegal acts, is this agreement a threat to Panama.'' The banking system has been a major factor in attracting business. More than 100 banks, most of them foreign, have offices in Panama. Dario Selles, president of the Panama Industrial Association, said in an interview there is worry in the private sector that money will go elsewhere if the system is changed. New investment is critical to Panama, Selles said. About 80 percent of the economy involves services: banking, the Panama Canal, construction and government work. Agriculture and industry account for the rest. ``Unemployment is Panama's single worst problem and the labor pool is growing at about 30,000 a year,'' Selles said. ``The service sector is still big, but it is saturated. It is important, but it is not generating new jobs.'' ``We are asking the government to develop some kind of plan,'' he said. ``In the past, there was no goal, no strategy. The dictatorship didn't have to promise anything.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Oct. 21

DOC.HEAD: Homeless From Invasion Relocating, But Complain of Shoddy Housing
With BC-Panama Today, b0700
DOC.TEXT: The El Chorrillo slum of reeking tenements, rats, crime and disease was no garden spot, but to thousands of families it was home. It also was home to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's headquarters, and when U.S. forces invaded in December, much of El Chorrillo was burned or blown to splinters. Nearly 3,000 families - about 16,000 people - lost their homes. The Panamanian and American governments have been working to relocate them. Centers for the homeless are emptying into renovated apartments and new subdivisions, but not everyone is happy with the results. On a sweltering afternoon, a dozen residents of the 24th of December Project, a cooperative apartment building heavily damaged in the battle, lounged on the front steps sipping beer and local rum. ``At least the elevator goes to the top now,'' one resident said about the 15-story building, which was reoccupied in July. ``Before, it only went partway and there was no water on the top floors.'' Another countered: ``I had tile on my floor and the looters took it, and my door won't close all the way. The sink leaks.'' Complaints outnumber compliments. ``The United States made us leave,'' said Rafael Olivardia, a member of the building committee. ``We left our apartments locked, then when we came back, there wasn't even a bed. The tile was ripped up, the copper plumbing was pulled out of the wall, all the furniture was gone.'' Aleyeda Teran told of a foot of water accumulating in a top-floor apartment during a rainstorm because of poorly plugged bullet holes and leaky walls. ``It dripped down through apartments on all 15 floors,'' she said. ``These things didn't happen before the invasion.'' Olivardia declared: ``The construction companies did bad work, but we blame the United States and Panama because they paid for the poor work. We have written letters to everyone, but nobody responds.'' The United States budgeted $2.5 million for the cooperative, which houses about 450 families, but used only $1.6 million and spent the rest on other buildings. Through the U.S. Agency for International Development, Washington is financing several options for displaced people as part of its Panama recovery plan. Those who return to renovated apartments in El Chorrillo are given $800 a family to replace personal belongings. Most say it is not enough. Others can get $6,500 to apply toward small houses in subdivisions built by private contractors, or to buy land and build. People with jobs may qualify for loans of an additional $6,500. Families choosing subdivisions get ownership of a lot, with water, electricity and septic tank service, and a concrete-block house with a metal roof. Many say the one-room house $6,500 buys is inadequte for a family. In most developments, houses offered at that price are about 15 feet square with a small division for the kitchen and bathroom. People who qualify for supplemental loans can buy larger houses. About 850 families have moved into the subdivisions and 270 more houses are ready for occupancy. ``Over the next few months we hope to complete about 250 houses a month,'' said Kevin Kelley of the USAID mission. ``There have been some complaints, we understand,'' he said of the 24th of December project. ``We have looked into them and most of them were lodged when the people first moved back. ``The contractors were bonded and (the buyers) have guarantees. We don't agree that construction was shoddy. It was well supervised by the Panamanian Housing Ministry and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. We think it was good.'' More than 700 families still live in centers, including hangars at a military base. Others are with family or friends. U.S. and Panamanian officials say they hope to have the hangar residents relocated by year's end, although many living there have been declared ineligible for relocation aid because they did not live in El Chorrillo. Much of El Chorrillo was built at the turn of the century as a barracks complex for Panama Canal construction workers. A U.S. Embassy official said many residents of the decrepit buildings were squatters. Many former residents will not be able to return to the old neighborhood because most of the land is privately held and the owners hope to use it more profitably.

DOC.HEAD: ROANOKE, Va.: of poverty.
DOC.TEXT: TAP has become a model for anti-poverty efforts across the nation. Three of its programs have been lifted whole to other states. Another, which brought safe drinking water and toilets first to rural homes in the Roanoke Valley, then all of Virginia, eventually moved to Washington as a national program. CHIP became TAP's 30th agency. It fit right in. To get it going, Brand brought together doctors, public health professionals, lawyers, TAP veterans, state and local officials, ``everyone we thought could help,'' he said. ``We identified the problem and worked out a plausible solution. The state health department gave us $118,000 and we were on our way.'' They started the program June 16, 1988 with Pierce, the five pediatricians in practice with him, and 100 patients. It went well. After a year they grew to 300 patients and more doctors. That went even better. Six months later the state upped its ante to $200,000 and the W.K. Kellogg Foudation of Michigan granted $1.5 million to expand further. Last August Kellogg, impressed, came up with another $2.3 million to spread CHIP across Virginia. Now CHIP has more than 900 patients enrolled. All six of the valley's children's dentists participate, and all but three of its 19 family doctors and 14 pediatricians. (CHIP turned down the three because they didn't cover on nights and weekends). ``We have a ways to go,'' said Peggy Balla, the CHIP director. ``We have identified 4,800 potential patients and hope to get them all. We get more efficient every day. We've worked out a lot of bugs. Our computer programs and all our experience will be helpful in the replication of CHIP in other areas.'' One of the bugs was getting prescriptions filled. The public health office, which fills them cut-rate, closes at 5 p.m. The valley's largest drugstore chain now provides 24-hour service at even lower prices. Another bug: doctor appointments missed for lack of transportation. A church donated a van. ``That's what community action is all about,'' said Cabell Brand ``It's the key to the whole program.'' The CHIP staff includes six public health nurses and six outreach workers. They work as teams, visiting each patient regularly at home - case management, an essential of the whole scheme. Each team has a case load of about 150, which they agree is too many but will improve with more staff. The nurse has a copy of the same records the doctor keeps. She sees that his orders are followed, medication given, appointments kept, the main complaints doctors had about the habits of Medicaid patients. ``Just convincing the parents that they really do have a doctor they can call any time they have a question, and persuading them to do it, even in the middle of the night, may be the hardest job of all,'' said one nurse, Connie Willet. ``But watching the way they light up when they finally come to realize they are included in the health care system, which most of us take for granted, is really satisfying. Sometimes I think their new-found self-esteem is the best medicine of all.'' Willet's outreach worker teammate, Darlene Brown, was able to come up with a second bed when Roberta McCraw had twins, has helped her find diapers in an emergency, as well as food and clothes. The five little McCraws also are regular patrons of CHIP's free Lending Library. Not books, toys. Case workers tend to get personally interested in CHIP families. One McCraw child now has a good winter coat that Darlene Brown's own daughter outgrew. Another has a coat formerly worn by a child of teammate Connie Willet. CHIP's doctors get paid at the Medicaid rate. If the patient doesn't quite qualify for Medicaid the same rate applies. Qualification in Virginia is the same as the federal minimum of 135 percent of the poverty level but CHIP stretches that to 150 percent to take in the working poor. Doctors say it covers about 70 percent of their regular fees. But CHIP does the billing, relieves the doctors of Medicaid paperwork and further makes life easier by sending along with each new CHIP patient a medical-history questionnaire already completed by the case nurse. Not to mention seeing to it that his instructions are followed and appointments kept. In the doctor's waiting room - or in the treatment room - there's no way to tell a CHIP patient from any other. When it's time to pay, the parent shows a CHIP card and that's that. Preventive medicine - shots, checkups, what the doctors call well care - are, like fire prevention, obviously beneficial but hard to measure in dollars. How much in future medical bills will CHIP save by giving children a healthy start? The Children's Defense Fund, a national group, says the annual saving is $10 for every $1 spent. Health insurance companies, with one eye on that huge group of uninsured, are keeping the other eye on CHIP. ``We have a chance to do some blow-away things here, it seems to me,'' said John Berry, head of Blue Cross-Blue Shield in Virginia. Blue Cross has supported CHIP from the beginning, completely outfitting the CHIP office in Roanoke with furniture and equipment. One major financial effect of CHIP is apparent right now from a recent survey of 10,000 children's visits to the Roanoke Memorial Hospital emergency room. It found that nearly half, 46 percent, were between 3 p.m. and midnight, and that fewer than 15 percent were ``justifiable emergency room visits,'' according to Dr. Preston Boggess, director of pediatric education. ``In an emergency room, with no records of the patient available, you have to practice defensive medicine,'' Boggess said. ``That means extensive tests and lab work to cover all the possibilities. ``They are mostly unnecessary, always costly and take time from real emergencies. But some people have no place else to take a sick child.'' Roberta McCraw has. ``The baby was fussing and running a fever and I was scared to death,'' she said. ``I had never called my doctor at night and didn't know whether I should maybe just go ahead to the emergency room. ``But I called, and he said to bring her in. ``It wasn't my doctor but was one in the same building. It was his turn to work that night. ``He examined her and looked at her records and in a minute said, `Mrs. McCraw, Amanda's teething. Take her home, she'll be just fine.' ``And she was.''
DOC.NOTE: END ADV

DOC.HEAD: Civilian Lowers Aim of the Anti-Missile Program
DOC.TEXT: Henry F. Cooper says he still believes in former President Reagan's dream of erecting an impenetrable shield in space against a massive missile attack. But as the new director of Star Wars, Cooper is quietly charting a more down-to-earth course for the multibillion-dollar project Reagan started in 1983. From his headquarters in the Pentagon basement, Cooper is piecing together a plan that shifts the Star Wars focus away from efforts to protect against an all-out Soviet attack with thousands of nuclear-tipped ballistic missiles. The new aim is more modest: to build a defense against a few dozen or few hundred missiles launched accidentally by Moscow or deliberately by a Third World despot. More than the numbers have changed for Star Wars, officially known as the Strategic Defense Initiative, or SDI. So, too, has the idea at the heart of Reagan's proposal: that a missile defense can be found that would make nuclear arms obsolete. In fact, quite a different view is behind Cooper's approach. He thinks that while the Soviet missile arsenal is still formidable and capable of destroying the United States, a greater danger is that more Third World nations are likely to acquire nuclear arsenals. In taking this new tack, Cooper is acknowledging that Congress has all but killed Star Wars in its original form. To keep the concept of anti-missile defense alive, Cooper is banking on public support for a more limited, less costly system. ``If we can get people to agree that at least limited protection is something that we ought to be doing . . . then we can go ahead with the research and development. It would be a great step forward,'' Cooper said in a recent interview. Cooper has even found a friendly acronym for his plan: PALS, or Protection Against Limited Strikes. He says it could be put into operation as early as 1996 and would cost less than the $55 billion price tag of the previous Star Wars plan. PALS is not yet official Bush administration policy, but Cooper said he is making decisions on the assumption that it soon will be. ``They hired me to make decisions, not to wait until the final `i' is dotted and the final `t' is crossed,'' he said. He is the first civilian director of SDI, but Cooper is no stranger to strategic defense. He was chief U.S. negotiator on defense and space matters from 1987 to 1989, a task that included trying to persuade the Soviets to drop their objections to SDI and to agree on a mutual transition from offensive arms to defensive weapons. In that job, Cooper says he became acquainted with many key members of Congress - relationships he hopes will help him turn the tide of congressional opinion on SDI. Over the past two years, the SDI program, while moving ahead with anti-missile technologies on the drawing board, has been losing ground in the political arena. Moscow still opposes the project and Congress has begun cutting the SDI budget, which may fall this year to $3 billion or less from $3.7 billion last year. Cooper said the previous Star Wars goal of defending against an attack by thousands of enemy missiles no longer fits the evolving picture of a reforming Soviet Union. ``We were thinking entirely of a world of competition with the Soviet Union,'' he said. ``We're now beginning to think in terms of a world of cooperation.'' Many in Congress believe the changing world order means SDI is less important. Even Cooper says that before he assumed the director's job last July, he harbored some doubt about the Bush administration's commitment to the project. ``I wrestled with the issue of whether or not to come because it is obviously a critical period - I refer to it as a make-or-break time,'' Cooper said, adding that before accepting the post he talked with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney about Bush's views. ``The secretary believes the president is committed to this program,'' he said. Cooper said that he sought no assurances directly from Bush before taking the job and that he has not been disappointed at the absence of heavy presidential lobbying for SDI. ``It hasn't bothered me that he's not talking out, not trumpeting SDI all the time,'' Cooper said. Still, Cooper has taken it upon himself to find a way of building or Star Wars and keeping it from withering on the scientific vine. ``I didn't come to package it up and put it on the shelf,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Oct. 14

DOC.HEAD: Milken to Extra Innings, and the Rich Get Poorer
DOC.TEXT: Is there a smoking gun in the Michael Milken affair? Government prosecutors would like nothing more than to produce one in a special presentencing hearing for the junk-bond financier that began this past week. But in the first day of the two-week show in Manhattan federal court, no big bombshells dropped. Two government witnesses failed to directly link Milken to the systematic stock manipulation alleged by the government. The first round of testimony still managed to produce some news. A trader for Milken's former employer, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., revealed he had a secret, middle-of-the-night meeting with Milken after stock speculator Ivan Boesky turned state's evidence in 1986. Boesky, once one of Milken's regular customers, would become his chief accuser. The ex-trader, Cary Maultasch, described a cloak-and-dagger rendezvous with Milken at Drexel's office in Beverly Hills, Calif. The pair spoke in hushed tones with a guard posted at the door. Milken scribbled his most sensitive comments about Boesky on a pad and erased them immediately, but Maultasch couldn't recall exactly what was communicated. The ``mini-trial'' resumes Monday before Judge Kimba Wood, who is trying to focus her image of Milken before pronouncing his sentence. She ordered the hearing after the government and the defense provided her with documents painting widely divergent portraits of the ex-billionaire. The hearing covers a handful of allegations beyond the crimes Milken admitted in his six-count guilty plea in April. Wood is nevertheless limited to the maximum penalty of 28 yars in prison prescribed in the plea bargain. The prosecution's case hangs on three transactions, in which it claims Milken abused securities laws. The defense, led by attorney Arthur Liman, will try to deflect those blows while promoting its alternative image of Milken as a misunderstood genius of finance and warm-hearted do-gooder. The hearing, although it takes the Milken chase into extra innings, has left some observers less than excited because of its limited scope. ``We will never have confidence in knowing what happened,'' said Albert Alschuler, criminal law expert at the University of Chicago Law School.
DOC.HEAD: PEOPLE: The Rich Got Poorer
DOC.TEXT: As Milken ran the gantlet of photographers and reporters on his way to court, he could at least take solace in the fact that he remains one of the nation's wealthiest people. The latest ranking of Forbes magazine's 400 richest Americans put the Californian at 115th, worth $700 million. That's a demotion from his days as a billionaire, thanks to the $600 million settlement included in his plea bargain. In general, the rich got poorer in the past year, according to the magazine. Fifty-three of the Forbes 400 suffered net-worth declines, ranging from $100 million to nearly $900 million. In contrast to Milken, most suffered at the hands of the economy. For the first time in the eight years Forbes has been publishing the register, the minimum fortune it took to make the grade dropped, from $275 million in 1989 to $260 million. John Werner Kluge, the Metromedia tycoon, topped the list with an estimated $5.6 billion.
DOC.HEAD: TRUMP: Among the Richest No More
DOC.TEXT: One name missing from the Forbes ranking was Donald Trump, whose 1989 fortune of $1.7 billion has almost completely disappeared. Trump's troubles continued during the week with word that his second book, ``Surviving at the Top,'' hadn't survived long on The New York Times best-seller list. The paper said the book had fallen off the list after only seven weeks. His first book, ``The Art of the Deal,'' lingered 48 weeks on the list after it was introduced in 1987. Trump was also reported to be negotiating new terms for loans on two of his casinos in his continuing efforts to keep his gambling, real estate and airline empire aloft. Takeover investor Carl Icahn (65th on the Forbes list at $1 billion) also emerged in the Trump storyline as a possible investor in Trump's casino bonds. Reports said Icahn was snapping up the sagging notes as a long-term investment.
DOC.HEAD: MARKETS: The Market's Balloon Loses More Air
DOC.TEXT: Bottom-fishing could become the sport of choice on Wall Street as the stock market swoons. Over three successive days the market lost more than 6 percent, as measured by the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 stocks, prompting The Wall Street Journal to proclaim the ``official'' arrival of the bear market. The Journal said that by falling below 2,400 on Thursday and more than 20 percent over the past two months, the Dow had fulfilled the classic requirements of a down market. Corporate earnings reinforced the market's pessimism. CBS Inc. reported a 30 percent drop in third-quarter profits; Chemical Banking posted a $43.7 million loss and slashed its dividend. Oil continued its relentless move upward, setting records above the $40 per barrel mark on the futures exchange. Silver, meanwhile, plummeted toward $4 per troy ounce. The silver slide heightened recession fears because it indicated sinking industrial demand for the metal.
DOC.HEAD: ECONOMY: Retailers Bemoan Mean Season
DOC.TEXT: The nation's retailers were slip-sliding toward Christmas with bad tidings for thefall season. Their sales reports for September were grim; some even showed a decline from year-ago levels. Worries about the economy and the Persian Gulf crisis were mostly to blame, but the weather also contributed. Warmer than normal temperatures dissauded some consumers from shopping for winter clothing. The government reported that wholesale prices shot up 1.6 percent in September, led by an unprecedented 20.6 percent leap in gasoline.
DOC.HEAD: SATURN: Hope for the Americans
DOC.TEXT: The great American hope for battling foreign auto imports rolled out of a Spring Hill, Tenn., plant. General Motors Corp. introduced its new fuel-efficient, affordable Saturn line of cars with predictions that two-thirds of future sales would come at the expense of GM's competitors, including the Japanese. But analysts were concerned about the other third, which would come out of GM's own hide. The cars go on sale Oct. 25, at base prices ranging from $7,995 to $11,775.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions Oct. 13-14
