DOC.HEAD: October Woes For Wall Street
DOC.TEXT: October has been putting in an earnest bid so far to live up to its reputation as a villainous month for Wall Street. In a three-day span this past week, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials took a drop of 158 points, or 6.29 pecent, to a new 18-month low. That was more than enough to evoke vivid memories of October massacres past in the stock market. Just a year ago, there was the Friday the 13th ``mini-crash,'' when the Dow fell 190 points in a single session. Two years before that was the Crash of 1987, which culminated in a 508-point collapse on Monday, Oct. 19. Further back in investment annals were the back-to-back declines of October 1978 (a loss of 9.2 percent) and 1979 (6.9 percent). And of course the 1929 crash, which helped to usher in almost a decade of economic misery, was another October production. With such past performances to go on, it seems no surprise at all that investors would be in a jumpy mood. The economic and political news, meanwhile, has fallen into step to help ensure that no stray element of cheer creeps into the picture. The stalemate with Iraq in the Persian Gulf has kept relentless upward pressure on world oil prices. The battle of the budget in Washington produces nothing but frustration. Corporate profits and dividends tumble, but interest rates cling stubbornly to their lofty perch. Against this background, the debate over the status of the stock market seems to have been settled. ``The stock market is in the midst of a primary bear market,'' declares Richard Evans, research director at the investment advisory service Dow Theory Forecasts in Hammond, Ind. Indeed, stocks' current problems started long before October came into view. They date back to midsummer, when the Dow Jones industrial average closed for two days running at a peak of 2,999.75. From that point through Thursday's close, the average took a 21.16 percent drop. Most recently, many Wall Streeters have been inclined to blame at least some of the market's woes on the White House and members of Congress and their failure to come up with a plan to manage the government's finances. ``Beyond the budget mania, there is a sick economy to deal with,'' observed Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities International in New York. At the close on Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average stood at 2,398.02, down 112.62 from the week before. Other readings for the week showed the New York Stock Exchange composite index down 6.28 at 164.42; the NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market down 19.80 at 327.56, and the American Stock Exchange market value index down 12.51 at 293.97. Volume on the Big Board averaged 156.19 million shares a day, against 170.70 million the week before. The market's malaise is beginning to make some startling impressions. If stocks don't rally somehow in the next 2{ months, they will post their worst yearly showing since 1974, when the Dow fell 27.6 percent. Hope dies hard in the financial world, however, and right now some optimists claim that they at least have contrary opinion on their side. ``We cannot rule out the potential for a near-term advance, especially some time this month, when everyone is expecting another horrendous October,'' said Ralph Acampora, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities. But Acampora adds, ``nothing has surfaced to change my mind about the primary trend in this market - it is down.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv Weekend Editions Oct. 13-14

DOC.TEXT: The first public airing of allegations that Michael Milken abused the nation's financial markets opened with testimony that the junk-bond financier never asked two traders to illegally manipulate securities. A former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. trader also described on Thursday a secret meeting with Milken where the two discussed in hushed tones Ivan Boesky's stunning 1986 deal to cooperate in the Wall Street insider trading probe. Milken, 44, took copious notes, shook his head and rolled his eyes during the daylong proceedings in Manhattan federal court. Testimony covered the first of three alleged crimes prosecutors claim reflect a pattern of illegal activity. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Dwindling U.S. stockpiles, looming cold weather and a British warning of a Persian Gulf conflagration combined to drive oil prices back over $40 a barrel to a new record close in hectic futures trading. The rise to $40.42 Thursday erased the decline a day earlier when traders dumped oil contracts on an unfounded rumor about the death of Saddam Hussein. The Iraqi leader's seizure of neighboring Kuwait more than two months ago led to an unprecedented U.S. military buildup in the petroleum-rich region and has doubled the price of oil since midsummer. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Chemical Banking Corp. reported a $43.7 million third-quarter loss and cut its dividend by more than half, another sign of painful times in the domestic banking business. The loss reported Thursday by the nation's 6th-largest banking company was an improvement over a year earlier but still reflected the rise in shaky loans and a softening economy that have afflicted several leading U.S. banks in recent months. --- BERLIN (AP) - German unity began paying off for some former East Germans in the form of higher pensions for retirees, a program to fix shoddy housing and a new Mercedes-Benz plant. The flurry of announcements Thursday from government officials and the automaker was rare good news for East Germans facing rising joblessness and higher prices as the cost of joining a free market economy. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - China is sending more than 200 buyers to the United States this week to negotiate the purchase of American products, but U.S. officials believe what the Chinese want most is goodwill. It's the largest trade delegation sent by the Communist government to the United States, arriving as lawmakers debate whether to extend for another year China's Most Favored Nation status, which reduces tariffs on Chinese goods sold in the United States. --- NEW YORK (AP) - R.H. Macy & Co. Inc., in a move to reduce its $4.8 billion debt load, said it is selling its credit operations to GE Capital Corp. The step will lower the retailer's debt by $1.5 billion, Macy said in a statement. The announcement Thursday came the same day as grim news that worries about recession and a possible war in the Persian Gulf kept consumers on the sidelines in September, giving many storeowners a dismal month. The retailers' monthly sales reports - some of which showed a decline from September 1989 levels - did not augur well for a robust Christmas shopping season, analysts said. --- NICOSIA, Cyprus (AP) - Iran's Abadan oil refinery, once the largest in the world but crippled in the eight-year war with Iraq, will resume full operations in about six months, Tehran radio reported. The refinery's capacity will rise to 300,000 barrels a day, more than twice the current production, the radio quoted Oil Minister Gholamreza Aqazadeh as saying Thursday. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The government's top highway safety official has refused to order a recall investigation of Jeep CJ vehicles. A consumer group said the decision was a ``death sentence'' for many Americans. An extensive inquiry turned up no evidence that design flaws make the Jeep CJ prone to overturn, Jerry R. Curry, administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said Thursday. --- SPRING HILL, Tenn. (AP) - General Motors Corp. has unveiled its new Saturn cars and is predicting they will lure more buyers from the competition than from other GM divisions. GM created the Saturn to compete with Japanese imports that have stolen a large part of the market from the Big Three automakers. The car, presented during a ceremony Thursday, has a price tag and fuel efficiency rating that's competitive with Japanese models. Don Hudler, Saturn Corp.'s vice president for sales and marketing, said he expected 65 percent of the GM subsidiary's first-year sales will be new business to GM. The rest would come from current GM owners, probably owners of Chevrolets. ---
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Stocks fell sharply Thursday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 42.82 to 2,365.10, bringing its loss over the past three days to 158.66 points. The dollar was lower in world trading. Orange juice futures braced for a price collapse after the federal government projected a 50 percent increase in Florida orange production. Oil futures surged; silver futures continued to plummet; gold rose slightly; grains and soybeans retreated; cattle futures fell; and pork futures were mixed. Bond prices slipped.

DOC.HEAD: A Barrel of Oil, From Top to Bottom
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: Graphic
DOC.TEXT: As the wildly swinging price of a barrel of crude oil grabs headlines and stirs fears of higher inflation, some folks might wonder: Just what is a barrel of oil? Physically, it's the unit by which oil is sold, a relic of early days in the industry when drillers filled 42-gallon barrels with crude oil. Nowadays, however, oil is bought and sold in amounts equivalent to thousands of barrels. Crude oil is as it sounds, a raw, unrefined version of the century's most important fossil fuel. Before oil is used by businesses or consumers as gasoline or other products, it is refined. That is a process of cooking and distilling that actually turns the 42 gallons of crude into a little more than 44 gallons of petroleum products, even though nothing is added. ``You do get more product than the crude,'' said Jim Williams of the American Petroleum Institute, the oil industry's trade group in Washington. ``After you break it up into various gasoline and diesel and stuff, you've rearranged the molecules. It's just rearranged differently. You're just changing the chemical makeup of the crude oil to make it more usable.'' The 2.03 gallons that appear through the molecular shuffling is known as the ``processing gain.'' The refining is done in stages, with the first step occurring as crude oil is heated at the bottom of a ``distillation tower.'' The oil turns to gas and rises, with various portions of the barrel condensing into liquids at different heights of the tower. At certain points of the tower, the refinery equipment collects the liquids that can be blended into gasoline. At other levels of the tower come portions of the oil that can be used in diesel and kerosene. What's left over at the bottom is then put through a similar tower that has a vacuum at the top and takes out portions of the oil that were too heavy to be collected the first time out. After that stage, the refiner is left with even heavier portions of the oil barrel that need to be broken up before they are used. ``You keep working it down until you can get it into gasoline,'' Williams said. ``The heavier the crude, the more of this you have to do. Not all refiners can do all of these things.'' The different steps that must be taken with different barrels of oil are necessary because all oil is not created equal. Crudes range from light sweet, the most desirable blend, to heavy sour, the least desirable. A crude's ``sweetness'' measures its sulfur content. Low-sulfur or ``sweet'' oil is easier to convert into fuels that meet U.S. environmental standards. Heavy ``sour'' has lots of sulfur and takes more refining before it can be used as fuel. When the refining is done, a little less than half of the barrel, 19.50 gallons, has been converted into finished motor gasoline, statistics from the federal Energy Information Administration show. The other products from a barrel are: distillate fuel oil, 8.61 gallons; jet fuel, 4.20 gallons; residual fuel oil, 2.77 gallons; petroleum coke, 1.60 gallons;asphalt and road oil, 1.39 gallons; liquified gases, 1.43 gallons; petrochemical feedstocks, 1.22 gallons; kerosene, 0.25 gallon, finished aviation gasoline, 0.08 gallon; and miscellaneous, 2.98 gallons.

DOC.HEAD: A Dismal September For Retailers Amid Fears of Recession, War
With PM-Retail Sales-Table
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Nervousness about a possible recession and war in the Persian Gulf kept consumers out of the stores last month, giving many of the nation's retailers a dismal September and signalling a difficult Christmas shopping season. ``I don't see anything to suggest an improvement,'' said Jeffrey Edelman, a retail industry analyst with Barclays de Zoete Wedd, after the biggest retailers issued their monthly sales reports Thursday. Several companies said their September sales fell from year-earlier levels. Jeffrey Feiner, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Co., warned, ``It could get worse. ... We believe that for the first time in a long time, we will have two very poor Christmases back to back.'' Many retailers were forced to slash prices - and consequently, their profit margins - to bring in sales last Christmas. Feiner predicted earnings would decline again in the fourth quarter although many companies are being very cautious and preparing for the worst - another bleak holiday season. A slump in profits in the final quarter could be devastating for retailers, who depend on this period for about 50 percent of their full-year earnings. September's results came as no surprise. August sales, which normally are boosted by back-to-school shopping, showed signs of a spending slowdown. Consumers were already nervous about the economy and the security of their own jobs when the Persian Gulf crisis and rising oil prices exacerbated recession fears and gave them less money to spend on so-called discretionary items such as clothes and furniture. The weather also affected sales, as temperatures ran above the norm, and few consumers were in the mood to shop for winter clothing. Feiner summed up the confluence of factors as ``a multi-faceted barrage on the consumer.'' The nation's largest retailer, Sears, Roebuck & Co., said sales at stores open at least a year rose 4.4 percent for the five weeks ended Oct. 6, while sales from all of its stores rose 4.2 percent. Analysts say sales from stores open at least a year - also known as same-store or comparable store sales - provide a truer picture of a retailer's performance than overall sales do. Newer stores tend to have extraordinarily robust sales that can skew a retailer's results. K mart Corp. said its same-store sales inched up 0.7 percent although overall sales rose 10.2 percent. Wal-Mart Stores Inc., the discount retailer that consistently outperforms the rest of the industry, reported a same-store sales gain of 9 percent and a 24 percent rise overall. J.C. Penney Co. Inc. said its same-store sales fell 3.4 percent, while overall sales were off 2.3 percent. Dayton Hudson Corp. reported a 2 percent decline in same-store sales, although overall sales were up 11.3 percent. Limited Inc., the nation's largest specialty apparel retailer, said its same-store sales dropped 3 percent, while overall sales rose 10 percent. Thursday's reports also came as bad news for the economy, as consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the gross national product. A drop-off in spending adversely affects other economic sectors, including manufacturers who sell merchandise to retailers. ``Retailers are playing a totally defensive ball game,'' reducing their orders to suppliers, said Feiner. The results announced Thursday differ from the monthly retail sales report from the government. The Commerce Department includes sales from supermarkets, restaurants and car dealerships in its figures. In other reports from retailers: - Woolworth Corp. reported a 2.1 percent gain in same-store sales, and a 6.2 percent rise overall. - May Department Stores Co. said its same-store sales fell 1.8 percent, while overall sales picked up 3.5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses Fail To Link Milken Directly to Illegal Trading
DOC.TEXT: The government's first two witnesses against Michael Milken couldn't directly link the former billionaire junk bond financier to scheming to manipulate a stock with inside trader Ivan Boesky. The first public hearing on charges against Milken after a four-year probe yielded details about the paranoia and fear that gripped Milken and others at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. after Boesky turned state's evidence in 1986. Prosecutors have picked three transactions they claim demonstrate that Milken routinely took advantage of clients and rigged the financial markets for his own gain. The allegations are contained in a pre-sentencing memo that urges a stiff sentence for Milken. Under questioning Thursday from government prosecutors and defense lawyers, former Drexel trader Cary Maultasch and former Boesky trader Michael Davidoff could not link Milken to the alleged 1986 manipulation of Wickes Co. stock. The government alleges that Milken directed Boesky's company to buy large blocks of stock in Wickes Cos., a Drexel client, in April 1986 to push up its price and help Wickes retire an issue of preferred shares with costly dividend payments. U.S. District Judge Kimba Wood asked Maultasch whether he had ``any reason to believe that Milken was involved in the decision to get the Boesky organization to buy Wickes stock.'' The witness paused before replying, ``No factual basis.'' Milken, 44, in April pleaded to six separate counts of conspiracy and fraud and agreed to pay $600 million rather than face trial on a 98-count indictment. He faces up to 28 years in prison. The government is trying to show that Milken manipulated the securities markets for his personal benefit. The defense is trying to prove his crimes were isolated cases of going too far to help clients. ``We find no nobility in cheating for a client to earn fees,'' Assistant U.S. Attorney John Carroll said in an opening statement. Milken attorney Arthur Liman countered that the government has trumped up charges against Milken to encompass the problems of Drexel, which also admitted felony crimes. ``When someone has the visibility and celebrity that Michael Milken has, it's easy to say that everything that ever happened at Drexel was his fault,'' Liman said. Liman hammered at the witnesses about whether Milken, in fact, had ever directed them to engage in any illegal behavior, including insider trading. They were unable to name any. Maultasch said Milken never discouraged him from cooperating with prosecutors and suggested he get his own lawyers, and never told him to destroy any records, withhold evidence or lie to the government. ``He never criticized you for making a deal to testify against him?'' Liman said. ``Not to my knowledge,'' Maultasch relied. Maultasch, who has been cooperating with the government in exchange for immunity from prosecution, also testified that he flew to Beverly Hills in a panic after receiving a subpoena on Nov. 14, 1986, when Boesky's cooperation agreement was announced. Maultasch said he met Milken at 4 a.m. in a Drexel conference room with a guard posted outside the door. In hushed tones, the two discussed the Boesky securities transactions listed in the subpoeana. Maultasch said Milken scribbled notes on a yellow legal pad rather than speaking, but he could not remember specifically what was said. Maultasch said he asked Milken about an October 1986 meeting with Boesky which had been tape-recorded by the government - and Milken replied that ``he was careful but he didn't know if he was careful enough.'' Milken took frequent notes, shook his head and furrowed his brow as government prosecutors stated their case during the daylong proceedings in a packed Manhattan federal court. The hearing is to resume Monday with testimony by former Drexel trader Peter Gardiner, whom Maultasch said told him to ask Davidoff to purchase the Wickes stock. The Boesky organization bought 1.9 million shares of Wickes on April 23, 1985, helping the stock hit a stipulated closing price at which the preferred shares could be redeemed. The pre-sentencing hearing is scheduled to last two weeks and each side has 20 hours to present testimony and cross-examine witnesses. The other transactions to be aired by the government involve alleged illegal dealings in Caesar's World Inc. and Storer Communications Inc.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter, Editor Dismissed in Flap Over Personal Investments
DOC.TEXT: The business editor and a reporter at a prominent Southern newspaper were ousted in a conflict-of-interest dispute that raises questions about what personal financial activity is appropriate for journalists. Business editor Leonard M. Apcar resigned from the St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times last week, days after firing banking reporter James Greiff. The episode at the 350,000-circulation Florida daily began late last month when Greiff disclosed he had been short-selling stock of Wells Fargo & Co., a San Francisco-based bank. After consulting with top editors, Apcar dismissed Greiff on Oct. 3. Two days later, Apcar quit under pressure after the editors learned his individual retirement account was invested in a mutual fund containing Banc One Corp. of Columbus, Ohio. Business journalism ethics have received increased scrutiny since the 1985 insider trading conviction of former Wall Street Journal reporter R. Foster Winans, who passed along unpublished tips about his widely read stock market column. Several editors and journalism professors contacted about the St. Petersburg incident drew a simple ethical rule for all media: Reporters shouldn't own stock or actively trade securities in industries they are assigned to cover. But they also said mutual funds and other passive investments generally aren't as problematic as profit-oriented trading in the realm of potential conflicts. ``It's part of a journalist's obligation to stay away from short-term trading of stocks they cover,'' said George Harmon, an associate professor at Northwestern University's Medill School of Journalism. ``With a mutual fund you're not controlling what stocks that fund owns,'' said Harmon, a former business editor of the Chicago Daily News. ``It doesn't seem to me that compromises your integrity. You don't have any control.'' Times Managing Editor Mike Foley said the dismissals involved ``a real disagreement'' over the newspaper's conduct guidelines, which warn against potential conflicts but don't prohibit any investments specifically. ``In neither of these cases did I feel that anything improper got into the news columns,'' he said. In short-selling, an investor sells borrowed stock on the expectation the price of the issue will decline. The investor profits if the price drops and the shares, usually borrowed from a broker, can be replaced at a lower price. The risky strategy, forbidden to journalists by at least one major business publication, amounts to a bet that a company's stock price will drop. Theoretically, a reporter writing a negative article about a company could ``short'' the stock of that company expecting the story to drive down the price. Greiff said he had not written about Wells Fargo. He was accused only of bad judgment, not any wrongdoing. Following Greiff's dismissal, Apcar said he told his immediate supervisor that he had bank stock in an IRA, but he didn't name the bank. Greiff, meanwhile, said he told Times executives that Apcar held shares of Banc One, which was mentioned in a story by Greiff the previous week as a possible suitor for a Florida bank. Apcar had edited that story and decided his mutual-fund holding presented no conflict. On Oct. 4, after rumors that Apcar owned stock in the bank filtered through the newsroom, Apcar said he voluntarily told his supervisor that Banc One was in the IRA. But a day later, Foley asked Apcar to resign. Mutual funds typically contain baskets of different stocks and other securities. Their contents usually are decided by fund managers, not investors. In an IRA, investors cannot withdraw money without penalty until retirement. ``You're not in a mutual fund . . . for a short period of time.'' said Apcar, 37, hired by the Times in early 1989 after more than 12 years as a Wall Street Journal reporter. ``You're in for the long haul unless you trade, and I don't trade.'' The Times' conflict-of-interest policy does not specifically bar any investments, but cautions reporters to avoid even the appearance of a conflict and to raise questions with superiors. Greiff, 35, a Times reporter for more than five years, said he did not violate any policy, written or spoken. He said business writers were told only not to invest in companies they cover or ones based in Florida. ``Within 10 minutes after placing my order with my broker I told several people in my department and told Len,'' he said. ``I said, `Do you have any problem with it?' and he said no.'' Apcar said he did not respond immediately to Greiff's admission. ``It went from being no problem to being a problem to being a firing offense in a matter of a few days,'' Greiff said. Rules governing reporters' investments vary widely. Dow Jones & Co., which owns The Wall Street Journal, has what is considered to be the strictest conflict-of-interest policy in the nation. Reporters and other staffers are barred from short-term trading and must hold securities at least six months. They cannot trade futures or options or sell short. Reporters and their families are prohibited from investing in companies related to their coverage areas. The Society of American Business Editors & Writers' ethics code urges avoiding even the appearance of conflict. It calls for skirting ``active trading and other short-term profit-seeking opportunities.'' Some editors said newspapers may be at fault if they discipline reporters without precise guidelines. ``If there is no specific policy that makes that clear I think the newspaper has overreached,'' said Sandra Duerr, business editor of The Courier-Journal in Louisville, Ky. Others said reporters need to be held to the same ethical standard they apply to their subjects. ``If the press as a whole is going to say that politicians should avoid even the appearance of conflict of interest, then we should hold ourselves to that extremely high standard,'' said Karen Rothmyer, an associate professor at Columbia University's journalism school.

DOC.HEAD: Iacocca Gets Neutral Reception From UAW
DOC.TEXT: United Auto Workers union leaders had a neutral response to Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca's explanation of why the company needs a contract different than pacts reached with GM and Ford. ``Well, you see he didn't come out with any bloody nose or anything,'' UAW spokesman Bob Barbee said Thursday after Iacocca spoke with negotiators working on a new contract. The union had indicated Iacocca was in for a rough time if he poor-mouthed the No. 3 automaker's situation. Iacocca has earned at least $4.6 million in salary and bonuses and exercised stock options worth millions more in the last five years. Chrysler, which is expected to say it lost millions when third-quarter earnings are released later this month, is in the worst financial shape of the Big Three. Iacocca said he neither pleaded poverty nor bargained during his meeting with the union, which has agreed on a new three-year contract with General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. Iacocca refused to say whether he asked the union to abandon pattern bargaining, in which the contracts with all three are intended to be virtually identical. ``We had a nice hour's discussion,'' Iacocca said. ``I gave them a state-of-the-union, state-of-the-company message.'' Talks between the UAW and Chrysler were suspended while the pattern contract was worked out between GM and the union. The pattern was adopted at Ford with slight modifications. Chrysler previously has bemoaned the cost of health-care coverage for the company's 67,000 hourly workers. At Chrysler, the average age is higher than at other U.S. and Japanese automakers. ``We took a lot of areas that we said we would have problems with and we said we would discuss them,'' Iacocca said. Most of the anticipated loss for the third quarter is attributed to down time for retooling at the company's highly profitable minivan plants. Iacocca recently has taken the blame for Chrysler's finances, saying management mistakes have led to some of the problems. Among those woes are the lowering of Chrysler's credit rating on Wall Street to the lowest investment grade, an exodus of top-level management to retirement or to other companies, and a dearth of new products for the early 1990s. Iacocca was irritated Thursday when asked whether he acknowledged such mistakes to the union. He said the news media has missed his point. ``The management mistakes are small compared to $1,250 rebates created by overcapacity from transplants, so put it in perspective,'' he said. Transplants are Japanese automakers manufacturing cars in the United States. Also Thursday, the Canadian Auto Workers union representing 36,500 GM workers reached a tentative agreement on a three-year contract. The pact mirrors the deal the union reached last month with Ford of Canada, union president Bob White told a news conference Thursday. The union expects Chrysler of Canada to follow this pattern in forthcoming talks, White said. The agreement calls for wage hikes of 7.5 percent in the first year, followed by increases of 6.7 percent and 4.8 percent, in addition to cost-of-living payments over the life of the contract.

DOC.HEAD: Saturn on Its Way
With PM-Saturn-Shipments
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Saturn cars are expected to pull more than a third of their first-year sales from other General Motors Corp. divisions, especially Chevrolet. About 65 percent of Saturn's sales during the next year will be new business for GM, said Don Hudler, Saturn Corp.'s sales and marketing vice president. The rest will come from people who would buy other GM cars, he said. But by the 1993 model year, about 80 percent of Saturn sales are expected to come from people lured away from other automakers, Hudler added. ``We'll do better as our perception gets out there,'' Hudler said after the official unveiling Thursday of Saturn's two- and four-door cars. Saturn's price range of $7,995 to $11,775 puts it in the same range as a host of imports and with the Geo Prizm and the Cavalier, both Chevrolets. Auto industry analysts have warned about Saturn's ``cannibalization'' of GM sales for some time. That tactic might be good for Saturn, but doesn't help GM profits. GM reported second-quarter earnings of $900 million, compared with $1.45 billion in the same quarter of 1989. Saturn began shipping cars to its 30 open dealers Thursday. About 1,000 cars will be in dealerships or on their way when Saturn officially goes on sale Oct. 25 in 30 retailers, mostly in then.'' Hudler drew cheers and applause from several hundred Saturn employees who got a 45-minute break from work to participate in the festivities. McWherter, who was state House speaker when GM announced in 1985 that Saturn was coming to Spring Hill 35 miles south of Nashville, recalled that his father moved their family from Tennessee to Michigan in search of work in the auto industry. ``I want to acknowledge the thousands and thousands of GM stockholders for their commitment to Tennessee,'' he said before driving a dark red, four-door sedan out of the plant. McWherter and the Saturn executives were joined on stage by Saturn-United Auto Workers coordinator Dick Hoalcraft and Bobby Lee Thompson, assistant director of UAW Region 8, who drew applause when he said he expects Saturn to surprise the imports. ``I happen to believe in the Saturn team to get the job done. But more important, I believe in you, the American public,'' Thompson said to more cheers. In the crowd was Jerry Benefield, president of Nissan Motor Manufacturing Corp. U.S.A., whose company makes Sentras and pickup trucks 40 miles away. ``It's pretty,'' Benefield said of the Saturn. Saturn is an American-made car designed to look and drive like it's Japanese. It is designed to compete with such companies as Nissan that have taken some of GM's market share. ``We're very, very good competitors,'' LeFauve said. ``It's guys like Jerry out there making the Nissan look good. And we're out there trying to make our car look good. ``In the end, it's the market that decides.''

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 9 a.m. EDT; time set by source. Also moving on general news wires.
Corporate Leaders Cautious About Recession Prospects
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy still can avert a recession, most of the nation's top business leaders said today, but others contended that a downturn already has begun or is imminent. Even if the economy does skirt a recession, the Business Council forecast calls for no more than a barely perceptible 0.3 percent growth during the second half of the year. The report prepared for the 100 chief executives of the nation's largest corporations, holding their semiannual two-day meeting at this mountain resort, was much more pessimistic than one last spring projecting moderate growth in the months ahead. ``They're much more worried'' than they were at May's meeting, Lewis T. Preston of J.P. Morgan & Co., the council vice chairman, said of the 19 corporate economists who compiled the forecast. ``Not worried enough, in my judgment.'' Asked whether he thought the economy already was in a recession, Preston told reporters, ``I do.'' Several other council members agreed. The council's economic consultants had predicted last spring the economy would continue to grow moderately at least through 1991. ``A clear majority ... still expect slow, but positive, growth through the middle of 1991,'' their new report said, although five of the 19 economists projected a recession. ``The September survey indicates that economic growth is expected to slow from the already sluggish 1.1 percent annual rate in the first half of 1990 to only 0.3 percent in the second half before gradually accelerating to a 1.2 percent pace in the first half of 1991 and 2.6 percent in the second half of next year,'' the report said. Although most of the consultants were not forecasting a recession, they raised the probability of a downturn by year's end to 39 percent from 22 percent last May. The probability of a recession by mid-1991 has increased from 29 percent to 47 percent, the report added. ``Indeed,'' it said, ``an informal poll taken at (an Oct. 2 meeting) indicated that a majority of the consultants had further lowered their growth expectations since the September survey as the result of additional increases in oil prices and generally weak economic reports.'' But the poll found that the economists believe any recession would be relatively mild and not as severe as the downturns of 1973-75 and 1981-82. At the same time, the report said ``there is broad agreement that the anticipated slowdown will have run its course by the middle of next year and that the economy will then revert to a more rapid pace of expansion.'' ``Not surprisingly, the thing that troubles them the most is the (Persian) Gulf crisis and the big jump that has occurred in both crude and product prices,'' Preston said at a news conference. Other concerns, he added, are a weaker economy than forecast last spring and federal budget uncertainties, ``including the distinct possibility that before this month is over, there could be a budget crisis or an impasse of crisis proportions.'' The council report said economic weakness is expected to be concentrated in housing, consumer spending on durable goods - usually expensive items expected to last more than three years - and business investment. Other highlights from the forecast: -Inflation as measured by the Consumer Price Index will reach 6.1 percent in the second half of 1990 before slowing to 4.5 percent in the first half of 1991 and 4.2 percent in the second half of next year. -The manufacturing economy will remain weak with orders, sales and profits showing little or no growth over the next six to nine months. Industrial production will advance less than 1 percent through the middle of 1991 but accelerate to a 3.6 percent annual rate in the second half of 1991. -The nation's merchandise trade deficit will continue to improve because of a lower dollar and strong economies overseas. The gap is predicted to drop from $109 billion in 1989 to $98 billion this year and $91 billion in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: Brady Asks More Money for S&L Bailout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires. Lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady is warning that savings and loan rescues ``will virtually cease within the next two months'' unless Congress provides more money before it adjourns. Brady, in a letter to the Democratic and Republican leaders of the congressional banking committees, said $40 billion would carry the bailout program through the 1991 fiscal year on Sept. 30. The money - to cover the losses in failed S&Ls - would be in addition to the $50 billion authorized under last year's thrift legislation. It also would be on top of about $60 billion in short-term borrowing, which would be repaid as regulators sell assets inherited from bankrupt institutions. Brady's letter, released Thursday and dated Wednesday, follows weeks of pressure from Democrats who said they were reluctant to provide more money without a specific request from the Bush administration. Earlier, Treasury Department officials had said a range of $40 billion to $80 billion more than last year's $50 billion was needed for S&Ls, but had not made a specific request. Brady said in the letter that it would be appropriate for Congress to give the administration open-ended spending authority. Because Congress may not want to go along, however, Brady said it could provide the $40 billion for the next fiscal year. The administration also would accept $20 billion to finance the program through April, Treasury officials have said. The Resolution Trust Corp., created last year to dispose of failed S&Ls, is ``projecting that RTC case resolutions will virtually cease within the next two months unless additional funds are provided,'' Brady said. A proposal before the Senate Banking Committee would provide $57 billion. The extra $17 billoon is included to increase the administration's short-term borrowing authority for S&Ls under a complex formula in last year's legislation. The bill also would cut short a financing mechanism that was intended to keep $30 billion in S&L spending from showing up in the federal budget deficit. So far, $23 billion has been borrowed through the Resolution Funding Corp., an off-budget agency known as Refcorp. Under the bill, the remaining $7 billion would have to be borrowed on-budget through the Treasury. The administration raised $5 billion for Refcorp on Thursday, selling 30-year bonds at an average interest rate of 9.33 percent. At a caucus of House Banking Committee Democrats Wednesday, most favored providing less than one year's worth of bailout money.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Stocks Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell on heavy morning losses while the dollar declined against the yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 195.47 points, or 0.87 percent, ending the day at 22,390.16 in thin trading. An estimated 320 million shares changed hands on first section, up from Thursday's 300 million. The Nikkei stock average, which lost 909.48 points the previous day, was 449.35 points lower at the end of the morning session due to index-linked selling from foreign brokerages and Japanese institutional investors discouraged by continuing declines on Wall Street, where the Dow Jones industrial average of 30 issues has fallen 158.66 points since Tuesday. ``The (Nikkei) index began falling as soon as the early session started,'' said Tomoya Koda, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. The dollar closed at 129.30 yen, 0.65 yen lower than Thursday. The currency opened higher, but started falling at late morning. ``Basically, the dollar is going down, and that's the trend,'' said Masafumi Koyama, a Bank of Tokyo dealer. Other dealers said the U.S. currency's rapid fall against the yen during the past weeks, coupled with concerns by Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno that the dollar has been falling too fast, kept the currency from dropping further. The price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds surged to 83.25 by 4 p.m. from Thursday's 82.24-point finish. Their yield was lower at 8.090 percent from 8.210 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Sun Belt Metro Areas Seen Growing Faster in '90s
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Cities-List
DOC.TEXT: The government is predicting that for the rest of the century the economies of Sun Belt metropolitan areas in the South and West will grow faster than manufacturing-dependent Rust Belt cities. West Palm Beach, Fla., topped a list of 54 metropolitan areas whose growth between 1988 and 2000 was estimated in a Commerce Department report Thursday. The city was first in projected gains in total personal income, population and employment. Other cities ranking in the top 10 in all three categories were: Phoenix, Ariz.; Orlando, Fla.; Riverside, Calif.; San Diego; Sacramento, Calif., and Tampa, Fla. ``The fastest growing areas ... all benefit from strong migration flows. ... This has been a part of their economic development for the past 25 years and the Commerce Department expects that to continue,'' said economist Mark Zandi of Regional Financial Associates in West Chester, Pa. ``Each of these areas have a good quality of life. Pollution, congestion, and crime are not problems, for the most part,'' he said. ``Also, housing affordability, except for Riverside and San Diego, are still pretty good.'' Other areas projected to have above-average growth are Anaheim, Calif.; Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; Atlanta; Seattle; Jacksonville, Fla., and Oakland, Calif., the department said. The six areas with the slowest projected growth are New Orleans, New York, Rochester, N.Y.; Pittsburgh, Cleveland and Detroit. Others expected to grow at a below-average rate are Louisville, Ky.; St. Louis and Bergen, N.J. Zandi said the slower-growing areas, in general, have either a higher-than-average dependence on manufacturing or on a single industry, such as oil. ``Even though output may be growing in manufacturing, improved productivity will keep growth in the number of jobs down,'' he said. New York's economy should remain fairly good, Zandi said, but its growth ranking is low because there is little room left to expand. West Palm Beach was projected to have 48.4 percent total income growth, adjusted for inflation; 24.8 percent population growth and 30.4 percent job growth. Phoenix was second in income growth and third in both job and population growth. New Orleans was the only city predicted to have a population decline, 0.1 percent, and it had the worst job growth, 6.1 percent. Rochester showed the smallest predicted inflation-adjusted income growth, 18.1 percent. New York ranked next to last in all three areas. The Commerce Department also looked at a fourth statistic - per capita personal income. Cities with the fastest growth predicted in general ranked low in 1988. Those with the slowest expected growth for the most part ranked highest in 1988. However, San Francisco, with a $26,309 per capita income, was expected to grow a better-than-average 16.2 percent to $30,582 and keep its No. 1 ranking. The average increase for all 54 cities in each area were: total personal income, 26.9 percent; population, 10.6 percent; employment, 15.8 percent, and per capita income, 14.8 percent. Among the nation's seven largest metropolitan areas - Los Angeles, New York, Chicago, Philadelphia, Detroit, Boston and Washington - only Los Angeles and Washington were expected to have better-than-average economic growth. George Downey, an analyst who worked on the report, said the Commerce Department used recent historical trends to predict the future. The projections do not take into account such extraordinary factors as recessions or wars. ``These are long-term projections for policy planning - for people building roads or dams,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says No Safety Probe Warranted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: There is no safety defect in Jeep CJ vehicles that would justify taking them off the road, the government's top safety official says in a ruling bitterly criticized by a consumer group spokesman. Jerry R. Curry, head of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, said he would not order a recall investigation of the vehicles, which went out of production in 1986. An estimated 420,000 are still registered for highway use. Three consumer organizations had petitioned the agency to conduct the investigation, saying the vehicles are dangerous because they frequently overturn. ``Americans have the right to make the choice'' to drive theJeep CJ, Curry said Thursday. ``You have to choose the lifestyle you want.'' The retired Army major general said he had ridden thousands of miles in the World War II jeep, after which the Jeep CJ was modeled. ``My son-in-law drives a CJ and my two granddaughters ride in it,'' he said. The Jeep CJ is safe if driven carefully, he said, although agency tests showed it and other light utility vehicles are more likely to overturn than passenger cars. Curry's decision is a ``serious wrongdoing,'' said Ben Kelly, spokesman for the Institute for Injury Reduction, a non-profit research and educational group founded by trial lawyers. Kelly, a frequent critic of the federal agency during the Reagan administration, said Curry ``has as little commitment to eliminating hazardous vehicles from our highways as his predecessors since 1980.'' ``For countless Americans, that is a death sentence,'' Kelly said. ``For the manufacturers, it is a continuing permit to make unsafe vehicles.'' The Jeep CJ was manufactured by American Motors Corp., which was purchased by Chrysler Corp. in 1987. Chrysler said in a statement, ``The NHTSA findings confirm that the Jeep CJ is a safe vehicle and we are pleased that the matter is now closed.'' Curry's ruling is the latest twist in a lengthy controversy surrounding the Jeep CJ. AMC sold 609,356 CJ-5 and CJ-7 vehicles between 1972 and 1986, when Chrysler replaced the CJ with the redesigned Wrangler. CJ rollover accidents caused 116 deaths in 1989, said Michael Brownlee, the federal agency's associate administrator for enforcement. Kelly's group joined the Center for Auto Safety and Public Citizen, groups founded by Ralph Nader, in requesting the NHTSA investigation. Their petition said the CJ's suspension system was defective and its roll-bar assembly inadequate. It is susceptible to overturning because its wheels are closer together than those of passenger cars. Also, its center of gravity is unusually high because the vehicle is built with extra space underneath to accommodate rough terrain. The agency studied all those claims before deciding not to proceed, Curry said.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel OKs $13 Billion in Farm Program Cuts
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Lead prospects uncertain; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: More than $13 billion in proposed farm program cuts, devised by the House Agriculture Committee, went today to congressional budget writers and negotiators on the 1990 farm bill. Meeting in closed sesson late into Thursday night, the committee approved the package by a 26-5 vote. The biggest savings - $5.8 billion - would come from a so-called triple-base plan, which would require farmers to reduce subsidized acreage by 15 percent in 1992 and 1993, 20 percent in 1994 and 25 percent in 1995. ``Pain, pain, pain,'' Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., said after the panel's work ended. ``I guess we are going to find out what market-oriented agriculture is all about.'' He predicted that farmers would see reduced income as a result of the changes. ``To make reductions is very difficult,'' said Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas. `` We hope we spread it around so it doesn't impact in a negative way (on farmers' income.)'' The plan, which reduces agriculture spending by $13.6 billion over five years, will be considered by the House Budget Committee, which is working to find $500 billion in savings in total government spending. It also would be woven into the 1990 farm bill, being worked out in a House-Senate conference committee, if the Senate members of the committee agree. The triple base plan gives farmers flexibility to plant several different crops on acreage they now are planting in a particular subsidized or ``program'' crop. Currently, farmers keep track of two so-called ``base'' land areas: the acres they plant in certain crops and land they leave idle at the demand of the government. Under the new plan, farmers would create a third base of acreage that they could plant in any program crop (wheat, corn, feed grains, rice or cotton); oilseeds, industrial crops, experimental crops or other commodities for which no substantial domestic production exists. This acreage would not be subsidized, but would give farmers the flexibility to answer market demands for certain food preferences. Other savings would be achieved by calculating deficiency payments on an average price over 12 months instead of an average of the first five months after harvest, when market prices are lowest. The government pays farmers the difference between its target price and the market price, and at harvest time that difference is greatest. Other major money saving proposals include: -Shifting 25 percent of Rural Electric Administration and all but $500 million of Farmers Home Administration direct loans to private lenders. -Putting a 1 percent user fee on loans for dairy, sugar, tobacco, peanuts, honey, wool and mohair and a 4 percent fee on soybean loans. -Setting soybean marketing loans at $5.02. -Having a 1991 reduction in wheat acreage of 15 percent. -Establishing user fees for the Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service. A new $5.295 billion expansion of the food stamp and nutrition programs in the 1990 farm bill would be retained if House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., is able to find money from other sources, de la Garza said. Meanwhile, on the House floor Thursday, the Agriculture Committee fought off an effort by Rep. Mike Synar, D-Okla., to instruct the House farm bill negotiators to insist that, at minimum, pesticide export controls in the House version of the farm bill be adopted. The motion, which failed 248-162, also would have required the House conferees to agree to provisions in the Senate bill that require the government to immediately stop allowing any produce into the United States that carries the residue of a banned pesticide. De la Garza pledged to fight for the provision, but he said he was insulted that Synar took the issue to the floor as if he didn't respect the chairman's ability to negotiate for it. On another instruction to House conferees, the House voted, 255-154, to insist that $10 million be authorized annually in fiscal years 1991 through 1995 for a public education program on the hazards of tobacco use.

DOC.HEAD: China Opens Grain Market
DOC.TEXT: In one of its few economic reforms this year, China opened a national wheat market Friday to replace central allocation of the nation's 85 million ton annual wheat harvest. More than 200 grain trading companies were to begin dealing on opening day at the Wholesale Grain Market in Zhengzhou, the provincial capital of Henan, China's wheat heartland, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. The market is one of China's few experiments in using markets to replace four decades of central planning. Most other reform initiatives were halted two years ago when conservatives accused the reformists of overheating the economy and generating market chaos. The Zhengzhou market's opening was delayed two years by inadequate planning and ideological reservations. Some conservative officials have denounced futures trading as speculative. But the Zhengzhou market was allowed to proceed because it will help the government manage grain distribution, long a serious problem. Although the government buys most grain grown in China, it lacks a network of modern storage facilities, and in bumper years much grain is left to rot outdoors. Serious shortages have occurred in some regions while others have surpluses. China still lacks wholesale markets for the 169 million metric tons of rice, its main crop, harvested annually. Most of the wheat will be sold for future delivery, a key element of a futures market. However, William D. Grossman, managing director of the Chicago Board of Trade's Asia-Pacific office, said the operatio lacks another element of a true futures market, standardized contracts. The Board of Trade, the world's largest futures market, has been training and advising Chinese personnel but will not be involved in the market's management. A futures market allows buyers and sellers to negotiate a price for what they think a commodity will be worth at a future date. The price holds regardless of subsequent market changes. ``The most immediate effect will be to promote circulation. In the long term, it will promote price discovery,'' Grossman said. Until now, state grain bureaus in each province had to go through the central government to buy or sell wheat to other provinces, setting a price through negotiation. The Zhengzhou market streamlines the process by bringing buyers and sellers together. Individual farmers will still sell their wheat to the state and will not be allowed to participate in trading. Commerce Minister Hu Ping said in June that the market will set maximum and minimum prices. If the price threatens to go above the ceiling, the market will automatically close. If there are no offers to buy at the minimum price, the state will buy the wheat. Only dues-paying members will be allowed to trade, said Grossman, and foreigners will be excluded. Traders will be mostly state farms and large consumers like breweries and noodle factories. Grossman has likened the Zhengzhou market to the Chicago Board of Trade when it opened in 1848. It took 20 years before the Chicago market developed from a cash market to a futures market. Chinese news reports say the government is considering a futures market for corn, rice and pigs.

DOC.HEAD: Retail Sales Up in September
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; no pickup; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Retail sales jumped 1.1 percent in September, artificially inflated by the soaring cost of gasoline, the government said Friday. Sales rose $1.6 billion to a seasonally adjusted $151.2 billion, the Commerce Department said. That followed a revised 0.4 percent decline in August, which had previously been reported as a 0.6 percent drop. September's gain was the best since an identical rise four months earlier. August sales too were bolstered by rising gasoline prices, which took off after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Service station sales were up 7 percent in August. Excluding gasoline, sales fell a steeper 0.9 percent in August and rose a lower 0.8 percent in September. Last month's performance also was helped by a rebound in auto sales, which have been slipping most of the year. Auto sales rose 2.9 percent to $31.1 billion in September after falling 3.7 percent a month earlier. Despite the gain, they were still 4.9 percent behind last year. Factoring out the volatile auto category, sales rose 0.6 percent last month following a 0.5 percent rise in August. Sales at department stores, one of the best gauges of consumer sentiment, were down 0.9 percent last month to $17.6 billion. That is being taken as a sign that the Persian Gulf crisis and lackluster economic performance in general continue to shake consumer confidence. In a separate private report on Thursday, major retail chains reported disappointing results for last month. According to the Commerce Department, all retail sales in the July-September quarter were only 2.8 percent higher than the same period a year earlier. That is not enough to account for rising prices.

Sales of durable goods, ``big ticket'' items intended to last three or more years, such as major appliances and autos, rose 1.4 percent in September, following a 0.5 percent gain the month before. Non-durable goods sales climbed 0.9 percent after a 0.8 percent gain in August. In specific categories, the government said: -Hardware, garden and building supply stores reported sales dropped 0.5 percent. -Furniture sales rose 0.7 percent. -Food store receipts rose 1.6 percent. -Clothing and accessory store sales fell 1.5 percent. -Restaurant and bar sales increased 1 percent. -Drug store sales were up 0.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: California Restricts Hair Sprays, Degreasers, Cleaners
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: California has adopted the nation's toughest air-quality standards for household products, ordering a 45 percent cut in smog-forming pollutants from such items as hair spray, window cleaner and floor wax. The order Thursday by the Air Resources Board will be phased in from 1993 to 1998 and could add up to 23 cents to the price of the 16 types of products covered, said Jim Boyd, ARB executive officer. Products covered include engine degreaser, windshield washer fluid, furniture polish, room air freshener, laundry prewash, nail polish remover, insect repellent, oven cleaner, hair styling gel and mousse, tile cleaner and shaving cream. When fully in force, the rules would eliminate about 45 tons per day of hydrocarbon emissions, an amount equal to the emissions of about 1.4 million vehicles. Currently the household products emit about 100 tons of hydrocarbons a day. ``No other state has adopted regulations that are these comprehensive,'' William Sylte, the board's chief deputy executive officer. The federal government, he added, does not yet regulate such product hydrocarbon emissions. The regulations stemmed from a 1988 California law requiring a crackdown on hydrocarbons in hair sprays, cleaners and other consumer goods. ``The federal government has taken so long in getting around to this, that the California Legislature went ahead and authorized'' the stringent regulations, Sylte said. Hydrocarbons are contained in chemicals used in the manufacture of some of the products or are found in the propellants of others. ``Once they escape into the atmosphere, however, they react with other pollutants to form urban smog in the same way as hydrocarbons from tailpipe exhaust,'' Boyd said. Despite potential cost increases, he said, ``we expect that virtually all of the products currently offered to consumers will continue to be available, and all of them will be environmentally more acceptable than what is on store shelves today.'' The ARB said some new hair sprays - six aerosol and 24 pump sprays - already have substantially lower hydrocarbons. Hair spray is the No. 1 producer of household hydrocarbons, followed by windshield washer fluid and room air fresheners. The regulations are patterned after similar rules governing paints, industrial degreasers, deodorants and antiperspirants. Thursday's order marked the second major environmental decision by the ARB in two weeks. In the earlier ruling, the ARB adopted the world's strictest pollution standards for new automobiles, requiring all cars built between 1994 and 2003 to be up to 85 percent less polluting than today's models. The decision also required production of nonpolluting electric cares by 1998. The state also has has cut emissions from factories. ``We won't meet health standards without controlling these (household) emissions, too,'' Boyd said.

DOC.HEAD: Tektronix To Close or Sell Workstation Business
DOC.TEXT: Tektronix Inc. said it will sell or shut down its unprofitable workstation business within 60 days, and the company gave layoff notices to about 175 employees. If it can find a buyer for the business, many of those workers would be re-employed, company spokesman Doug Babb said Thursday. Otherwise, they will join the more than 2,000 Tektronix employees who have been laid off since the beginning of the year. The company has laid off or lost by attrition about half of the more than 24,000 employees it had nine years ago. ``We made the decision it is time to put our resources behind other products,'' Babb said. He said flat-panel computer displays and liquid crystal color shutters, an advanced technology for color computer screens, are two promising areas where Tektronix is focusing its efforts. Workstations, which are powerful desktop computers used in design work and other areas, face tough competition. The market is dominated by other brands, particularly Sun Microsystems Inc. and Hewlett-Packard Co.'s Apollo division.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Propel Britain's Inflation To 10.9 Pc
DOC.TEXT: Higher oil prices propelled Britain's annual inflation rate to 10.9 percent in September, its highest level in nearly nine years, but politicians predicted the worst may be over. Although inflation is peaking, the worse-than-expected figures for September suggest that a decline in the rate will not be as fast as had been hoped, economists said. ``A bit of a shock'' is the way Ian Harwood, an economist at the London investment firm Warburg Securities, described the news. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said Friday that inflation ``will soon begin to decline.'' Linking the pound to Europe's currency system earlier this week ``will reinforce our own financial discipline against it,'' she said. Britain has the worst inflation among the major industrialized nations despite Mrs. Thatcher's efforts to the contrary. She has said fighting inflation is her No. 1 economic priority. Mrs. Thatcher, speaking at the Conservative Party's annual conference, said that ``signs are clear'' that the government's interest rate policy is working. She made reference to a cut in base rates by one percentage point to 14 percent earlier this week. Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major told reporters the hike in inflation was ``where we thought it would be.'' In his speech to the conference on Thursday, Major warned that recent increases in oil prices had yet to appear fully in the inflation statistics. But he also predicted inflation would fall sharply next year. The 10.9 percent rate was the highest level since inflation stood at 11 percent in February 1982 and compared with a rate of 10.6 percent in August, the government said. The underlying level of annual inflation, which excludes mortgage payments and a per-capita tax, rose to 8.3 percent in September from 7.9 percent in August. Retail prices rose 0.9 percent in September from the previous month. The government blamed the hike on a sharp increase in gasoline prices to an average of $4.55 a gallon, from $4.20 in August. Oil prices have risen sharply since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. There also were price increases in a wide range of other goods and services. The financial markets, which had expected a 10.8 percent figure, reacted calmly to the news. ``September will be the peak,'' Harwood said. ``The bad news however, is that the unexpected robustness (in the underlying rate) means the fall in the rate will be less than expected.'' Gwyn Hache, an economist with James Capel and Co., said what was worrisome was that non-oil prices rose more than expected. Although Harwood expects inflation to fall below 10 percent by the end of the year, he said forecasts that it will fall to 5 percent or lower in 1991 are proving optimistic.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 323.30 off 2.31 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Rise After Crop Report
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices rose moderately this morning on the Chicago Board of Trade after the the Agriculture Department lowered its projection for 1990 U.S. soybean production. Corn futures also opened higher on a lower corn harvest estimate, then turned mixed. Wheat futures were mostly lower in early trading. In a report released Thursday afternoon, the USDA projected 1990 U.S. soybean production at 1.82 billion bushels compared with the September estimate of 1.84 billion and market expectations averaging 1.83 billion. The agency estimated a corn harvest of 8.02 billion bushels compared with its September estimate of 8.12 billion and market expectations averaging 8.06 billion. In early trading, wheat futures were 2} cents lower to 1 cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.69\ a bushel; corn was unchanged to 2 cents higher with December at $2.32} a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1 cent higher with December at $1.19} a bushel; soybeans were 3 cents to 6} cents higher with November at $6.27 a bushel. Cattle futures were mixed and pork futures were higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were unchanged to .23 cent higher with October at 78.75 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .17 cent lower to .10 cent higher with October at 87.40 cents a pound; live hogs were .15 cent to .43 cent higher with October at 56.95 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .85 cent to 1.2 cents higher with February at 65.60 cents a pound. Cattle futures retreated on Thursday; pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Wholesale Prices Soar 1.6 Percent in September
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale prices shot up 1.6 percent in September as turmoil in the Persian Gulf battered the U.S. economy and fueled a record-breaking jump in gasoline prices, the government reported today. The Labor Department blamed virtually all of the steep increase on higher oil costs that persisted in September following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. A 20.6 percent increase in gasoline last month was the highest one-month increase recorded since the government began tracking the commodity in 1947, the government said. ``The oil shock is hitting with a vengeance and it's coming at a time when inflation overall is still untamed. ... It's just one more jolt to an already fragile economy,'' said Robert Dederick, chief economist at the Northern Trust Co. of Chicago. Last month's rise in the Producer Price Index - the biggest jump in wholesale inflation since a cold snap sent prices up 1.9 percent in January - followed a similarly sharp increase of 1.3 percent in August. That surge was also blamed on higher energy costs brought on by the gulf crisis. It was the biggest two-month jump in producer prices since 1980, the government said. In another economic report today, the Commerce Department said retail sales jumped 1.1 percent in September, bolstered by the soaring cost of gasoline. Excluding gasoline, sales rose 0.8 percent during the month. Overall, sales rose $1.6 billion to a seasonally adjusted $151.2 billion, the Commerce Department said. The fallout from the Persian Gulf conflict has heightened analysts' fears that higher inflationary pressures will aggravate an already staggering U.S. economy. Many economists believe, in fact, that the nation has already slipped into recession. The oil shock threatens to ``intensify the downturn, deepen it, perhaps lengthen it,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist at the Boston Co. Analysts said the inflation outbreak, coupled with today's relatively positive retail sales report, deepens the dilemma for the Federal Reserve. The central bank has been under pressure from the Bush administration to ease its inflation-fighting campaign and lower interest rates to spur the economy. ``How in the world can the Fed ease? The consumer at least hasn't rolled over and inflation is rebelling. The two (reports) give a further reason for the Fed to remain frozen in its current posture,'' Dederick said. At the White House, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said, ``Inflation going up is never good news.'' He declined to criticize the Federal Reserve's apparent tight monetary policy. ``We still are concerned about growth and about preventing a recession. We think the Fed has recognized all these factors and is on the right course,'' Fitzwater said. The September rise in wholesale prices would translate into an annual increase of 20.9 percent if prices rose that much each month, the government said. That is far above the 3 percent advance, at an annual rate, in the Producer Price Index from January through July, before the Middle East erupted. With August and September increases figured in, wholesale inflation has increased at an annual rate of 6.3 percent so far in 1990, the government said. In September, energy costs overall rose 13.8 percent, the biggest one-month jump since the government began tracking that statistic in 1974, the government said. Gasoline jumped 20.6 percent while fuel oil rose 21.3 percent. Natural gas was up 1.3 percent, today's report said. Food prices, meanwhile, were down 0.9 percent after rising 0.8 percent in August. Fresh fruit prices fell 3.6 percent while vegetables were down 4.8 percent. Egg prices, which had soared 25.8 percent in August, fell 7.0 percent, the government said, Costs were down for rice, pasta, beef and pork. They were up for bakery products, chickens and turkeys. Prices for goods excluding the volatile food and energy items - often taken by economists as a better barometer of underlying inflationary pressures - rose 0.6 percent. In August, this so-called core rate rose 0.3 percent. Passenger car prices were up a sharp 3.4 percent after having risen 0.8 percent in August, the government said. Clothing prices were up slightly for women's, men's and boys' apparel but fell 0.7 percent for girls', children's and infants' clothing. Footwear rose 0.4 percent. Tobacco prices rose 1.2 percent and were 13.6 percent higher than they were a year ago. Inflation at earlier stages of the production process was up sharply, too, largely due to the gulf crisis, the Labor Department said. Crude goods jumped 4.6 percent while intermediate goods jumped 1.8 percent. An example of the three processing stages would be clothing for finished goods, cloth for intermediate and cotton for crude. The various changes put the Producer Price Index for all finished goods at 120.3 in September. That means a hypothetical selection of goods that cost $100 in 1982 cost $120.30 last month, up from 113.60 a year earlier. The Consumer Price Index, which measures the price of goods and services at the retail level, is due out next week. Analysts are worried that the current inflation outbreak is likely to become more entrenched, filtering through to the thousands of plastic, chemical and other products made with petroleum. Oil also figures into products that must be transported long distances and shows up in utility costs, too.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Proposes Layoffs or Pay Cuts to Union
DOC.TEXT: The machinists' union at Northwest Airlines said today it is considering a proposal by Northwest Chairman Alfred Checchi that it choose between laying off workers or taking a 10 percent pay cut for six months. Checchi, whose airline faces soaring jet fuel costs, made the proposal Wednesday night to Guy Cook, president of the 24,400-member International Association of Machinists at Northwest, the Saint Paul Pioneer Press reported today. It quoted unidentified sources. Cook today generally confirmed the report, but said the number of layoffs is ``up in the air.'' He said figures of ``ten, fifteen and 20 percent were all mentioned.'' ``Another possible scenario is management paying attention to some areas to cut costs,'' Cook said. ``I have mentioned that to Checchi.'' Cook said he planned to respond later today to Checci's offer. The union covers mechanics, baggage handlers, reservations agents and other ground personnel. Northwest would not confirm or deny that a proposal was made. ``All I can say is the airline has for some time now been considering ways in which we can control expenses in light of higher jet fuel costs,'' company spokesman Doug Miller said. ``We're looking at a number of possibilities but haven't made any decision.'' Northwest employs about 44,000 workers, about 16,500 in Minnesota. A 15 percent cut would amount to 6,600 jobs. Other big airlines, including USAir, Pan American World Airways, Trans World Airlines and industry heavyweight American Airlines, have already announced layoffs to cope with a sluggish economy and a 65 percent increase in fuel prices. The fuel price run-up, sparked by Middle East turmoil, could add $800 million to $1 billion a year to Northwest's tab for fuel. Duane Woerth, chairman of the 5,600-member Northwest Air Line Pilots Association union, said he planned to meet with Checchi today. He said contract provisions with Northwest do not allow the carrier to lay off any pilots until mid-February. The provision was triggered by the airline's participation in government programs to allow Northwest pilots and jets to shuttle U.S. troops to the Middle East. He said the provisions also restrict layoffs to pilots hired since Aug. 28, 1989. Union figures suggest only 273 pilots would be vulnerable to layoff after mid-February. ``If the goal is to prevent layoffs, that's something we can help construct,'' Woerth said, suggesting vacation schedules could be juggled to help avert job cuts.

DOC.HEAD: Disaster Recovery in the High-Tech Age
DOC.TEXT: With companies so computer-dependent, how can they to business if a hurricane or earthquake hits or their equipment is knocked out by a power outage or busted water pipe? Mostly likely they don't, unless they have a plan to quickly retrieve enough data to function. But what good is the information when the company can't get it because the computer system is flooded, burned, leveled or the victim of a brownout? That's where the disaster recovery industry comes in, says Ira Josowitz, who helped set up International Business Machines Corp.'s year-old, $50 million Business Recovery Services Center in Tampa. Recovery planning is becoming big business as sophisticated computer systems take over more of the corporate workload. A wide range of businesses from ``mom and pop'' operations to industry giants have elaborate and expensive contingency plans they hope they never have to use. ``You do it so you can continue to operate. It's good and prudent business,'' said Tom Green of Price Waterhouse, a major accounting and consulting firm. ``Tampa is a flood-prone, lightning-prone, brownout-prone environment. If something can go wrong, this is the place for it,'' said Green, who is among IBM's customers in the U.S., Canada and the Caribbean. IBM is a fledgling in the competitive disaster recovery market, which traces its roots to the 1970s. ``IBM got into the disaster recovery business last year to help customers prepare for calamities like hurricanes and earthquakes that can wipe out data and computer systems that are vital to their businesses,'' said Mike Hill, regional manager. A company - large or small - can be back in business in a matter of hours at IBM's ``hot site,'' a corporate home-away-from-home. Executives notify IBM they're in trouble and retrieve critical backup tapes from a vault or storage site sometimes as far as 1,000 miles away. They summon key personnel who will keep the company alive from the remote laboratory while recouping from the disaster. At IBM, three suites are ready. More are planned next year to eventually accommodate 12 customers simultaneously. The largest command center could handle a small army of corporate officials with 15 computer terminals, monitors, phone banks and IBM staff trained to assist. A 5,000-square-foot room is stuffed with communications equipment in 6-foot-tall cabinets. Another room four times that size holds state-of-the-art processors which can handle a billions of bits of information. Cost to a business for this risk-insurance is not cheap. It runs from $125 to $50,000 a month, depending on company size. Businesses get 72 hours of on-site testing - fire drills to work out the bugs. If they declare a disaster and have to use the site, there's an added fee of $50,000 for the first 48 hours and $25,000 a day for up to six weeks. If more time is needed, they can bring in equipment and set up at the facility, free of charge. Among IBM's 600 customers are insurance companies, manufacturers, retailers, brokerage houses, and service providers such as hospitals and municipalities. eu IBM has another key site in Franklin Lakes, N.J., and other smaller recovery facilities in Chicago, Los Angeles, Washington, Philadelphia, Detroit, Atlanta and one being built in Dallas. Coopers & Lybrand, a top accounting-consulting firm with operations in 104 countries, has joined IBM in a disaster partnership to help customers devise a recovery plan - a process which takes several months. ``IBM provides the technology, we provide the plan so the business can survive,'' said Leonard Gilbert, a Miami-based partner for Coopers & Lybrand. Gilbert said hundreds of businesses devastated when Hurricane Hugo went ashore last year in the Carolinas didn't have a disaster plan and never came back. ``These were the ones that didn't have files, key personnel ready or a program in place. There were no automatic tellers to withdraw money. Customers outside the disaster zone called in, but lines were down or no one was there if they got through. The customers went somewhere else,'' Gilbert said. ``It all depends on how long you can be out of business with your computers down,'' he said. ``Computers are the lifeline of companies today and a disaster recovery plan is something they need to have to survive.''
