DOC.HEAD: Slumping Economy Cuts Into Tax Rolls
DOC.TEXT: The slumping economy cuts into cities' and states' tax collections, turning up budget shortfalls that make municipal bond investors wary and intent on getting higher returns for their risk. New York City, Philadelphia and Massachussetts have been the most recent and widely publicized of those in the credit-rating doghouse because of widening gaps between the costs of services and revenues. Standard & Poors Corp. last week placed New York City on its ``credit watch'' list, meaning the bond rating agency is reviewing the city's ability to pay interest and principal on its $13 billion in general obligation bonds. Philadelphia's debt, meanwhile, has been downgraded to junk bond status by both S&P and Moody's Investors Services Inc. Massachuessetts' recent offering of $1.035 billion of general obligation bonds got a low rating that forced yields of nearly 8 percent at auction. As credit ratings go down, yields go up. That means municipalities already struggling to make ends meet have the added burden of paying higher interest rates to borrow money. Investors have driven up the yields for New York City bonds in the past week. For Philadelphia, the city couldn't even get access to the market for its annual sale of about $375 million in short-term notes amid predictions by city officials that it would run out of money by Dec. 1. The most serious problems have been confined to the Northeast. However, there have been problems in Florida as tax collections have been hurt by the souring housing market. Would-be immigrants to Florida from the Northeast have had trouble selling their homes. Tax collections have slowed in Illinois, Michigan and Ohio. ``Their manufacturing base and exports continue to do well, but that may catch up with them,'' said Hyman C. Grossman, managing director at S&P in charge of municipal bonds. Analysts also note some concern for southern California. While for some cities and states the tide of severe economic troubles has yet to come, others have been able to help their credit rating steady by keeping spending in line with revenues. ``Sometimes you have to put a leash on spending and its a tough political issue. Those who can respond without raising taxes all the time have the answer,'' Grossman said. Before management can lead a municipality through tough economic times, there has to be the political will to make unpopular decisions, said Neal Atterman, vice president and director of municipal research at Kidder, Peabody & Co. ``Management by the chief executive and a political meeting of the minds between the legislative branch and the executive as to how to deal with problem'' is key for negotiating a strong credit rating though economic uncertainty,'' Atterman said. While the liklihood that some municipal bond issuers may miss an interest payment or two is growing, the chances of a long-term serious default on any issue is remote, analysts say. Municipal bonds are basically IOUs issued states and local governments to raise money to build highways, bridges, schools, hospitals, etc. Revenue bonds have been traditionally viewed as less secure because they depend on income from a specific project, such as bridge tolls, to pay interest and principal. General obligation bonds are backed by the full faith and credit of the issuer, who can draw interest and principal payments from general funds. But it has been the general obligation bonds that have come under pressure lately, partly due to the poor real estate market that has pushed down property assessments. The slow housing market has been at the root of the Northeast's problems, analysts say, but many cities and states are getting caught between programs mandated by a higher level of government and an eroding tax base.

DOC.HEAD: Mortgage Rates Up
DOC.TEXT: Fixed-rate mortgages averaged 10.22 percent this week, up from 10.08 percent last week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders asked an average initial rate of 8.24 percent, down from 8.25 percent last week. The rates do not include add-on fees known as points.

DOC.HEAD: Italian National Airline Boosts Order by 20 Airbus Planes
DOC.TEXT: The Italian national airline Alitalia ordered 20 Airbus passeger jetliners Friday, bringing its total order for the new model to 60 aircraft, including 20 options. Jean Pierson, administrator of the Airbus Industrie consortium, said the 40 firm orders are valued at $3.1 billion. The Italian airline had been the first to buy the new A321 model short- to medium-range aircraft and now has ordered more than any other customer, Pierson said. The first will be delivered by spring 1994 and will be used on the airline's internal, European and Mediterranean services. The A321 is a longer, fuel-efficient version of the twin-engine A320 and holds 191 passengers. It has a 1,100-mile range. Airbus Industrie has 131 firm orders for the aircraft. The Toulouse-based Airbus consortium consists of four aircraft manufacturers from France, Germany, Great Britain and Spain.

DOC.HEAD: Colgate-Palmolive Becomes First Advertiser on Soviet Buses
DOC.TEXT: Colgate-Palmolive Co. has become the first company to place its ads on Soviet buses, officials said Friday. The New York-based consumer products company signed a contract for the ads with Transportation Displays Inc., a company that places ads on transit facilities. The Colgate ads, promoting toothpaste the company has started selling in the Soviet Union, will appear on the sides of buses in Moscow and Kiev, the capital of the Ukraine, Colgate and TDI said. ``Colgate - the World's Most Popular Toothpaste,'' the signs say in large Cyrillic letters. The ads were developed by Young & Rubicam. Colgate says the ads are part of its strategy to develop increased awareness of its products among Soviet consumers and dentists. TDI obtained the exclusive right to place ads on transportation vehicles in major Soviet cities in March. ``Colgate-Palmolive's pioneering decision to advertise on TDI's network will undoubtedly pave the way for other American advertisers,'' said Howard Ziff, who is in charge of TDI's Soviet operation.

DOC.HEAD: KLM Cuts Jobs in Wake Of Rising Oil Prices
DOC.TEXT: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines announced Friday it was cutting 500 jobs and warned that rising jet fuel prices and a weak dollar could wipe out profits this fiscal year. The company also may cut part of its foreign network as part of a $231 million cost-cutting plan over the next three years, said KLM spokesman Hugo Baas. But an industry analyst said the measures were too little, too late. Rob Sweers, head of institutional investment at the Parisbas bank in Amsterdam, noted that the cuts represent only a small percentage of KLM's total workforce of 25,000. ``Under the present circumstances, it may not be enough,'' he said. Prices of jet fuel have skyrocketed in recent weeks because of tensions in the Middle East, and all the major airlines have felt the effects. At the same time, the U.S. dollar, on which KLM's international ticket sales are based, has been sliding to lows not seen in years. Baas warned that unless both trends are reversed, KLM will probably face a loss in the current fiscal year. The airline also blames its troubles on the low cost of labor in the Far East, which allows competitors there to operate more economically. ``We are living in a totally different social system,'' said Baas, referring to the relatively high social welfare costs that boost European wages. The layoffs will take place in the Netherlands, where 19,000 of KLM's personnel are based. KLM had net income of 340 million guilders, or $197 million, in the fiscal year ending March 31.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Financial News Network Fires Executive; Changes Auditors
DOC.TEXT: Financial News Network, the 24-hour business-oriented cable television service, said Friday it fired a top executive for improper financial dealings and dismissed its auditors. The company said two other employees in the accounting staff were put on leave while FNN reviews their ``status.'' Chief Financial Officer C. Steven Bolen, 44, was dismissed following a board investigation that concluded he ``received compensation payments that were not properly authorized and . . . that certain bank accounts administered under (his) direction were not properly recorded.'' Bolen has been on leave since summer, when questions about payments to him first surfaced, said sources close to FNN who spoke on condition they not be identified. Bolen, who had been with the company for about five years and worked out of its Los Angeles office, earned $185,000 annually. No charges have been filed against him. Bolen could not be located for comment. FNN said in a statement that it believes all the funds have been accounted for. FNN spokeswoman Amber Gordon would not comment on how much money was involved. Separately, FNN and Infotechnology Inc., which owns 47 percent of the news service as well as 97 percent of United Press International, said they have terminated the services of their accounting firm, Deloitte & Touche. A committee comprised of FNN board members recommended the termination because it didn't think the firm ``would be able to complete the audit work in a timely fashion.'' Deloitte, in turn, notified FNN, Infotechnology and its UPI subsidiary, that the financial statements it prepared for them should no longer be relied upon. Deloitte said it was withdrawing its 1989 opinion of FNN's financial health because of fresh information concerning some transactions between FNN and UPI, as well as questions about 1989 financial statements by Bolen. FNN since has retained Coopers & Lybrand as its auditors. FNN provides business and market news and sports news on 3,500 cable systems throughout the United States and Canada. The company said its broadcasts reach 35 million homes.

DOC.HEAD: Grain Futures Fall, Paced By Wheat
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower Friday on the Chicago Board of Trade as selling pressure from the wheat market eroded the support of a bullish corn and soybean crop report. Wheat futures fell moderately amid speculative selling that reflected abundant wheat supplies and slack demand, the same factors that have weighed on wheat prices for several months. Thursday's monthly Agriculture Department crop report contained slightly lower corn and soybean harvest estimates than traders had expected, which gave those markets an early boost, But a more significant number in the report was a prediction that U.S. soybean stockpiles will fall from about 250 million bushels to 175 million by Sept. 1, 1991, analysts said. Gerald Zusel, manager of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s floor operations at the Board of Trade, said the stockpile number may not provide much support for near-term prices but indicates that soybean prices may rise sharply over the next 11 months. At the close, wheat futures were 4 cents to 6 cents lower with the contract for delivery in December at $2.67 a bushel; corn was 2{ cents lower to 1\ cents higher with December at $2.30\ a bushel; oats were \ cent to { cent lower with December at $1.19\ a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cents lower to 4\ cents higher with November at $6.20 a bushel.
Stock prices gained ground today in a rally encouraged by declining oil prices. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 34.90 at 2,400.00.

DOC.HEAD: Steel Plant To Be Built in Windsor, Ontario
DOC.TEXT: An industrial park in Windsor, Ontario, has been chosen as the site of a $200 million steel plant being built by National Steel Corp. and companies from Canada and Japan, the companies said Friday. Steel made on the continuous galvanizing line will supply automotive markets in the United States and Canada. The 260,000-square-foot plant will be built by a joint venture of National Steel, Dofasco Inc. of Canada and NKK Corp. of Japan. Dofasco will own 50 percent of the facility, NKK will own 40 percent and National Steel will own 10 percent. The 28-acre site is located in the Ojibway Industrial Park near the Detroit River in the southwest area of the city, National Steel said. Construction of the line will begin almost immediately and should be completed in early 1993, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Union Asks Customers to Boycott Giant Stores
DOC.TEXT: The United Food and Commercial Workers International Union on Friday urged consumers to boycott Giant and Martins food stores until officials treat workers fairly. Union leaders said Giant and Martins, both owned by the Netherlands-based company Ahold, want to force American workers to pay part of their health care costs while benefits for foreign employees are fully paid. ``Expecting workers in America to have a co-pay where there wasn't one before is blatantly unfair,'' said Carl Huber, president of Pittsburgh Local 23, which represents 23,000 workers. In Pennsylvania, 5,000 workers are employed at 52 Giant stores. Only two stores, in Lewistown and Burnham, are unionized. Martins employs 1,000 employees in a dozen stores in Maryland, West Virginia and Virginia, according to union spokeswoman Denise Crowe. Huber said a strike at those two stores is likely sometime Saturday night. Company officials did not return several phone calls.

The stock market rebounded from the slide of the past three sessions with a technical rally today. Analysts said the upswing was encouraged by a modest decline in bond-market interest rates. In addition, oil prices dropped amid conjecture that chances might be improving for some break in the stalemate with Iraq in Kuwait. But brokers also said the economic and financial news offered little evidence of lasting relief from the recession worries that have plagued the market for several months. The Labor Department reported that the wholesale price index of finished goods jumped 1.6 percent in September, propelled by surging energy prices. Negative news had been widely anticipated from the index, which provides a measure of inflationary pressures in the distribution pipelines of the economy. Still, brokers said, the figure served as a damper on whatever hopes existed for a relaxation of the Federal Reserve's credit policy any time soon.

DOC.HEAD: Bally Casino Unit Skips Payment; Gets Lower Bond Rating
DOC.TEXT: Bally Manufacturing Corp. said Friday its casino subsidiary would miss an $18.4 million mortgage interest payment while the entire company undergoes a financial review and a shakeup of top-level management. In New York, Moody's Investors Service lowered the debt ratings of Bally and its subsidiaries from B2 to Caa, a designation for bonds that are considered of ``poor standing.'' Because Bally Grand Inc. will take advantage of a 30-day grace period provided for its Oct. 15 scheduled interest payment, Moody's also lowered its rating from Ba3 to Caa. The company, which is heavily in debt, has been plagued in recent weeks by unfavorable financial rumors and even speculation that Bally could seek shelter in U.S. Bankruptcy Court. Bally's board of directors also decided to suspend payment of dividends on its common stock and is moving toward restructuring its finances, the Chicago-based gambling and fitness company said in a statement. ``I have a significant investment in Bally, and I am pleased that the board has decided to consider a restructuring plan,'' said Arthur M. Goldberg, whom the company named interim chief executive officer. ``I believe that we can develop an overall plan that is feasible and in the best interests of the company, its stockholders and creditors,'' he said. Goldberg, a New Jersey investor, replaces Robert E. Mullane, who retired, the company said. Credited with turning several other companies toward profitability after acquiring control, Goldberg had taken a 5.4 percent stake in Bally last month. A newly created office of the chairman will consist of Goldberg; Roger N. Keesee, Bally president and chief operating officer; Kenneth C. Nichols, a member of the board of directors; and Richard Gillman, president and chief executive officer of Bally's Park Place Inc. subsidiary. Gillman also was named to the board of directors. Last year, New Jersey gaming officials had opposed the company's plans to spin off to shareholders two casinos each in Nevada and Atlantic City, N.J. Bally owns four casino hotels and a nationwide network of fitness centers, while making gaming, fitness and lottery products. Its health clubs operate under the names Chicago Health Clubs, Holiday Health, Jack LaLanne, Scandinavian and Vic Tanney.

DOC.HEAD: Alcoa's Earnings Decrease 43 Percent in Third Quarter
DOC.TEXT: Alcoa said Friday its third-quarter profits declined nearly 43 percent, reflecting decreasing orders and lower aluminum prices. Other factors were lower earnings from the company's Brazilian operations and a decrease in orders for some fabricated products, said Alcoa spokesman Al T. Posti. For the three months ended Sept. 30, net income totaled $125.1 million, or $1.46 a share, compared with $219 million, or $2.46 a share, in the corresponding period of 1989. Included in the latest quarterly earnings were unfavorable translation and exchange adjustments of $10.9 million, or 13 cents a share, Alcoa said. Quarterly sales fell nearly 4 percent to $2.7 billion from $2.8 billion in 1989. For the first nine months of the year, earnings fell 44 percent to $435.6 million, or $5.01 a share, from $780.2 million, or $8.79 a share. Nine-month sales totaled $8 billion, compared with $8.2 billion a year earlier. Earnings for the first nine months of the year reflect lower average aluminum ingot prices and an $82 million reduction in the earnings contributions from the company's Brazilian affiliate due to government actions to improve that country's economy. Alcoa employs 61,000 people at 152 operating and sales locations in 20 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Silver Rebounds but Gold Slips
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar finished mixed Friday in a world market traders said was influenced by a myriad of factors, from uncertainty in federal budget negotiations to falling oil prices. Silver prices recovered slightly after sinking to levels not seen in 14 years, but gold prices slid. In New York, one British pound fetched $1.9675, less expensive than $1.9775 late Thursday. But in London, the pound rose to $1.9740 from $1.9640 late Thursday. ``This is just a very volatile market,'' said Lloyd G. Atkinson, chief economist with the Bank of Montreal. ``There's not much to make out of trends. It's just a very, very nervous market.'' Atkinson said foreign traders were shocked at developments in Washington, where budget negotiators have been unable to reach an agreement on a deficit reduction plan. ``I'm astounded in terms of the flip-flop that's going on on the part of George Bush,'' Atkinson said, referring to the President's shifting stance on raising taxes for the wealthy in exchange for a cut in the capital gains tax. The dollar settled at 129.05 Japanese yen, down from 129.47 on Thursday. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.65 yen to a closing 129.30 yen. Later, in London, it fell to 128.65 yen. Other selected late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday rates included: 1.5243 German marks, up from 1.5138; 1.2860 Swiss francs, up from 1.2730; 5.1055 French francs, up from 5.0705; 1,142.25 Italian lire, up from 1,134.75; 1.1471 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1468. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday included: 1.5175 German marks, down from 1.5330; 1.2780 Swiss francs, down from 1.2910; 5.0855 French francs, down from 5.1292; 1.7110 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7280; 1,137.25 Italian lire, down from 1,147.25; 1.1470 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1512. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery fell $2.20 to settle at $387.50 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $388.00, down $3.00 from late Thursday. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $388.15 a troy ounce from $389.75 bid per ounce late Thursday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $388.00 from $389.60 late Thursday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.95 to close at a bid $387.76. Silver bullion for current delivery rebounded to settle at $4.306 a troy ounce, up from $4.235 Thursday. Silver also recovered somewhat in London to a late bid price of $4.34 a troy ounce, up from $4.28 Thursday, when silver's price fell more than 5 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Super Collider's Funds Cut by Budget Conferees
DOC.TEXT: Representatives of the House and the Senate cut 23 percent from the superconducting super collider's 1991 budget Friday as part of Congress' deficit-reduction effort. The size of the cut stunned the atom smasher's supporters and threatened its long-term survival. Members of the House and Senate appropriations committees cut the collider's budget by $75 million to $243 million. The committee freed $25 million that had been set aside for later use on the collider, an action that reduced the effect of the cut to $50 million. The cut will delay the collider's completion, now scheduled for 1998, and raise its cost, proponents said. And both those factors will harm its support in Congress. The collider, housed in a 54-mile underground ring to be built south of Dallas, would be used by scientists to study subatomic matter. Both the House and the Senate earlier approved spending $318 million on it in 1991. But that was done without an overall budget outline. Congress on Monday approved an outline telling committees to develop spending cuts and tax hikes to meet a deficit-reduction target of $45 billion in 1991. The appropriations conferees had been asked to cut $750 million from the 1991 appropriations bill for energy and water projects. The atom smasher, still in the beginning stages of construction, is 10 percent of that savings. Randy Erben, director of the Texas Office of Federal-State Relations, said state officials may consider making up the $50 million. But, he added, ``without the reimbursement guarantee, we'd be essentially buying a pig in a poke.''

DOC.HEAD: Miller To Operate Seventh Brewery
DOC.TEXT: A brewery built in 1983 by the Miller Brewing Co. but which never opened because of sagging sales will be producing beer by next July, the company said Friday. Preparation for producing canned beer at the $411 million brewery near Trenton in southwest Ohio will begin in January, with bottle and keg lines to follow, spokesman Richard Klemp said. Klemp said the brewery will be able to produce any kind of Miller product and will be fitted with special equipment to produce Miller Genuine Draft, which the company said is one of its fastest-growing brands. State Rep. Michael Fox, R-Hamilton, said Miller has received $11.5 million in tax reductions for the plant. He said it stands to receive another $10.1 million in tax breaks under an agreement to provide 1,500 jobs and a $30 million payroll by 1982. Political leaders, irked that Miller had not delivered the promised jobs, had threatened to revoke the tax benefits unless the plant opened. It will be Miller's seventh brewery, complementing others in Milwaukee, Wis.; Fulton, N.Y.; Eden, N.C.; Albany, Ga.; Fort Worth, Texas, and Irwindale, Calif. Miller shipped a record of nearly 42 million barrels of beer last year. The 3.7 percent gain over 1988 was the company's largest in three years.

DOC.HEAD: Widespread Layoffs Cause Fear and Loathing in the Workplace
Graphic
DOC.TEXT: It's sweaty-palm season in the American workplace. Squeezed by tough times, more than two dozen major U.S. corporations this year are slashing payrolls by several hundred to a few thousand workers each. Reflecting this upheaval, the U.S. unemployment rate worsened for the third straight month in September, to 5.7 percent, the first time since the 1981-82 recession that the jobless rate rose three months in a row. Behind these figures looms an emerging human toll that could have serious repercussions on American industry and the traditional bond between employer and employee. As layoffs ripple through a range of businesses and geographic regions, the newly unemployed are growing angry and frustrated. People who still have jobs are worried about losing them. The situation is exacerbated by the fact that these layoffs - unlike the blue-collar upheavals of previous recessions - are hitting white-collar professionals and other groups that once thought themselves immune to corporate cost-cutting. ``All of a sudden there's a whole class of young professionals having their hopes dashed,'' said Ronald S. Ebert, a psychologist at the Levinson Institute in Belmont, Mass. The list of giants announcing cuts in recent weeks read like a who's who of corporate America: Chase Manhattan Corp., Pan Am Corp., Digital Equipment Corp., Ford Motor Corp. and Saks Fifth Avenue among others. The hardest hit regions so far have been the Northeast, particularly New England, the South Atlantic region and the Midwest. One senior level executive, who requested anonymity, was earning ``well in excess'' of $200,000 annually at a major Midwestern packaged foods company when he learned he would be let go in September, part of company-wide layoffs of nearly 1,000 workers. Morale in the ranks of many departments, including sales and marketing, suddenly plummeted, he recalled. ``People are looking over their shoulder and waiting for the other shoe to drop,'' he said. ``Frankly I think it is getting in the way of the business. People are concerned about who's going to be let go next and whether or not they will have a job the next day or next month or next year,'' he said. Things are no better for the victims of the cuts, many of whom have been left without jobs after long careers. ``You can see the hurt in a guy's eyes who's got himself an MBA, got himself two kids who've gone to college, a house and wife up in Connecticut, making $170,000 for last five years, all of a sudden coming out with no place to go,'' said Mark Altman, president of M-A Management Associates Inc., a New York City recruitment firm. Some dismissed professionals internalize the frustration and suffer depression, counselors and psychologists say. A few, on the other hand, may seek revenge. ``It's not often the employee sets out to do something terrible to the employer,'' said Nella G. Barkley, president of Crystal-Barkley Corp., a New York career consulting concern. But she said employees have a ``tremendous potential for disrupting the relationship with corporate clients'' by purposely messing up a company's product or by joining the competition after dismissal. Of course, many companies remain gracious in the way they show employees the door. Friday was the last day for the Procter & Gamble Paper Products Co. plant in Cheboygan, Mich., a small town on the shore of Michigan's Lake Huron. All that was left for about 150 workers was to pick up their final paychecks, but 130 others opted to be transferred to other plants in Green Bay, Wis., and Cincinnati. P&G also expanded its retirement package, giving benefits to workers whose age and accumulated years of service added to 75 or more. ``I'm used to getting up and having a job to go to and putting my 40 hours a week in. Now it's not going to be there,'' said departing P&G electrical technician Tracy Heath, 42. ``But it's deer season. I think we just have to keep a positive outlook.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Retreat Slightly
DOC.TEXT: Oil prices slipped Friday to close below $40 a barrel after declining even more sharply during the day on a rumor that Iraq was considering retreating from Kuwait. That rumor, which spread through the market about midday, caused oil futures prices to plunge by about $2 a barrel, said Simom Trimble, an oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. But U.S. government officials later said there was no indication Iraq was considering such a move, causing oil prices to return to near their morning level, analysts said. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the November-delivery price of light sweet crude, the benchmark grade of oil, closed at $39.69 a barrel, down 73 cents. On Thursday, the same contract rose $1.73 to close at a record $40.42 a barrel. Later contract months were all down. However, prices of some refined oil products rose Friday. Home heating oil for November delivery rose .51 cent on the Nymex to close at $1.0536 a gallon. Unleaded regular gasoline for November delivery rose 1.13 cents a gallon to close at 97.13 cents. Later contract months for both products were mixed. Natural gas fell 1 cent per 1,000 cubic feetoon the Nymex to close at $1.95. Oil prices opened higher Friday morning after climbing in Europe on word that the speaker of the Egyptian parliament had been shot to death by terrorists, Trimble said. That development heightened fears of increased terrorism in the Mideast. However, other than the rumor about an Iraqi withdrawal, there was little news to affect domestic oil trading the rest of the day, Trimble said. Thomas Blakeslee, an analyst with Pegasus Econometric Group Inc. in Hoboken, N.J., said another factor pushing down oil prices may be wariness by traders in keeping oil above the $40 level. ``You're seeing a lot of resistance buying above this level,'' he said. ``The producers are comfortable with the prices where they are now, and refiners are a little hesitant to refine at these levels.'' But Trimble said he did not interpret the price retreat Friday to indicate a change in the direction of oil prices, which have been driven sharply higher since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Music Fans: You've Got Your MTV
DOC.TEXT: For all those Kremlin rockers screaming ``I want my MTV!'', their wish has come true. Starting this weekend, that most American of youthful tube treats - music television - will be beamed to 88 million Soviet households on primetime tv. Thanks to a deal two years in the making that was inked by the New York-based cable music video channel and the Soviet television company Gostelradio, the hourlong weekly rock'n roll show will also include several commercials from such U.S. advertisers as LA Gear and Wrangler. ``It's sort of another nail in the coffin in the Cold War,'' said Tom Freston, chairman of MTV Networks. ``It's certainly a snapshot of a subculture (viewers) have seen very little of.'' In evidence that American rock music is a universal tongue, the show and commercials are spoken entirely in English, with only Russian-language subtitles to guide young rockers. MTV is the latest in a string of U.S. cultural icons welcomed by the Soviets since they began liberalizing their economy in the late 1980s. Just in the past year, purveyors of Americanism ranging from McDonald's to Pizza Hut to Time Warner movie theaters have set up shop in the Soviet Union. The MTV programming, included in a popular youth-oriented Soviet program called ``Glance,'' consists of two music video shows produced by MTV Europe. The MTV Europe fare, which is already seen in Eastern Europe, will be broadcast for a year on Soviet television, according to the agreement. ``European Top 20 Countdown,'' one of the shows featured in the music program, will be seen by viewers in 25 countries with the addition of Soviet viewership, Freston said. The other show featured on the program, ``The Party Zone,'' comprises this weekend's debut program. The episode will feature American rappers LL Cool J and Young MC. While the program conspicuously lacks any Soviet rock bands, MTV officials say they expect to include some later. None of the show's advertisers are currently distributing their products in the Soviet Union, although Wrangler and Benetton are expected to begin shortly, Freston said. But advertising experts say the publicity surrounding a U.S. advertiser's entry into Soviet television may lend products a cache that could fuel sales in the United States. In addition, ``There's a lot of brand recognition among Soviet consumers for goods they can't legally acquire and that in the near future they may be able to legally acquire,'' said Thomas Remington, an expert on Soviet life at Emory University in Atlanta. For its debut on the show, LA Gear is showing a 30-second spot that stars Michael Jackson wearing the high-fashion sneakers. The same LA-gear commercial that is shown in the U.S. and in other countries, this music-only ad lacks any spoken dialogue so Soviet views should have little trouble comprehending it, said Tom Keefer, vice president of international marketing at the Los Angeles-based LA Gear. For the right to air its programming, MTV will pay Gostelradio an undisclosed amount of cash as well as two minutes' worth of programming time that the Soviet television company can sell on its own. MTV retains six minutes' worth of commercial time. In addition, MTV is currently looking into the possibility of running its programming on a 24-hour basis on a 100,000-subscriber cable television system in Leningrad, as well as on several smaller cable systems.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Agree to Send Natural Gas to Poland in Return for Food
DOC.TEXT: Poland will send thousands of tons of food and tobacco to the Soviet Union to help alleviate shortages there, in exchange for natural gas Poland needs badly, officials said Friday. The huge barter deal was negotiated during a visit to Moscow by Polish diplomats led by Foreign Minister Krzysztof Skubiszewski. Skubiszewski met Friday with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The agreement benefits both sides. Soviet consumers have been enraged by a lack of cigarettes and meat and Polish officials have been working anxiously to assure supplies of fuel for homes and factories next year. The Polish-Soviet agreement reflected new links between Moscow and its former East European allies as they grope to define their economic and political relations. The deal will not completely solve either country's problems. But it may avert hunger in some Soviet cities this winter and help keep the Polish economy from stalling as it shifts from communism toward private enterprise. Polish officials are still hoping to obtain firm contracts for deliveries of Soviet oil. For decades, the Soviet Union provided a steady supply of both oil and natural gas to Poland at subsidized prices. But this year, Soviet crude oil shipments were cut by about 25 percent after labor unrest reduced Soviet oil extraction. Also, the Soviets have announced they will put trade with their former East bloc allies on a hard currency basis, charging much higher prices for oil and natural gas starting Jan. 1. Dariusz Ledworowski, Poland's undersecretary of state for foreign economic relations, said Friday the reduction in Soviet fuel supplies and sudden rise in prices was ``a new shock for our economy.'' Under the agreement reached Friday, Ledworowski said, Poland will deliver 10,000 tons of butter, 100,000 tons of sugar, 10,000 tons of milk powder, 10,000 tons of meat and 3 billion cigarettes to the Soviet Union this year. He said the food and tobacco would have an international market value of about $120 million. In return, the Soviets will provide 1.4 billion cubic meters of natural gas in the first quarter of 1991. He said those deliveries, combined with 5.2 billion cubic meters guaranteed by previous contracts with the Soviet Union, would meet 70 percent of Poland's annual needs for imported natural gas. Ledworowski said Poland has been unable to obtain similar assurances for crude oil deliveries. ``In gas, we have a guarantee. In oil, up to now, we haven't any guarantee,'' he said. ``They (the Soviets) are not in a position to inform me what they will be doing with oil.'' In the past, the Soviet Union has provided about 85 percent of Poland's oil. To help make up the shortfall, Poland has agreed to buy half a million tons of crude from Iran and has sharply raised domestic gasoline prices, officials in Warsaw said Thursday. As Gorbachev has steered the Soviet Union toward a market-based economy, the old central planning system has broken down. Consumers face high inflation, shortages of essential goods and workers in key industries have threatened strikes.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Unions Preparing For Contract Talks
DOC.TEXT: Three United Airlines unions, which had been involved in the unsuccessful employee buyout attempt of parent company UAL Inc., announced Friday they would meet to prepare for contract talks. The Association of Flight Attendants, the Air Line Pilots Association and the International Association of Machinists said they will meet Wednesday. Each of the unions' contracts has expired, but members have been working under the provisions of the previous pacts, union officials said. The flight attendants' contract expired Nov. 1, 1987; the pilots' ran out April 1, 1988; and the machinists' ended Nov. 1, 1989. The unions have been negotiating on and off since then with management, said Bobbie Pilkington, a spokeswoman for the flight attendants union. The buyout attempt, which intensified early this year, also slowed talks, she said. A bid for full employee ownership was rejected Tuesday by UAL's board, marking the fourth failed takeover attempt of the carrier in 3{ years. The employee group was unable to arrange financing by Tuesday's deadline for the $201-a-share, $4.38 billion offer the UAL board had accepted in principle in April. The company said then that it wanted quick settlements of the contracts with the pilots, machinists and flight attendants. No date has been set for union talks to resume, Pilkington said Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Soar on Report Iraq Mulling Kuwait Withdrawal
DOC.TEXT: The main U.S. Treasury bond soared nearly $11 Friday on a report that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein was considering withdrawing from Kuwait. A pullout by Iraq from neighboring Kuwait almost certainly would push down skyrocketing oil prices, lowering inflation and improving the chances of lower interest rates - all of which would help bonds. The government's benchmark 30-year bond gained 1 3-32 point, or $10.94 per $1,000 in face amount, regaining all of a $9 drop Thursday. Its yield, which falls when prices rise, sank to 8.95 percent from 9.06 percent late Thursday. Analysts said government reports showing a weak economy in the wake of rampant inflating pegged to the Middle East crisis were somewhat better than anticipated and did not have a major impact on bonds. The Labor Department reported that wholesale prices shot up a steep 1.6 percent in September, an annual rate of more than 20 percent. But analysts said that excluding food and energy, prices were up 0.3 percent, about half of what was forecast. Also, the Commerce Department said retail sales were up 1.1 percent last month, a better performance than anticipated. Moving the market, though, was a statement by a group of Iraqi exiles that Saddam is considering withdrawing from the emirate it occupied Aug. 2. The claim by the Kurdistan Democratic Party-Iraq was not independently confirmed. ``It's quite possible that oil prices could immediately fall $10 or more a barrel'' if Iraq withdraws from Kuwait,'' said Scott Winningham, a market analyst with Stone & McCarthy Research Associates in Princeton, N.J. ``If that were to happen it obviously would have positive implications for the inflationary outlook and consequently interest rates,'' he said. The Federal Reserve has been under pressure to lower interest rates to spur the struggling economy. Lower interest rates typically translates to higher prices for fixed-income securities such as bonds. In the secondary market for Treasury bonds, prices of short-term governments rose 5-32 point to 5-16 point, intermediate maturities rose 11-32 point to 19-32 point and long-term issues were up 15-16 point to 1 3-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, rose 5.40 to 1,146.76. Yields on three-month Treasury bills were unchanged at 7.36 percent as the discount rose 1 basis point to 7.14 percent. Yields on six-month bills dropped to 7.50 percent as the discount rate lost 1 basis point to 7.14 percent. Yields on one-year bills fell to 7.56 percent as the discount dropped 3 basis points to 7.08 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge each other on overnight loans, was quoted at 7~ percent, unchanged from late Thursday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 87 15-16, up 9-32 point. The average yield to maturity fell to 7.84 percent from 7.87 percent late Thursday.

U.S. District Judge A. David Mazzone ordered Eastman Kodak Co. to pay Polaroid Corp. $909.5 million in damages and interest for infrining on seven Polaroid patents. In his decision Friday, the judge said Kodak's infringement was not willful and declined to award the $12 billion Polaroid had sought in punitive damages. Kodak officials said the award would be paid out of its earnings without any substantial impact on the company's finances. Polaroid said it would review the decision before determining its next step in the 4-year-old suit. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - The U.S. Labor Department reported wholesale prices soared 1.6 percent in September - an annual rate of more than 20 percent - as gasoline prices shot up at their fastest pace on record. While the Labor Department on Friday blamed much of the steep increase in wholesale costs on costlier petroleum, prices excluding the volatile energy and food areas were still up a worrisome 0.6 percent - twice the August gain. The 20.6 percent rise in the cost of gasoline was the highest one-month increase since the government began tracking the commodity in 1947. --- WASHINGTON (AP) - Rebounding automobile purchases and surging gasoline prices powered retail sales to a strong 1.1 percent gain in September, the government said. The figures released Friday showed the biggest advance in four months, but economists said the two special factors were masking an otherwise weak report, which included a large decline in department store sales. --- HOT SPRINGS, Va. (AP) - Top business leaders have predicted the U.S. economy will stagnate during the second half of this year. A minority say a recession is here or on the way. The Business Council's fall forecast projected a nearly imperceptible 0.3 percent economic growth rate in the second half of 1990, and said oil-driven inflation will climb to 6.1 percent before falling back below current levels. The forecast was presented Friday to the 100 leaders of the nation's top corporations at their semiannual, two-day meeting at this mountain resort. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Dow Jones & Co., publisher of The Wall Street Journal, is freezing capital spending and salaries and imposing other news and business cutbacks to cope with weak financial results and the sluggish economy. The cuts, announced in an internal memo to managers Thursday, followed weeks of rumors about a possible retrenchment and triggered concern over possible future layoffs at the media and financial industry giant. --- NEW YORK (AP) - Financial News Network, the 24-hour business-oriented cable television service, said it fired a top executive for improper financial dealings and dismissed its auditors. The company said two other employees in the accounting staff were put on leave while FNN reviews their ``status.'' Chief Financial Officer C. Steven Bolen, 44, was dismissed following a board investigation that concluded he ``received compensation payments that were not properly authorized and . . . that certain bank accounts administered under (his) direction were not properly recorded.'' --- BEIJING (AP) - In one of its few economic reforms this year, China has opened a national wheat market to replace central allocation of the nation's 85 million ton annual wheat harvest. More than 200 grain trading companies were to begin dealing on opening day Friday at the Wholesale Grain Market in Zhengzhou, the provincial capital of Henan, China's wheat heartland, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. The market is one of China's few experiments in using markets to replace four decades of central planning. --- SHANGHAI, China (AP) - U.S. investors celebrated as Shanghai's largest and glitziest hotel and office complex opened after nearly five years of delays, cost overruns and political turmoil. A sellout crowd of about 1,000 foreigners and Chinese on Friday watched China's premier of the American play ``Driving Miss Daisy'' in the center's theater, performed by the Alliance Theatre Co. of Atlanta. Then they broke for champagne and caviar. --- NEW YORK (AP) - For all those Kremlin rockers screaming ``I want my MTV!'' their wish has com true. Starting this weekend, that most American of youthful tube treats - music television - will be beamed to 88 million Soviet households on prime time TV. Thanks to a deal two years in the making that was inked by the New York-based cable music video channel and the Soviet television company Gostelradio, the hourlong weekly rock 'n' roll show will also include several commercials from such U.S. advertisers as LA Gear and Wrangler. ---
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: Stocks rose Friday after several days of decline. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 32.92 points to 2,398.02, cutting its loss for the week to 112.62 points. The dollar was mixed, while gold prices fell. Bond prices soared. Orange juice futures prices collapsed; petroleum futures were mixed; grains and soybeans retreated; and livestock and meat futures advanced.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Airline's Largest Union Says No to Wage Cut Proposal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for ST. PAUL-dated item on AM-Business News Digest
DOC.TEXT: The president of the largest union at Northwest Airlines told the carrier's top executive Friday that wage cuts are not an option in solving a cash crunch created by soaring fuel costs. ``All we have said to this point is that we're not interested in reducing the standard of living of our members by reducing our wages,'' Guy Cook, president of the International Association of Machinists District Lodge 143, said. ``We're willing to work with management in almost any other form to try to find solutions to the problem.'' Cook said Northwest Chairman Alfred Checchi has asked the machinists' union to choose between laying off between 10 percent to 20 percent of workers or taking a 10 percent pay cut for six months with no job losses. ``I called Mr. Checchi early this afternoon over the issue of wage cuts to inform him that has to be eliminated from the possible solutions,'' Cook said Friday. ``If layoffs have to be, then management will have to make that decision. ``But I think offering a leave of absence to more senior people would go a long way to alleviate some of that,'' Cook added. Northwest is not commenting on the details of Checchi's strategy to reduce costs. Kevin Whalen, a spokesman, wouldn't even confirm Friday whether Checchi is seeking concessions from labor groups. ``It's pretty sensitive and I can't get into any comments,'' Whalen said. ``Its been no secret. We need to look at how we can cut expenses.'' Cook said he delivered his message to Checchi Friday after consulting with union members. There was no proposal for the rank-and-file to vote on, Cook said. He said union members have expressed a willingness to increase productivity and improve cost efficiency as a way to combat the 65 percent increase in fuel costs. Northwest is the nation's fourth largest airline, headquartered in the Minneapolis suburb of Eagan. It employs about 44,000 workers, including about 16,500 in Minnesota. If Northwest trimmed 15 percent of its total work force, such a cut would equal 6,600 jobs. Members of the machinists' union include mechanics, baggage handlers, reservations agents and other ground personnel. A 15 percent layoff would affect about 3,300 union members. Other big airlines such as USAir, Pan American World Airways and American Airlines have already begun laying off thousands of workers in an effort to combat a 65 percent increase in fuel prices. The fuel price run-up, sparked by Middle East turmoil, could add $800 million to $1 billion a year to Northwest's tab for fuel. Duane Woerth, chairman of the 5,600-member Northwest Air Line Pilots Association union, told the Saint Paul Pioneer Press Thursday he planned to meet with Checchi Friday. Woerth could not be reached Friday for comment and Whalen would not comment on whether a meeting occurred. Woerth said Thursday that, under contract agreements with Northwest, the carrier cannot lay off any pilots until mid-February. That provision has been triggered by the airline's participation in government programs to allow Northwest pilots and jets to shuttle U.S. troops to the Middle East. Under its agreement with pilots, he said, the airline also is restricted to laying off only pilots hired since Aug. 28, 1989. That means only new hires - who have been brought in at the lowest pay - could be laid off. Union figures suggest only 273 pilots would be vulnerable to layoff after mid-February. ``If the goal is to prevent layoffs, that's something we can help construct,'' Woerth said, suggesting that vacation schedules could be juggled to help avert layoffs.

DOC.HEAD: Silver Futures Rebound from New 14-Year Low
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS grafs 2 and 4 to show gold prices fell
DOC.TEXT: Silver prices rose Friday after hitting a new 14-year low that some analysts said might have marked the bottom of a dramatic slide. On other commodity markets, gold fell; orange juice collapsed; petroleum futures were mixed; grains and soybeans retreated; and livestock and meat futures advanced. Silver settled 7 cents to 7.1 cents higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with the contract for spot delivery up 7.1 cents at $4.306 a troy ounce. Gold ended $2.20 to $2.30 lower with spot October at $387.50 a troy ounce. Spot silver opened at $4.20 on the Commodity Exchange after tumbling as low as $4.05 overnight on overseas markets. The overnight price represented the metal's lowest price since late 1976, when silver hit $3.80, according to the Commodity Exchange. The fact that prices rebounded after nearing the psychologically important $4 level may indicate the market is seeking or has found a bottom, analysts said. Don Tierney, metals analyst with Fortune Commodities Inc. in New York, said it costs $4 to $4.50 an ounce to mine domestic silver. ``With the market holding above that magic $4 number, it will look attractive to traders looking for a new, cheap position,'' he said. Bruno Zbinden, chief of precious metal trading for Swiss Bank Corp., said he would not rule out a price dip below $4 an ounce, ``but this is a level where investors should be able to buy silver and do nicely over the long term.'' Silver's plunge from about $4.70 an ounce began Tuesday, triggered by mounting fears that a recession would curtail industrial demand for the metal. Some analysts said Friday's gain of almost 33 points in the Dow Jones industrial average may have helped ease recession worries. Orange juice futures crashed on the New York Cotton Exchange after the Agriculture Department on Thursday released a Florida orange harvest projection that was far above expectations. The near-term contract, for delivery in November, opened down the permitted daily limit of 10 cents a pound, forcing a trading halt. Trading resumed with an expanded limit of 20 cents in the November contract. Frozen concentrated orange juice for November delivery settled down 16.45 cents at $1.1345 a pound. All other delivery months fell their permitted limit of 5 cents. The USDA estimated a Florida orange harvest of 165 million 90-pound boxes and a yield of 1.52 gallons per box compared with last year's frost-reduced harvest of 110.2 million boxes and yield of 1.23 gallons per box. Crude oil futures fell in choppy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange after an Iraqi opposition group said Iraq is considering withdrawing from Kuwait and that its ruling political party has circulated a questionnaire asking key members for their opinion. Light sweet crude oil ended 8 cents to 73 cents lower with November at $39.69 a barrel; heating oil was .56 cent lower to .51 cent higher with November at $1.0536 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .90 cent lower to 1.13 cents higher with November at 97.13 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures prices ended mostly lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as selling pressure from the wheat market eroded the supportive influence of Thursdy's bullish corn and soybean crop report. Wheat futures settled 4 cents to 6 cents lower with December at $2.66{ a bushel; corn was 2{ cents lower to { cent higher with December at $2.30\ a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent lower with December at $1.19\ a bushel; soybeans were { cent lower to 4 cents higher with November at $6.20{ a bushel. Most pork belly futures jumped the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, leading livestock futures higher. Supplies of frozen pork bellies are nearly depleted, providing support to the market, analysts said. Firmer cash markets boosted cattle and hog futures. Live cattle settled .02 cent to .48 cent higher with October at 79 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .48 cent higher with October at 87.62 cents a pound; live hogs were .40 cent to 1.10 cents higher with October at 57.62 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.87 cents to 2 cents higher with February at 66.40 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Kodak Ordered To Pay Polaroid $900 Million for Patent Infringement
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Friday ordered Eastman Kodak Co. to pay to Polaroid Corp. $909.5 million for infringing on instant camera patents, ending a 14-year legal battle with what is believed to be the largest such award in history. But in his ruling, U.S. District Judge A. David Mazznne said Kodak did not willfully infringe on Polaroid patents for instant camera and film when it entered the business in 1976. Despite the record size, the award was far less than the $12 billion Polaroid sought in its damages lawsuit against Kodak and the $1 billion to $2 billion predicted by analysts. Kodak had said it should pay $177 million, equal to 5 percent royalties on the instant cameras and film Kodak sold from 1976 until 1985. U.S. District Judge Rya Zobel in Boston in 1985 ruled that Kodak had infringed on seven of about 150 Polaroid patents on instant cameras and film. She barred the Rochester, N.Y.-based company from the business in January 1986. Kodak Chairman Kay R. Whitmore said in a statement the award would be paid from profits and would have ``no material financial impact'' on the company. He said Kodak was pleased Mazzone ruled the infringement was not willful. ``It has always been our firm policy to respect the valid patent rights of others and the avoidance of any patent infringement was uppermost in our minds in the design of our instant cameras and films,'' Whitmore said. I. MacAllister Booth, president of Cambridge-based Polaroid, said in a statement that Polaroid was reviewing the decision ``considering the significance of the injury to the company and its shareholders.'' The statement did not rule out the possibility that Polaroid would appeal the damages award and a company spokeswoman declined to comment. Booth's statement said Polaroid's board would review how to use the damages money ``but will not announce how we plan to apply the proceeds when received until there is a final resolution of this litigation.'' Instant photography was invented by Polaroid founder Edwin H. Land in 1947 and first marketed in 1948. Polaroid held a monopoly for almost 30 years until Kodak entered the field in 1976. Polaroid argued that Kodak's competition cut into profits and forced Polaroid to sell some cameras below cost. The two companies had a good relationship for decades, with Kodak making film for Polaroid, but things soured in when Polaroid introduced the SX-70 color instant camera in 1972. When Polaroid tried to work out a deal for Kodak to provide film for its new camera, Kodak officials said they would do it if Polaroid gave them license to create its own instant photography. Polaroid refused and built its own film manufacturing facilities. The damages award was disclosed after the stock markets closed. Kodak shares fell $2.75 to close at $35.25 in consolidated New York Stock Exchange trading, while Polaroid shares lost 12{ cents to close at $29.37{. David S. Nelson, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. in New York, said the award amounts to a nearly $20 per share boost Polaroid stock before taxes. ``The difference is a major factor for the value of Polaroid's common stock,'' he said. But Nelson added that ``some people will be disappointed that the damages with interest are less than $1 billion.'' A $207 million damages award against Smith International Inc. to Hughes Tool Co. in 1986 for copying drill bit technology is believed the previous record patent infringement award. Analysts have predicted that a sizeable award would allow Polaroid to diversify into fields such as information retrieval or conventional photography. Kodak already has paid more than $100 million in cash to about 3.4 million owners of its instant camera to settle a class-action lawsuit seeking cash as part of the company's settlement with people who bought the banned cameras. Kodak gave each camera owner a cash refund of $19 to $52, plus rebate coupons worth $18 to $30 for use on Kodak products.

DOC.HEAD: Pillsbury Settles Racial Discrimination Suit For $3.6 Million
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Friday gave preliminary approval to a $3.6 million settlement of a race discrimination lawsuit against Pillsbury Inc. The suit was filed in May 1989 and focused almost entirely on alleged discriminatory practices against black employees and job applicants from 1984 to 1988, before the acquisition of the Minneapolis-based food company by Grand Metropolitan PLC in January 1989. The settlement involves no finding by the court nor admission by Pillsbury or Grand Met of wrongdoing. The parties agreed to it to avoid further lengthy litigation, said attorneys for the plaintiffs. ``The settlement affects certain black persons who are presently or were formerly employed by Pillsbury in salaried jobs anywhere in the United States, as well as black persons who were applicants or were deterred from applying for salaried employment with Pillsbury in Minnesota,'' U.S. District Judge David Doty wrote in a notice of settlement. Members of the settlement class could include blacks who were fired before May 8, 1989, blacks who applied for a job but were not hired and blacks who considered applying but did not apply, according to the notice of settlement. Charles V. Wilson, a Grand Met spokesman, said the settlement ``will enable us to accelerate the momentum which has been building in our cultural diversity efforts since the Grand Met acquisition. The programs that will be funded by this settlement over the next few years will improve opportunities for all employees.'' Paul Sprenger, lead attorney for the plaintiffs, said he was ``pleased with the settlement. But I am even more pleased by the willingness of Grand Met and Pillsbury to step forward from the moment the case was filed to resolve these important issues in a way that maximizes the long-term benefits to everyone involved.'' According to the settlement, detailed in a consent decree filed in federal court in Minneapolis, Pillsbury will allocate over four years $3.6 million, including attorneys' fees and expenses, to or for the benefit of the settlement class. The funds will be used to settle the claims of the 14 named plaintiffs and to pay awards to eligible former employees fired between 1984 and 1989. The funds will also support the cultural diversity department at Pillsbury. In addition, the settlement will create funds to pay training and education expenses and dependent tuition scholarships, as well as to support career development for eligible current employees.

DOC.HEAD: Building Company Seeks Chapter 11 Protection Because of Asbestos Suits
DOC.TEXT: Celotex Corp., citing a crush of asbestos-related lawsuits, announced Friday it has filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy laws. Kenneth Hyatt, the company's chairman, president and chief executive, said the filing in U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Tampa will allow it to resolve the lawsuits while continuing in the manufacture and sale of building products. ``The decision to file Chapter 11 was forced solely by an inability to continue to obtain insurance proceeds to fund the enormous costs associated with the massive asbestos-related litigation,'' said Hyatt, stressing that the company will continue its operations fully. Like other companies that once made asbestos, Celotex and wholly-owned subsidiary Carey Canada Inc. have been fighting litigation surrounding the cancer-causing insulation material since the early 1970s. By the end of last month, there were more than 140,000 personal injury lawsuits pending against the companies in state and federal courts around the country. Settlement and defense costs for such suits have exceeded $587 million, the company estimated, most of it paid through its insurance coverage. But Celotex said several insurance carriers have disputed coverage, leading to more litigation to recover under the policies. Celotex said in a statement that, through bankruptcy protection, it hopes to be able to resolve its remaining coverage disputes and develop a plan which will permit fair payment of its asbestos-related liabilities. Asbestos-related cases form the largest number of personal injury lawsuits nationwide. Several dozen companies that manufactured asbestos are defendants. The biggest defendant is the Manville trust, a fund to pay claims established as part of the reorganization of the Manville Corp., once the nation's largest producer of asbestos.
